HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE NATION
CALIFORNIA;
Gov. Wilson's Comeback Ends in Re-election Victory

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Pete Wilson was elected to a second term as California's governor tonight by a commanding margin over his challenger, Kathleen Brown, the State Treasurer.
But it remained unclear whether the powerful tide of support for Mr. Wilson ran deep enough to also spell victory for Proposition 187, the highly divisive voter initiative that would deny to undocumented immigrants most government services, including schooling and nonemergency health care. 
 Governor Wilson has made immigration control a central theme in his re-election battle with Ms. Brown.
Shortly after 11 P.M. Pacific time, The Associated Press said that based on early returns, it appeared that the measure would pass. The news service also reported that three-fourths of Californians who voted for Proposition 187 also voted for Governor Wilson.
Ms. Brown, in a mood of somber but good-humored realism, conceded defeat shortly after 10:15 P.M. Pacific time. After complimenting the Governor on his victory, Ms. Brown affirmed her commitment to the principles she had championed in a long, grinding campaign.
"Twenty-eight years ago tonight," Ms. Brown said, "My father told a group of supporters who were similarly gathered, he said we have to keep going. Our principles are right.
"We lost the battle," she concluded, "But we will win the war."
Minutes later, Mr. Wilson told a crowd of cheering supporters, "I must say it wasn't too long ago, the smart money pundits were not only writing me off, they were writing off California."
"About a year ago, I faced longer odds than George Foreman," he said, alluding to the boxer who on Saturday night became the oldest man ever to win the world heavyweight title.
"And to quote one of my favorite authors," he added, "as I said after the Northridge quake, they can shake us up, but they can't break us. All Californians have been fighting like a junk yard dog to turn this state around, and you are succeeding."
Mr. Wilson's triumph marked an extraordinary comeback for a politician all but repudiated by Californians less than a year ago when Ms. Brown, a 47-year-old moderate liberal, seemed to have the race sewn up. At that time some independent polls gave her a commanding 20-point lead over the incumbent.
But Ms. Brown's campaign began to falter, plagued in part by organizational disarray, but perhaps more importantly, by what analysts said was a deep current of discontent with politicians, particularly those espousing a liberal platform, coursing through the California electorate.
Political analysts also attributed Ms. Brown's slippage and eventual defeat to her ineffectiveness in finding a message to compete with Mr. Wilson's ability to define and exploit this year's most potent issues -- crime and immigration.
Moreover, Mr. Wilson was helped mightily by what many voters viewed as his decisive handling of California's recent traumas, not only natural disasters like drought, floods, fires and earthquakes, but also an economy that is beginning to show signs of reviving from the worst recession since the 1930's.
Since surveys of voters leaving polling places detected the Wilson victory long before the voting was over, Proposition 187 provided most of the suspense tonight.
Proposition 187, named "Save Our State" by its proponents, is based on the premise that California's social services are the main magnet drawing illegal immigrants across the border. Turning off that magnet, they argue, will deter new arrivals.
The measure would not only deny undocumented aliens schooling and nonemergency medical care, but would require teachers and doctors to give immigration authorities the names of all people they know or suspect to be in the nation illegally.
But no matter how Draconian benefit polices become, most analysts say the lure of California's jobs and comparatively high wages are likely to keep attracting Mexicans, Central Americans and others over the border and to keep most of the 1.5 million illegal immigrants now estimated to be in the state from voluntarily returning home.
Still, until last month, independent surveys consistently put the pro-187 forces far ahead, some by more than 25 points. Since then, there has been a drastic fallout in support for the proposition, particularly since it was criticized by national political figures who share little ideological common ground.
The Associated Press reported that about 500 people shouting "racism! racism!" rallied near the United States Embassy in Mexico City today in the latest of a series of boisterous protests against Proposition 187. At least 100 riot police with metal shields and clubs guarded the American compound.
Here In Los Angeles, several law enforcement agencies ordered extra patrols at polling places and schools after outbreaks of violence during the campaign, and some civic leaders here fear their could be an eruption of lawlessness if the measure should win.
There were also scattered student protests -- mostly by Hispanic-Americans, Asian-Americans and African-Americans -- against Proposition 187, but the demonstrators made up only a fraction of the enrollments of the local school districts.
Late tonight the Los Angeles Unified School District's Board of Education announced it will go to court on Wednesday if Proposition 187 won.
"We stand firmly with all of our students and their parents in opposition to this disruptive and divisive proposals," said Mark Slavkin, the school board president.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE SENATE
VIRGINIA;
After a Bitter Campaign, Voters Stick With Robb

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Wednesday, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Senator Charles S. Robb beat back a ferocious challenge yesterday by his Republican opponent, Oliver L. North, after one of the bloodiest and most closely watched campaigns in the country.
With Republicans winning elsewhere, analysts here were surprised by how quickly Mr. Robb's victory became evident tonight. Virginia is a conservative state, and Mr. Robb, a Democrat, was thought to be hobbled not only by reports about his personal life but also by his association with President Clinton, whose standing here is relatively low. 
 But Virginians apparently cared less for Mr. North than they did for Mr. Clinton, whom Mr. North attacked at every turn. Robert D. Holsworth, a political analyst at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond, said Mr. North probably erred in concentrating more on anti-Clinton sentiment than he did on Mr. Robb's personal problems.
At 1:50 A.M. today, with 99 percent of the precincts reporting, the vote was:
Robb . . . 46%
North . . . 43%
An independent, had Marshall Coleman, had 11 percent.
"How sweet it is!" Mr. Robb yelled into a microphone at his headquarters in Tysons Corner.
He attributed the win to his wife, Lynda, saying she had worked harder to secure it than he had. Perhaps her most significant role was in standing by her husband despite accusations about his personal life, including those by Republican saying he had attended parties with drug users and had an extramarital dalliance with a former beauty queen.
Mr. North made his concession speech from the Richmond Center. In a conciliatory tone, he told his somber supporters that they had "redefined the political debate" in the country.
Larry Sabato, a political analyst at the University of Virginia, said it was "just incredible" that a "damaged, liberal Democrat, beholden to President Clinton" could win in a Republican year. He attributed this phenomenon solely to Mr. North's weakness.
Mr. North spent $18 million on the race; Mr. Robb spent $5 million.
Mr. Robb benefited by a strong turnout in the Washington suburbs, where his support for abortion rights, the crime bill and President Clinton's economic program were appreciated and where disapproval of Mr. North's ties to the Christian Coalition and right-wing conservatism ran deep.
Mr. North's supporters attributed his loss to dissension within the Republican ranks. Mr. North, a former Marine lieutenant colonel, was repudiated by several leading Republicans, including former President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, and leading military officers. Mr. North was convicted of felony charges for his role in the Iran-contra affair. The conviction was later overturned.
But the North camp put the heaviest blame on Senator John W. Warner, the state's senior Republican, who denounced Mr. North as unfit to serve in the Senate and who stuck strongly through Election Day to the independent candidacy of Mr. Coleman.
Senator Warner sloughed off accusations last night that by supporting Mr. Coleman he had split the Republican vote and lost the seat for the party against one of the most vulnerable Democrats in Virginia history.
Some analysts said last night that Republicans had made a grave mistake in nominating a candidate as divisive and polarizing as Mr. North.
Exit polls from the television networks showed that 42 percent of the voters thought neither candidate had the honesty and integrity to serve in the Senate.
Both candidates ran television commercials in the last few days in which they admitted that they were not perfect and that they had made mistakes.
Several analysts said last night that the campaign turned against Mr. North three weeks ago. His campaign aides, perhaps overconfident at that point, apparently believed that they were far enough ahead to stop attacking Mr. Robb and to turn instead to presenting a more positive image of Mr. North.
"We thought it was going to be 'the liar versus the pervert,' but it came down to 'Clinton versus character,' " said Mr. Holsworth, the analyst. "North didn't hit him on what many people thought was Robb's major vulnerability."
That is, while Mr. North started attacking Mr. Clinton, Mr. Robb kept pounding Mr. North on character.
That onslaught reached its climax on Monday, when Mr. Robb called Mr. North "a document-shredding, Constitution-trashing, Commander in Chief-bashing, Congress-thrashing, uniform-shaming, Ayatollah-loving, arms-dealing, criminal-protecting, resume-enhancing, Noriega-coddling, Society Security-threatening, public school-denigrating, Swiss-banking-law-breaking, letter-faking, self-serving, election-losing, snake-oil salesman who can't tell the difference between the truth and a lie."
Mr. North, by contrast, took to wearing a blue flannel shirt and khakis and projecting the image of a family man in commercials with one of his daughters. He ran one advertisement against Mr. Robb that focused on the Senator's extramarital liaisons, but quickly pulled it, saying his mother did not like it.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK GOVERNOR
MAN IN THE NEWS: George Elmer Pataki;
Soft but Forceful Steps Lead to Paradoxical Victory in the Governor's Race

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
State Senator George E. Pataki, who was elected New York's 55th Governor last night, is almost a millionaire, yet he comes off as homespun and unpretentious: He says "gosh" a lot and is so forgetful of his appearance that on a recent campaign trip he mismatched one suit's blue jacket with another's gray trousers, and then had to change pants in a hotel alcove.
He is a graduate of Yale College and Columbia Law School and can argue points like a Wall Street litigator, yet he cries at one of his favorite films, "Old Yeller," and carries a dollar signed for good luck by the late Lubavitcher Grand Rabbi, Menachem M. Schneerson. 
 In such ways, Mr. Pataki, 49, has distinguished himself as an unpredictable and often independent personality. And to his friends and supporters, he possesses a Zen-like balance, a willingness to listen and an ability to negotiate compromises.
For those reasons, his supporters say, Mr. Pataki can be expected to govern the state much as he served in the Legislature, moving with soft but forceful steps to win the things he wants.
"You'll see in January," said his friend, legislative counsel and campaign chairman, Michael Finnegan. "George isn't the type that needed to have his name on every bill he worked on. He wins things with quiet consensus."
A onetime Mayor of Peekskill and five-term state legislator, Mr. Pataki also stands out in sharp relief to the man he has unseated, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Where Mr. Cuomo offers baroque explanations for the state's daunting problems and how to deal with them, Mr. Pataki has been a study in simplicity: cut taxes, cut spending, get tough on crime. Where Mr. Cuomo can eviscerate with his street-smart wit, Mr. Pataki is unflappably affable. Where Mr. Cuomo's oratory takes wing, Mr. Pataki speaks in the tripping cadences of the regular guy.
What is perhaps most paradoxical is that 13 months ago, those very characteristics seemed to conspire against Mr. Pataki's becoming the Republican nominee. He was too bland, they said. He couldn't raise money. He was unknown outside the Hudson Valley communities he had quietly represented in the State Legislature for 10 years.
But Mr. Pataki, son of a postal worker and waitress, worked for the Republican nomination just as he worked every campaign he had ever run, all against incumbents, all victorious. He crisscrossed the state for months, meeting Republican leaders and building a small but loyal following. He was also the right candidate at the right time, according to Republican polls: a Roman Catholic from the suburbs with a record of opposing tax increases while supporting abortion rights, even though he voted against Medicaid funds for abortions in the Legislature.
In the end, he convinced the one Republican whose support truly counted, United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who hammered his nomination through the Republican State Convention in May.
His critics said the alliance represented everything that was wrong with Mr. Pataki: he was too pliable, too eager to make Faustian deals, too willing to let his brash patron dominate a campaign that should have been his own show.
But to his many friends, the alliance was a mark of a pragmatic politician, one prepared to campaign publicly beside Mr. D'Amato while working behind the scenes to shape his own strategy.
"The bottom line is that all this about him being an empty suit, that's all nonsense," said Vincent S. Vesce, an old friend who ran on the Pataki slate for Peekskill City Council 13 years ago. "This guy is down-to-earth, he cares, he has a vision."
Of his style, Mr. Pataki once said: "One of the reasons I think I've always gotten along with everybody is that I'm willing to listen and really think about it. I'm pretty confident in my judgment, but I'm always willing to listen."
George Elmer Pataki was born in Peekskill, a city of about 19,500 in northern Westchester County, on June 24, 1945. Both of his grandfathers worked for the Fleischmann's Company, and his father grew up in company housing near its yeast and gin plants along the Hudson River. Later, his paternal grandfather bought a fruit and vegetable farm on the city's outskirts, and Mr. Pataki was raised there along with a brother and 12 cousins.
He graduated from Peekskill High School in 1963, an erudite basketball player who won a scholarship to Yale. During summers he also worked for Fleischmann's, shoveling coal to run the generators and stacking bottles of gin for $3 an hour.
Mr. Pataki graduated from Yale with a degree in history and went to Columbia Law School, again on scholarship, where he was an editor on the law review.
In 1974, after a four-year stint with a Wall Street law firm, Mr. Pataki returned to Peekskill and opened a branch office for the White Plains-based law firm of Plunkett & Jaffe. Along the way he married Elizabeth Rowland, known as Libby, whom he met while they were body surfing, in a storm, off Long Island. They have four children: Emily, 15, Teddy, 12, Allison, 9, and Owen, 7. Mrs. Pataki is a former manager for Paine Webber who quit her job to raise the family. Teddy is named after Mr. Pataki's political idol, Teddy Roosevelt.
The family eventually moved into a Victorian mansion in the Putnam County hamlet of Garrison, a home that Mr. Pataki bought with $700,000 in profits from his real estate transactions. His real estate deals became an issue this year when the Cuomo campaign contended he illegally avoided paying taxes on profits, a charge Mr. Pataki has denied.
Long active in Republican politics, Mr. Pataki had helped on the gubernatorial campaigns of Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1970 and Malcolm Wilson in 1974. He also worked as a legislative aide to former State Senator Bernard G. Gordon and his successor, Mary B. Goodhue.
He first sought office in 1981 when he ran for Peekskill mayor on a slate with three Republican City Council candidates. Mr. Vesce recalled prepping Mr. Pataki for the first televised debate in Peekskill history before the election. "It was all 'ahs' and 'ums,' " he said of Mr. Pataki's delivery. "It was so bad I rushed to the kitchen looking for a knife to commit suicide."
Despite his unpolished speaking skills, which he has since burnished over the years, as well as the Democrats' edge in registered voters, Mr. Pataki and his allies handily defeated the incumbents and ushered in an era of Republican dominance in Peekskill politics that continues today. Mr. Pataki won re-election in 1983.
As Mayor, Mr. Pataki used a variety of incentives to bring real estate developers to Peekskill to help boost the local economy. After leaving the office, he set up a law practice with his brother, Louis Jr., that did business with, and profited from, some of those same developers -- a move that has brought criticism from political opponents.
In 1984, Mr. Pataki defeated another Democratic incumbent, Assemblyman William J. Ryan, and began the first of four terms in the Assembly. As a Republican in the Democratic-controlled house, he was often relegated to casting protest votes against tax increases and welfare spending. But he won praise from environmentalists for working to protect the Hudson River and from teachers unions for fighting to increase state aid to suburban schools.
In 1992, Mr. Pataki defeated his former mentor, Ms. Goodhue, in a bitter and closely fought Republican primary and went on to win the general election. Ms. Goodhue has accused Mr. Pataki of being a mudslinging campaigner, and she refused to support him this year.
But Mr. Pataki had plenty of supporters at a rally on Monday night. And it seemed only appropriate that the candidate, a virtuoso small-town politician performing in the Carnegie Hall of New York State races, should spend the final hours of his campaign with the hometown crowd in Peekskill.
Several hundred people gathered under balloons and bunting to cheer the local hero at a restaurant built in the old Fleischmann's gin distillery in Peekskill. As the crowd enclosed the weary but smiling Mr. Pataki, Tim Carey, a friend and political consultant, looked on admiringly.
"George is that kind of guy," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK GOVERNOR;
Concession and Victory: Words of Pataki and Cuomo

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the concession speech of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last night, as transcribed by The New York Times.
CUOMO Which brings me to my final thank-you, and that is to the people of the State of New York, this magnificent place. Long ago, long before our first victory in 1982, this state had already given me and my family more opportunity and reward than we had any right to expect. Then it added three terms as Governor of the greatest state in the nation. I don't have the words to describe the deep sense of gratitude and depth that I feel for that immense opportunity. 
 I had great plans for this state in the coming years and I have great hopes for her still, because of the strength of our people, the scope of the great gifts that nature has given us and all the good that we inherited from those who came before us. And the extraordinary things we were able to achieve for the people in just 12 years, despite two serious national recessions, and with a decade of disdain from Washington. We have enormous power here; we have a fantastic future potentially. I've surely made mistakes as Governor, but I'm as proud as I can be of what we have accomplished together and I'm just absolutely -- I'm absolutely convinced that there's enormous -- there's an enormous amount more we can do.
Now I have a regret, one main regret, this year: that I was not able to make the case clearly enough in this campaign to gain for you -- all of you -- the victory that your good work deserved. I'm sorry to have let you down because you deserved, you deserved another four years.
Now, my greatest hope, my, my greatest hope for this state and -- and maybe even for the nation beyond, the reason -- the reason we wanted to run, the reason we thought it was important is that we sensed all across this nation a negativism, a harshness, a divisiveness, a willingness to pit people against one another, even a cynicism that we didn't like. It's not appropriate for this country and it's certainly not appropriate for this great state.
We've been given too much, we have been too fortunate to become bitter and negative -- that's a dangerous thing. My great hope is that this state will grow together, put aside the divisions between upstate and downstate, between communities, between colors, between sexes, between sexual orientations and that we will remember what the proper direction is for us as a state and for the nation and -- and -- and please understand that this state has known from the beginning what the proper direction is; it's part of your seal. It was the slogan that helped launch the state.
The word is excelsior, and I'll leave you with words that I've used over and over all through this campaign that say it much better than I could say it: Where are we supposed to go? What direction are we supposed to travel in? E. B. White told us: remember New York is to the nation what the church spire is to the village -- the symbol of aspiration and faith, the white plume saying the way is up, not down, not backward, up. Excelsior! Let's keep going up.
Thank you. God bless you. Thank you for everything. Thank you.
Following are excerpts from the victory speech of George E. Pataki, as transcribed by The New York Times.
PATAKI And I'd also like to thank someone, a United States Senator -- a United States Senator who on Jan. 1 will become chairman of the Senate Banking Committee; someone who has suffered unfair attacks during the course of this campaign. Let me just say to him, and to everyone out there: You can call me, Al.
D'AMATO I hear you.
PATAKI God bless you. . . .
Let me at this time also thank Gov. Mario Cuomo. Governor, I thank you from the bottom of my heart for your kind words this evening. The people of this state, all the people of New York State, salute you, Governor, for your service to all of us. Thank you for that service. . . .
You know, the people of this state voted for change. The people of this country voted for change, all across the country -- and thank you for doing that. Let me pledge to you New Yorkers, all New Yorkers -- upstate, downstate, the New Yorkers in the city, that I will work with you to bring about the change you voted for today. We are going to have a government that serves the people instead of a people that serve the government. And that is a change that we will make.
We pledge -- we pledge to control state spending and cut taxes. And let me tell you, we are going to do that, we are going to cut the taxes. And one of my top priorities is going to be to make sure that you can walk the streets and play in the parks and have your kids go to school, and live at home in safety, because we are going to change the criminal justice system of this state . . . Let me just make one thing simple: I love this state, I am very proud of New York, I am very proud to be a New Yorker, I am very grateful for the opportunity that this state has given me, a mailman's kid from Peekskill, to stand before you tonight as the next Governor.
If there's one thing -- if there's one thing this campaign has stood for day in and day out it's about again restoring people's confidence in the future of this state, again restoring their belief that the best of this state is ahead of us, that we can again become number one in economic opportunity and new jobs, that we can again become number one in the quality of our schools and the safety of our streets. That we can again be a place where dreams come true -- for ourselves, for our children, for our grandchildren, and for all New Yorkers.
With your help, we're going to make the changes. We're going to bring this state back. And we are again going to be very proud, all of us from all parts of this state, to call this the great Empire State.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE NATION
THE CAPITAL;
Barry Rebounds From Disgrace to Win Again in Washington

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. last night regained the office he had left in disgrace almost five years ago, but not without widespread defections of black voters to his Republican opponent, Carol Schwartz.
At 12:48 A.M., with 73 percent of the precincts reporting, the vote was:
Barry . . . 54%
Schwartz . . . 44%
The margin was enough to force Mrs. Schwartz to concede shortly after 11 P.M. last night. 
 "We have dreamed the impossible dream and made the impossible possible," said Mr. Barry, who left office in 1990 after being arrested on charges of possession of cocaine. In an emotional victory speech with a theme of unifying ethnic groups to rebuild the city, Mr. Barry said: "We have come together as never before. Now is not the time to gloat in our success. Now is the time to build bridges together and help me rebuild Washington together."
In a city in which more than two-thirds of the voters are black and the vast majority are Democrats, his victory also reflected a strong abandonment by many of the black voters who had supported him in the September primary.
In her second campaign against Mr. Barry, who is black, Mrs. Schwartz, a white candidate, ran unusually well in several predominantly black wards of the city in which Mr. Barry was presumed to have built invincible strength. According to a count of early votes, in Ward 6, a predominantly black middle-class area, Mrs. Schwartz drew unusually large support: Mr. Barry led her there by just 5,751 to 4,776 votes. By contrast, in Ward 8, a largely black but lower-income area, in which Mr. Barry lives, he led in the early count by 5,572 to 496.
One thing that is certain is that her showing was the strongest of anyone who had ever opposed Mr. Barry in a general election for mayor. Eight years ago, she finished second, with 32 percent of the vote.
Mr. Barry's victory seemed virtually certain since the primary on Sept. 13, when he defeated six other Democrats, including Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly, who won election four years ago on the promise of clean government and change. Mr. Barry's plurality of 47 percent became the surest sign that voters were willing to overlook his arrest for smoking crack cocaine in a downtown hotel with a woman who was not his wife, the incident that drove him from office in 1990.
After he was convicted on a single charge of drug possession, he served six months in prison.
But if his misdemeanor conviction, drug rehabilitation and political redemption served as the emotional backdrop to the general election, more urgent issues affecting the city dominated the daily debate between him and Mrs. Schwartz, including how to satisfy the Congressional order to cut $140 million in spending from the city budget.
While Mrs. Schwartz, a 54-year-old widow of a prominent Washington lawyer, attacked Mr. Barry's proposals as worn out and ineffective, Mr. Barry tied together the emotional and pragmatic themes of his campaign, asking voters who could better to lead the redemption of a city than someone who had pronounced himself redeemed.
For Mrs. Schwartz, it was an uphill fight all the way, shaped by an electorate in which Democrats outnumber Republicans more than 10-to-1 and blacks outnumber whites more than 2-to-1. She battled Mr. Barry on issues facing the city, making her main thrust the constant reminder that the city and its services had deteriorated in his last two terms in office.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE HOUSE
THE VOTERS;
In Chicago (Truly!), Many Stay Home

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Precinct captains stood outside nearly empty polling places. They looked at their lists and checked off names. They got people rides to the polls. They got babysitters for voters' children. They slipped reminders on front porches and palm cards in people's hands. They got doors slammed in their faces and weak promises from voters who vowed they would vote but did not.
By the end of Election Day in a city where politics is a blood sport more important than even baseball, less than half of the voters had cast ballots for state and Congressional races that politicians said could change the face of Washington. 
 "They're really not interested this time, to tell you the truth," said John Amerin, a Democratic precinct captain on the Northwest Side.
There are many reasons. Two Congressmen on the Chicago ballot are under indictment -- Dan Rostenkowski on charges of fraud and embezzlement, Mel Reynolds on charges of sexual assault of a minor. (Mr. Rostenkowski lost while Mr. Reynolds faced no opposition.) Voters say negative advertising has eroded whatever respect they had for some candidates. And this year, "crook" and "politician" have been used interchangeably in what now seems an echo chamber of discontent.
In interviews today, voters told why they were sitting out this election, why they were drinking espresso or running errands or heading to the gym instead of going to the polls in one of the tightest, meanest midterm elections in years.
They spoke in the venomous tones that have characterized the campaign. "Politicians are finaglers, liars, jugglers and seat-holders," said Lloyd Jackson, a welder. "At election time, tongues wag both ways. Politics have done absolutely nothing for me."
Some said they were simply too busy. "I just graduated from school, I work 65, 70 hours a week, I've got student loans to pay back," said Keith Frainey, a psychologist. "What mainly interests me is trying to make a living."
Some said they could not stomach the ballot choices. "The candidates are unworthy because they run simply by attacking each other instead of saying what they will do," said Bob Makey, a real estate developer trying to gather the energy to drag himself to the polls. "I don't even know most of the candidates. The press has discouraged me from voting because it looks like it's going to be a Republican landslide and there is nothing I can do about it. People are frustrated, emasculated, and there's no hope anymore."
Joseph Paulus, a store manager in training, said that he had voted for President Clinton but that he was too turned off to vote this time. "It's the same old garbage," Mr. Paulus said. "Nothing changes. I'm just so frustrated and fed up."
He said he wants radical change. "We need to do away with Congress," he said. "It should be a lottery just like jury duty. You should be drafted to go to Washington. That way we would get reporters and teachers and farmers and businessmen. It would be a better representation of the country."
Sarah Dusek, a paralegal, said she felt guilty because she was a political science major in college. But, she said, "I'm not going to vote because I don't know who's running and I'm fed up with all the mudslinging, awful TV commercials."
Even people who decided to vote had a hard time deciding what to do once they got inside the booth. "I know I should vote, but I'm not excited or anything," said Charisse Landise, a shiatsu practitioner.
She sat with a cup of coffee, studying the front page of The Chicago Tribune before walking to the voting booth. "I'm looking for some type of reference point of who is declaring what," Ms. Landise said. "I'm in the dark. I'm looking for who I should vote for. Just clues."
This time of year in Chicago, a city where people really do call their alderman's office when their trash is not picked up, there should be a forest of yard signs and arguments over candidates at every dinner table. "Normally Chicago is abuzz this time of year," said Richard Mell, an alderman on Chicago's Northwest Side. "This is a strange one. I just don't see the enthusiasm."
So the precinct captains have had to work a little harder. "We're dragging everybody out to vote and hoping they're sympathetic," Mr. Mell said. "We drive them if they need a ride and babysit for them if they need a babysitter.'
Cozella Ireland, an election judge on Chicago's South Side, said she spent all day Sunday trying to get people in her predominantly black district excited about voting.
"I passed out literature about Nelson Mandela and the history of what it took for Africans to vote," Ms. Ireland said. "The literature had pictures of mothers with children on their backs and shoulders walking for three days to vote. And these people live right around the corner and won't come."
In Chicago, where nearly half of all voters are black, Democrats and Republicans have gone so far as to try to woo blacks with rap campaign commercials. (Gov. Jim Edgar, a Republican who was re-elected, stiffly did his own rap in a radio spot: "Well, my name is Jim and I've just been dissed/So I've got to respond 'cause my point was missed.")
Velma Rivera, a nursing assistant who is black, said it was a further insult in an election year when issues like crime and welfare seemed to be assaults on them. "I'm 32 years old," Ms. Rivera said. "Rap is for my 16-year-old son. It just shows what they think of us." She said she was not voting.
The apathy crosses wards and races. "They just don't care," said Patricia Cullerton, an alderman on Chicago's Northwest Side. "They're saying their lives are too busy to vote. They feel politicians don't help them anyway, so it doesn't matter."
Russ Gibbs, a marketing executive who voted for Ross Perot in the 1992 Presidential election, said he saw no reason to go. "It doesn't seem like there are that many issues pertinent to me," Mr. Gibbs said. "The economy is doing pretty good. I'm not really affected by crime. If you're not in any particular pain, you're not going to vote. It's going to go on without me."
Steve Joslyn was beyond apathetic about the election. "I don't even know when it is," said Mr. Joslyn, a chef at a North Side restaurant, who said he did not have time to vote. "It's Thursday, isn't it?"

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK GOVERNOR
CUOMO;
Governor, Philosophical, Concedes and Soldiers On

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
He never prayed for victory on his final Election Day, the most sorrowful day in a career that had known few such moments of defeat. Instead, said Mario M. Cuomo, he fashioned a different prayer.
"The prayer we say is not, 'Lord, let me win,' " he said, "but the prayer we say is 'Lord, let me understand the outcome and deal with it.' " 
 That was at noon on Election Day, scant hours before the final tally of votes that abruptly ended a political career that once seemed boundless. But even then, the Governor seemed to struggle with the possibility of loss, working to understand an electorate that had failed to grasp a truth that seemed to him so obvious.
 At midnight, when it came time to concede, he still seemed frustrated and puzzled by a national cynicism and bitterness so alien to his nature but so powerful that it had cut him down.
"The reason we wanted to run," he said in his final speech, "the reason we thought it was important, is that we sense all across this nation a negativism, a harshness, a divisiveness, a willingness to pit people against one another, even a cynicism that we didn't like. It's not appropriate for this country, and it's certainly not appropriate for this great state. We've been given too much, we have been too fortunate to have become bitter and negative."
As he spoke, there was no trace of personal bitterness on his face, riddled with the lines and caverns and bags that had long shielded his emotions from public view. He thanked scores of family members and friends and aides, he thanked the entire state. He even, amazingly, thanked and praised the media. To the very end, there was a determined old-world stoicism that he joked about earlier in the day.
"Wistful?" he lectured a reporter. "Wistful? I'm from Queens. We don't get wistful. We don't get wan."
He took upon his own shoulders the responsibility for defeat, apologizing in the face of audience protest for letting down his supporters.
"I have one main regret this year," he said, as tears flowed down the faces of those around him. "That I was not able to make the case clearly enough in this campaign to gain for you, all of you, the victory that all of your good work deserved."
Staff members said he was just as composed after the polls closed and the first, ominous returns began trickling in. He had the television set on in his suite at the New York Sheraton, occasionally switching off the election news to watch the Knicks game, chatting amiably with family and friends as if the world was not closing in. Just before conceding, he dropped by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's hotel suite and jokingly told a mayoral aide to get married.
And perhaps, for a man who willingly gave up a lifetime seat on the Supreme Court and a chance to be President, it was not the end of the world. His innermost ambitions and dreams were always so concealed that perhaps despite the fervor of his campaign, he could imagine a life outside of government. Though he confessed to a sleepless night on Monday, he said it was caused by the mundane possibilities of unemployment, not the thought of political cataclysm.
"You don't sleep," he said, just after he voted with his wife in Hollis, Queens. "You have to think about what happens if you win, what happens if you lose. If you win, there's a tremendous amount of work to do. If you lose, you have to find work, you have to find a place to live. So."
Was he really spending the night before his last election worrying about real estate, how to stay busy, how to make a living? Throughout the campaign he had insisted that voters not support him out of concern for the Cuomo family, but out of concern for the state. But it was not in his nature to admit that his insomnia resulted from a profound fear, a dread of something larger than a personal upheaval.
Mr. Cuomo had painted himself for weeks as the candidate of optimism, the only one of the pack to foresee hope for New York State. Even on the last day of his last campaign, he could hardly be seen predicting any less for himself or, for that matter, life under his successor.
"We have enormous power here," he said in the ballroom of the Sheraton, where so many of his campaign speeches had been delivered. "We have a fantastic future, potentially. I've surely made mistakes as Governor, but I'm as proud as can be for what we've accomplished together."
His Democratic colleagues, themselves struggling for an explanation that the Governor never sought, insisted that the voters had not rejected his vision, but had simply been restless.
"I think it was a general feeling that people said enough," said Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn. "Even though people respect the Governor for his integrity, for his vision, they're saying, 'We want to change something.' They may be buying a pig in a poke, but they want a change."
If there was a vagueness to that kind of thinking, a fuzziness of mind, it was precisely what Mr. Cuomo had always railed against in his 12 years as Governor. When reporters asked him questions that were less than perfectly formed, he lashed out. If a voter said he opposed the Governor because he wanted change, Mr. Cuomo demanded to know precisely what needed to be changed, and how, and under what circumstances, and who would do the changing. But he could not demand his own precision of mind from an electorate who saw him living on a different mental plane.
"This is a system that rewards involvement and punishes aloofness," he said yesterday afternoon. The context was one of urging people to vote, but he might as well have been talking about himself and his final separation from a populace who no longer shared his expansive vision of the state's possibilities.
"You stay away from the system," he said, "and it hurts you."

HEADLINE: U.S. Agency Is Accused of Bias in Making South Africa Grants

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Several current or former officials in the Agency for International Development are engaged in a dispute over whether the agency has improperly sought to exclude non-black groups both in the United States and in South Africa when it awards grants to aid that African nation.
Paul Neifert, an A.I.D. official who was transferred out of South Africa after criticizing agency policies there, complained that just when the new Government of President Nelson Mandela was seeking to build a country free of discrimination, A.I.D. was increasingly basing its grants on the color of recipients. 
 In a scathing article in the November issue of Foreign Service Journal, Mr. Neifert pointed to several instances in which the agency had strained to insure that grants went to black-led organizations. He wrote that after the agency adopted its new policy in mid-1992, A.I.D. managers in South Africa informed their staff members that "those uncomfortable with the new Afro-centric direction" of agency programs "should leave."
He wrote about one agency official who, eager to award grants to black groups, asked in an open meeting what it would take to get a white South African to resign as leader of an A.I.D.-funded organization.
In interviews today, senior A.I.D. officials denied any improper actions, asserting that they were merely following American laws that allow favoring black-led organizations when awarding A.I.D. contracts. The agency plans to provide about $200 million in aid to South Africa over each of the next three years.
"They're alleging that the U.S. has made a policy decision to utilize only African-American groups to work in South Africa, and that's just not true," said John F. Hicks, A.I.D.'s assistant administrator for Africa.
Mr. Hicks said, for instance, that it makes sense to award grants to black schools, like Howard University, to help improve South African education programs because they have a lot to offer with their long history of teaching students who have suffered discrimination.
Mr. Hicks noted that of the $132.6 million his agency has granted so far this year to assist South Africa, $62 million has been channeled through American groups. About $11 million of this has gone to black-led or black-owned groups, while the other $51 million went to groups that are not black-led.
But the agency's critics say its affirmative action policies have gone so far that they have sought to exclude Asian-Americans and multi-racial organizations in South Africa from winning contracts.
Last April, Harry Johnson, a 27-year agency veteran, now retired, sent a letter to A.I.D.'s top official, J. Brian Atwood, to complain that its grants to South Africa were being improperly skewed to favor the "African community, as opposed to the 'Colored' or 'Asian' communities," which he said were also considered disadvantaged.
Mr. Johnson complained that managers blocked consultants' recommendations to grant money to a multi-racial business group, rather than a black-led organization, to teach skills to black-owned small businesses in South Africa.
Several Republicans in Congress have joined the attack. Accusing the agency of engaging in a frenzy of "political correctness," Representative Daniel Burton, an Indiana Republican, said, "The South African people deserve better than to have themselves turned into a trough of spoils and rich contracts."
Mr. Hicks sought to downplay the criticism. "They're challenging a policy that is trying to work with black-led groups to the maximum extent possible," he said.

HEADLINE: Aristide's Cabinet Is Sworn and Pledges to Get to Work

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 8

 BODY:
After nearly a month of highly publicized consultations with friends and foes and a bit of old-fashioned politicking behind closed doors, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide finally has a Prime Minister, a full Cabinet and a Parliament-approved plan of action.
At a ceremony at the National Palace this morning, before guests who included Haitian politicians, foreign diplomats and Maj. Gen. David Meade, commander of the American troops here, Prime Minister-designate Smarck Michel and his Cabinet took their oaths of office and pledged to begin work immediately on the daunting task of rebuilding a country devastated by military dictatorship, corruption and harsh economic sanctions. 
 "I thank the Haitian people for their patience," Mr. Michel, 57, a businessman, said. "I hope I don't disappoint you."
The swearing-in followed a vote of confidence late Monday night in which Parliament formally endorsed Mr. Michel, his 17-member Cabinet and the program of government he had submitted for the lawmakers' approval.
That plan, markedly more mainstream in tone than the approach President Aristide took during his first tenure in office, emphasizes the establishment of democratic institutions and the rebuilding of the economy through market forces and foreign assistance.
Mr. Michel was selected as Prime Minister on Oct. 24, but Parliament, which still has a large contingent of former supporters of the military junta that ousted President Aristide in 1991, dragged its heels on his confirmation through a variety of procedural devices. That forced the President to meet with opposition legislators, as well as factions from his own coalition, and appeal for their cooperation.
President Aristide was eager to have his Cabinet confirmed and installed because a delegation from the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank is here this week to discuss the economic reconstruction of Haiti. Had the Cabinet appointments and program not been ratified, it would not have been clear who had the authority to meet with the visitors and make commitments on behalf of the President.
In the end, the President was able to retain close associates whom he originally appointed while in exile in most of the important economic posts, including Finance Minister Marie-Michele Rey, Planning Minister Jean-Marie Cherestal and Agriculture Minister Agronome F. Severin. The Foreign Minister, Claudette Werleigh, and Interior Minister, Rene Prosper, also are carry-overs.
As his Defense Minister, President Aristide named a retired general, Wilton Lerisson. Today's swearing-in ceremony was attended by Maj. Gen. Jean-Claude Duperval, who replaced Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras as Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces last month, and other members of the high command. They listened attentively as the President urged them to work "hand in hand" with the civilian authorities.
Evoking the three years of state-sponsored terror and repression Haiti has just suffered through, President Aristide said his goal was for all Haitians to "feel like they have security" and are "living in a country where their hearts are not pounding, but are beating calmly." He pledged that his Government would work "not for one or two people, or one group of people, but for each and every person."
In an effort to reach out to constituencies that his predecessors largely ignored, including women, intellectuals and the approximately one million Haitians who live abroad, President Aristide also created four new Cabinet posts. These are the Ministries for Women's Affairs, the Haitian diaspora, Culture and Public Functions, which was spun off from the Planning Ministry.
The new Cabinet also includes one minister, Marc Henri Rousseau-Francois of Public Works, who held the same post under the military dictatorship that overthrew President Aristide on Sept. 30 1991. Another member, Trade and Industry Minister Maurice Lafortune, who was elected last month as president of the Haitian Chamber of Commerce, served under one of the military governments that held power before Father Aristide's election.
The United States Ambassador to Haiti, William L. Swing, described the appointees as "a good, strong group of people" and praised the Haitian President for assembling "a very broad-based" Government that included people outside his Lavalas movement.
Mr. Swing also promised that the Clinton Administration and President Aristide's other foreign allies would do their best to help the new Government succeed during the 15 months remaining in his term.
"I believe Haiti has the best opportunity in its modern history to build democracy and a sound economy," Mr. Swing said. "In contrast to a lot of other transitional countries, the political resolve of the Haitian people and the international community is being matched by commensurate economic and financial resources to support them at this time of watershed change."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: GOVERNOR;
Promise to Repeal Income Tax Helps Rowland and G.O.P. to Apparent Victory

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Wednesday, Nov. 9

 BODY:
John G. Rowland, a Republican who has vowed to repeal the state's three-year-old income tax, was elected governor of Connecticut yesterday with little more than a third of the vote, defeating William E. Curry Jr., a Democrat, and two other major candidates.
Mr. Rowland's narrow victory puts a Republican in the state's top office for the first time in two decades. And it means that an income tax introduced in 1991 -- the major legacy of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. -- may once again be the focus of debate in the State Legislature. 
 The election also raises questions about the viabilty of Governor Weicker's third party, A Connecticut Party, which was established in 1990 for his bid for office. His heir apparent, Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, appears to have failed to garner the 20 percent needed to hold onto its major-party status, and the party is likely to cease being a significant player in the political scene.
The fourth major candidate was Tom Scott, a leader of the anti-income tax movement running as an independent.
With 99 percent of the 820 precincts reporting, the vote was:
Rowland . . . 36%
Curry . . . 33%
Groark . . . 19%
Scott . . . 11%
In other races, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman was easily re-elected over his Republican opponent, Gerald Labriola, a retired pediatrician and former state senator, 67 percent to 31 percent, with 91 percent of the votes counted.
Mr. Rowland declared victory at 11:25 P.M. at a celebration at the Sheraton Hotel in Waterbury, saying that his campaign marks a new era for Connecticut.
"We ask you all across the state -- Republicans, Democrats and unaffiliated voters -- to put your courage and your trust in the free-enterprise system," he said. "Let the free-enterprise system get us through the economic recovery. Let's try trusting individuals and trusting cities and towns to take care of our problems rather than rely on Big Daddy government in Hartford and in Washington."
A few minutes later, when a reporter asked if he would be able to govern effectively with such a small plurality, he responded: "I anticipated that would be the very first question from the press. I think we have a mandate if you look at the amount of support we got in a four-way race. And the bottom line is whether its 36, 38 or 48, I'm going to be the governor."
In Hartford, about the same time as Mr. Rowland declared victory, Mr. Curry conceded defeat.
"This was a hard night," he said, adding, "I wish to congratulate John Rowland on his victory, and to wish his administration well in contending with all the very difficult challenges that confront our state."
Mr. Rowland's victory was apparently accompanied by a Republican gain of at least one seat in the State Senate, meaning that Mr. Rowland effectively has a majority in that house. The Democrats picked up a number of seats in the State House of Representatives, increasing their majority.
It was difficult to gauge tonight how much the income tax was the turning point in the race.
According to exit interviews conducted by Voter News Service, a consortium of the four television networks and The Associated Press, 60 percent of the 1,153 repondents favored repealing the income tax and 38 percent wanted to keep it. But the survey also showed that people did not necessarily use the income tax as a litmus test. About 35 percent of those opposed to it voted for either Mr. Curry or Mrs. Groark, both supporters of the income tax.
Mr. Rowland, 37, was the front-runner since announcing his candidacy in January. A former three-term Congressman who lost a close contest for governor in 1990, he began this campaign better known than any of his opponents and quickly developed a fund-raising advantage that his competitors never came close to matching.
As of Oct. 25, Mr. Rowland had raised more than $3.3 million, 40 percent more than Mr. Curry and more than triple what Mrs. Groark had raised.
And with an electorate frightened about crime and angry over taxes, Mr. Rowland's message about the "wrong people being afraid" and his promise to repeal the income tax proved popular.
"Now is our time," Mr. Rowland said in July when he received his party's nomination and appeared confident that he would become the first Republican governor of Connecticut since Thomas J. Meskill's victory in 1970.
Still, the race involved substantial hurdles for Mr. Rowland that few would have predicted.
Over the summer, Mr. Rowland was faced with an unexpected primary challenge from Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer, who aggressively attacked Mr. Rowland for his work as a Capitol Hill consultant over the last four years and for his 108 overdrafts from the House Bank in the 1980's. Mr. Rowland defeated her decisively and then won her support for the general election.
More recently, Mr. Rowland had to deal with controversy over an argument he had with his former wife, Deborah, on April 10 that prompted her to call the police to her home in Middlebury. The incident made headlines when The Hartford Courant tried to obtain a copy of the police report, and the police chief, a Rowland supporter, and Mr. Rowland opposed its release.
For weeks, the legal battle over whether the report should be made public dominated campaign news, and although a judge ultimately ruled that the report should not be released before the election, the controversy appeared to have damaged Mr. Rowland's support among women.
Mr. Rowland tried to blunt the damage, running a commercial that cast himself as a victim, saying he was being smeared by The Courant and his "political enemies."
Mr. Rowland also benefited from the dynamics of a four-way race that could have worked against him. Many had predicted that Mr. Rowland's bid had suffered a fatal blow when Mr. Scott, a conservative Republican who led the fight against the income tax, entered the race as an independent in September.
Polls have shown that Mr. Scott took away some of Mr. Rowland's more conservative supporters, and Mr. Scott was a constant thorn in Mr. Rowland's side during debates, arguing that Mr. Rowland was not truly committed to eliminating the income tax. Indeed, Mr. Rowland never detailed all the budget cuts that would be needed to eliminate the income tax, which provides about $2.5 billion to the state, roughly one-fourth of its revenues.
But Mr. Rowland reacted quickly to Mr. Scott. Early in the campaign, when Mr. Scott first threatened to run, Mr. Rowland shifted his position on the income tax, promising to repeal it, after initially ruling out such an option. For the remainder of the campaign, Mr. Rowland delivered a conservative fiscal message that included tax cuts while insisting they could be instituted without severe cuts in government services, as Mr. Scott favored.
As the campaign came to a close, Mr. Curry and Mrs. Groark fought for the anti-Rowland vote, with Mr. Curry insisting that a vote for Mrs. Groark would help elect Mr. Rowland. For her part, Mrs. Groark argued that voters should follow their hearts, rather than "waste" the vote on their second choice, just to block Mr. Rowland.
And Mr. Rowland managed to drown out the other candidates' messages with a media blitz of 14 television commercials that began at the end of the summer.
The ad campaign conveyed his message of an income-tax repeal, tougher sentences for criminals and an overhaul of the welfare system, but it also defined Mr. Curry for many voters. In five attack ads, Mr. Rowland portrayed Mr. Curry as a tax-and-spend liberal who was soft on crime and part of government as usual.
"A vote for Curry is a vote for more money out of your pocket," Mr. Rowland said in one commercial, ignoring Mr. Curry's pledge to reduce property taxes by 25 percent, a centerpiece of Mr. Curry's campaign that never seemed to capture the public's imagination.
Mr. Curry responded to some of the spots, but he was not able to equal Mr. Rowland's advertising barrage, and his two attempts to attack Mr. Rowland for his consulting work and overdrafts apparently did not have much impact.
The victory is something of a vindication for Mr. Rowland, as many of his supporters believe that he was unjustly deprived of the job in 1990 because of Mr. Weicker's decision to abandon the Republican Party and run as an independent.
In that election, Mr. Rowland received 37 percent to Mr. Weicker's 40 percent. Since then, Mr. Rowland has attributed the loss to perceptions that he was mean and to anger raised by his threat to lay off state employees to balance the budget.
In this election, Mr. Rowland projected a softer, more moderate image and promised that he would not lay off state employees. His commercials sometimes featured him in casual dress, with soft piano music in the background.
"People are afraid of losing their jobs," he said. "We're losing our streets to crime. But it doesn't have to be that way. More than anything else, I want to bring hope back to Connecticut."

HEADLINE: World Bank Approves Loan to Help Russia Clean Up Pollution

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The World Bank today approved its first loan to Russia aimed at cleaning up some of the country's contaminated rivers, polluted industrial sites and toxic waste dumps, and said it was the first step in a broad program to undo seven decades of environmental mismanagement.
By international standards the loan is small, about $110 million. But bank officials, who have been heavily criticized for financing huge infrastructure projects in the developing world with little regard for their environmental effects, insisted today that the loan symbolized a change of direction that took place several years ago in the bank's lending, and is being speeded. 
 The loan, combined with $45 million in investments from newly privatized businesses in Russia and $90 million in donations from the United States, the European Union and other other nations, would soon be felt in some of Russia's most fouled urban areas.
"This is an important first step that focuses on a few areas where the need is critical," said Roger Batstone, the bank's principal environmental engineer for the project. "This is the first installment of a large program of environmental lending for the Russian Federation."
Russia's environmental problems are tied directly to decades of central planning that ignored environmental concerns in the failed effort to increase the country's industrial output. Underpriced energy, economists say, only worsened the problem, as economically inefficient factories spewed enormous amounts of untreated exhausts and chemical wastes into the atmosphere.
The bank said today that 43 Russian cities were in urgent need of relief from air pollution, and that Russian industry discharged more sodium dioxide, the substance that causes acid rain, than all the factories in the United Kingdom, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and France combined. Deforestation is widespread, largely because so many trees are still harvested for firewood, and fish harvests are declining because of pollution and the diversion of water for irrigation.
The World Bank program will focus on three regions: the Upper Volga, the North Caucasus and the Urals. "These are areas where there is some local commitment to cleaning things up," Mr. Batstone said, "so we believe they are good test areas."
Nonetheless, nearly half the project funds will be spent outside of Russia, for foreign environmental cleanup equipment and foreign consultants. The first step will be to establish a database of environmental hazards, and to develop plans for water-quality management in several regions.
The bank's president, Lewis Preston, is traveling in Russia, Kyrgyzstan and Kazakhstan this week to discuss their transition to market economies. Mr. Preston has been arguing in recent months that the bank's critics have overblown its past lack of interest in environmental issues, noting that in the last four years it has spent $2.7 billion for environmental projects. Nearly half that figure, however, was spent last year. The bank issues about $17 billion in loans each year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler Switch to New Mini-Vans

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., Nov. 8

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation expects to lose about 60,000 sales of its highly profitable mini-vans in 1995 because it will temporarily shut two assembly plants to prepare for new models, company officials said today.
Auto industry analysts on Wall Street believe Chrysler makes $5,000 to $7,500 on every mini-van it sells. Taking the lower figure, that means the No. 3 auto maker could lose at least $300 million because of the lost production and sales. 
 The cutback will cost Chrysler about 12 percent of its mini-van sales, which it predicts will reach 500,000 in the United States this year.
Wall Street auto stock analysts were expecting a production decline in the range Chrysler announced today. And no one is urging Chrysler to rush the introduction of its new mini-van model. "It's a major changeover, and Chrysler's got to do it right," said Michael P. Ward, auto industry analyst with Kidder Peabody in New York. "So when in doubt, slow down."
Chrysler's shares slipped 37.5 cents today, to $46.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Chrysler may not return to full production of mini-vans in North America until the third quarter of next year, the company said today.
"We're going to go through a huge shortage of mini-vans in the first six months next year," said E. Thomas Pappert, Chrysler's vice president for sales and service, in a meeting with reporters today at Chrysler headquarters here. Chrysler expects the new mini-vans to begin reaching dealers in small numbers by March.
Competition has intensified in the mini-van market that Chrysler defined and dominated. Since introducing its new Windstar mini-van earlier this year, the Ford Motor Company has eroded Chrysler's market share. The Honda Motor Company is now bringing a new mini-van to the United States that is not expected to take much marker share.
Separately, Chrysler announced today that it expects the United States car and truck market to grow to 16.5 million units in 1995, up about 1 million units from this year. That 1995 estimate was significantly down from Chrysler's previous, more bullish, projection of 17 million in June, although it was still above most industry forecasts.
Chrysler said it expected interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve to restrain sales.
Chrysler now makes mini-vans in two assembly plants, one in St. Louis and the other in Windsor, Ontario. It is refurbishing another plant in St. Louis to being producing the new mini-vans in February. It will close the existing St. Louis mini-van plan early next year and plans to begin producing full-size pickups there beginning in the third quarter of 1995.
The Canadian mini-van plant is scheduled to close in the second quarter, and start up again in the third quarter.
While Chrysler would not estimate the impact of the shutdowns on its earnings, Mr. Pappert said the shortage would disprove the notion that the mini-van is Chrysler's only crown jewel. "That myth will shatter over the next 18 months," he said. Increased production of vehicles like the Jeep Grand Cherokee, Dodge Neon subcompact, and Chrysler Cirrus compact sedan should help offset the blow to earnings, he said.
At full capacity, the mini-van plants will be able to produce up to 645,000 vehicles a year in North America, about the same number they can produce now. Since Chrysler expects the mini-van segment to continue to grow beyond this year's level of 1.3 million units, however, it will likely lose some market share.
While the mini-van market is hotly contested in the United States, announcements today by all three domestic auto makers suggest that in China, at least for the moment, all mini-vans are equal. Chrysler, Ford and the General Motors Corporation each announced today that they would sell 700 mini-vans to China during the 1995 model year.
Each of the three auto makers reached agreement to sell the mini-vans with Vice Premier Li Lanqing, who is visiting Detroit this week.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: NEW JERSEY;
New Jersey Congressional Races

 BODY:

2d DISTRICT
Lobiondo, the Republican, Wins
Over Democratic Newcomer
Frank A. Lobiondo, a Republican running with widespread Democratic support, handily captured the Second Congressional District seat being vacated by William J. Hughes, the Democrat, who is retiring. 
The district, covering most of the state's forested southern counties, is a traditional Republican stronghold, but its politics have shifted toward the center in recent years with the rise of new communities around Atlantic City.
Mr. Lobiondo, a State Assemblyman and family trucking company executive, bested the Democrat, Louis N. Maguzzu.
The race was won on the Republican issues that have dominated much of New Jersey's political debate this year -- lower taxes, less spending and reduced Federal government. Mr. Lobiondo was also aided by his stature as a member of the State Assembly and former member of the Cumberland County legislature.
Mr. Maguzzu, a Vineland lawyer, was a political newcomer who has never held elected office; he was also something of an insurgent in the district's Democratic Party, not originally supported.
Local labor unions were open in their support for the Republican: "Vote for the Two Franks," their literature said, referring to Mr. Lobiondo and to Frank Lautenberg, the Democratic Senator running for re-election to a third term.
Mr. Maguzzu stressed gun control and fighting crime in his campaign.
 
8th DISTRICT
Martini the Victor Over Klein
Bill Martini, a Republican city councilman from Clifton, claimed victory in a closely watched race for the House seat representing the Eighth Congressional District over Herbert Klein, a first-term Democratic incumbent.
At 10:50 P.M., Mr. Martini appeared before supporters at a hall in Totowa and said, "I think it's time that we have a chance to bring forth to the American people the policies that they want, the policies of opportunity."
Mr. Klein conceded about 15 minutes later, saying: "Politics is like the ocean, it ebbs and it flows. Unfortunately, we were in a down period, but I know that I have served with pride."
Throughout the campaign, both candidates had stressed issues of crime, taxes and the problems with unemployment in a part of the state that has not registered the same economic recovery as the southern counties. The Eighth District was redrawn two years ago to embrace some of the prosperous, and Republican-leaning, suburbs of Glen Ridge and Verona, offsetting the district's urban cores in Patterson and Passaic. The Republican Party had long hoped that the district's more balanced electorate would make the Eighth a place where the party could dislodge the first-term Democrat before he became entrenched.
Mr. Klein sought to protect himself from Republican charges of favoring taxes and spending by opposing tax increases during his first term, and by sometimes voting against President Clinton's programs on the grounds that they were too expensive.
But he cited President Clinton's recently enacted crime bill as evidence that his party was able to take a hard stance on the crime issue, while Mr. Martini characterized the crime bill as laden with "pork."

HEADLINE: 'Bell Curve' Critics Say Early I.Q. Isn't Destiny

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Are children who score poorly on standardized tests of ability fated to lives of poverty, crime and social squalor?
Charles Murray and Richard J. Herrnstein, authors of the controversial book, "The Bell Curve: Intelligence and Class Structure in American Life" (the Free Press), make no secret of their pessimism about the prospects for elevating the underclass. "For the foreseeable future," they wrote, "the problems of low cognitive ability are not going to be solved by outside intervention." 
 But many social scientists, saying they are dismayed by the book's conclusions, believe that intervention can make a big difference -- that study after study of children living in poverty suggests that early attention can improve performance.
"Murray and Herrnstein just ignored the evidence," said James Heckman, an economist at the University of Chicago. "They are 180 degrees off course."
Much of "The Bell Curve" is devoted to showing that "cognitive ability," as measured by I.Q. and other intelligence tests, is a powerful predictor of everything from earnings to criminal behavior to competence as parents. Were it possible to make "people smarter with the right kind of help," they wrote, their own research would "constitute a clarion call for programs to do so."
They concluded that Head Start-style preschool enrichment for disadvantaged children held little promise because the gains they made in them quickly faded. Improving the quality of schools (where quality is measured by class size or per-pupil spending) does not seem to make much difference, either. And while Mr. Murray and Mr. Herrnstein, who died recently, said that years of schooling do matter, they argued that the benefits of pushing more people through more grades would be modest.
But others plainly disagree with this rationale for laissez faire. A just-completed survey of thousands of Head Start children around the nation, by Janet Currie and Duncan Thomas of the University of California at Los Angeles and the Rand Corporation, does confirm one of the Murray-Herrnstein contentions -- that black children record substantial gains in standardized tests while they are in preschool programs but that the test scores drop after a few years.
Strikingly, though, the Currie-Thomas study's evidence on white children runs counter to the Murray-Herrnstein conclusions. Ms. Currie and Mr. Thomas found that poor whites initially gained as much from Head Start programs as blacks from comparable backgrounds did, but that the whites did not lose the edge when they began school. These white children were less likely to repeat a grade and were taller at age 9 than a sample group of youngsters who were not in Head Start, a finding that suggested that the participants were also healthier than the nonparticipants.
The most plausible explanation for the racial difference, Ms. Currie and Mr. Thomas said, is that black children in poverty live in harsher environments and thus need continued help to benefit from Head Start.
The most famous experiment in preschool enrichment -- relied on heavily by Murray-Herrnstein -- is the Perry Preschool program in the mid-1960's. About 123 black children living in poverty in Ypsilanti, Mich., with I.Q.'s below average, were divided into experimental and control groups. Those in the experimental group attended an intensive preschool progam and scored an average of 11 points higher on I.Q. tests than those in the control group. And, as Mr. Murray and Mr. Herrnstein noted in their book, the differences had faded after a few years.
That, however, is not the end of the story. Edward Gramlich, an economist at the University of Michigan who evaluated the Perry children through the age of 19, found that those in the experimental group continued to do better than those in the control group, by measures other than I.Q. These children were absent from school fewer days, less likely to be classified as retarded and more likely to graduate from high school.
What's more, as young adults, the children in the experimental group were found less likely to be on welfare or to have been arrested for a serious crime. And at the time of the survey, the young women in the experimental group had given birth to only half as many children as those in the control group. All told, Mr. Gramlich calculated that the savings to taxpayers represented by the findings far exceeded the cost of the preschool program.
There is conflicting evidence on the impact of special programs designed to enhance the performance of disadvantaged children once they are in school. A study led by the sociologist James Coleman of the University of Chicago, along with a subsequent survey of research by Eric Hanushek of the University of Rochester, disclosed no systematic relationship between student achievement and class size, teacher credentials or dollars spent.
But the preponderance of evidence suggests that intervention does work if it is planned carefully. The State of Tennessee, for example, formally experimented with class sizes in the mid-1980's to see if extra attention by teachers could raise the scores on standardized achievement tests of children living in poverty. The experimenters found that small classes offered the biggest advantage in kindergarten and perhaps first grade, and that the students in them still scored better in the second and third grade. But the gap in achievement did not widen.
Richard Murnane, a Harvard economist, and Frank Levy, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, also discovered selective benefits from school enrichment. Cash with no strings attached given to elementary schools in poor neighborhoods of Austin, Tex., as part of an anti-discrimination settlement generally had no impact on test scores. When schools reorganized teaching methods, however, there were substantial dividends. "Where the money was used to change the student environment radically, scores rose sharply," Mr. Murnane reports.
By the same token, research that links years of schooling to earnings later on has been dogged by accusations that the measures it uses are spurious. Smart children from affluent backgrounds generally go to school longer and earn more as adults. But is it the years of education or the combination of heritable intelligence and family background that leads to their success?
The most sophisticated efforts to tease out cause and effect in education and earnings point in one direction. Orley Ashenfelter and Alan Krueger, economists at Princeton University, looked at the differences in earnings between identical twins. A sibling with more education earned more money -- a stunning 16 percent more a year -- for every extra year in school, they found.
David Card, another economist from Princeton, compared men who grew up near low-cost colleges with those who did not. He found that college proximity mattered a lot, raising years of schooling and average earnings. This implies that ease of access to higher education, a factor independent of intelligence or family background, helps determine earnings for adults.
Mr. Hanushek of the University of Rochester concluded, "Poor kids, dumb kids, black kids, etc., all find that their lifetime earnings are raised by added years of schooling."
Numerous questions relevant to the Herrnstein-Murray thesis remain unanswered. There is no clear evidence about which preschool, school or post-school training strategies works best to raise achievement or income. Nor is it clear that every program able to improve student performance is cost-effective: social scientists are deeply divided between those who think early intervention is essential and those who think the disadvantaged can catch up as adults.
Perhaps most important, it is far from clear that Americans are prepared to invest what is necessary to eliminate the culture of poverty if the payoff in terms of lower crime and reduce dependence on welfare takes a generation to reap. But most social scientists who have looked closely at the issues do believe that the pessimistic determinism of "The Bell Curve" is unwarranted.
"The evidence is overwhelming," says Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution. "There is good reason to be optimistic that intervention can work."
