HEADLINE: At Salomon, Trader Earns $30 Million

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Even though Salomon Brothers is losing more money than any other large securities firm, one of its traders is perhaps the highest paid on Wall Street.
Robert M. Stavis, a vice president in the company's New York-based bond arbitrage group, will be paid $30 million this year, according to Investment Dealer's Digest, a securities industry trade publication. 
 Mr. Stavis, who specializes in betting Salomon's capital on complex trades related to the arcane relationships between government bond prices and the fluctuation of interest rates, is one of a long line of such traders who have earned fabulously high payouts even when other parts of the industry were stumbling.
In 1990, Lawrence E. Hilibrand, who also worked in Salomon's bond arbitrage group, reportedly earned $23 million.
But Mr. Stavis will not be getting all his compensation in cash. Those earning multimillion-dollar paychecks at Salomon receive half their compensation in company stock, which they are given at a 15 percent discount to its trading price but cannot sell for five years.
Yesterday, Salomon Brothers shares closed at $38.125 each, up 62.5 cents, a 28 percent drop from their 52-week high of $52.75.
Salomon Brothers lost $547 million before taxes in the first three quarters of 1994. The so-called proprietary trading businesses, the area in which Mr. Stavis works, lost $21 million during the same period.
But Salomon compensates its executives on a 12-month period ended Sept. 30, which includes the last quarter of 1993, when the proprietary businesses earned $508 million.
Mr. Stavis and the half-dozen people who work with him in the small bond arbitrage group reportedly made a profit of $1 billion during that 12-month period.
"It seems high, but on the other hand it's possible," said a former Salomon executive familiar with Mr. Stavis who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Mr. Stavis was traveling yesterday and was unavailable for comment. Responding to inquiries, a Salomon spokesman said it was the firm's policy not to comment on employee compensation.
A 1984 graduate of the Wharton School in Philadelphia, Mr. Stavis, who is in his early 30's, has been working at Salomon for about 10 years. "He's sharp, young, curious -- a good guy," the former Salomon executive said.
But despite his salary, he hardly maintains a high profile at the firm. "I don't even know who the guy is," said a senior Salomon Brothers executive who also spoke on condition of anonymity. "Have you talked to anyone at the firm who knows anything about him?" he asked.
Mr. Stavis's outsized paycheck creates some strains for Salomon Brothers. Last month, the firm introduced a new compensation plan that would more directly link salaries and bonuses to overall performance.
Under the new plan, Mr. Stavis and Salomon's other proprietary traders will have their compensation averaged over several years, mixing the good with the bad.
"He may be the last guy to eat at the trough," the Salomon executive said.

HEADLINE: Black Investors Buy Franchises From Denny's

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
The Denny's restaurant chain, which for years has been accused of widespread prejudice against black customers, announced yesterday that a black-owned company in Atlanta had agreed to buy and operate as many as 47 Denny's restaurants in New York and New Jersey.
The arrangement moves Denny's close to meeting a goal the chain established with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to add 53 minority-owned restaurants by 1997. Only a few months ago, none of the more than 1,500 Denny's restaurants were owned by blacks. One black franchisee was added in June and a second one last week. 
 Under the new agreement, NDI Inc., which owns 23 Blockbuster video stores among other holdings, will buy 17 of the casual, sit-down restaurants this year and will have the right to acquire five more next year. At the same time, it can build 25 restaurants in New York and New Jersey over five years.
NDI said it sought the franchises based on economic opportunity, but it added that it was careful to look into the racist stigma that envelops Denny's. "You can always stand on the sidelines and say that a company is racist," said Richard Venegar of Atlanta, an NDI board member. "The best thing to do is get involved and become part of the solution. We looked into the allegations and we thought Denny's was making strides to alleviate their past."
The initial group of 17 restaurants are located in upstate New York and in south and central New Jersey. There are no Denny's restaurants in New York City. Denny's would not divulge the exact locations of the restaurants, most of which are along highways, because it said it had not yet notified their employees.
NDI said the restaurants included 10 in New York in places like Syracuse, Albany, Newburgh, Poughkeepsie and Fishkill, and 7 in New Jersey in towns like Toms River, Raritan and Eatontown.
The restaurants, NDI said, are primarily in racially mixed neighborhoods, though some are in predominantly black and some in predominantly white areas. They are now owned by the corporation, as are about two-thirds of the restaurants in the chain. Denny's would not divulge the purchase price, though NDI said it was paying about five times the cash flow.
In recent years, Denny's, owned by Flagstar Companies of Spartanburg, S.C., has been buffeted by allegations that its restaurants discriminated against black customers, turning it into a symbol of bigotry. While the company has maintained that the incidents were isolated and not part of any corporate policy, it has taken several expensive steps recently to try to shed its tarnished image.
In May, Denny's agreed to pay more than $54 million to settle lawsuits filed by thousands of black customers who contended that they had been refused service, been forced to wait longer than white patrons or been asked to pay in advance. The settlement was the largest under the Federal public-accommodations laws.
In July 1993, Flagstar, which also owns 600 Hardee's restaurants and more than 400 others carrying the names Quincy Family Steak House and El Pollo Loco, reached a "Fair Share" agreement with the N.A.A.C.P. to spend $1 billion in jobs and contracts for minorities over seven years.
The agreement requires the company to hire a significant number of black managers and subcontractors, as well as to name a black board member and increase black franchisees. It set as franchise targets 8 minority-owned restaurants by the end of 1994 and 53 by 1997.
Fred Rasheed, the national director of economic development for the N.A.A.C.P., said he was pleased with yesterday's development. "It's a significant step on their part to achieve the goals and commitments they made to us," he said.
So far as other areas of the Fair Share agreement, He said that the N.A.A.C.P. was happy with the increase in black managers at Flagstar, but he said "the jury is still out" on increasing minority purchasing contracts.
NDI is entirely black-owned and says it has revenues of about $25 million, which will double with the addition of the first 17 Denny's restaurants. Its majority investor is the Levmark Corporation, a New York black-owned investment company. Leon Wright, a 51-year-old entrepreneur, is Levmark's principal owner and founded NDI in late 1990.
James Holden, 37, joined NDI as its president and chief executive officer nine months ago, coming out of the cable service and investment banking fields. Charles Davis, who has been in the fast-food business, will serve as chief operating officer at NDI for the Denny's restaurants.
NDI said that the 17 restaurants that it is buying this year have average revenues of some $1.4 million, above the $1.2 million average for the entire chain. "They're not dogs," Mr. Venegar said.
He said the new Denny's restaurants that NDI might build were expected to include places on Long Island and, possibly, in New York City.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: MAN IN THE NEWS -- John Grosvenor Rowland;
Behind the Issues, a Yearning for Lost Innocence

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 8

 BODY:
In his victory speech on primary night two months ago, John G. Rowland talked about the good old days in his hometown of Waterbury, a time not so long ago when children had the run of not just their neighborhoods, but the entire city.
In his neighborhood, he recalled, he and his friends hopped a fence so often to cut across one family's yard that the father finally did something about it: he put a gate in the fence. "Now," Mr. Rowland said, "they'd probably call the police." 
 In running for governor, Mr. Rowland campaigned against a state government that he said had grown at the expense of its constituents, overtaxing and overregulating them while failing to protect their jobs from a weak economy and their homes and families from criminals.
But beneath those issues, the 37-year-old Republican was campaigning against the loss of innocence felt by so many people since his own childhood in the 1960's. Neighborliness has diminished, fear and insecurity have grown, and to Mr. Rowland, government is to blame. Or at least, government is one problem about which something can be done.
"We're told by government every day what to do and how to do it," he told his cheering supporters that night.
"Our philosophy is sound," he said. "We want less government in our lives."
John Grosvenor Rowland was born in Waterbury on May 24, 1957, the first of five children -- four sons and a daughter. Rowlands had lived in Waterbury for generations, and they were Republicans active in the city's politics. Both his father and grandfather had served as comptroller.
Growing up in the Overlook section, a hilltop neighborhood of large stately houses, Mr. Rowland attended Holy Cross High School, where he was captain of the wrestling team and senior class president. After graduating in 1975, he attended Villanova University and earned a business degree.
Mr. Rowland's main energies at Villanova, however, were invested in his fraternity, Tau Kappa Epsilon, which elected him president, and the campus chapter of College Republicans, which he also led. "Work hard, play hard," was his motto, friends say.
He also found time to manage the primary campaign of another young Republican, Robert McMahon, challenging the party machine for a legislative seat in Pennsylvania. His candidate narrowly lost.
In 1979, Mr. Rowland came home to Waterbury to work in his family's insurance agency. The city was in economic eclipse, its brass industry wiped out by the popularity of a cheaper material, plastic, and by cheaper labor in other states. In 1980, at age 23, he ran for the State House of Representatives and was swept into office in the first Reagan landslide.
In Hartford, Mr. Rowland became a member of the Republican opposition, voting against the growing state budget and proposing a plan to change Connecticut's welfare system. In 1982, he won re-election and was appointed a House minority whip.
Economic distress made Waterbury and the Naugatuck Valley a prime territory for Reagan Democrats, and in 1984 Mr. Rowland rode the second Reagan landslide to a victory over the Democratic incumbent in the Fifth Congressional District, William Ratchford.
In Washington, Mr. Rowland, at 27, combined youth and a fraternity president's good humor with patriotic conservatism. He won a seat on the Armed Services Committee and led a task force pressing the search for soldiers missing in action in Vietnam. In 1988, he won re-election to a third term with 74 percent of the vote.
Among Connecticut Republicans, power was shifting from the old elite to a more conservative middle-class base exemplified by Mr. Rowland. When Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a liberal, lost his Senate seat in 1988, he also lost his hold over the party, and Mr. Rowland emerged as its candidate for governor in 1990.
Democrats were in disarray, but Mr. Weicker entered the race as an independent and quickly took the lead. And in a statewide campaign, Mr. Rowland's youthful conservatism hurt him for the first time. His endorsement of abortion rights, a reversal of his longstanding opposition, was attacked as insincere. He appeared alternately harsh and flippant as he vowed to end the state's fiscal crisis at the expense of state employees rather than raise taxes. Even so, he lost to Mr. Weicker by only 32,736 votes.
After 1990, Mr. Rowland founded a consulting firm and worked with some of the state's largest military contractors. He also separated from his wife, Deborah, with whom he had three children, and in 1994 was divorced.
Mr. Rowland, in interviews, has maintained that he has never had a grand plan for his political career. "When I was a state rep I never thought I would go to Congress," he said. "When I was in Congress I never anticipated running for governor."
And early this year, he announced as a candidate for governor again, saying Connecticut was worse off than in 1990. Looking to Christine Todd Whitman in New Jersey and William Weld in Massachusetts as models of fiscally conservative but socially moderate Republicans, he set restoring Connecticut's economy by cutting taxes and spending -- by getting government out of the way -- as the main issue in the campaign.
"We want to get back to the basics," Mr. Rowland would say throughout the campaign. "We want to bring back things to local control."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Economic Data Help To Lift Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A successful start to a quarterly refinancing and two weaker-than-expected economic reports helped to lift bond prices yesterday for the first time in seven sessions.
Even gold prices rebounding from a 12-week low and a weaker dollar could not dampen the rally. Investors instead focused on the Treasury's $17 billion three-year note auction. 
 The auction drew solid demand at the average yield of 7.41 percent, up from 6.61 percent in the last auction on Aug. 9 and the highest since the auction of Nov. 6, 1990, when it was 7.78 percent. Traders expected the three-year auction to go without too much difficulty, since the yield is attractive to investors and the duration comfortably short enough.
The yield at the auction was a fair one, said Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston, even if the Federal Reserve raises interest rates. "It was a solid day against what is still a negative longer-term outlook," Mr. Alexy said. The price of the 30-year bond rose 14/32 , to 933/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 8.12 percent, from 8.16 percent on Monday. Prices also improved on the short-maturity bills.
Investors were also encouraged by two reports yesterday. The Johnson Redbook weekly sales report was down 4 percent and weaker than expected. Some analysts say it may have served as a reminder that the economy may not be all that robust.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said stockpiles, or inventories of unsold goods, at the nation's wholesalers rose a modest four-tenths of 1 percent in September. The Government said sales declined by three-tenths of 1 percent, the first drop in five months, against a revised 3.2 percent in the prior month, up from an original 2.7 percent.
James Hale, a fixed-income analyst for MMS International, said the auction set the tone and that the Johnson Redbook report helped to ignite a small short cover rally in the market.
Typically traders try to push prices lower ahead of an auction. But yesterday, speculators betting on lower prices were forced to reverse those bets as the yield on a three-year note surged to 7.34 percent and some traders started buying the securities. Short-covering occurs when traders sell borrowed securities in the hope of buying them back at a lower price and pocketing the difference.
The Treasury will auction $12 billion in 10-year notes today and $17 billion in new one-year bills and $12 billion in 37-day cash management bills tomorrow. Late in the day, in when-issued trading, the 10-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 8.02 percent, down a basis point from the previous day. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The market must also look ahead to a number of significant events in the next two weeks, including the release of the October report on producer prices tomorrow and a meeting of the Fed's policy-making committee on Tuesday.
"I think the elections will be overshadowed by market developments," said Mr. Hale of MMS International, noting the 10-year note auction, the reports on producer and consumer prices and the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. "It's a case of the market being oversold and due for some corrective upticks," he said.
The following are the results of yesterday's three-year Treasury note auction:

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 21.87 as Voting And Bonds Provide a Lift

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock traders, possibly looking forward to a Republican victory in midterm Congressional elections, bid up stock prices yesterday in brisk trading.
But a small rally in the bond market, the first gains in seven sessions, probably provided the biggest lift to stocks, analysts said. And the stock market rally was limited. Barely one stock rose in price for every one stock that fell on the New York Stock Exchange. There were 1,118 advancers and 1,061 decliners. 
 Moreover, the stock rally is likely to be short-lived, even if Republicans win soundly, analysts say. With the election out of the way, traders can give full vent to their anxiety about the extent to which the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates for the sixth time this year. The Fed's policy-making committee meets next Tuesday.
"Everybody will be preoccupied -- hmmm, that's too light a word -- everyone will be obsessed with what the Fed is going to do," said Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist for C.H. Dean & Associates in Dayton, Ohio.
What's more, stock and bond traders are beginning to speculate about a bigger-than-normal Fed increase of 75 basis points, or 0.75 percent, in short-term interest rates. "The Fed debate is going to be about 50 or 75, not 25 or 50," Mr. van Dijk said.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 21.87 points, to 3,830.74, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 2.59 points, to 465.65. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 5.23 points, to 767.54.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was about normal, with 289.1 million shares changing hands.
Todd Clark, a senior trader at Mabon Securities in New York, said strong demand for a $17 billion auction of three-year Treasury notes helped keep interest rates moderate. But he said much of that demand was attributed to short-selling bond traders who were forced to buy to replace borrowed notes that were bought in expectation of poor demand at the auction.
"There's nothing behind this stock market" except the rise in bonds, Mr. Clark said.
Long-term interest rates, as reflected in the bond market, fell a little. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond declined to 8.12 percent from 8.16 percent.
But the dollar fell, too. The dollar dropped in New York to 97.11 yen from 97.35 yen and to 1.5092 marks from 1.5170 marks. The fate of the dollar is significant because its value will influence whether foreign investors will want to buy assets valued in dollars, like stocks and bonds.
A few stocks were up sharply. Maxxam Inc., a Houston conglomerate, rose 2 3/4, to 37 3/4, on a Wall Street Journal report that it might sell its Pacific Lumber subsidiary. Shortly before the market closed yesterday, Maxxam said it had asked Salomon Brothers to explore "business and financing alternatives" for Pacific Lumber but that "it is not pursuing" the alternatives.
UNUM, an insurance company, established a 52-week low of 39 5/8, before closing at 40 1/4, down 6 3/8. UNUM said on Monday that it would take a $10 million fourth-quarter charge for changing certain insurance policies that helped lead to a third-quarter loss.
Cincinnati Milacron, a maker of machine tools, saw its share price fall 2 1/4, to 24, after its earnings increase failed to meet analysts' expectations. Shares of America Online, a computer service for consumers, fell 6 3/4, to 66 1/4, after new reports on Microsoft's plan for a competing on-line service. Microsoft rose 1 3/4, to 63 5/8.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.99 point, to 255.28, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.64 point, to 451.05.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrial, 19 rose, led by Walt Disney, which gained 1 1/4, to 41. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 274 rose, led by General Electric, which increased 7/8, to 49 1/8.
The most active stock, at 4.9 million shares, was Young Broadcasting, an initial public offering and owner of television stations, which closed at 19 1/2, up 1/2 from its offering price, on its first day of trading.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Generation X Makes Its Mark

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman 

 BODY:
IN this season of heightened cynicism, how will today's young and relatively innocent first-time voters come to remember their political initiation?
How in years to come will they recall the time they cast their first ballot as grown men and women, as candidates who vied for their vote were mostly casting stones? 
 "Well, I can't say it's been particularly inspiring," said David Straussman, a 20-year-old aspiring actor who voted in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. "I guess I will remember that Howard Stern pulled out of the gubernatorial race. Maybe he thought politics was too sleazy."
MR. STRAUSSMAN, who said he voted because that's the way he was raised, said the campaign seemed to drag on.
"Everybody kept shouting at everybody and spending a lot of money," he said, "but I can't really say what the issues were except that everybody talked about character and integrity, which never seem to mean too much in politics.
"I thought it was great how Cuomo used the Paul Simon song with the line, 'You can call me Al,' to slag on Pataki for being D'Amato's man. Another good part was when that guy from Staten Island attacked Karen Burstein for being a lesbian and then he got denounced by his own brother, who was gay."
Mr. Straussman said he felt more of a sense of inclusion when he bought his first Lotto ticket, for the recent $72.5 million lottery drawing, than he did in voting. "I think there were more tickets sold in the lottery than there will be votes cast, and if you win in the lottery, you win much bigger than you do as a voter, and if you lose, that hurts less in the lottery than when you vote."
THEN there were Kevin Low and Allison Briseno, 18-year-old New York University freshmen who were working on their chemistry homework at Washington Square. They had registered but not yet voted.
"I have no idea when I'm going to vote," Ms. Briseno said. "I'm not really aware of what's going on. In a way it's pointless to vote because we don't think we can make a difference.
"We're a little pessimistic about politicians because we have to trust them by their words," she explained. "They say they are going to do a lot of things, but from what we've seen they really haven't done anything."
Mr. Low nodded. "We were just thinking of going out and getting a paper so we can read up on the issues," he said, at 11:30 on Election Day morning. He said he had watched the candidates' television commercials. "It seems the candidates were just trashing each other."
At a polling place in Greenwich Village, Sarah Parr, 23, said she was delighted to be voting even though the campaign seemed bad-mannered and uninformative to her. She said she could not understand why so many of her friends were not voting. "They don't care, they don't know the issues and they don't believe that voting will have any effect on them," she said.
FARTHER uptown, at the New School for Social Research, Chris Rosso, an 18-year-old psychology major, emerged from the voting booth for the first time more relieved than proud.
"I compare this campaign to a long and difficult surgical procedure with numerous arterial breaks. Something with a lot of blood and guts, but thankfully, coming to an end once it's sutured up."
Mr. Rosso, who grew up in the Bronx, said he really studied the positions of the gubernatorial candidates, an effort that left him envying the system his mother used. "So long as the candidate is Italian, she says he can't be that bad," Mr. Rosso said.
Carl Jean, a pre-med freshman at N.Y.U. whose family migrated from Haiti, said he was proud to be voting. "It's my right as a citizen," he said. "I want to be able to say I had a role in electing someone."
But he, too, admitted dismay at what he had seen and heard: "The ads no longer tell about the candidate's good qualities. It's like a game, if I can make you look bad and you look worse than me, then I win. Year after year it gets worse. I don't know where it's leading to."
IN contrast, Adina Berrios, an economics and political science student at Columbia who had been president of her high school class, was enthusiastic. "This year I was, like, 'Yes, I get to vote,' " she said as she left the polling place at 116th Street and Riverside Drive. "I feel like I've been waiting 18 years to do this. I know that statistically my vote won't make a difference, but if everyone had that attitude no one's vote would ever matter."
She added that the most disappointing part of the experience was that there were no people handing out materials. "I really wanted to get one of those 'I Voted' stickers," she said.
And so it went on another election day. Some of the young got into habits of democracy, swimming through currents of cynicism and duplicity, jumping over obstacles like fish heading upriver to spawn.
Others just sat around.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Profits from higher-rate loans to low-income home buyers.

BYLINE: By Michael Quint 

 BODY:
FOR a profitable mortgage-lending business, consumers with low incomes and checkered credit records marred by delinquent payments are not the usual prospects. But they are the bread and butter for the United Companies Financial Corporation of Baton Rouge, La., and some other finance companies, which have found that low-income homeowners will mortgage their houses at relatively high interest rates to obtain loans unavailable from other sources.
While the traditional mortgage-lending business is slumping as interest rates rise and middle-class homeowners have stopped refinancing, some lenders in low-income areas are expanding rapidly. With the help of Wall Street and bond insurance companies, these "B" and "C" loans issued to borrowers with credit blemishes are now routinely packaged into securities that can be sold readily in the financial markets. 
 That business of making high-interest-rate loans, selling them as securities and then making more loans has transformed United from a sleepy consumer loan and annuity company into a fast-growing mortgage company. United first caught the eye of analysts in mid-1993, when it sold its original bundle of mortgage securities. Since then, it has packaged $1.1 billion in mortgages and its stock has more than tripled in value.
But it still may be a good buy. After starting at less than $10 in mid-1993, United rose in over-the-counter trading to a peak of $48 in March. Affected by the general weakness in mortgage company stocks, however, it has fallen and traded at $33.50, unchanged, on Nasdaq yesterday. That is less than six times next year's expected earnings.
"This is one cheap growth stock," said Stephen Eisman, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. He noted that demand for United's loans was little affected by rising interest rates and said the company could earn $5.75 a share next year, up 26 percent from this year.
Making small mortgage loans that average about $40,000, United encourages low-income families to take out new long-term mortgages to consolidate other debts or pay for home improvements.
Borrowers, ineligible for bank loans because of their blemished credit histories, agree to interest rates that would make the typical suburban home buyer shudder. In 1993, for instance, the national averages for 15- and 30-year fixed-rate mortgages were 6.08 percent and 7.02 percent, respectively. United charged an average of 11.8 percent for its 15- and 30-year loans.
United also charged fees (added to the loan amount) that averaged 7 percent of the loan, compared with the national average of 1.75 percent.
"United's customers are not people who worry about the difference between 8 percent and 8.25 percent," said Mr. Eisman of Oppenheimer. "They look to see if they can afford the monthly payment." A longer repayment schedule and the tax deduction for mortgage borrowing help make the payments lower than other consumer loans. The secret of United's success is an ability to keep losses to a minimum. While United's borrowers are more likely to be delinquent than typical mortgage customers, the company's losses have been held to under 1 percent of the loans by limiting the cash outlay to 65 percent or 70 percent of a home's estimated value.
Some critics, however, complain that the high-rate lending that United and other companies aim at low-income neighborhoods amounts to "reverse redlining."
"Our problem with these companies is not that they are not making loans," said Martin Leary, a consultant to the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union. "The problem is the terms and conditions of those loans."
The market for United's mortgages remains largely untapped and the company is growing rapidly. Using offices in 34 states and nearly 900 independent mortgage brokers, the company issued $657 million of loans in the first nine months of this year, up 83 percent from a year ago.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
EQUITABLE COS. (EQ,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Equitable Companies said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 25 percent, as life insurance sales continued to cushion the company from higher interest rates that hurt its brokerage business.
Equitable, the insurance and investment banking company based in New York, said net income increased to $89.3 million, or 47 cents a share, from $71.3 million, or 36 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenue fell to $1.62 billion from $1.68 billion. 
 The results exceeded Wall Street's expectations of 43 cents a share, based on a survey of nine analysts by Zacks Investment Research.
In Equitable's units, earnings at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, the brokerage firm, fell 48 percent, swept along in Wall Street's worst slump since 1990. The brokerage earned $25.5 million, down from $48.7 million in the comparable quarter a year earlier.
Richard H. Jenrette, Equitable's chairman and chief executive, said continued improvement in individual life insurance and annuities sales had offset the results of "volatile financial markets."
The most recent quarter included a gain of $29 million from the sale of investments and restructuring charges of $10.1 million. The comparable quarter in 1993 included a gain from investment sales of $6.1 million and restructuring charges of $17.2 million.
Earnings at the insurance and annuity operations rose 68 percent, to $63 million, from $37.4 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Medieval Marketing: A Rare-Book Copy For a Mere $16,425

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Act now while the supply lasts, and you can buy a rare facsimile of an 11th-century, illuminated German manuscript for only $16,425. After March 15, the price will rise to $19,205.
This is what S. Fischer Verlag of Frankfurt, the publisher, has told prospective German buyers interested in acquiring a 410-page, gilded copy of a pericope, a collection of richly illustrated Latin scriptural passages commissioned by Emperor Henry II of Germany in 1012 and now the property of the Bavarian State Library in Munich. 
 "It is not the most expensive book in the world," said Gabriele Shettle, a marketing assistant at the publishing house, who hopes that institutions and wealthy art lovers in Japan and America will also be undeterred.
Insel Verlag, another Frankfurt publisher, produced an edition of 1,000 copies of a 12th-century German illuminated manuscript, the Gospel of Henry the Lionhearted, five years ago and offered 950 of them at a subscription price of $19,868, which later went up to $22,517.
The unexpected financial strain of Germany's reunification in 1990, along with a recession that followed a surge in interest rates, kept them from selling like hot cakes, and a few are apparently still available.
But now, with German economic institutes and the Government confidently asserting that the recession is over, Fischer and its co-publisher, Verlag Muller & Schindler of Stuttgart, plan to bring out 500 copies of Henry II's gift to the Bamberg Cathedral, hand-lettered, gilded and richly bound for him on the island of Reichenau in the Lake of Constance.
The facsimiles, on pages measuring 12 1/2 by 16 3/4 inches, are hand-gilded with 23 1/2-carat gold and bound the way the original was, in green silk and silver and gold medallions.
The original, taken apart for the preparation of the facsimile and for later preservation and restoration, is on display in the National Museum in Munich.
"This has given the book a new lease on life," Mrs. Shettle said. The Bavarian State Library will receive a facsimile as part of the arrangement.
"We are selling this book through booksellers only, not directly to individual customers," she said. Bookstores could obtain it at a trade discount, though one considerably less than the 33 percent reduction prevailing for trade books in Germany, said Mrs. Shettle. "The price overseas booksellers choose to charge for it is beyond our control," she said.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Rich and Poor in Cuba as Castro's Sun Sets

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Fidel Castro's condition must be verdaderamente desesperado if public television can't find a good word for him. "Last Days of the Revolution" depicts a nation in despair. The loss of Cuba's Soviet patrons, the continuance of the United States embargo and the bunglings of its Communist masters have sent the country's economy into free fall and thousands of its people on perilous voyages to Florida.
This tour by Jose de Cordoba of The Wall Street Journal was not arranged by any Cuba-United States friendship society. It finds little light on the sunny island, where blackouts can last 16 hours. Severe fuel and fertilizer shortages mean empty shelves in food stores. Medicines, too, are in short supply. The young have little hope of good jobs, and some former Fidelistas declare their loss of faith. 
 The Government's need for hard currency has brought back some of the ills the Cuban revolution was supposed to cure: the camera finds rich foreigners living it up, with the cooperation of prostitutes, while citizens suffer. Many people scrape by with the help of money orders from relatives in the United States.
The question for Washington is whether to maintain the embargo in hopes of forcing Castro to quit or at least stop jailing dissenters, or to relax the embargo to ease life for suffering Cubans and reopen a nearby market to American businesses. United States policy, Mr. De Cordoba notes, is constrained by the fierce anti-Castro sentiment of the Cuban exile community in southern Florida.
As the film crew departs the unlucky island, the longest-lived Communist dictator gives no signs of making political reforms, much less going quietly into the political night. The one-time glamour boy of the left is last seen clinging to a bankrupt ideology in a bankrupt country.
 
'The American Experience'
'The Battle of the Bulge'
PBS, tonight at 8:30
(Channel 13 in New York)
In December 1944, the Allied troops rolling victoriously toward Germany were stopped short and hard by a quarter of a million German soldiers. The surprise counterattack sent the Allies reeling back 50 miles; 16,000 Americans, mostly infantrymen, died and tens of thousands were wounded or taken prisoner. A stunned American general is quoted on tonight's 90-minute account of that military disaster: "I've lost a division faster than any other commander in the U.S. Army."
Making grimly effective use of newsreels and Army photographs, "The Battle of the Bulge" relays the experiences of a dozen American soldiers, from a colonel to several privates, who found themselves outnumbered by a better-equipped force in freezing temperatures. Lacking air support because of overcast skies, for about a week the Americans became part of a bitter retreat. One says, "Both the enemy and the weather could kill you."
After the skies cleared, it took two arduous weeks more to regain the ground lost, that famous bulge. Recalling the ill-trained, ill-conditioned young men who were rushed to the front to help push back the Germans, an officer says, "Sergeants never even got to know their names before they were wounded or killed the next day."
In June, television was filled with commemorations of D-Day, another costly battle, which offered the consolation of beginning the liberation of Europe. The Battle of the Bulge, of course, also ended in victory, but the failure of Allied intelligence that put so many Americans at the mercy of the enemy and the elements left these survivors only with memories of pain and loss.

Kristallnacht Programming
CUNY, all day
City University's television channel devotes a full day to the anniversary of Kristallnacht, the 1938 Nazi assault on synagogues, stores, homes and people that signaled the destruction of German Jewry. Among several documentaries is "More Than Broken Glass," witnesses' descriptions of the terrible night of Nov. 9.

HEADLINE: Republican Gains and Obligations

 BODY:
"I need help, folks," said President Clinton during his final, desperate burst of campaigning. He did not get it. The result was a historic shift of power to the Republicans, in Washington and in statehouses throughout the nation.
The consequences of the weak Democratic showing were particularly painful in New York State. It lost a Governor of great stature, Mario Cuomo, in favor of an untested newcomer, George Pataki. Mr. Pataki's promise of a sweeping tax cut poses a clear threat to New York City. Its Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, responded heroically to this threat with his endorsement of Mr. Cuomo. The first test for Mr. Pataki will be to show that he is not vindictive toward the city or the Mayor, and that he is independent of his political sponsor, Senator Alfonse D'Amato. 
 The task for Mr. Clinton is more formidable. With Republicans winning control of both the Senate and the House, he must now articulate a legislative program that stands some chance of success despite a far weaker hand. There were a few bright spots -- Oliver North's defeat in Virginia among them -- but over all this was a powerful body blow to Bill Clinton and a repudiation of his party's conduct in Congress.
Mr. Clinton is not wholly to blame. His advisers fear that the losing Democrats will fault him for their individual misfortunes and that the survivors will decide they owe him nothing. But the reasons for the Democratic debacle go beyond the President and predate his tenure. When Mr. Clinton came to town the Democrats controlled both houses of Congress, and the Congressional leadership could not deliver on the agenda defined by him and endorsed by their convention and their Congressional candidates.
This failure of governance must be laid at the feet of the retiring Senate majority leader, George Mitchell; the embattled Speaker, Thomas Foley, and a leadership team that placed loyalty to them above cooperation with the White House or public demands for Congressional and campaign finance reform. Add this non-performance to the familiar witches' brew of public discontent -- the sour national attitude toward politics generally and the rebellion against incumbents in particular -- and it is easy to see why the Democrats got whacked.
There is at least one other major cause: a nagging, nationwide sense of economic discomfort. On its face this is puzzling. The economy has improved, inflation is low and the deficit is under better control than it was during the 12 Reagan-Bush years.
But to millions of people this is vague and theoretical stuff. They do not feel better in their pocketbooks. Meanwhile, the party that promised welfare reform produced none; the party that made a huge bet on health-care reform used a secret laboratory to create a Frankenstein's monster that defied legislative redesign. The fact that there was a crime bill, a North American Free Trade Agreement and some smaller trophies did not, in the end, count for much with the public.
In a CBS News/New York Times Poll a couple of weeks ago, only 30 percent said that "government should do more to solve national problems" while 63 percent said government was doing "too many things better left to businesses and individuals." That is one big problem for a President who still sees himself as an activist. His other big problem is all those feisty Republicans who will be parachuting into Washington come January.
These Republicans do not much believe in government and they are not likely to be helpful. Many of them ran and won on Newt Gingrich's seductive but simplistic "Contract With America." Some of them ran on demagogic symbols -- the death penalty, immigrant-bashing.
Whatever they ran on, all of them ran against Bill Clinton. This is not a happy prospect for a man who campaigned in 1992 on one theme: change. But as Senator Phil Gramm suggested, the new force in Congress cannot expect to sell two-party gridlock as the solution to the one-party version that the voters rejected so powerfully yesterday. "Now the burden is on Republicans," Senator Gramm observed. "Can we give them a coherent program?"

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Let's Not Rush Into World Trade Agreement

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In early December the House and Senate return to vote on implementing the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, which was negotiated with more than 100 other countries over a period of several years. Sadly, press coverage has been thin and not very substantial. 
 In the last two and a half years, I've taught the Dunkel draft/Uruguay Round text three times in my international trade and finance classes. I've become well acquainted with grave GATT shortcomings.
Unfortunately, most public debate focuses on shallow labels (like free trade versus protection) rather than substance. Neglected are:
* The World Trade Organization's unbalanced voting regime (like the United Nations General Assembly).
* The great weakening of United States trade law remedies.
* Inadequate discipline over foreign subsidies in agriculture, manufacturing and services.
* Emasculation of United States safeguard relief.
* Weak and dubious language supposedly giving the United States protection for service and intellectual property interests abroad.
* A dispute settlement regime that forces binding arbitration on United States interests in agriculture, the environment, manufacturing, services and intellectual property.
* Overall entrenchment of unequal trade openness that hurts United States working people, causing a net loss of American jobs.
Why did United States trade negotiators accept such a deal? They promised in the spring of 1993 to sign a draft agreement on Dec. 15, 1993, no matter what. Not surprisingly, the United States lost out.
The Administration felt its prestige was on the line. The 1994 world trade agreement then became a symbol of President Clinton's accomplishments, and a political football, with hardly any attention to its 450 pages of highly technical language. Few commentators show a grasp of these details.
But there is some good news in all this. Because of partisan wrangling and sneaky inserts in the implementation bills, Congress wisely put the vote on GATT off until after the elections.
Now Congress should delay any implementation until full and detailed hearings are held in the next Congress in 1995. The fall election pressure over political symbols is over, and Congress has a duty to the public to give the trade agreement a careful, probing examination.
Finally, we should realize that a more open (though unequal and unbalanced) global economy and trade regime is well established and secure. The United States economy is the most open in the world. That's part of the problem! The United States needs a more level playing field in global trade. GATT 1994 fails this test. It only entrenches unequal trade openness and makes it much harder to open foreign markets.
That's why Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, has achieved virtually nothing in trade negotiations with Japan. GATT 1994, signed in Marrakesh, Morocco, in April, greatly erodes our leverage and ability to restrict American imports in response to foreign subsidies and trade practices.
These remarks are not intended to be partisan. Democrats, moderates and Republicans and, most important, the bulk of the American people will benefit greatly if we slow down, re-examine and substantially improve the GATT deal.
There's no rush. The Uruguay Round has already taken 12 years from early gestation efforts in 1982. But let's get it right, and not gravely damage United States interests in agriculture, the environment, manufacturing, services and overall employment.
 
WILLIAM A. LOVETT
Professor of Law and Economics
Tulane Law School
New Orleans, Nov. 3, 1994

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: STATE BT STATE;
Northeast

 BODY:

CONNECTICUT
Joseph I. Lieberman, one of only a half-dozen Senate Democrats with seemingly secure seats, trounced his challenger, Gerald Labriola, a retired pediatrician and former State Senator who made little headway against the popular incumbent. Mr. Labriola had promised to serve only one term if he won.
With the retirement of Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the race for governor was a muddled four-way contest won by John G. Rowland, a former Republican Representative. His opponents were William E. Curry Jr., a Democrat who is the state comptroller; Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark of Mr. Weicker's A Connecticut Party, and an anti-tax crusader, Tom Scott, running as the long-shot Independence Party candidate. Mr. Rowland overcame a late setback when it was disclosed that he had tried to suppress a police report about a marital dispute. 
In a notable House race, Representative Gary Franks, who in 1990, became the first black Republican with voting status in the House since 1935, held on to defeat James H. Maloney, a State Senator.
 
SENATE, 97% reporting
Labriola, 321,890, 31%
Lieberman, 701,304, 67%
 
GOVERNOR, 96% reporting
Curry, 348,724, 32%
Groark, 204,522, 19%
Rowland, 388,866, 36%
Scott, 120,524, 12%
 
DELAWARE
William V. Roth Jr., a genial Reagan-era tax-cutter seeking a fifth Senate term, turned back a challenge from Charles M. Oberly 3d, the state's 47-year-old Democratic Attorney General.
Mr. Oberly, who is a proven statewide vote-getter for the Democrats, faded in the polls despite strong anti-crime credentials and the fact that Mr. Roth, 73, who campaigns with a trademark St. Bernard, has been precluded from running on the Republican platform for change. Mr. Roth was seen as vulnerable enough that Representative Michael N. Castle, a former Governor, considered a challenge in the primary.
Mr. Castle was likely to retain the state's sole House seat by dispatching Carol Ann DeSantis, a hospital executive.
 
Senate, 93% reporting
Oberly, 78,928, 42%
Roth, 104,659, 56%
 
DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
Redemption was the campaign theme of former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., who struggled back from a 1990 drug conviction and six-month jail term. Carol Schwartz, a Republican who also lost to Mr. Barry in 1986, conceded shortly before midnight after staying even in early ballot returns.
Ms. Schwartz blamed Mr. Barry for the city's chronic budget deficits, dilapidated public schools and steady loss of jobs and residents to the suburbs. She advocated the sale of city land and tough tax collection. Mr. Barry stressed his 30 years of experience in public life, calling for a spirit of healing to address the city's crime and drug problems.
 
MAYOR, 57% reporting
Barry, 58,391, 53%
Schwartz, 50,426, 46%
 
MAINE
It was supposed to be a relatively calm political year in this state, but Senator George J. Mitchell's plan to retire set off a ripple effect from the state's highest office to the lowest.
Both United States Representatives -- Thomas H. Andrews, a Democrat, and Olympia J. Snowe, a Republican -- gave up their House seats to run for Mr. Mitchell's seat. Ms. Snowe won easily.
Early on, Mr. Andrews seemed well positioned to keep the Senate seat in Democratic hands. Some of Mr. Mitchell's popularity seemed to rub off on the 41-year-old liberal Congressman, who was elected twice to the House with large majorities. And President Clinton is highly regarded here.
The fiercely independent character of the state seems to have been a factor.
Ms. Snowe's moderate Republican views attracted many supporters of Ross Perot, who won 30 percent of the vote in the 1992 Presidential election.
Mr. Andrews also had a hard time selling his liberal views to Republicans.
Before Mr. Mitchell's announcement, most attention was on the governor's race, which was a tight one between Joseph Brennan, a Democrat who was Governor from 1979 to 1987, and Angus King, a businessman who is running as an independent. But Mr. Brennan could be hurt by the independent streak of voters. Susan M. Collins, a Republican, was not expected to pose a challenge.
 
SENATE, 24% reporting
Andrews, 37,339, 37%
Snowe, 58,959, 59%
 
MARYLAND
For weeks it looked as if Parris N. Glendening, a three-term Prince George's County executive, would easily succeed his fellow Democrat, Gov. William Donald Schaefer, who was barred by law from a third term. That changed after Ellen R. Sauerbrey, the Republican leader of the Maryland House, pulled a stunning upset in a primary against Representative Helen Delich Bentley.
Patterning her campaign after that of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, Ms. Sauerbrey pledged to cut income taxes 25 percent. Last night, it appeared the race might be decided by absentee ballots.
With one of the lower profiles in the Senate, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Democratic incumbent, looked vulnerable to some political experts early in the campaign. But he easily fended off a challenge from William E. Brock 3d, a former Republican Senator from Tennessee and a former head of the Republican National Committee.
Two factors combined to help Mr. Sarbanes retain the seat that he first won in 1976. Democrats hold a 2-to-1 advantage in voter registration, and Mr. Sarbanes attacked Mr. Brock as a carpetbagger.

 Brock, 538,351, 41%
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Glendening, 683,995, 50%
 Sauerbrey, 677,804, 50%
 
MASSACHUSETTS
In the toughest election of his 32-year political career, Senator Edward M. Kennedy defeated his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, after a hard-fought final month of campaigning.
Mr. Romney, a venture capitalist, had been even with Senator Kennedy in polls in September, but in the campaign's final weeks, Mr. Romney's performances in two debates failed to generate heat. He tried to regain the initiative with half-hour commercials in the style of Ross Perot.
Mr. Romney, the son of former Gov. George Romney of Michigan, was credited with a polished campaign style in this, his first, race. His negative advertisements painted Senator Kennedy as obsolete and tired, including one commercial that showed the Senator having difficulty sitting. But Mr. Romney was largely successful only in casting himself as an alternative to his veteran opponent, whose checkered personal life hurt his popularity.
Mr. Kennedy, who has won six times with at least 55 percent of the vote, was an uncomfortable campaigner. But he put up a strong defense in the last month, characterizing Mr. Romney as a businessman who "puts profits over people." .
In the race for the governorship, William F. Weld, a Republican, handily won re-election against State Representative Mark R. Roosevelt.

 Weld, 488,088, 71%
 
NEW HAMPSHIRE
Ever since Representative Dick Swett, a Democrat, broke the 76-year Republican hold on the state's Second District House seat in 1990, he has been a target for overthrow.
And in a race dominated by hard-hitting advertising, Mr. Swett's Republican challenger, former State Senator Charles F. Bass, appeared likely to reclaim the seat for his party. Mr. Bass criticized his opponent's ties to President Clinton and relied on his mainstream record to court swing voters.
This year's curse of incumbency notwithstanding, other officeholders appeared safe. Gov. Steve Merrill, a Republican, defeated Wayne D. King, a State Senator, by a wide margin. And a two-term Republican Representative, Bill Zeliff, cruised to victory over his challenger, Bill Verge.
 
 GOVERNOR, 78% reporting
 King, 58,654, 25%
 Merrill, 161,439, 70%
 
NEW JERSEY
With 89 percent of the votes counted, Chuck Haytaian, the Republican State Assembly Speaker, did better than expected against Senator Frank R. Lautenberg. But the incumbent still won a third term from New Jersey's notoriously volatile electorate.
Last spring, Republicans eyeing control of the Senate had cited Mr. Lautenberg's seat as vulnerable. But Mr. Haytaian was at a disadvantage, having raised $3 million less than the incumbent's $7.4 million, in a state where television advertisements must be bought in both the costly New York and Philadelphia markets.
Mr. Haytaian, a strict conservative, campaigned on a flat Federal income tax and sought to ride the coattails of the popular Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, who appeared with him often on the stump. Mr. Lautenberg was also endorsed by Ross Perot.
In the House races, Republicans were expected to fill two open seats. In one, Frank A. Lobiondo, a State Assemblyman, should succeed Representative William J. Hughes, a Democrat who is retiring after 10 terms.
The Republicans may gain another seat in the state's closest Congressional race, in which Herb Klein, a freshman Representative is running against William Martini, a lawyer and former Assistant United States Attorney.
 
Senate, 89% reporting
Haytaian, 833,666, 47%
Lautenberg, 896,795, 51%
 
NEW YORK
New York voters declared it was gold-watch time for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, one of the nation's most unabashed liberals. Another well-known liberal, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, was on the ballot this year, but most people in the country may not have even been aware Senator Moynihan was up for re-election because he never faced any real threat from the Republican, Bernadette Castro, the convertible sofa heiress.
Not so Governor Cuomo, whose chances to win a fourth term always seemed at risk during the campaign, and the reasons had little to do with his Republican opponent, George F. Pataki, a state legislator and former Mayor of Peekskill. Mr. Cuomo's vulnerabilities were a combination of the same troubles that have bedeviled other incumbents, especially Democrats, this year as well as a kind of voter fatigue with the intense Governor himself.
In the final weeks, Mr. Cuomo fought back, one of his principal weapons being the endorsement of New York's Republican Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Guiliani said he crossed party lines because Mr. Cuomo would help New York while Mr. Pataki's policies would make it harder to run the city. But the Mayor now has to live with his decision as Mr. Pataki will occupy the Governor's mansion in Albany.
 
SENATE, 95% reporting

 GOVERNOR, 93% reporting

PENNSYLVANIA
Senator Harris Wofford, a Democrat who won his seat in a special election three years ago largely on a platform of overhauling the nation's health care system, was in a tight race with Representative Rick Santorum. Less than two weeks ago, Mr. Wofford had been trailing. But he fought back with television commercials accusing Mr. Santorum of favoring a delay in Social Security benefits until recipients reached the age of 70.
That was not the only hotly contested race in Pennsylvania. The decision by the popular Governor, Robert P. Casey, to step down generated a heated race between Lieut. Gov. Mark S. Singel, a Democrat, Representative Tom Ridge, a Republican, and Peg Luksik, an abortion opponent who ran as an independent. Mr. Ridge won that race. Mr. Singel had problems: with reports that as head of the State Board of Pardons, he recommended parole for a prisoner who is now charged with rape and murder in New York City.

RHODE ISLAND
Lincoln C. Almond, a Republican and former United States Attorney, was in a dead heat with State Representative Myrth York in the race for governor, according to early results. It is a race that will be remembered for primaries in which the Democratic incumbent was denied renomination by his party and the Republican front-runner lost by a wide margin.
Ms. York got twice as many votes in the September primary as Gov. Bruce Sundlun, whose administration was plagued by ethical and fiscal problems. But despite the state's Democratic tilt and early polls indicating a tight race, Ms. York fell behind Mr. Almond, a no-nonsense, take-charge campaigner who did well with voters anxious about crime and the economy.
Senator John H. Chafee, a moderate Republican seeking his fourth term, defeated State Representative Linda J. Kushner.
But a Democrat, Patrick J. Kennedy, was favored for the seat vacated by Ronald K. Machtley, who lost the Republican nomination for governor to Mr. Almond in the primaries. Mr. Kennedy, the 27-year-old son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, campaigned as the candidate best suited to bring Federal programs and money to the state.

VERMONT
Although Vermont is noted for upsets in non-Presidential years, Senator James M. Jeffords, an independent-minded and well-financed Republican, won a second term despite a late spurt by Jan Backus, a Democratic State Senator, who ran as an ordinary "mom". An endorsement on Friday from the state's biggest paper, The Burlington Free-Press, did not help Ms. Backus much.
But the Democrats did hold onto the governorship, as the popular incumbent, Dr. Howar Dean, won a second term. Dr. Dean, a physician, was ineffectively challenged by two opponents who split the meager anti-Dean vote.
Probably the most interesting race was for Vermont's lone House seat held by Bernard Sanders, the former Burlington Mayor who runs as an independent but calls himself a socialist. He put himself at risk by angering gun control opponents with his vote for the crime bill and its ban on assault weapons. In 1990, Mr. Sanders won his seat when gun owners aggressively opposed his Republican opponent. This time, the Republicans have put up John Carroll, majority leader of the Vermont Senate. No Democrat is on the ballot.
 
WEST VIRGINIA
Anti-incumbent sentiment has been weak in West Virginia, one state where voters still appreciate Federal spending. Robert C. Byrd, the six-term Democratic Senator, is known in his home state as a coal field orphan who put himself through law school at night and has never forgotten his roots. As chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee since 1989, he has directed at least $1.5 billion to his home state, much of it for roads to connect the hills and hollows of this Appalachian state.
West Virginia voters responded today by choosing him over Stan Klos, a wealthy Republican real estate developer who did not campaign actively.
 
SENATE, 77% reporting
Byrd, 213,834, 70%
Klos, 92,329, 30%

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: STATE BT STATE;
Midwest

 BODY:

ILLINOIS
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the 18-term Chicago Democrat who stepped down as the head of the Ways and Means Committee after his indictment earlier this year on corruption charges, lost to a relative unknown, Michael P. Flanagan. Mr. Rostenkowski had run a low-profile campaign and, sensing his vulnerability, the national Republican Party last week sent his campaign more than $50,000 for an advertising blitz.
Gov. Jim Edgar, a Republican in his first term, trounced the state's comptroller, Dawn Clark Netsch, whose campaign never got off the ground after she staged an upset victory in the primary last spring. 
 One other House contest offered a strong chance for changing from Democrat to Republican hands. Polls showed the seat in Joliet held by Representative George E. Sanmeister, a Democrat who is retiring, as likely to be won by State Representative Gerald C. Weller, a Republican.
In Peoria, the seat opening up with the retirement of Robert H. Michel, the House minority leader, was captured by his former chief of staff, Ray LaHood, who was facing a contest against Mr. Michel's old opponent, G. Douglas Stephens.

INDIANA
Senator Richard G. Lugar swept to victory with more than twice as many votes as his Democratic opponent, former Representative Jim Jontz. Mr. Jontz tried to prod anti-incumbent sentiment with advertisements in which he visited Indiana towns with names like Moscow, Peru and Lebanon looking for the foreign aid that Senator Lugar voted for in 18 years in office, but he could not dent the Senator's popularity.
David McIntosh, a Republican who was once on Dan Quayle's staff, won Muncie's Second District, opened by the retirement of Representative Phil Sharp, a Democrat.In the Fifth DistrictRepresentative Steve Buyer, a freshman Republican, fended off a challenge from John D. Beatty.

IOWA
Gov. Terry E. Branstad, a Republican, was considered vulnerable in his unprecedented bid for a fourth term, having only narrowly survived a bruising primary challenge from Representative Fred Grandy, a more moderate Republican. Mr. Grandy, who was an actor on the "Love Boat" television series, refused to endorse Gov. Branstad, and Mr. Grandy's wife was an outspoken supporter of the Governor's opponent, Attorney General Bonnie Campbell.
The election left Iowa with an all-Republican Congressional delegation. The only Democratic House incumbent, Neal Smith, lost his seat to Greg Ganske. Representative Jim Ross Lighfoot, Jime Leach and Jim Nussle all fended off Democratic challengers. An Mr. Grandy's district went to the Republican candidate, Tom Latham, whose opponent was Sheila McGuire.
 
GOVERNOR, 89% reporting
Branstad, 514,128, 57%
Campbell, 377,009, 42%
 
KANSAS
With no Senate seats at stake, the main interest in this Republican state is the gamble by Jim Slattery, a six-term Democrat who is the only member of his party this year to give up a House seat to run for governor. But Mr. Slattery has failed to find significant issues to distinguish himself from his friend and Republican opponent, Bill Graves, the Kansas Secretary of State for eight years. Mr. Slattery trailed in his effort to hold one of the Democrats' most vulnerable governorships.
The was open because Joan Finney, a 41-year veteran of Kansas politics who is an advocate of term limits, was retiring.
The hottest House race was the one to succeed Mr. Slattery in his Topeka-based district. This, too, tilted Republican, although the party's candidate, Sam Brownback, a former state agriculture secretary, failed to pull away decisively from former Gov. John Carlin, whose extensive political baggage included higher taxes.
 
GOVERNOR, 58% reporting
Graves, 309,613, 63%
Slattery, 185,739, 37%
 
MICHIGAN
Michigan was one state that switched from the Democratic to the Republican column when Spencer Abraham, the former state Republican chairman and aide to Dan Quayle, defeated Representative Bob Carr in the Senate race for the seat that had been held by retiring Senator Donald W. Riegle.
Mr. Carr had been counting heavily on support from organized labor, but it was insufficient because Mr. Abraham was able to ride on the coattails of John Engler, the Republican Governor.
Earlier this year, Mr. Engler won a huge victory in a referendum to reduce property taxes and change the way public education was financed. With the economy on the rebound, Mr. Engler was able to defeat handily former Representative Howard Wolpe, whose campaign was less than adept.
Democrats managed to fend off serious challenges for most Congressional seats they had held.
 
SENATE, 64% reporting
 Abraham, 994,901, 52%
 Carr, 808,153, 42%
 GOVERNOR, 63% reporting
 Engler, 1,181,699, 62%
 Wolpe, 730,606, 38%
 
MINNESOTA
In a year when Democrats were struggling to hold onto the Senate, Ann Wynia was the only one of 13 Democrats running for Republican-held seats who seemed to have a real chance of winning.
But she lost to her Republican rival, Representative Rod Grams. The choice could not have been clearer.
Ms. Wynia, the 51-year-old former majority leader in the State House, has stressed the need for a greater government role in issues involving women and children.
But Mr. Grams, a 46-year-old House freshman with a voting record as conservative as any in the House, campaigned on a platform calling for a smaller Government that is tougher on crime.
The importance of the race was underscored by the fact that both President Clinton and Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, made campaign stops in the state.
Experts said the outcome of the race could depend on whether religious conservatives and other conservative Republicans -- the voters Mr. Grams is counting on -- turn out to vote in large numbers.
Gov. Arne Carlson, a Republican moderate, won in a landslide over State Senator John Marty, who has changed campaign managers three times.
 
SENATE, 68% reporting
 Grams, 595,629, 48%
 Wynia, 562,403, 45%
 GOVERNOR, 68% reporting
 Carlson, 773,334, 64%
 Marty, 408,966, 34%
 
MISSOURI
Representative Alan Wheat, the first black to be nominated for statewide office in Missouri, lost his bid for a United States Senate seat to John Ashcroft, a Republican and former Governor. The seat was held by John C. Danforth, who is retiring.
Mr. Wheat, a six-term Democratic Congressman, was hampered by the battering he took in the primary, in which he depleted his campaign treasury and was attacked for his use of Congressional perks and his 86 overdrafts at the House bank.
Mr. Ashcroft had virtually no opposition in the Republican primary.
A Republican also posed a strong challenge to the incumbent Democrat in the Congressional district that includes Columbia. Representative Harold L. Volkmer, who had won his primary with 57 percent of the vote against five challengers, was in a tight race with Kenny Hulshof, a Republican state prosecutor who had attacked Mr. Volkmer as a liberal spender and a supporter of big government.
The only serious challenge to a Republican-held Congressional seat was in southwestern Missouri, where Representative Mel Hancock was criticized as too conservative. The Democratic nominee, James R. Fossard, a lawyer from Springfield, ran on a moderate-to-conservative platform, favoring abortion rights while backing capital punishment.
 
SENATE, 37% reporting
Ashcroft, 359,447, 59%
Wheat, 225,899, 37%
 
NEBRASKA
Senator Bob Kerrey's well-publicized attacks on President Clinton's leadership helped him shield himself from the Republican challenger, Jan Stoney, a former top executive at US West.
The Senate campaign overshadowed the race of Gov. Ben Nelson, a 53-year-old Democrat, who trounced Gene Spence, 60-year-old director of Omaha Public Power.
Not all Democrats were getting off lightly. Representative Peter Hoagland, 52, faced an attack by a 31-year-old Republican insurance executive, Jon Christensen.
Nebraskans appeared likely to approve a term-limit initiative.
 
 SENATE, 54% reporting
 Kerrey, 164,686, 54%
 Stoney, 138,476, 46%
 GOVERNOR, 54% reporting
 Nelson, 222,963, 74%
 Spence, 79,692, 26%
 
NORTH DAKOTA
Senator Kent Conrad, a freshman Democrat, defeated Ben J. Clayburgh, an orthopedic surgeon. Coming from a state that handed three electoral votes to President Bush, Mr. Conrad was one of the Democrats in the West who campaigned by distancing himself from Mr. Clinton. But his advertisements were unusual for the pains they took to keep away from the White House. They noted that Mr. Conrad had voted with Bob Dole, the Republican Senate leader, more than half the time.
In the contest for the state's sole House seat, the Democratic incumbent, Earl Pomeroy, was the favorite against State Representative Gary Porter.
 
OHIO
Two wealthy men tried to present themselves as ordinary citizens as they pursued a Senate seat in this heavily blue-collar state. Joel Hyatt, the Democratic son-in-law of Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, a Democrat whose retirement left the seat up for grabs, made a fortune from his legal services company and had appeared in its television advertisements for years. But low public esteem for lawyers caught up with him in the campaign, as many people told pollsters that they personally disliked him.
Voters chose instead the Republican candidate, Lieut. Gov. Mike DeWine, the scion of a family that made its money in seeds. He wore plaid shirts and took a down-home tone in building solid support in heavily Republican rural areas.
Joseph Slovenec, an anti-abortion campaigner, made a strong showing for a candidate from outside the two major parties.
Gov. George V. Voinovich, a Republican and former Mayor of Cleveland, easily won re-election over Robert Burch, a Democratic State Senator.
 
 SENATE, 70% reporting
 DeWine, 1,277,339, 54%
 Hyatt, 915,865, 38%
 Slovenec, 187,402, 8%
 GOVERNOR, 62% reporting
 Burch, 527,421, 27%
 Voinovich, 1,384,791, 70%
 
SOUTH DAKOTA
It was something of an upset when William Janklow defeated Gov. Walter D. Miller in the Republican primary. But Mr. Janklow was not an unknown. He had been Governor for two terms, but state law bars a third consecutive term.
Mr. Janklow defeated his Democratic opponent, Jim Beddow, the former president of Dakota Wesleyan University, who hoped voters would want a a fresh face.
But Mr. Janklow had made an issue of two ballot initiatives -- one to cut property taxes and the other on the fate of the state's video lottery -- arguing that an experienced leader could handle the fiscal crisis that could result from their passage.
Representative Tim Johnson, a Democrat, won a fifth term.
 
 GOVERNOR, 78% reporting
 Janklow, 142,644, 55%
 Beddow, 106,479, 41%
 
WISCONSIN
The nation's anti-incumbency epidemic spared Wisconsin. Senator Herb Kohl, a centrist Democrat, kept his seat, shrugging off a challenge from Robert T. Welch, a conservative Republican. Senator Kohl, who owns the Milwaukee Bucks baseball team and many commercial properties, spent millions of dollars of his own money to win the seat in 1988, and millions more this time around.
And Gov. Tommy G. Thompson won a third term, pulling more than twice as many votes as his Democratic opponent, State Senator, Charles J. Chvala. Gov. Thompson has remained a voter favorite in part because of his tough stance on welfare -- the state's welfare rolls have shrunk by 23 percent during his tenure -- and Mr. Chvala aroused little voter interest with his
charge that Gov. Thompson was mean-spirited, pointing out that child poverty rose as the welfare rolls shrank.
 
SENATE, 85% reporting
Kohl, 789,204, 59%
Welch, 531,256, 40%
GOVERNOR, 84% reporting
Chvala, 417,582, 32%
Thompson, 881,724, 67%
