HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: STATE BT STATE;
West

 BODY:

ALASKA
A Democrat, Tony Knowles, went into Election Day with a big lead in the polls in his bid for re-election as Governor despite an acerbic campaign run by his Republican opponent, Jim Campbell, a retired Anchorage businessman.
One advertisement, which the Campbell campaign ran briefly in October, created a flurry of concern among Mr. Knowles's supporters, who complained that it wrongly accused him of womanizing. 
 In the commercial, a male radio announcer says, "President Clinton is tall, has a shy smile, good hair," then adds: "Some women tell me he's really good-looking. And then I noticed Tony Knowles -- tall, shy smile, good hair -- same thing with the women."
Lieut. Gov. Jack Coghill was running as the Alaska Party Choice in the race.
The incumbent for Alaska's only House seat, Don Young, a Republican, was also favored to win re-election. Mr. Young narrowly won in 1990 and 1992.
For the fourth time in two decades, a measure was on the ballot to move the state capital from Juneau, a waterfront city of 26,000 people, to Wasilla, a frontier-like town of 4,000 people. The effort has failed in the past because of concern about the cost of moving.
 
ARIZONA
Democrats were hoping their designs on Arizona, long a conservative bastion, would be realized in the strong race for governor mounted by Eddie Basha, a supermarket magnate, against the Republican incumbent, J. Fife Symington.
But in a close race Mr. Basha lost to Governor Symington, who used his opponent's support for homosexual marriages to undercut his opponent's popularity among conservative Democrats.
In a pivotal race for the Senate seat held by Dennis DeConcini, a Democrat who is retiring, Republicans were poised to gain a seat. In early returns, Representative Sam Coppersmith, a freshman Democrat, trailed Representative John Kyl, who had a solid head start when he breezed through the Republican primary with no opposition. Mr. Coopersmith trailed throughout the campaign.
Republicans also picking up three House seats, including the one Mr. Coppersmith vacated and one in the Sixth District, where Representative Karan English, a Democrat, struggled against a challenge by J. D. Hayworth, a first-time candidate who is a former sportscaster.
 
SENATE, 63% reporting
Coopersmith, 276,699, 39%
Grainger, 48,765, 7%
Kyl, 379,662, 54%
GOVERNOR, 62% reporting
Basha, 310,011, 44%
Symington, 374,006, 53%
 
CALIFORNIA
The Senate race in California captured the nasty air of the 1994 campaign. By Election Day, Senator Dianne Feinstein, the Democrat, was calling her opponent a carpetbagger and a hypocrite, and the Republican, Representative Michael Huffington, was calling her a liar and a disgrace to the state.
A transplanted Texan with an oil fortune, Mr. Huffington broke all records for spending in a Senate race, dipping into his own pocket for $28 million, two times Ms. Feinstein's war chest, for what was largely a battle of the airwaves.
Mr. Huffington's surging campaign sputtered badly in the last two weeks, after disclosures that he and his wife, Arianna, had hired an illegal alien. Reports last week said that Ms. Feinstein had a similar problem, but she said that the immigrant, a Guatemalan, had documents that showed that she was in the United States legally, although after a bit of confusion the Immigration and Naturalization Service said her status was illegal. By early this morning, the race was too close to call.
Almost overshadowed by the invective, Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, rebounded from the lowest approval ratings in state history to win a second term over Kathleen Brown, daughter of a former governor, Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, and sister of another, Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr. Once more than 20 points behind, Mr. Wilson, 61, attacked illegal immigration and accused Ms. Brown, 49, of being soft on crime.
The national Republican tsunami also carried the entertainer Sonny Bono into a Congressional seat.
Long the wellspring of controversial ballot measures, California is at it again this year with Proposition 187, which would bar illegal aliens from welfare, education and nonemergency health services.
Californians were apparently dismissing challenges to the measure, and seemed poised to approve it.
Californians also appeared to be voting down two initiatives: one to create a single-payer health care system, and another, heavily backed by the tobacco industry, to replace local anti-smoking laws with statewide standards that would in some cases be looser.
 
 GOVERNOR, 30% reporting
 Brown, 871,134, 37%
 Wilson, 1,372,715, 58%
 La Riva, ind,19,049, 1%
 McCready, ,ind,38,385, 2%
 Rider, ,ind,41,675, 2%
 
COLORADO
Gov. Roy Romer won a third term despite deep voter displeasure with incumbent Democrats in general and Mr. Romer's close ties to President Clinton, who is unpopular in Colorado.
Mr. Romer's victory may have owed less to the state's economic growth than to the self-destruction of his challenger, Bruce Benson, a millionaire oilman and a former state Republican chairman. What had been a dead heat until last month turned against Mr. Benson after a series of embarrassing disclosures about him. Voters also disdained his decision to cancel eight debates with Mr. Romer, who Mr. Benson said was a better debater.
No upsets were expected in Congressional races.
Also on the ballot was an initiative to raise tobacco taxes to increase health care to the poor. Another initiative would give towns and cities more power to outlaw sexually explicit books, magazines and videos.
 
 GOVERNOR, 8% reporting
 Benson, 54,727, 38%
 Romer, 82,163, 57%
 
HAWAII
For much of the year, Patricia F. Saiki, a former Republican Representative, seemed poised to become the state's first female governor and its first Republican leader since 1959. A decline in tourism as well as rising living costs and welfare rolls threatened the Democrats' grip on the office.
But Lieut. Gov. Ben Cayetano, a Democrat, recently gained momentum and was expected to succeed Gov. John Waihee 3d, who could not run for a third consecutive term.
The challenge of a popular independent, Frank Fasi, a former mayor of Honolulu, siphoned votes from both parties.
Senator Daniel K. Akaka, the incumbent Democrat, seemed headed toward an easy victory.
Despite an aggressive challenge by Orson Swindle, a Republican who advised Ross Perot in 1992, Representative Neil Abercrombie, the two-term incumbent, had a comfortable lead with 60 percent of the votes counted.
 
SENATE, 67% reporting
Akaka, 171,933, 73%
Hustace, 55,255, 23%
GOVERNOR, 69% reporting
Cayetano, 94,534, 39%
Fasi, 70,952, 29%
Saiki, 71,978, 29%
 
IDAHO
With the retirement of Gov. Cecil D. Andrus, a Democrat, voters saw a tight race between Attorney General Larry EchoHawk, a Democrat who sought to become the first Indian governor in the nation, and his Republican challenger, former Lieut. Gov. Phil Batt.
Mr. Batt, who hoped to become the state's first Republican governor in 29 years, tried to paint Mr. EchoHawk as a clone of President Clinton.
Larry LaRocco, a two-term Democratic Representative, fell far behind in his bid to keep his Boise seat from a Republican energy consultant, Helen Chenoweth. Mr. LaRocco's campaign stumbled in October when it was revealed that his former brokerage firm had paid his female assistant $40,000 to settle a sexual discrimination lawsuit. In his previous race, Mr. LaRocco said rumors of the relationship were a lie, but he was forced to backpedal and acknowledge it this time around.
 
 GOVERNOR, 62% reporting
 Batt, 121,907, 52%
 Echohawk, 104,499, 45%
 
MONTANA
Senator Conrad Burns was on his way toward defying expectations in his bid to become the first Republican re-elected to the Senate from solidly Democratic Montana.
Democrats had hoped that the Senator's poor ratings from voters and his spotty legislative record made his seat ripe for the picking. But his opponent, Jack Mudd, a lawyer and first-time candidate, was unable to mount a strong campaign.
A recent poll showed that Mr. Burns's support grew, from 44 percent at the start of the campaign to 51 percent at the end, despite a highly publicized remark in which he used a racial epithet. Mr. Mudd's support remained about 37 percent throughout the campaign.
In a hotly contested House race Pat Williams, an eight-term Democratic Representative, expected to fend off a challenge by Cy Jamison, former director of the Bureau of Land Management.
Voters appeared quite unlikely to support a measure requiring voter approval for tax increases.
 
SENATE, 56% reporting
Burns, 111,859, 61%
Mudd, 71,614, 39%
 
NEVADA
Nevada, at least, was a welcome place for the Democrats this year. Gov. Bob Miller was the person principally responsible for delivering Nevada to the Democratic column for Bill Clinton in 1992, and his Republican opponent this year, Assemblyman Jim Gibbons, worked tirelessly to remind voters of it, but to no avail.
Senator Richard H. Bryan, an incumbent Democrat was also re-elected.
Nevada's ballot was also bristling with propositions for the voters, including two that would add the state to the growing list of those trying to impose term limits on officeholders. But another ballot referendum would require a two-thirds vote of the Legislature to raise taxes.
 
 SENATE, 54% reporting
 Bryan, 73,067, 53%
 Furman, 54,3641, 39%
 GOVERNOR, 55% reporting
 Miller, 128,821, 54%
 Gibbons, 94,183, 40%
 
NEW MEXICO
Republicans once seemed to be within striking distance of gaining a Senate seat in New Mexico, but Senator Jeff Bingaman, a Democrat, was the winner in a tight race with Colin R. McMillan, a Republican rancher who had counted on Mr. Bingaman's support of President Clinton's land policies to swing rural voters his way.
As Mr. McMillan pulled to within 3 percentage points of Mr. Bingaman in recent polls, the Senator, who had been running a low-key issue-oriented campaign, ran negative television advertisements that questioned Mr. McMillan's support of Social Security and Medicare.
In response, the challenger called in big Republican guns like the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and Dick Cheney, Mr. McMillan's boss when he was an Assistant Defense Secretary.
Despite the Democrats' 2-to-1 registration edge, Republicans appeared likely to win the governorship. With more than half the precincts reporting, Bruce King, the Democratic incumbent, trailed the Republican, Gary E. Johnson, by more than 10 percentage points. A former Democratic Lieutenant Governor, Roberto Mondragon, collected enough votes to establish his Green Party as a major party under the state's election law.
 
 SENATE, 77% reporting
 Bingaman, 173,901, 54%
 McMillan, 147,345, 46%
 GOVERNOR, 77% reporting
 Johnson, 160,561, 50%
 King, 127,971, 40%
 Mondragon, 33,873, 11%
 
OREGON
The Republicans had targeted the seat held by Representative Elizabeth Furse as one that was vulnerable. But Ms. Furse had the lead in early returns and was expected to hold on to her seat. One reason was that her Republican opponent, Bill Witt, a businessman, had been criticized for his past ties to the Oregon Citizens Alliance, a group promoting a conservative agenda that included a measure on the ballot to limit government protections for homosexuals. The proposal was behind in early returns.
Ms. Furse emphasized her support for abortion rights and opposition to the anti-gay rights initiative.
In the governor's race, John Kitzhaber, a Democrat and a doctor who designed Oregon's health care rationing plan, beat Denny Smith, a former Republican Congressman.
Mr. Kitzhaber's path to the Democratic nomination was cleared this year when Gov. Barbara Roberts, the Democratic incumbent, announced she would not run.
Also on the ballot, and expected to win approval, was a measure to allow the terminally ill to obtain lethal prescriptions for suicide.
 
 GOVERNOR, 36% reporting
 Kitzhaber, 199,490, 53%
 Smith, 152,513, 41%
 
UTAH
Although Utah has been in the forefront of the term-limits movement, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the 60-year-old Republican and Judiciary Committee power, handily won a fourth term. His opponent, Patrick A. Shea, a former State Democratic Party chairman, proved to be only token opposition.
Utah had one of the more interesting House races in the re-election effort of Karen Shepherd, matched again with her 1992 opponent, Enid Greene Waldholtz. Ms. Shepherd, a Democrat who as a freshman championed changing how Congress works, had received contributions from unions despite voting for the trade agreement with Canada and Mexico. A conservative independent, Merrill Cook, who finished second in the 1992 governor's race, was running neck-and-neck with the other two.
Voters were also deciding on a term-limit petition, financed by Mr. Cook, that could produce a bizarre situation if passed, leaving Utah with conflicting laws on the subject.
 
SENATE, 16% reporting
Hatch, 195,428, 68%
Shea, 83,231, 29%
 
WASHINGTON
Whenever political analysts looked for examples this autumn of anti-incumbent sentiment, rising Republican strength and public distaste for aging Democratic Congressional leaders, they looked first to Speaker Thomas S. Foley. The 15-term Democrat struggled hard for re-election, trailing his Republican opponent, George Nethercutt, by as much as 19 percentage points in September polls.
With nearly half the vote counted, Mr. Foley lagged by six percentage points. But a survey of voters leaving the polls indicated a very close race.
Even if Mr. Foley won, he faced the possible ignominy of no longer leading House Democrats, not to mention the House.
Young Democrats in the chamber have chafed for years at his reluctance to match the partisan tone of House Republicans and could look for a more combative replacement if they become the minority party.
Mr. Nethercutt, the 50-year-old chairman of the Spokane County Republican Party, played on voter hostility toward the Federal Government, accusing Mr. Foley of favoring unnecessary social spending and broad gun controls. Mr. Foley responded that as Speaker he had brought Federal jobs to the state. To reassure gun owners in his district, the state's easternmost and one of the most conservative, Mr. Foley shot a few rounds at a firing range.
Senator Slade Gorton, a Republican, did win re-election, beatingelection, beating Ron Sims, a member of the County Council in King County, which includes Seattle. So broad was the Democratic rout that the state's House delegation, now eight to one Democratic, could become seven to two Republican.
 
 SENATE, 46% reporting
 Gorton, 382,036, 56%
 Sims, 295,068, 44%
 
WYOMING
The least-populous state ranks among the most dependent on Federal cattle-ranching and mining subsidies, which the Clinton Administration wants to cut. Republicans won the races for governor and the Senate by linking their Democratic opponents to the unpopular Administration.
Representative Craig Thomas beat Gov. Mike Sullivan in the race to replace Senator Malcolm Wallop, a Republican who is retiring. Mr. Thomas contended that Mr. Sullivan, a longtime friend of the President, would vote against Wyoming's interests.
Jim Geringer, a Republican State Senator, defeated Kathy Karpan, Wyoming's Democratic Secretary of State, to replace Mr. Sullivan in the House.
Two ballot propositions were closely fought. One would allow slot machine gambling, and the other would subject people performing abortions to felony prosecution, except in cases of rape or incest or when the woman's life was in danger. Women having abortions would not risk prosecution.
 
 SENATE, 82% reporting
 Sullivan, 66,199, 41%
 Thomas, 93,450, 57%
 GOVERNOR, 82% reporting
 Geringer, 792.759, 57%
 Karpan, 67,848, 42%

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
PIPER JAFFRAY COS. (PJC,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Shareholders of the Piper Jaffray Companies saw their dividend cut yesterday as the securities firm prepared to defend itself against lawsuits stemming from its management of bond mutual funds. Piper Jaffray also said earnings fell almost 70 percent in its fourth quarter.
"While the ultimate outcome of the litigation cannot be determined, we believe it is prudent to reduce the dividend at this time," said Addison Piper, the company's chairman and chief executive. 
 Piper Jaffray is being sued by a group of individual shareholders and a teamsters' union affiliate who contend that the company did not properly disclose risks tied to investments made by the Institutional Government Income Portfolio and other bond mutual funds.
Piper Jaffray said it "has acted professionally, while adhering to legal and regulatory guidelines, in creating, marketing and managing these funds."
The company, based in Minneapolis, reported that net income fell to almost $3.57 million, or 20 cents a share, from $11.84 million, or 65 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Revenue was down 15 percent, to $96.66 million. "Our revenues and earnings for the quarter and the year reflect the difficult financial markets that we and our competitors have been operating in since interest rates increased sharply beginning in February," Piper said.
Piper Jaffray's board decided to cut the quarterly dividend to 7.5 cents a share, from 17.5 cents, at a meeting on Monday. The company said the reduction brought its yield more in line with that of other brokerage firms, or to about 3 percent.(Bloomberg Business News)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS;
Other Highlights

 BODY:

VIRGINIA
In Brutal Battle, Robb Defeats North 
 In what may have been the bitterest fight of a bitter year, Senator Chuck Robb, a one-term Democrat, narrowly defeated Oliver North. Mr. North, the former national security aide to President Ronald Reagan, rallied an intensely loyal following among the religious right, opponents of gun control laws and bitter voters wanting to shake up Washington. But his involvement in the Iran-contra affair proved more damaging than the allegations of marital misconduct against Mr. Robb. Page B3.
 
GOVERNORSHIPS
Wilson and Weld Win; Bushes Split
Republicans swept all but one of the major governors' races. Gov. Pete Wilson, given up for politically dead two years ago as California staggered through a fierce recession, completed a stunning comeback by trouncing State Treasurer Kathleen Brown. Page B4.
In Masschusetts, Gov. William F. Weld easily turned back State Representative Mark Roosevelt, establishing himself as a possible player in the 1996 Republican Presidential sweepstakes. Page B3.
For two sons of President George Bush, it was a split decision, but not in the way experts had predicted. George W. Bush was elected in Texas, upsetting the incumbent, Ann Richards. But his younger brother, Jeb Bush, lost to Gov. Lawton Chiles in a close race in Florida.
For George W. Bush, the Texas triumph was sweet revenge against one of his father's old antagonists. The battle was close to the end, with Ms. Richards buoyed by the last-minute support of Ross Perot. Jeb Bush, a newcomer considered more conservative than his father, had been favored against the veteran Mr. Chiles. Page B4.
 
MASSACHUSETTS
Kennedy Beats Back Romney
Senator Edward M. Kennedy proved that after more than three decades on Capitol Hill, he is not ripe for replacing. In the toughest race of his career, the 62-year-old Senator beat a political newcomer with a larger personal fortune and another famous name, Mitt Romney.
 Mr. Romeny, the 47-year-old son of George W. Romeny, the former Governor of Michigan, had tried to tap this year's anti-incumbent fervor, arguing that it was time for a change, but on the stump and in political debates, Senator Kenney underscored his long experience, his comman of the issues and his intimacy with the legislative process.
 
ILLINOIS
Chicago Earthquake: Rostenkowski Is Out
If any seat in the House seemed safe at the outset of the year, it was that of Dan Rostenkowski of Chicago, longtime chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. But reeling under an indictment and an anti-Democratic wave in Illinois, the 66-year-old Mr. Rostenkowski lost to a 31-year-old political neophyte, Michael Patrick Flanagan. Page B3.
 
NEW YORK
Moynihan Win A Fourth Term
 In a year when liberal incumbents faced stiff challenges from the right, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat who is the chaiman of the Senate Finance Committee, easily defeated the Republican candidate, Bernadette Castro. Page B12.
 
TENNESSEE
A Senate Sweep for the G.O.P.
Tennessee had two Democratic Senators. Now it will have two Republicans. Jim Sasser, a three-term Democratic incumbent who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee and a close ally of President Clinton, lost to William Frist, a wealthy heart and lung surgeon who has never held public office.
And Fred Dalton Thompson, a lawyer for the Republicans on the Senate Watergate committee in 1973, defeated Representative Jim Cooper for the seat left vacant when Al Gore was elected Vice President. Page B3.
 
WASHINGTON, D.C.
The Redemption Of Marion Barry
Marion Barry came back from the ignominy of a drug conviction to return as Mayor of Washington, defeating a Republican, Carol Schwartz. Mr. Barry served as Mayor from 1979 through 1990, when he was videotaped smoking crack in a hotel room with a woman who was not his wife. He was convicted and imprisoned. In this campaign, he stressed his strength of character in overcoming personal weakenesses. Page B4.
 
PENNSYLVANIA
Upset Winner in '90 Is the Loser in '94
A pitched battle of ideological opposites ended with Representative Rick Santorum, a conservative Republican, narrowly defeating Senator Harris Wofford, a liberal Democrat. Mr. Santorum had aggressively promoted less government, lower taxes, more military spending and his opposition to a ban on assault weapons. Mr. Wofford, whose own upset victory four years ago put health care at the top of the national agenda, made Social Security the pivotal issue in this election.

HEADLINE: Gasoline Prices to Rise in Many Areas

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
New Federal clean-air rules will force drastic changes in the recipe used for gasoline in most urban areas in the next few weeks, and refiners and distributors are struggling to get supplies of the reformulated gasoline into place. Some analysts are predicting spot shortages and sudden price surges.
"We're going to have the biggest change in gasoline chemistry ever, even bigger than what we saw when we went to unleaded gas in 1973 and 1974," said William Berman, chief environmental affairs lobbyist of the American Automobile Association. 
 The new rules will instantly cover about 30 percent of the national gasoline market, nearly 30 million gallons a day, enough to fuel 43 million passenger cars. By contrast, the last big change, to unleaded fuel, was gradual, with only enough produced at first to supply 1974 model cars.
The areas where the new gasoline will be required are most of the Boston-New York-Washington megalopolis, extending south to Richmond, north to most of coastal Maine and west to much of western Pennsylvania; the Chicago region, including northeastern Indiana and eastern Wisconsin; sections of Kentucky in the Louisville area and near Cincinnati; the Houston and Dallas-Fort Worth areas, and the Los Angeles and San Diego areas.
Some of those areas already require fuel with special characteristics but the new rules are much stricter.
Distributors must have the new fuel on hand by Dec. 1, and refiners in areas where reformulated gasoline is required must have switched over completely by Jan. 1. In many areas, retailers are already pumping the new fuel, although most preferred to wait as long as possible because the it is more expensive.
The new fuel, designed to cut smog by 20 percent, will burn more thoroughly, evaporate more slowly, and even smell different. It will have sharply reduced levels of compounds like toluene and benzene, which refiners have used for years to enhance octane but which scientists have determined are toxic.
And the reformulated fuel will cost more, because it will require more refining and must include oxygen-containing molecules. That oxygen requirement is contributing to a temporary shortage of gasoline ingredients that contain oxygen. The "oxygenated" gasoline now costs about 9 cents a gallon more than ordinary fuel at wholesale.
Experts say that the cost of the oxygen-containing additives may decline, becoming no more per gallon than the cost of the gasoline it is blended with. But in the long term, drivers will probably pay 4 to 6 cents a gallon more for reformulated gasoline, because of the additional refining work needed.
Other than price, drivers probably will not notice much change. "The customer is not going to see a change in vehicle performance, in the sense of acceleration, riding down the road, knock, or anything else," said Reginald R. Modlin, the manager of vehicle emissions regulatory planning at Chrysler. "What we're talking about is emissions performance."
Some automotive experts say, though, that the new gasoline is likely to be blamed for anything that goes wrong with a car after Jan. 1.
The new gasoline, like the old, is a potpourri of hydrocarbon molecules derived from crude oil. But in unreformulated gasoline the largest of those molecules tend to go through engines without burning, so the new rules will allow fewer of the big molecules. In addition, the smallest molecules tend to evaporate easily, which also adds to air pollution, so the new gas will have fewer of those.
As a result, refiners will have to fuse the smallest molecules, and break up the biggest, or take those materials out of the gasoline altogether. None of the technology is complicated, but it involves more refining equipment and more work.
The law also has "anti-dumping" provisions, so that chemicals taken out of reformulated gasoline cannot be thrown into the mix in rural areas and other places that do not now have an air pollution problem.
This has created logistical problems for refiners and distributors. "You're basically introducing yet another kind of gasoline," said Bryan Davis, a spokesman for Sun Oil Company. But the number of pipelines and storage tanks is not changing. "It's like putting something new on the shelf without building any more shelves," he said.
Some experts are predicting sudden swings in the gasoline prices of 25 cents a gallon or more. "We're heading into a situation where it's going to be very, very tight in January," said Philip K. Verleger Jr., an economist who specializes in energy markets, at Charles River Associates, a consulting company based in Boston.
Others think the new rules will raise prices because they will reduce competition in the marketplace. Edwin S. Rothschild, of Citizen Action, a nonprofit group in Washington, said that major oil companies would have an easier time complying with the new rules than small companies, which formerly imported much of their gasoline and now would find it harder to obtain supplies that meet the complicated new specifications.
And, he said, companies would no longer be able to swap supplies so easily, because "unleaded regular" is no longer one product, but two, reformulated and unreformulated.
And some places where reformulated gasoline is not required will end up using it anyway, because the terminals or tanker trucks may change over to the new fuel for all of their distribution area, even if only part of it must have the new fuel.
Even the rules governing who must have the reformulated gas are a patchwork. For nine urban areas the changes are mandated by the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990; 40 other areas decided to require the new gasoline, in preference to other measures to clean up the air, like stricter controls on factories or tougher car inspections or new rules on new cars. Refiners expect more areas to voluntarily adopt the new fuel, which may eventually cover more than half the national market.
The rules taking effect on Jan. 1 are only the first stage; the Clean Air Act calls for stricter rules on Jan. 1, 1998, and a third phase, stricter yet, on Jan. 1, 2000.
This January, motorists who keep careful track may notice a decline in mileage of about 1.5 percent, because the new fuel has more molecules that contain an oxygen atom. The idea is to provide more oxygen in the cylinder, so when the fuel is burned, the exhaust contains less carbon monoxide, which is poisonous, and more carbon dioxide, which is not. But the oxygen-containing molecules have less energy.
A national program to require oxygenated gasoline in wintertime, when carbon monoxide is a problem, began in late 1992; it is now entering its third winter. But the new reformulated gasoline also calls for oxygenated fuel, and that will be year-round.
The oxygenate most popular with refiners is methyl tertiary butyl ether, known as MTBE, but it is now in short supply, because of the increased demand, combined with recent breakdowns at refineries that make the ingredients of MTBE. MTBE usually sells for about the same price per gallon as unleaded gasoline, 65 cents, but it is now selling for double that.
As a result, gasoline with oxygenates is now selling at wholesale for about 9 cents a gallon more than regular gasoline; last winter the difference was only 3.5 cents.
A 9-cent increase at retail would be large if it came suddenly. But prices show a considerable variation over the period of a few months. According to the American Automobile Association, the national average price for a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded was $1.065 in March vs. $1.188 in August. The most recent figure, for mid-October, was $1.157 a gallon.

HEADLINE: In Mozambique and Other Lands, Children Fight the Wars

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOANE, Mozambique

 BODY:
In the rebel camps where Alberto Matevui spent five years of his childhood, he says the commanders usually called upon the young boys to perform the executions.
The victim might be an uncooperative hostage, or an adult guerrilla who had disobeyed an order, or a child soldier who had tried to escape. 
 The commander would summon the camp as if for a school assembly and select one of the new boys to do the killing. If he did well, he might be rewarded with the right to carry a pistol and to order the other children around.
"Sometimes they were younger than me," Alberto said of the executioners. He was 10 when he was kidnapped into the rebel movement called Renamo, and even now, restored to his family at the age of 15, barefoot and baby-faced, he looks scarcely old enough for the Boy Scouts.
Alberto Matevui's war is over, and Mozambique's first elections have brought hope of healing after a conflict in which one million people are estimated to have died. But experiences like his have begun to galvanize international agencies and human rights groups.
In Sudan and Liberia, Angola and Rwanda, Afghanistan, Cambodia and the Middle East, child soldiers are a repellent commonplace of warfare, said Samir Basta, director of the Geneva office of the United Nations Children's Fund. The fund is one of several organizations that has seized on the issue with fervor, though with little hope of curtailing the practice.
Children, it turns out, make good killers. They learn fast, they work cheap, and their sense of right and wrong has not outgrown their yearning to be accepted by whatever liberation group or guerrilla army has become their surrogate family.
"In Rwanda and other places, the perpetrators of some of the worst atrocities were children," Mr. Basta said. "They want to belong and be praised, and their only peer approval may come from being even more brave or barbarous than the adults."
Besides, he added: "Guns are toys. You give somebody a machine gun, and, my God, what a toy!"
Reynaldo Mucavel, who has been tracing the families of child soldiers in Mozambique for the American agency Save the Children, said he had interviewed many youngsters sent by rebels to kill and pillage in their own villages, a tactic apparently aimed at securing the loyalty of young troops while demoralizing civilians.
"I know of one case of a kid who was asked to shoot his mother and father and then cut their necks like he was cutting an onion," said Mr. Mucavel. "He did it. He was 8 years old."
In some cases, children go to war out of desperation, because in a battle-starved economy it is the only way to get food and clothing and occasional provisions to send home to the family.
In other cases, in the Middle East, the former Soviet republics or the remnants of Yugoslavia, young teen-agers are caught up in a nationalist or patriotic spirit.
"In Lebanon or Iran, the parents themselves are proud that their kids go to war and become martyrs and so on," Mr. Basta said. "In the former Yugoslavia, we saw many young people volunteering and wearing these Rambo-like uniforms. They feel brave, they feel manly, they feel that their families expect it of them."
And sometimes, as in Mozambique, where civil war mangled the country for 16 years, children were snatched from their homes and press-ganged into service.
According to Save the Children, both Renamo and the ruling Mozambique Liberation Front pressed children into combat, although the rebels were by far the worse offenders.
Save the Children has matched 8,000 Mozambican children with their families, and has lists of 4,000 more still searching for their parents. Some are children of families scattered during the fighting, but most were either soldiers or camp servants for the warring rivals.
Agostinho Mamade, who is in charge of the matching program, said the search is complicated by the fact that 5 million Mozambicans were uprooted by the war in addition to the million estimated to have died. And some children were stolen so young that they cannot remember the names of their villages.
"We had boys from 8, trained and forced to commit atrocities," said Mr. Mamade. Boys younger than eight helped in the camp until old enough for military training. Girls were kidnapped for the sexual amusement of the men, or to cook and clean.
Alberto Matevui's case was not unusual.
In June 1989 he was tending the village cows with his friend Felisberto Massicuane when a guerrilla patrol came to the outskirts of their village near here. The village is so small it is known only as Kilometer 16, its distance from Maputo.
The gunmen snatched the two boys and Alberto's 9-year-old sister. The friend escaped after a few months. (Asked his career ambitions, he said he wants to be a soldier.) The sister was set free two years ago when a cease-fire began. Alberto was released last July, after Save the Children traced his family.
Alberto said he was trained to use an AK-47 assault rifle, but half-heartedly insisted he was never called on to shoot anyone. Brown eyes downcast, he spoke reluctantly of his experience, recalling mainly long periods without food.
When they began their matching project, Mr. Mamade said, Save the Children had a therapist to counsel the tiny warriors, but the project was soon overwhelmed by the numbers. The agency decided the best therapy was to get the children quickly home.
As a result, there is only anecdotal evidence of the emotional damage inflicted by a childhood at war, and little understanding of how quickly children recover.
"It's difficult to guess what kind of human being you have who lived his whole life in a military environment, and a bloody one, a very cruel one," said Mr. Mamade, who is 31 years old and the father of two children. As for comprehending how anyone could force such a life on a child, he said, "I've given up."
For Mozambique, whose rival armies have been recast by the elections as rival political parties, there is also the question of whether these cruelties will lurk in the national psyche like the numberless mines buried in the landscape.
The other day in Alberto's village, two parents of children kidnapped by the Renamo rebels sat in the slanting light of late afternoon and discussed the prospects of reconciliation.
Antonio Sitoe, whose son and daughter were stolen by the guerrillas and recently recovered, was the voice of resignation: "If they are elected, you have to accept. They are going to govern us, and we must accept them."
But Alberto's mother, Marta Matusse, was having none of that.
"Myself, I will never forgive them," she declared. "If they were living among us in the village, in time we would forgive them, though we would not forget. As it is, I cannot forgive what they have done."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: STATES
THE PRESIDENT;
One Hand Tied, Clinton Offers the Other

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Even as President Clinton reached out to victorious Republicans, the White House was casting about today for ways to govern that would not require Congressional cooperation.
Looking somewhat chastened and sounding very conciliatory at a White House news conference, President Clinton accepted his share of responsibility for the devastating defeats suffered by Democrats in Congress, and he said that he would try to seek common ground with Republicans on issues like welfare reform. 
 But while congratulating Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who is almost certain to be the new majority leader, and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the apparent next Speaker of the House, Mr. Clinton also warned that his political rivals must now do their part to help him govern.
"We were held accountable yesterday," Mr. Clinton said of Democrats in the White House and Congress. He said that Republicans would now have "a larger responsibility for acting in the best interest of America." He called on them "to join me in the center of the public debate where the best ideas for the next generation of American progress must come."
But the White House was grim today as Mr. Clinton's advisers tried to grapple with the magnitude of the defeat. With both houses of Congress soon to be in hostile hands, advisers to Mr. Clinton said today that he recognized that much of his legislative agenda might be doomed.
The advisers said that Mr. Clinton might have to resort to regulations, executive orders and other Presidential tools to work around Capitol Hill, much as Ronald Reagan and George Bush did when the House and Senate were in Democratic hands.
For instance, President Bush used executive orders to allow states to experiment with new approaches to welfare. Mr. Clinton has already begun to follow that example.
"There's a lot you can do without Congress, and believe me, we'll be looking at everything," a senior White House official said.
The aides also spoke with apprehension about the likelihood that Republicans led by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York would intensify a Congressional inquiry into the Whitewater affair to make it a permanent distraction. Mr. D'Amato is in line to be the new chairman of the Banking Committee.
These advisers said the President had concluded that it would be pointless to spend the second half of his term waging a confrontation with Capitol Hill across a broad front. They said he would aim to strike accords with Republicans on measures that have bipartisan support, like an effort to overhaul the welfare system.
But the President now expects only modest changes in the health care system, they said, and has little chance of winning backing for the new domestic spending he has portrayed as a necessary investment.
The President will also have to contend with initiatives like a balanced-budget amendment and term limits that Republicans have made central to their campaigns and that they are now likely to try to rush into law.
Mr. Clinton has been opposed to both proposals, but his chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, equivocated today when asked about them, suggesting that he could be open to a compromise.
The advisers say that while Mr. Clinton will almost certainly have to begin exercising his veto power, he is wary of being seen as the kind of obstructionist that he has spent two years railing against.
Asked at his news conference today about the road ahead, Mr. Clinton said, "I will still work for the things that make America strong." But as he called repeatedly for bipartisan cooperation, he conceded that his own power had been substantially diminished. "A lot has changed since yesterday," the President said.
Mr. Clinton and his advisers had steeled themselves for the prospect of Democrats' losing the Senate, and some had warned that the House, too, might be at risk. But none had foreseen that the losses would be so heavy. While he did not name any of them, the President took time to express regret that Congress would now be without so many Democrats whom he said had "made this a lot better country."
The Republican victories are the biggest setback for Mr. Clinton since 1980, when he lost his first bid to be re-elected governor of Arkansas, and he plainly recognized that today marked an important moment. He told reporters he had taken time to reread the speech he gave as he began his quest for the Presidency three years ago, when he said that the job of government was to create opportunity and let citizens assume the responsibility for making the most of it.
"They don't think we've done that yet," he said, and his advisers conceded that he might now be badly weakened as he begins an expected quest for a second Presidential term.
The President had traveled nearly nonstop for the last three weeks to build support for Democrats by calling attention to his achievements at home and, with four frenetic days in the Middle East, to what he had accomplished abroad. He stayed awake until at least 2 A.M. today to monitor the returns, his aides said. His voice was hoarse, and there were deep bags under his eyes as he appeared at the afternoon news conference, his first public appearance since the election.
In an opening statement, Mr. Clinton tried to call attention to areas in which Republicans and Democrats had taken similar approaches to solutions. He said it was vital that they work together to promote further economic recovery and continued cuts in the Federal deficit.
Mr. Clinton said he would also support Republican efforts to give the President a line-item veto, a tool that he said would make it easier to hold the line on Government spending.
But he made clear that he would oppose attempts by Republicans to redeem the full range of promises made in the party's Contract With America, in which candidates committed themselves to a program of tax cuts and spending increases that Mr. Clinton denounced as a return to the economically destructive policies of the 1980's.
He promised to block any proposals that would "take us back to the policies that failed us before." And he said he would strongly object if Republicans tried to repeal the ban on assault weapons or the controls on handguns approved by Congress over their objections.
The President's tone today was far more gentle than it has been on the campaign trail, where he spent the final days before the election attacking Republicans as members of a party willing to let Americans suffer as the price for political success. Repeatedly, he called for bipartisan cooperation and said that he accepted part of the responsibility for the Democrats' defeat.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE LEADERS
THE SPEAKER;
Foley, Defending Congress to the Last, Concedes Election Defeat by Newcomer

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 9

 BODY:
The House Speaker, Representative Thomas S. Foley, a 30-year incumbent, has always said that the best way to insure term limits was at the ballot box. On Tuesday, voters in eastern Washington followed his advice.
Mr. Foley conceded today at midday, even though he trailed the Republican challenger, George Nethercutt, by only 2,200 votes with 14,000 absentee ballots still to be counted. The odds appeared too long to make up, Mr. Foley said. 
 If the numbers hold up, he will be the first Speaker ousted by the voters since 1860, when William Pennington of New Jersey was defeated.
But with Mr. Foley's fall coming at the end of a Republican national sweep in the House and Senate, that distinction did not seem to matter much. In the end, he was another casualty, going down with other House Democrats, including some from the leadership.
The storm that hit Mr. Foley also produced the biggest numerical change, by party, of any state's House delegation. Washington, considered a Democratic stronghold, went from an 8-to-1 Democratic alignment to 7 to 2 in favor of the Republicans.
In defeat as throughout his Speakership, Mr. Foley, who is 65, defended Congress as an institution that the press and voters had unfairly disparaged.
"Despite what people say, the overwhelming majority of members, both Democrat and Republican, are wonderful, upstanding and talented people," he said today.
He refused to answer questions about whether he would consider taking a White House appointment. He has been mentioned as a possible successor to Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
In a year when all politics was national, Mr. Foley could not save himself by emphasizing his ability to bring Federal dollars and prestige to this district, a long stretch of farm and forest land from the Canadian border to Oregon.
Exit polls showed that the overwhelming reason people voted against Mr. Foley was that they thought he had been in Congress too long. He has represented this district since 1964, a point made clear today as the Speaker thanked a long list of Presidents with whom he served, beginning with Lyndon B. Johnson.
Throughout the campaign, he was criticized for opposing term limits and characterized as a career politician and creature of Congress who had become removed from local concerns. "He's a Washington, D.C., man, not a Washington state man," said Kathy Cruz of Spokane, who campaigned for Democrats in the past but switched parties this year. She wore a button that said, "We made history."
Mr. Foley suffered rare indignities in recent months for a House Speaker. Fighting round-the-clock slights on local talk radio, he took to the airwaves, only to be asked questions like whether he is a homosexual. Mr. Foley, who has been married for more than 20 years, said he is not gay.
At times in the last month he seemed unable to comprehend how much his vision of government was at odds with that of so many of his constituents. When, he argued in a debate, for example, that government could be a force for good in areas like education, he was booed.
His opponent, Mr. Nethercutt, a 50-year-old Spokane lawyer who is a political neophyte, could not have represented more of a contrast. He played up his inexperience in government, saying he wanted to return to something closer to the part-time Congress of old.
"This vote is a voice of the people to change the system in Washington," said Mr. Nethercutt, who has promised to serve no more than three terms. "That's what we are really about."
Mr. Foley, stunned by the magnitude of the Democratic loss nationwide, said in an interview late Tuesday night that the Democrats failed to communicate their accomplishments.
"If the public believes the deficit is going up when it's going down, that we are in a recession when in fact we've added millions of new jobs, that's a problem of perception," he said. "But perception is reality in this day of politics."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges as Analysts See Improved U.S. Outlook

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar surged yesterday, and some analysts cited expectations that the big Republican gains in elections on Tuesday would mean an improved outlook for the United States economy.
"The feeling is that Republicans are going to be more fiscally conservative and bring down inflation expectations, which would be good for the dollar," said David Durst, vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company. 
 For the first time in 40 years, Republicans took control of both the House and Senate -- putting the two chambers at odds with President Clinton.
In the days leading to the elections, the dollar fell, as analysts warned that the currency would suffer if the Republicans gained a majority in both houses.
Analysts predicted that a Republican victory would weaken the President's efforts to push legislation through Congress and thus reduce investors' confidence in the currency. Foreign investors often shun the currency of a country whose leader is perceived to be weak.
But in overnight trading in Asia and Europe, the dollar rallied strongly, surprising a number of analysts.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5315 German marks, from 1.5092 marks on Tuesday. The dollar rose to 97.80 yen, from 97.11 yen on Tuesday.
"The dollar moved up based on the assumption that there would be less spending from the Administration, which would benefit the bond market," said Hillel Waxman, vice president at the Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York.
But traders said it would take more than a changing of the Congressional guard to remedy the fundamental problems that have recently plagued the dollar.
"What has been weighing on the dollar are inflation concerns," said Amy Smith, a currency analyst at the consulting firm Idea.
The dollar rose against most other currencies. The British pound fell to $1.6055, from $1.6184 on Tuesday. The dollar rose to 1.2825 Swiss francs, from 1.2615 francs; to 5.2502 French francs, from 5.1838 francs, and to 1,569.50 Italian lire, from 1,550 lire. But the Canadian dollar rose to 73.83 United States cents, from 73.76 cents.

HEADLINE: Aristide Promises Greater Aid To Haiti's Impoverished North

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CAP-HAITIEN, Haiti, Nov. 9

 BODY:
President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on his first foray to the provinces since being restored to office last month, promised jobs, markets, roads, water and school supplies today to thousands of cheering residents in the northern town of Cap-Haitien.
"This work will be done quickly," he told an audience of more than 2,000 people as hundreds of supporters waved handkerchiefs and hats to the beat of a snare drum and trumpet. Others sang "Aristide Baby, Oh, Aristide Baby!" 
Ringed by American and Guatemalan soldiers, President Aristide said he would bring at least 50 markets to northern Haiti. He vowed to build roads in a region devoid of all but rocky paths and said 39,700 pounds of food would soon be distributed to local hospitals. He also promised to send supplies to state schools.
President Aristide said he would present the proposals at a Cabinet meeting on Thursday "so the people of the north feel this is not just words but action."
But the crowd was not so enthusiastic when it came to the subject of reconciliation with the military leaders who took control of the country for three years. Most refused to reply when he asked, "Are we going to work for justice and reconciliation?"
When the response was tepid, he cried out: "I'll ask one more time. Are we going to work for justice and reconciliation?" The crowd's response was louder then.
As if to illustrate his commitment to putting the past behind him, the Roman Catholic priest embraced the region's right-wing bishop, Francois Gaillot, who was seen as an ally of the former military Government.
President Aristide thanked American soldiers for their support in helping to restore him to the presidency and called on the United States to keep aiding Haiti. "I congratulate you and I am proud of you and I ask you to continue working," he said in English.
He stayed here for two hours before returning by helicopter to Port-au-Prince with the United States Ambassador, William L. Swing.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: STATES
CALIFORNIA;
Californians Pass Measure On Aliens; Courts Bar It

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Californians overwhelmingly approved a new law cutting off most government services to illegal aliens on Tuesday, but Gov. Pete Wilson's orders to begin enforcing some of its provisions today were immediately blocked by Federal and state judges.
Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat who opposed the popular initiative as too restrictive, claimed victory in a closely fought race against Representative Michael Huffington, a Republican who supported the measure. Mr. Huffington has not conceded pending a count of the absentee ballots. 
 The immigration initiative, called Proposition 187, passed by a margin of 3 to 2 with the strong backing of Mr. Wilson, who had made the costs of illegal immigration a central theme of his own successful re-election campaign. The measure denies welfare services, nonemergency medical treatment and public schooling to foreigners living in the state illegally.
United States District Judge Matthew Byrne Jr. today barred enforcement of the measure's provisions for one week, until he can hold a hearing. A San Francisco Superior Court judge blocked enforcement of the provision that denies schooling to children who are illegal aliens. A flurry of lawsuits were filed today challenging the measure's constitutionality.
At the same time, law enforcement officials around the state urged disappointed opponents of Proposition 187 to remain calm and not take to the streets in rowdy protest, as they had done in the days leading up to Tuesday's voting.
Mr. Huffington's strong support for the initiative, the most hotly debated issue in California this year, was apparently not enough to give him the edge against Senator Feinstein. Of votes cast at polling places, 47 percent went to Ms. Feinstein and 45 percent to Mr. Huffington -- a lead for her, but one so narrow that her opponent refused to concede until absentee ballots were counted.
"I'm very optimistic that I'm the victor," Ms. Feinstein said this morning.
Mr. Huffington countered that there were enough absentee ballots outstanding to tip the balance. "The election is still in the hands of the voters," he said.
Election officials said that if past voting patterns held, the absentee votes would closely track those cast at polling places.
Ms. Feinstein's apparent victory was particularly notable in an election in which most high-profile Democrats were swept aside by the Republican tide. Outspent two to one, pummeled by negative television advertisements portraying her as the ultimate Clintonite liberal and seared by the hyperheated debate over Proposition 187, she was able to convince voters that it was acceptable to be an unabashed "inside the beltway" incumbent and an ideological ally of President Clinton.
Surveys of voters leaving the polls on Tuesday indicated that besides the immigration issue, the Huffington-Feinstein contest was decided by factors, ranging from the candidates' experience and trustworthiness to the economy and crime.
Ms. Feinstein, a 61-year-old veteran of more than three decades in California public life, bested Mr. Huffington among voters when it came to experience and knowledge of the needs of California.
Mr. Huffington, a 47-year-old Texan who moved to California in the early 1990's and who has been in public life for less than three years, did better on crime and tax issues.
Ms. Feinstein ran particularly well among women, held on to most of the liberal and Democratic vote, outpolled the Congressman among moderates and independents, and even stole away some Republicans. She also captured the votes of most black and Hispanic voters.
After all their talk about the immigration problem, both candidates suddenly found themselves embarrassed near the end of the campaign by disclosures that they had employed illegal aliens as household workers. Both then stepped up their spending on television ads while the campaign became exceptionally mean-spirited, with the word "liar" the favored pejorative.
In Tuesday's exit polls, many voters said they found Mr. Huffington's huge personal campaign spending excessive and his advertising blitzes too negative. Many voters also faulted the Senator along those lines, but they were more forgiving of her than her opponent.
Mr. Huffington poured $28 million of his $70 million personal fortune into his campaign, spending most on relentlessly vituperative television advertisements that catapulted him from political unknown to serious contender.
All told, Mr. Huffington and Ms. Feinstein spent $42 million in their contest, $16 million more than had ever been spent in a Congressional race. Mr. Huffington alone exceeded the previous Congressional race spending record of $26 million.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Demonstrators carrying a Mexican flag marched through the Mission District of San Francisco yesterday on their way to City Hall to protest the passage of an initiative limiting public aid to illegal immigrants. (Darcy Padilla for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Researchers Ask Whether Prenatal Care Truly Saves Money

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
Prenatal care is often described as preventive medicine that pays for itself by averting future costs, but a new analysis says the savings have not been substantiated.
The investigators hasten to add that prenatal care is medically important and that all pregnant women should receive it. But they say the argument that for every dollar spent far more will be saved is a myth. 
 For more than a decade, it has been widely accepted that the cost of prenatal care will be more than offset by a reduction in the number of premature babies, whose medical costs can be astronomical.
This contention is used to persuade state legislatures to pay for prenatal visits for poor women, and is repeatedly cited by those who argue that preventive medicine must be included in health insurance programs.
The analysis of the prenatal-care literature was conducted by Dr. Frederick A. Connell, who directs the maternal and child health program at the University of Washington in Seattle, and Dr. Jane Huntington, an internist at the Group Health Cooperative in Seattle. Their paper is being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine.
Dr. Connell and Dr. Huntington looked at more than 100 papers claiming that prenatal care saves money by preventing the births of premature babies. Most papers cited the same few studies, and those studies, they found, were deeply flawed.
The researchers found that the studies, for example, compared babies born to women who had prenatal care with those of women who did not. But the women who did not receive care tended to be poorer and to have social problems like drug or alcohol abuse that might lead them to have low-birth-weight babies anyway.
The studies also assumed that routine care was enough to help poor women with complex problems. But most experts say women at high risk of having premature babies need intensive care, starting early in pregnancy, to identify problems like violence at home, poor nutrition, and drug and alcohol abuse. Such comprehensive care is much more expensive.
Most studies also made insupportable assumptions about the effectiveness of care and the medical costs of prematurity. They assumed, for example, that the care largely prevented the births of very premature babies, that is, those born after 28 weeks or less of pregnancy. But if prenatal care helps prevent prematurity at all, it prevents such births in the last three months of pregnancy, when medical problems are not nearly so severe, the researchers said.
Despite these problems with the studies, Dr. Connell and Dr. Huntington say, advocates of prenatal care have even put dollar amounts on the supposed savings, with what the researchers term "remarkable precision." Health planners have said that for every dollar spent on prenatal care, $1.70 or $2.57 or $3.38 will be saved.
Dr. Connell and Dr. Huntington say they have qualms about questioning the cost savings. "It's goring the sacred cow," Dr. Connell said. "I don't want this to be construed as an anti-prenatal-care article."
Other experts had the same concern. Dr. Bernard Guyer, chairman of the department of maternal and child health at the Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health, said that even though the money-saving arguments do not stand up, "No one should ever interpret this as saying women shouldn't get good prenatal care and that prenatal care shouldn't be covered by public programs."
But Dr. Connell said, "It is disturbing that the public has so confidently and with such precision embraced the idea that prenatal care saves money." In part, he blames the scientific community, which at times seemed so eager to promote prenatal care for poor women that it glossed over the inadequacies of the cost-savings data.
Dr. Marie McCormick, chairwoman of the department of maternal and fetal health at the Harvard School of Public Health, said it was true that "justification of these services on a cost-benefit analysis is a weak reed," but added that "people were reduced to this kind of effort" by politicians reluctant to spend money on services for the poor.
Dr. McCormick said prenatal care could help women as well as babies, by detecting health and nutrition problems and helping women to stop smoking. But it may be too much to ask, given the social problems of poor women and the paucity of knowledge of how to prevent premature births, to expect it also to save money, she said.
Dr. Louise Russell, a research professor of economics at Rutgers University, said it had been a mistake from the start for scientists to promote the cost-savings argument. "If you try to sell it on cost savings, it will and should come back to haunt you," she said. "If it doesn't save costs, then people can come back and say that it isn't worth doing."
Dr. Russell said that well-meaning scientists and policy makers "who think prevention is a good thing are shooting themselves in the foot in trying to argue that it saves money, because it is absolutely not true."
"And that isn't the right ground to argue on," she added. "We don't go into medical care to save money. We go into it to improve health and save lives."
Dr. Connell said he sees another danger in "how the so-called data have been used." He said the public and politicians feel that once prenatal care is included in Medicaid programs, "they've solved the problem." But, he added, the problems are complex and involve nutrition, smoking, drug use, access to medical facilities and lack of education. "Our preoccupation with prenatal care takes us further from true solutions," he said.
Dr. Guyer, of Johns Hopkins, said: "These are very complicated social problems and they can't be solved by simplistic interventions. We should have been willing to say that earlier, but it wasn't easy in that political environment.
"I've had this argument with so many of my advocacy friends. When you're afraid to say what the information really shows, that worries me. Someone's going to find it out anyway. It's not that this article is bursting the bubble. The bubble was going to burst anyway."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: VOTERS
THE OUTCOME;
Asked to Place Blame, Americans in Surveys Chose: All of the Above

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
While Republicans touted their electoral surge on Tuesday as a repudiation of President Clinton and an endorsement of conservative Republican policies, there was little evidence that these motivations moved most voters.
Instead, voters who were surveyed as they were leaving their polling places blamed a host of factors for the nation's failures in solving problems. Indeed, a majority said that special interest groups and members of Congress from both parties were more at fault than the Clinton Administration. 
 Republicans scored their biggest gains among independents and men, winning support from both groups in much higher proportions than they have in years. Those who backed Ross Perot in the 1992 Presidential election voted overwhelmingly for Republicans. The party also drew significant support from the suburbs.
More Republicans than Democrats went to the polls. Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, estimated that the turnout was nearly 39 percent, more than two percentage points higher than in the mid-term elections of 1990. He said his projections showed that for the first time since 1970, more Republicans than Democrats voted.
Yet the encouraging results for Republicans were offset to some extent by voter survey findings that showed that the number of people who identify themselves as Republicans had not increased from four years ago. The electorate is still about evenly split between the two major political parties. And though the newly elected class of House and Senate Republicans has a conservative tilt, it does not appear to reflect an ideological shift among the voters. Almost half of the voters yesterday identified themselves as moderates.
The survey of 5,260 voters leaving polling places across the country was conducted by Mitofsky International, an independent organization in New York.
Short of an overall distaste for government, there was no unifying theme among voters who supported Republican candidates. For example, 4 out of 10 voters listed crime as the No. 1 issue that influenced their voting for House candidates. But of those people, half voted for Democrats and half for Republicans. In addition, 4 out of 10 voters said their voting for House candidates had nothing to do with Mr. Clinton.
Ruth Smith, a 49-year-old legal secretary in Houston who usually supports Democrats, said she had mixed feelings about the President but voted for several Republicans on the ticket out of a general frustration with the Government. "I feel like some of the good old boys have been there too long; they're complacent, owe too many people," Ms. Smith said. "They're not listening to what we're saying, what we want, the average American."
One voter who backed Mr. Perot but favored Republicans on Tuesday was Hugh Magnusen, 59, who owns a small vending machine business near Seattle. He said his distress over the Government was personified by two veteran Democrats who were defeated on Tuesday, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Chicago.
"It's a gigantic mess back in Washington, D.C., because of the Foleys and the Rostenkowskis," he said. "I just don't trust them."
It was a message that reached the Oval Office. At a news conference yesterday, Mr. Clinton said the voters were telling him: " 'Look, we just don't like what we see when we watch Washington. And you haven't done much about that. It's too partisan, too interest-group oriented, things don't get done. There's too many people up there playing politics. Democrats are in charge. We are holding you accountable, and we hope you hear this, Mr. President.' "
For months, Mr. Clinton has complained that voters do not give him credit for an improved economy. Indeed, the survey found that an overwhelming proportion of people who said that their standard of living was getting worse supported Republican House candidates. But almost as many voters said their standard of living was getting better, and most said they had voted for Democrats. More than half said it had stayed the same. They split evenly between Democrats and Republicans.
The Republican victories did not seem to reflect any new hostility toward Mr. Clinton. While 49 percent of voters said they disapproved of how he was handling his job, his popularity has hovered at that level for months. And the 44 percent who approved of his performance was only one percentage point more than his winning share of the vote two years ago.
Stanley Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's pollster, argued that Republicans would be misguided if they make too much of what the outcome says about the President. "The Republicans will make a very big mistake if they interpret this election as having settled the Clinton Presidency," he said. "The forces at work that threw them out in 1992 are still at work in '94. The Democrats were seen to be in power, which is why they paid the price."
While Linda DiVall, a Republican pollster, interpreted the results as a rebuke to Mr. Clinton, she, too, warned her party to not read too much into them. "The results show no particular allegiance to one political party," she said. "In '92 they punished a lot of Republicans. In '94 they punished a lot of Democrats. It seems to be that voters are still looking for change."
Although voters clearly wanted to send a message to Washington, there is little evidence that they were endorsing a Republican agenda. Recent polls have found that most voters did not know about the "Contract with America," a proposal signed by more than 300 Republican House candidates that called for cutting taxes, balancing the budget and increasing spending for the military.
Ned Lowry, 61, a retired engineer from Seattle who considers himself an independent, said he had voted for a Republican for the House for no other reason than that he did not like the Democratic candidate. "He was a turkey," Mr. Lowry said. He acknowledged that he had heard of the Republican contract but said his vote for a Republican "didn't have anything to do with it."
The survey also found that people who identify themselves as evangelical Christians and have been more visible in Republican politics this year voted overwhelmingly for Republicans. Six out of 10 backed Republican candidates for the House.
A particularly striking finding was an eight-point gap between men and women in voting for House candidates. Fifty-four percent of men voted for Republicans and 46 percent for Democrats; the figures were reversed for women.
This was the first time in eight elections that there has been as wide a division between male and female voters. The Republican edge among men greatly benefited candidates like George W. Bush, the former President's eldest son, who defeated Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas.
Still, many women switched to Republicans in their voting. Reva Holcomb, an 85-year-old retired secretary in Miami, said she voted for Republicans this year because Mr. Clinton "has been in power too long, and when you get too much power you go bad."
"I think the American people as a whole have lost confidence in their Government," she said.
But while Ms. Holcomb blamed the President, another Miami resident, Lorraine Watson, 32, was motivated more by statewide personalities. Ms. Holcomb, a nurse, said she usually votes for Democrats but could not bring herself to support Gov. Lawton Chiles, who was re-elected in a tight race with Jeb Bush, another son of the former President. "They say he's experienced," she said of Mr. Chiles, "but there's no change. We need a new guy."
The shift among independents was also significant. Fifty-six percent of those who identified themselves as independents voted for Republicans, while 44 percent voted for Democrats. The last time independents cast more of their votes for Republicans than for Democrats was in 1984, and the gap was narrower then, 51 percent Republican and 49 percent Democrat. People who voted for Mr. Perot backed Republicans by a 2-to-1 ratio.
An example of how independents voted came in the Michigan Senate race, where 53 percent chose the Republican candidate, Spencer Abraham, and 47 percent backed Representative Bob Carr, the Democrat who lost. And though Mr. Perot endorsed Governor Richards, a Democrat, almost twice as many independent voters backed Mr. Bush, the winner in the Texas governor's race.
Despite indications that there was much more at play in the results than Mr. Clinton and his policies, Democratic strategists sounded shell-shocked yesterday.
"I think the voters meant to send a major message to Clinton and the Democrats," said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster, "and I think we'd be foolish to pretend otherwise."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: CONGRESS;
THE NEW FACES IN THE SENATE

 BODY:

ARIZONA
Jon Kyl, 52, Republican
The son of a Congressman, a lawyer and four-term House member, Mr. Kyl has been a strong critic of cuts in the Pentagon budget and played an important role in preserving spending for the Stars Wars program. In the race to succeed Senator Dennis DeConcini, the retiring Democrat, he campaigned against Representative Sam Coppersmith by emphasizing his opposition to abortion rights and President Clinton's health plan.
 
MAINE
Olympia J. Snowe, 47, Republican
A member of the House since 1978, Ms. Snowe defeated Representative Thomas H. Andrews to take over the seat now held by Senator George J. Mitchell, the Democratic leader, who is retiring. She entered politics in 1973 by running for the state House seat left vacant by the death of her first husband, Peter Snowe. A widely known and popular figure around the state, Ms. Snowe was one of a group of Republican women who called on President George Bush to modify his opposition to abortion rights. She supports a balanced budget amendment and in 1987 led the drive to have the new American Embassy in Moscow demolished after listening devices were discovered in it. Ms. Snowe is married to the state's governor, John McKernan. 

MICHIGAN
Spencer Abraham, 42, Republican
A former state Republican chairman, he was an aide to former Vice President Dan Quayle. His campaign tied Representative Bob Carr to President Clinton and to the Administration's deficit reduction plan, as well as to Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Democrat incumbent, who is retiring. One of Mr. Abraham's ads showed Mr. Carr's face metamorphizing into Mr. Riegle. Less negative and ideological than many other Republican candidates this fall, Mr. Abraham emphasized the need for the Federal Government to limit its work in fighting poverty to roles it serves well, rather than suggesting it is useless in the field.
 
MINNESOTA
Rod Grams, 46, Republican
A former television news broadcaster who won election to the House of Representatives in 1992, Mr. Grams decided to give up his House seat in a bid to replace Senator Dave Durenberger, who is retiring. Mr. Grams, who boasted early in the campaign of his 100 percent approval rating by the Christian Coalition, a conservative group, campaigned against his Democratic opponent, Ann Wynia, by stressing the need for a smaller Federal Government and a tougher approach to crime. He supports term limits and opposes abortion rights.
 
 
MISSOURI
John Ashcroft, 52, Republican
A lawyer, gospel singer and songwriter, Mr. Ashcroft was elected Governor in Missouri in 1984 after serving as state attorney general He won re-election handily in 1988, but was barred from a third term by state law. Last year, he ran unsuccessfully to become national Republican Party chairman. This fall, he cited the seven death row inmates executed during his tenure as proof that he is tough on crime and proposed cutting the cost of welfare by capping benefits at the previous year's level. He says he favors an incremental approach to health legislation, concentrating on changing insurance rules.
 
OHIO
Mike DeWine, 47, Republican
The lieutenant governor, he has spent his entire professional life in politics. He served as a county prosecutor, state senator, and four terms as United States Representative in addition to his current post. He captured this Democratic seat which Howard M. Metzenbaum, the retiring incumbent, had hoped to hand over to his son-in-law, Joel Hyatt, the founder of a chain of legal clinics. In addition to calling for tougher measures on crime, he said he would work to reform the Senate to make it more responsive. Mr. DeWine supports a requirement to balance the Federal budget.
 
OKLAHOMA
James M. Inhofe, 59, Republican
A three-term House member and former three-term mayor of Tulsa, Mr. Inhofe emphasized his conservative record in the race to replace Senator David Boren, the conservative Democrat who is resigning in mid-term to head the University of Oklahoma. His opponent, Representive Dave McCurdy, was a conservative Democrat much in the Boren mold; both men ran campaigns critical of President Clinton. Mr. Inhofe had to overcome a string of controversies about his business background, including a the failure of an insurance company he inherited and a Federal judge's order that he pay the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation more than $500,000 in a dispute over a loan.
 
PENNSYLVANIA
Rick Santorum, 36, Republican
A lawyer and former Congressional aide, he was first elected to the House in 1990, representing the Pittsburgh suburbs. An aggressive conservative, he criticized Senator Harris Wofford as an emblem of failed liberalism and as a supporter of President Clinton. Mr. Santorum fiercely opposes abortion, gun control, family leave and extending unemployment insurance. When he was criticized by a prominent local Republican, Theresa Heinz, the widow of Senator John Heinz, who held the seat until his death in 1991, he responded by suggesting she made the remarks because she is dating a Democrat, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts.
 
TENNESSEE
Bill Frist, 42, Republican
A Nashville heart surgeon, Mr. Frist is a first-time candidate who first registered to vote in 1988. His family founded the Hospital Corporation of American, and Mr. Frist spent almost $2 million of his own money to oust Senator Jim Sasser. In one ad, he said he supported "term limits for career politicians and the death penalty for career criminals." He also called for tough welfare reform; he calls abortion a personal choice, though one he opposes; he is against gun control. But most of his energy in the campaign went into attacks on Mr. Sasser. "For the past 18 years, Bill Frist has been transplating hearts and lungs," he said at a recent rally. "For the past 18 years Jim Sasser has been transplanting your wallets."
 
Fred D. Thompson, 52, Republican
Mr. Thompson is a lawyer and lobbyist but many people know him best as a movie actor. He pursued a conservative anti-Washington line and regularly criticized his opponent, Representative Jim Cooper, for having voted last year for the Clinton deficit-reduction bill. An effective campaign speaker, he emphasized a down-home appeal to contrast with his opponent, who is a Rhodes Scholar. Mr. Thompson's political mentor has been former Senator Howard W. Baker, who hired Mr. Thompson as a counsel on the Watergate committee.
WYOMING
Craig Thomas, 61, Republican
First elected to the House in 1989 to fill the seat vacated by Dick Cheney, Mr. Thomas focused as much on President Clinton as on his opponent, Gov. Mike Sullivan, a long-time Clinton ally who was one of the first governors to endorse Mr. Clinton in 1992. In his race to succeed Senator Malcom Wallop, the Republican who is retiring, Mr. Thomas repeatedly railed against what he called Mr. Clinton's "War on the West." He also strongly criticized the Clinton health plan, calling instead for one that would have more flexibility in serving rural areas. Before going into politics he had a varied career in business, among other things working as general manager of the Wyoming Rural Electric Association and as a partner in a motel.
