The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 10, 1994

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 952 words

HEADLINE: The Election's Fallout for the Economy;
Stocks Rise, But Euphoria Doesn't Last

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Traders stormed into the stock market like a herd of elephants yesterday morning, pushing prices sharply higher in the wake of the Republican sweep of the House, the Senate and the governors' mansions.
But few investors followed them, and by the end of the day the herd had turned into bears as Wall Street debated the effect of the Republican victory; after falling at midday, blue-chip stocks recovered to eke out a tiny gain. 
 "There was euphoria overnight, because Republicans are more market-oriented than Democrats," said David Shulman, the investment strategist for Salomon Brothers. "But then reality set in: this is not going to change the Fed tightening." Most analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates on Tuesday, after its policy-making committee meets, a move that they do not expect to be good for the stock market. Nevertheless, the bond market and the dollar both rose slightly yesterday.
The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.01 points, to 3,831.75; the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 0.25 point, to 465.40. Stocks of smaller companies also dropped; the Russell 2,000 index edged down 0.43 point, to 251.69, while the Nasdaq composite index declined 0.29, to 767.25. Trading was heavy, as 337.9 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange, where the average volume recently has been under 300 million. More stocks fell than rose; the ratio of declining to advancing stocks was 6 to 5.
Most of the action yesterday, analysts said, was generated by short-term traders, who were active in the options and futures markets. "To read any logic or long-term perspective into it is lunatic," said Michael Metz, chief strategist for Oppenheimer & Company.
Indeed, Wall Street does not seem to have a consistent view on whether the Republican victory will benefit investors over the long haul. There are deep divisions over that question among investment gurus and money managers -- even those who all work at the same firm.
For example, Tom Stiles, chief investment officer of Smith Barney Shearson's Greenwich Street Advisers, sounded a positive note, suggesting that the Republican victory had averted rancorous gridlock in Washington. "Instead, the Republicans will have something very close to a super-majority, and an activist leadership" that could cut the tax rate on investment gains, he said.
But Jeffrey Russell, who manages Smith Barney's largest international mutual fund, said he thought it likely that the Republicans would concentrate on thwarting President Clinton and trying to win the 1996 Presidential election rather than enacting a positive program. "Even if you are a rock-ribbed Republican," he wondered, "is this really a good development?"
And Hersh Cohen, president of Smith Barney Shearson Asset Management, said he did not think the election would have much effect on the market, for good or bad. "What happens in the political arena and events of the day, unless they are a total surprise like the Iran-Iraq war, well, the markets tend to do what they are going to do anyhow," he said. Anyway, he added, "All Republicans are is mean-spirited Democrats."
History buffs can find evidence on all sides. Republicans have taken credit for one of the biggest stock market rallies of all time in the 1980's. After Ronald Reagan entered the White House and Republicans took over the Senate in 1981, the Dow Jones industrial average almost doubled, to 1,896 at the end of 1986, when the Democrats regained dominance in the Senate. And in 1953 and 1954, when Dwight D. Eisenhower shared power with a Republican-controlled Congress, the market soared almost 40 percent.
But to find a situation exactly like the one about to occur in Washington -- a Democratic President and a Republican Congress -- analysts must look all the way back to 1947, when Harry S. Truman was in the White House and the Republicans held the House and Senate.
And there, precedent is not so positive. During 1947 and 1948, the market basically marked time; the Dow began that period at 177.20; it ended up two years later at 177.30.
Of course, there were many factors at work in the late 1940's, most notably the transformation to a peacetime economy. But that is always the case; trying to isolate the effect of politics on the stock market is like trying to isolate the taste of the bay leaf in the lamb stew, said Laszlo Birinyi, who runs a research firm in Greenwich, Conn. Anyway, he said, while the market may be focused on the election now, "by next week it will be, what election?"
Clearly, however, some stocks did get a big push from the election. The market cheered the apparent death of comprehensive health care legislation by bidding up the stocks of drug and medical companies. Merck, the giant pharmaceutical company, climbed 1, to 36 3/4, and was one of the most active stocks of the day. Other gainers included A. L. Pharma, a generic drug maker, which rose 1 5/8, to 17 3/4; United American Health, up 1 3/4, to 27, and Regency Health, up 5/8, to 11 3/4.
Local races also had an effect on some issues. The Long Island Lighting Company's shares dropped 1 3/8, to 16 3/8, as investors bet that the Republican Governor-elect, George E. Pataki, would not carry out Mario M. Cuomo's plan to take over the utility.
Casino stocks tumbled because voters rejected some measures to legalize gambling; International Game Technology, which makes slot machines, fell 1 5/8, to 18 7/8, and Promus, which runs Harrah's, dropped 2 3/4, to 30 1/2. But the same news on gambling buoyed the stock of Walt Disney, which successfully opposed legalizing casinos in Florida; the company's stock rose 1 1/4, to 42 1/4.

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: IN THEIR OWN WORDS;
Clinton: Voters Are Demanding That the Parties Work Together

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today on the results of Tuesday's election, as transcribed by the Federal Information Systems Corporation, a private transcription service:
PRESIDENT CLINTON Ladies and gentlemen, last night and again this morning, I spoke with both Republicans and Democrats to congratulate those who won and console those who lost their elections. I also called the leaders of the next Congress, Senator Dole and Congressman Gingrich, to tell them, after this hard-fought campaign, that we are ready to work together to serve all the American people in a nonpartisan manner. 
 The American people sent us here to rebuild the American dream, to change the way Washington does business, to make our country work for ordinary citizens again. We've made a good start by cutting the deficit, by reducing the size of the Federal Government, by reinventing much of our Government to do more with less. We have increased our investment in education and expanded trade, and our economy has created more than five million jobs. We've also made a serious start in the fight against the terrible plague of crime and violence in this country. I remain committed to completing the work we have done.
Still, in the course of this work, there has been too much politics as usual in Washington, too much partisan conflict, too little reform of Congress and the political process. And though we have made progress, not enough people have felt more prosperous and more secure, or believe we were meeting their desires for fundamental change in the role of Government in their lives. With the Democrats in control of both the White House and the Congress, we were held accountable yesterday, and I accept my share of the responsibility in the result of the elections.
When the Republican Party assumes leadership in the House and in the Senate, they will also have a larger responsibility for acting in the best interest of the American people. I reach out to them today and I ask them to join me in the center of the public debate where the best ideas for the next generation of American progress must come. Democrats and Republicans have often joined together when it was clearly in the national interest.
For example, they have often chosen to put international affairs above politics. I urge them to do so again by passing the GATT agreement this year. Our prosperity depends upon it. And there can be no compromise when the national interest and the livelihood of American households are at stake.
Last night the voters not only voted for sweeping changes, they demanded that a more equally divided Congress work more closely together with the President for the interests of all the American people. So I hope that we can do that on GATT, and that by doing so we will pave the way for further cooperation on welfare reform and on health care reform, on a continued investment in our people's educational opportunities and the continued strength of our economy.
We must also take more steps to restore the people's faith in our political institutions and agree that, further, in the best tradition of our own foreign policy that politics will continue to stop at the water's edge.
To those who believe we must keep moving forward, I want to say again I will do everything in my power to reach out to the leaders and the members of this new Congress. It must be possible to make it a more effective, more functioning institution. It must be possible for us to give our people a Government that is smaller, that is more effective, that reflects both our interests and our values.
But to those who would use this election to turn us back, let me say this: I will do all in my power to keep anyone from jeopardizing this economic recovery by taking us back to the policies that failed us before. I will still work for those things that make America strong -- strong families, better education, safer streets, more high-paying jobs, a more prosperous and peaceful world. There is too much at stake for our children and our future to do anything else.
Well, a lot has changed since yesterday, but what hasn't changed is the reason I was sent here and the reason the members of the Congress will be sent here: to restore the American dream and to make this country work, this Government work, this city work for the interests of ordinary Americans again.
That is what the American people expect of us.
Last night they said they were not satisfied with the progress we have made. They said the Democrats had been in control of the White House and the Congress, they said they were going to make a change, and they did make a change. But they still want the same goal. I pledge today to work with all the members of the Congress, and especially the new Republican leadership, to achieve that goal. If they will work with me -- and they have pledged to do so today -- then we can make great progress for this country. We should be optimistic and we should work to make that optimism real.
 
Taking Responsibility
 
 
Q. Not a single Republican incumbent lost in any race for governor, House or Senate, while the Democratic party, your party, suffered its worst losses in four decades. Do you view this as a repudiation of you, or as another common denominator in this election that we're missing?
A. I think that I have some responsibility for it. I'm the President. I'm the leader of the efforts that we have made in the last two years, and to whatever extent that we didn't do what the people wanted us to do or they were not aware of what we had done, I must certainly bear my share of responsibility, and I accept that. There will be a lot of you doing exit surveys asking the American people what they meant and said. But what I think they said is they still don't like what they see when they watch us working here. They still haven't felt the positive results of things that have been done here that they agree with when they hear about them but they don't feel them.
They're still not sure that we understand what they expect the role of Government to be. I think they want a smaller Government that gives them better value for their dollar, that reflects both their interests and their values, that is not a burden to them but that empowers them. That's what I have tried to do, but I don't think they believe we're there yet by a long shot. They want us to do more.
I went back today and read my announcement speech for President, and I said in that speech that the job of Government was to create opportunity and then to expect citizens to assume the responsibility to make the most of that opportunity. I think that's about where the American people are. They don't think we've done that yet, and the only thing I think they knew to do yesterday was to try to make a change in the people who were in control and who had been. And I regret that some of the people who lost are people who made this a lot better country and who will always, when the history books are written, get the credit they deserve in the hindsight for helping to make the American people more secure.
I don't believe the American people were saying, "We're sorry the deficit has been reduced; we're sorry the size of Government has been reduced; we're sorry you've taken a tough stand on crime; we're sorry you're expanding trade." I don't believe that. I don't think they were disagreeing with a lot of the specifics.
Q. Do you think you would have survived if you were on the ballot yesterday?
A. Well, some Democrats did. I'd like to think I would have because I believe that I would have been a ferocious defender of what we have done.
 
Contract With America
 
 
Q. What do you think this does for your expected bid for re-election? And how will you deal with Contract For America if there are proposed cuts in Social Security and Medicare, veterans' benefits, the whole nine yards?
A. We've got plenty of time to worry about the next election. The American people are sick of the one they just had, and they want to get away from politics for a while. I think we should think about the people, their interests; I think we should say, what message were they sending us and what are we going to do about it, and how can we pull this country together, how can the Democrats and the Republicans in the Congress, and the White House and the Republican leadership work together in a nonpartisan way to push this country forward?
Now, on the contract, there are some things in that contract that I like. I hope the Congress will give me the line-item veto and do it quickly. If they do, we'll bring this deficit down even more quickly. I hope that we will have aggressive efforts to work together on welfare reform. I hope we will be able to still reduce several areas of Federal spending and continue this whole reinventing Government effort to do more with less.
The issue in the contract is what it has always been. I do not believe that we can afford to go back to the days of exploding deficits, which I believe would lead to a weaker economy, to lost jobs, and to a more difficult future for ourselves and our children.
So, the question there is how will all this be paid for? I do not believe -- now many Republicans in the campaign said they did not believe that we should cut Social Security or Medicare. So if we can't cut Social Security or Medicare if we must maintain the world's strongest defense which I think -- and the Republican leadership and I are strongly in agreement upon -- then what else are we going to do? And that will be a challenge.
 
Compromises Ahead?
 
 
Q. Do you think you'll be able to compromise with them on that?
A. I'm not going to compromise on my convictions, what makes America strong. We are stronger today but we have more strength to get. We have to have -- I'll say again what I think makes our country strong. Strong families, better education, safer streets, more high-paying jobs, a Government that reflects their values and the interests of the American people, and work to make a world that's more prosperous and peaceful.
Those are the principles on which I do not intend to compromise. But I want to work with them. Look, let me give you just one example. I have always wanted to make the tax code more fair. The tax code is more fair today than it was when I took office. We did cut income tax rates for families with incomes of up to $27,000. They want to go further than that. I would like to go further on that. The question is, how far can we go?
Can we focus on working families with children, how are we going to pay for it? We have to answer now, the details. And in large measure that is a question that can only be answered by some sort of partnership, and by getting their views. And again, I say, let's give them a day or two to enjoy their victory and then they'll have an opportunity to work for it.
 
The Federal Budget
 
 
Q. Would you support a tax cut, such as they propose in their Contract With America, of $500 for every family under $200,000 income if you don't think it's paid for? Or would you veto it? Would you get into that kind of confrontational mode with them on something specific?
A. They have to have a chance to look at the budget now. When you're in opposition you can be an advocate entirely, and you can put out ideas you think are good.
I hope we can find some way to continue to improve the fairness of the tax code and to help middle-class working Americans. When I was trying to reduce the deficit in 1993, and make the tax code fairer, we had to stop at $27,000 in income for families with children, working families with children, in our tax relief. I think perhaps we can go further, but I don't want to get into a lot of the details today. I'll just say that if we do this, we need to pay for it. We don't need to explode the deficit again.
 
Welfare and Health Care
 
 
Q. Government intervention seems to be what a lot of the voters ruled out, voted against. Are you willing to scale back your expectations in areas like health care and welfare reform, or are you going to go in with plans that look like the ones you had this past year and wait for them to compromise, or will you go to them with something less than you had asked before?
A. First of all, let me say if you look at the welfare reform issue, let's take that first. I sent them a bill last March that is quite similar to one that several Republicans themselves have proposed. I don't think anybody would characterize it as a Government-intervention bill. It's a bill designed to move people from welfare to work after a certain set time, to have tougher child-support enforcement, to provide education and training and support for people who go into the workplace so they can know their children are all right. I think there is over 80 percent support in this country among Americans of both parties, among people of all races and backgrounds, for doing something like this. So I think we will get an agreement.
On the health care issue, I will concede that by the time the folks who were characterizing our program had finished with it -- and one of your publications said that they thought about $300 million had been spent in lobbying against the health care reform -- it looked like a Government program designed to solve the problem by restricting the choices of the American people and injecting the Government more into health care. That is not what I want to do.
And I will concede this. I have got to find a way to reassure the American people that if they like what they've got, they can keep it.
But let me say, I remain committed to solving the health care problem. Last year another million Americans, almost all of them in working families, lost their health insurance. We have more and more people -- I talk to them all the time when I go out in the country -- small businesspeople and others who have health insurance that is so limited because their co-pays and deductibles are so high that all they've really got insurance against is losing their home if they get sick. So I remain committed to finding a way to keep Americans from losing their health insurance if they change jobs or someone in their family gets sick, to controlling the cost of increases in health care by market mechanisms, by -- to providing ways for people in small businesses and self-employed people to buy health insurance at the same rates that those of us in Government or big employers -- working for big employers can do it.
 
Whitewater Inquiry
 
 
Q. Are you especially concerned that Senator Alfonse D'Amato, if he becomes chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and Representative Jim Leach, if he becomes chairman of the House Banking Committee, will now intensify their Whitewater investigations?
A. No, I have said I would cooperate with the Congress, and I will continue to cooperate with the Congress, as I have.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton turning to answer one more question as he left the press conference. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1578 words

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: VOTERS;
'It's Like a Call to Arms, Which the Democrats Will Ignore at Their Peril'

 BODY:

Howard Baker
Former Republican senator from Tennessee, who is now a lawyer in private practice.
This is unprecedented in my memory. It is important to point out that it was not just anti-incumbency, since not a single incumbent Republican in the House or Senate has been defeated. 
 But the country is in gentle rebellion, and I think it has been now for the last two or three election cycles. By that I mean the long-term rising of the anger. People are focusing their anger right now on a few specific things, but mostly they are just expressing their dissatisfaction with the existing order.
I don't know where they are going, and I don't think they know where, either. But what frightens me, is that if we do not address their feelings, they may develop a tendency to savage our institutions.
In effect, the country has given the Republicans a chance, and in two years they are going to be re-examining it. But for now, it is a time for exhilaration for the Republicans.
 
George S. McGovern
Former senator and Democratic Presidential candidate in 1972, who is now president of the Middle East Policy Council in Washington.
One of the basic problems is that while the people in the top 20 percent of the American public are benefiting from the growth in the economy -- from deficit reduction, the fairly stable growth rate, the stock market being steady, inflation steady -- for everyone else, 80 percent of the public, including the middle class, are not doing as well as they were a few years ago.
We are told the election is going to result in less government and reduced spending, except for the military, and in tougher stands on welfare, and so on. Even some tax reduction. But I don't think that addresses the problem that I have just described.
And my guess is that if that is the direction we go in, that the Republican time will come in a couple of years down the road.
 
Shelby Foote
Historian and novelist.
I hope it's not going back to the situation of Andrew Johnson -- you know they almost ended up impeaching him. I simply hope it doesn't happen. They were out to get him, and they damn near got him. I hope this attitude is not what their attitude was. It wasn't that they were different parties, although they were. The real problem is that the Congress was absolutely furious that they had crossed him -- they only missed him by one vote.
Of course, they [the Republicans] are going to have to accept some responsibility for what happens in the next two years -- especially if they try to balance the budget. They're going to have an awful lot of problems. Any plans I've heard don't include reducing the deficit. The best benefit I can find is that Clinton has learned something from it and that he will come back with a better approach, although it's going to be a lot more difficult than it was a short time back.
 
Doris Kearns Goodwin
Historian and author of "No Ordinary Time, Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt."
It's like a call to arms, which the Democrats will ignore at their peril. The time has come for those who still believe, as most Democrats do, that the government has a positive role to play in the lives of the people to re-define what that role is, and to communicate that definition with a passion and a conviction that's equal to the kind of conviction that the Republicans seem to have evoked in their call for no government or less government or smaller government.
Somehow, the Republicans have captured that insurgent feeling against all politicians in general. And now it's their turn to try to prove that their solutions for the complex problems of America -- the balanced budget, lower taxes, somehow magically reducing the deficit, and welfare reform and harsher measures on crime -- will actually work.
 
Alan Brinkley
Professor of history at Columbia University.
The magnitude of it surprised me. I had a bad feeling about it, especially in the past week. I'm still trying to digest it myself. I think suddenly the Republicans have to deal with some problems. It's very different being the majority party. I'm certainly not prepared to say anything but that this is a triumph for the Republicans.
Now they'll start to be held accountable. If the mood in the nation is as angry and poisonous as it has appeared, the Republicans have a big job ahead. Politics is a process of trying to win power -- and they won it and that's the benefit.
The Republican Party in particular has not in recent years had much of a positive agenda. It seems to want power to prevent things from happening instead of to do things. The benefit for the Republicans is that nothing will happen in the next two years that they don't want to happen. It's hard to imagine that they're going to be able to transform government. But they've got all sorts of opportunities to produce embarrassments for the Clinton Administration.
 
Fred Greenstein
Historian at Princeton University.
I think this is a little bit like what doctors call iatrogenic -- medically induced illness. The attempts to diagnose the political system have contributed to the malaise. Crime rates are lower; the economy is not bad. But the word has been out and anyone who consumes the network news hears day after day what a terrible time people are having, how everyone is angry, how politicians are corrupt, and how incumbents are bad.
I think if you're a conservative, the new situation is good. If you believe in positive government, then not much is going to come out of this. It's possible there may be some paradoxes on things like health care where it will be in everyone's interest to put together some modest reform. But basically I think you can expect a period of statis and position-taking.
 
Julian Bond
Former Georgia legislator, who is now aprofessor of government at The American University in Washington and a professor of history at the University of Virginia.
It's the Democrats' inability, which is fairly longstanding, to promote their message in an aggressive way, and to set the agenda in an aggressive way. I think it's just an American discontent with some important issues, like crime and immigration, that have a slight, or more pronounced, depending on who you are, racial cast to them. The combination of all three of these things produced this staggering result.
We'll have a chance now to see whether they [the Republicans] can say yes to anything, instead of just saying no. And I think they are going to be subjected, I hope, to the same kind of intense negative scrutiny that the President and the Democrats have faced.
 
Pete Dexter
Author of "Deadwood" and "Paris Trout."
I think there's a general unease. I think that with Clinton, there's something there that people essentially don't trust, and I think for very good reason. I think this is a reaction to the personality, more than the direction the country's going or all that stuff about change. It comes from the very top of the Democratic party. I can't figure it any other way. You look at the candidates, some of the right people lost . . . Huffington, North. It wasn't just simply a mandate to get all Democrats out, though that seemed to be the theme of it. Where Republicans lost, in California and Virginia, is because of the people they ran, as opposed to the people running against them. When somebody was running who was perceived as slick or dishonest or distasteful, then that person was rejected, too.
What I woke up this morning thinking is that we would be seeing that much more Newt Gingrich, and I don't consider that a big plus. I think maybe the good part of it is it goes back and forth.
 
David Halberstam
Pulitzer Prize-winning author and journalist.
The country is in the midst of profound economic change. We're going from an essential blue-collar economy and relative easy affluence to a time where we're in a international economy and the blue-collar jobs are disappearing, and where in many homes there is more anxiety and more and more the middle class depends on education. These are changes that have been going on for decades, but the political consequences are just beginning to surface.
Also, there has always been a "they" in American politics, and for a long time the "they" were the communists. Even though the Cold War is over, the instinct to look for a "they" is still strong, but now it's switched from the communists to being someone here domestically like immigrants.
 
Michael J. Sandel
Professor of government at Harvard University.
This election was haunted by the fear that we are losing control of the forces that govern our lives, that the moral fabric of community is unraveling around us, and that our political institutions are unable to respond. The issues of crime, immigration and welfare stand for these larger fears.
The next two years are likely to deepen these frustrations. Democrats and Republicans will struggle to avoid being held responsible for the likely impasse, so as not to be the target of the next round of voter wrath. But if the deeper problems go unaddressed, and if disenchantment is compounded by economic downturn, darker scenarios become imaginable. There is the danger that the politics of protest may find its next expression in the "man on horseback," an authoritarian figure who offers a way beyond impasse, above politics, and beyond the messy, often frustrating restraints of constitutional government.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: CONGRESS
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
On Capitol Hill, a World Is Turned Upside Down

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The Capitol was an eerie place today, quiet and void of its usual bustle and the famous faces who orchestrate it. They are home either nursing wounds or nurturing new-found importance.
Left behind were their staffs -- Capitol Hill's permanent denizens, who discovered today that some were more permanent than others, their fates largely contingent on the electoral fortunes of their patrons. 
 Already, the word is out: members of the House and Senate who lost elections on Tuesday must vacate their offices -- and dismiss their staffs -- by Dec. 15. Democrats who won re-election might be able to keep their same personal offices, but those who headed committees or subcommittees must turn over their grand chairmen's suites to their Republican successors.
Committee staff members are bracing for a wholesale layoff within their ranks. Not even Republican staff members are immune, not when their bosses promised an angry electorate that they would clamp down on the Government's payroll, including that of Congressional staff.
Compounding the situation, there are few places for newly unemployed Democratic staff members to go.
"There is a glut on the downtown market," said a senior Democratic staff employee, sitting in his large committee office. "The law firms, consultants, lobbying firms, the Administration -- the market is already over-bloated."
Moreover, Democratic staff members have lost an advantage intrinsic to working for the majority party. "If a Rostenkowski lost, there would be a new Democrat somewhere else who would value the skills you had developed as an aide to a prominent Democrat, and that gave you a certain marketability," said a leading Democratic House aide. "That's gone."
Another Democratic staff member pointed out: "Having experience with the Democratic Congress is not necessarily the most sterling, attractive credential you can have to sell yourself. What are you selling? Ties to the minority? Who cares? The firms downtown need Republicans who can call up Dole or Gingrich. It's a very bleak job market."
Bleak was also the pervasive mood among Democratic staff members. "People are definitely depressed," said Joel Lane, a 31-year-old legislative assistant for Representative Frank McCloskey, Democrat of Indiana, who lost his bid for re-election. "It's not something you get over overnight. You have to realize that this is the reality for the future."
Republicans seemed sobered by the magnitude of their new responsibility, or by the thought that unbridled glee could come back to haunt them. Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said at a news conference this morning that his wife had cautioned him "not to gloat."
It is unclear just how drastic the cuts will be among the committee staffs. The House has about 2,250 employees on its 23 full committees; the Senate has about 1,700 on its 20 full and select committees.
Newt Gingrich, the Speaker-in-waiting, has talked about cutting the entire House committee staff by one-third. For Democrats, those cuts could be even more severe.
"You can't regulate major industries without staff," said a Democratic aide who seemed unaware that that was just what the Republicans had been promising.
In the past, the District of Columbia Government sent staff to the Hill to help newly unemployed workers file unemployment claims. Mike Heny, director of the House Finance Office, said he had heard rumors, which were not confirmed, that the District would again send such help and hold a seminar.
One person still wearing a smile was a member of the permanent Capitol Hill security force. "They come and go," he said. "And I'll still be here when the new ones leave."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

COMPANY: REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE (74%); DEMOCRATIC CONGRESS (65%); 

ORGANIZATION: REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE (74%); DEMOCRATIC CONGRESS (65%);

HEADLINE: The Election's Fallout for the Economy;
Trade Vote Is First Test For Victors

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Newly victorious Republicans and a humbled Clinton Administration face their first big test even before the new Congress takes over in January, in a scheduled vote after Thanksgiving on whether to approve a long-delayed world trade pact.
Both parties say they support the 123-nation agreement hammered out under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which is known as GATT and is considered to be one of the most important economic initiatives of the last decade. But the two sides still find themselves at odds as soon as they start discussing its details. 
 While GATT will set an international framework for American business, the immediate post-election fallout for the domestic marketplace will revolve around new personalities rather than radically new policies. That reflects the changes in the leadership of several key Congressional committees and the potential repercussions from a shift to a Republican-controlled legislature.
Picking the winners and losers is risky. In general, health care, telecommunications and heavy industry stand to benefit from a trend toward less regulation. But the military industry and banking may not gain as much. [Page D7.]
For business as a whole, the attention in the new Congress will focus on whether Washington faces two more years of gridlock or whether the White House can find compromises with Republicans on issues like taxation of capital gains and budget policy. But those issues will take months to settle, if not longer.
At issue immediately, however, is the GATT accord, which advocates say would raise United States exports by $20 billion by the end of the decade. The failure to approve the pact would undercut President Clinton's case that he is creating jobs in the United States by pressing free trade agreements in Asia and Latin America.
For weeks his Cabinet members have insisted -- especially to foreign governments that have delayed their own approval of the pact until Congress acted -- that passage was a sure thing. The objections, they have said, will fade away immediately after the elections.
Congress meets in a special session after Thanksgiving to consider GATT.
Today that confidence seemed a bit shaken. As Mr. Clinton prepared to leave for an economic summit meeting in Indonesia with Asian leaders, he appealed to the Republican Congress to put international affairs above politics and approve GATT, saying, "Our prosperity depends on it."
But doubts crept into the voices of Administration officials who fear the vote could get hung up in the Senate on a budget technicality and then be pushed over to the next and more conservative Congress.
"People are real nervous about it," one senior Administration official said.
Still, most officials argued the opposite publicly, saying that the expansion of GATT would be a chance for the new Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, and other Republicans to show that they are striving for bipartisanship, even if the mood does not last long.
"If we can have both the Democrats and the Republicans working together to get GATT passed, it could set, certainly, a better framework for the next session," Leon E. Panetta, President Clinton's chief of staff, said this afternoon. Mr. Dole discussed the issue with Mr. Clinton by telephone this morning.
But as Mr. Clinton's chief economic advisers were acknowledging even before the magnitude of the Democratic loss was known, their ability to press for additional economic initiatives beyond the trade accord -- from more deficit reduction to new jobs programs -- will be severely limited.
"We've got to recalculate the agenda," Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown said several days ago. "There is a lot of implementing of existing programs that is within our grasp, a lot you can do from the executive branch. But you have to pare down expectations on new activities."
Mr. Clinton implicitly acknowledged during a news conference this afternoon that outside of efforts to promote jobs through international trade, his economic options were constrained. As an economic tool, fiscal policy is nearly dead. So many areas of the national budget have been declared untouchable that there is little money left to affect the economy, except around the edges.
For example, while both parties are talking about tax cuts, both sides have steered clear of the kind of spending cuts that would pay for them. The Republicans probably will press for new economic estimates to support their supply-side arguments that tax cuts would eventually produce new revenue and thus pay for themselves.
The first step in obtaining those estimates, Republicans said today, would probably include replacing the head of the Congressional budget office, Robert D. Reischauer, with an economist more likely to provide the Republicans with the kind of statistics they want to see. Mr. Reischauer's term expires in January.
For his part, Mr. Clinton said today that he was committed to continued cuts in the national deficit, the one move that brought the bond markets to his side.
"I do not believe that we can afford to go back to the days of exploding deficits," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference this afternoon. Even the trade agreement has a budget implication, and that may be the complication that trips up its passage.
The key to the legislation is the reduction of tariffs and other trade barriers worldwide. That will largely benefit American exporters, because foreign nations, by and large, have far higher tariffs than does the United States.
But the loss of tariff revenue will cost roughly $11 billion during the next five years. While passage seems assured in the House -- where the future Speaker, Newt Gingrich, has already voiced his support -- Senate rules call for passage by at least 60 votes if the bill will reduce revenues during the next 10 years.
By the White House's count, there are at least 50 votes for GATT, but perhaps not 60. The budget issue could provide cover for those who object to other provisions of the bill, a category that includes consumer advocates like Ralph Nader, labor unions like the International Union of Electrical Workers and small businesses that fear competition from overseas multinationals.

HEADLINE: America Online Buys 2 Internet Companies

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
America Online Inc., facing a challenge from the Microsoft Corporation in the market for on-line computer services, said yesterday that it had acquired two small Internet service companies for a total of more than $34 million in stock.
The companies acquired by America Online, Navisoft Inc. and Booklink Technologies Inc., would become the core of America Online's recently formed Internet Services Company. The companies, which are start-ups that have generated no revenue to date, make software that allow businesses and consumers to more easily use the Internet, especially the rapidly growing area known as the World Wide Web. 
 Some of the software would be incorporated into America Online's own consumer software, allowing the company's 1.2 million on-line services customers to gain access to the World Wide Web, which is increasingly being used by businesses to market goods and services to computer users.
The acquired software would also be used as a cornerstone for a new on-line service that would focus on business applications for the Internet.
"It's a brilliant move on A.O.L.'s part," said Mary Modahl, senior analyst at Forrester research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. "Consumers are not going to buy more than one information service. They will go to the place that has the widest door to what's available in the on-line universe. By adding Web access, America Online will have the widest open door."
"It's an aggressive move to counter what A.O.L. sees as a looming threat from Microsoft and is clearly timed to blunt the impact of Microsoft's announcement of Marvel next week," said Adam Schoenfeld, news director of Jupiter Research Inc. of New York. Marvel is the code name for the rival on-line information service that Microsoft is planning to introduce next year along with its next generation of the Windows operating system.
America Online's stock has been pummeled in the last two days, losing about 10 percent of its value, in reaction to investor fears about the competitive impact of Microsoft's Marvel. Yesterday, America Online's shares dropped $3, to $63.25, in Nasdaq trading. On Tuesday, the shares fell $6.75.
In acquiring Booklink Technologies of Wilmington, Mass., for $30 million in stock, America Online would gain control of prototype software called Internetworks, which is scheduled to be formally introduced next week at the Comdex computer trade show in Las Vegas.
Advance copies of Internetworks have been praised by some testers as superior to existing programs for browsing the World Wide Web, including Mosaic and its variations. Besides Web access, the software includes a full range of Internet services, including access to electronic mail, discussion groups and a variety of file searching and transfer tools. It is said to work especially well with the common computer modems and telephone lines used by consumers.
Booklinks is a wholly owned subsidiary of CMG Information Services.
In the second facet of the deal, America Online would acquire Navisoft for 65,000 shares of stock, which at current levels would be valued at slightly more than $4 million. Navisoft's president, David C. Cole, a venture capitalist who was formerly president of the Ashton-Tate Company and Ziff Communications, is to become president of America Online's Internet Services Company, the company said.

HEADLINE: Fewest U.S. Farms Since 1850: 1.9 Million

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Continuing a trend that began six decades ago, the number of American farms has dipped below two million for the first time since before the Civil War, the Census Bureau said today.
The bureau, which produces a farm census every five years, counted 1,925,300 farms in the United States in 1992, the lowest number since 1850. The decline has been steady since 1935, when the total number of farms peaked at 6.8 million as the Depression began the migration off the land and into the cities. 
 The number of farms continues to shrink despite Thomas Jefferson's view that "the small landowners are the most precious part of society." But at the same time farms are also ever more efficient and productive.
The Census Bureau defines a farm as any entity that produces or has the ability to produce $1,000 a year worth of agricultural products, like beef, hogs, poultry, grains, fruits or vegetables.
Rural demographers say such a liberal definition of what constitutes a farm may overstate the number of working farms. When only working farms are considered, experts in the agricultural economy say the abiding long-term trend has led to increase consolidation of agricultural holdings into fewer and fewer hands.
The bureau reported that while the number of farms and the amount of farm acerage dropped between 1987 and 1992, crop sales rose by 28 percent. There are fewer farms, said Jorge Garcia-Pratts, an agricultural statistician at the Census Bureau, "but they are producing much more."
Along with continued increases in agricultural productivity, the new study highlighted sweeping structural changes in the rural landscape.
For example, the report noted, total farm acreage declined to 282 million acres in 1992 from 296 million acres five years before. Agricultural experts say the decrease reflects, in part, the increasing amounts of rural land being taken for residential or recreational purposes as people continue to flee cities and suburbs close to cities.
"Crop land in the U.S. in areas that have subtropical winters -- the Florida peninsula, the lower Rio Grande Valley, Southern California -- all of those areas are having very rapid population growth, almost runaway population growth," said Calvin Beale, senior demographer at the Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service.
The report said cotton production was shifting from semi-arid areas of California, Arizona, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas back to its historic home in the Mississippi Delta and other Southeastern states. In part, experts say, this shift is caused by the diversion of water from agricultural uses to residential and recreational ones in the West and Southwest.
Despite these pressures, and even though farmers continue to operate on thin profit margins, experts say, they have rebounded strongly from the dire financial conditions of the mid-1980's, when their debt soared, commodity surpluses increased, prices plummeted and the number of foreclosures reached their highest level since the Depression.
"General economic indicators are much better," said Keith Collins, chief economist at the Department of Agriculture. "The number of farms that are vulnerable to bankruptcy is much lower; the debt-to-asset ratio of agriculture as a whole is much improved; farmers debt levels are down substantially, and their assets have gone up, particularly land."
One sign of improved financial security on farms is the decrease in the number of acres placed in Federal commodity programs, which pay farmers to leave cropland fallow. In 1992, farmers placed 7 million acres in these programs, down nearly 84 percent from the 43 million acres left idle in 1987.
But if farmers are more prosperous, the consolidation of cropland into fewer and fewer farms has meant that fewer and fewer people are entering into the profession.
The report indicated that the average age of farm operators increased to 53.3 years in 1992, from 52 years in 1987. Mr. Beale, the Department of Agriculture demographer, said that trend was a result of the declining birth rate among farm families and the economic upheavals of the 1980's.
"It's the combination of a smaller supply of younger adults to draw from and from many of them being disillusioned with making a financial success out of farming, given the problems they grew up with in the 1980's."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK STATE
GIULIANI;
His Man Unhorsed, Giuliani Confronts His Political Plight

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Having gambled and lost in his dramatic endorsement of Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has now been left needing millions of dollars of assistance from the state but facing a Republican governor who owes him nothing and drew little of his support from New York City.
In a sign of his political plight, the Mayor admitted yesterday that he had twice called Governor-elect George E. Pataki since his victory, but had not heard back. 
 Just four days after he assailed Mr. Pataki and his patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, by saying that "if the D'Amato-Pataki crew ever get control, ethics will be trashed," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he wanted the Governor-elect to know that "I want him to succeed" and "want him to be as successful a governor as he can be because it will help the city of New York."
At a news conference at City Hall, he expressed confidence that his fierce battle against Mr. Pataki's election would not affect how his fellow Republican dealt with the city, though he seemed more tentative about what the political repurcussions would be for him personally, as members of his party vowed vengeance.
"I don't see any future for him in his own party," said Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island, once one of Mr. Giuliani's closest allies and now an implaccable foe. "The only thing that makes sense is that he becomes a Democrat."
In City Hall, it was the first day of a new relationship between a Republican Mayor and a Republican Governor that many other political officials predicted could be as stormy as the notorious feud between Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Mayor John V. Lindsay. But while his aides appeared exhausted and glum, Mr. Giuliani acted like a man at peace with himself, saying he would not have changed his decision to endorse Mr. Cuomo.
He even showing flashes of galllows humor. Asked if he expected to be hatcheted in the back by his fellow Republicans, Mr. Giuliani, who was standing alone at a lectern, laughed and said: "That's a very comforting thought. I do notice there's no one standing up here with me."
Mr. Giuliani said the responsibilities of being Governor would cause "any good and decent person -- and George Pataki is that -- to understand that you have to work together -- and he does understand that -- and whatever political consequences there are -- are things that we can only speculate about."
At a separate news conference, Mr. Pataki said he would not take retribution on the city, which is the economic engine of the state. "I have pointed out time and again, first that I love this city," he said, "second that I understand how important this city is to the entire state, and third that I am going to be Governor for all the people of this state."
But many Republicans noted that there were ways for Mr. Pataki, Mr. D'Amato and the Republican leaders now controlling Congress to make sure that Mr. Giuliani never gets to share in any of the political credit for any grants or projects or benefits they steer to New York City. One senior Republican leader said of Mr. Pataki: "He's going to make sure the city gets its fair share, but that doesn't mean he won't take it out on Giuliani personally."
The official, who asked not to be identified, also said that what Mr. Pataki considers a fair share may not coincide with Mr. Giuliani's idea of what is fair. Mr. Pataki said yesterday that his pledge to cut taxes and spending would be the cornerstone of his administration and that he would not back away from his pledge to cut state income taxes by 25 percent over four years.
But the Governor-elect indicated that he was willing to look at proposals Mr. Giuliani made in his latest plan to close a $1.1 billion budget gap that call for the state to continue paying its share of programs financed jointly by the city and the state -- even as the city cuts its share. And while not embracing the takeover of local Medicaid costs that could solve the city's structural deficit, Mr. Pataki said he would be seeking to achieve cost containment in Medicaid spending and to find ways to reduce welfare costs.
One Giuliani aide said the true test of what Mr. Pataki's election would mean for New York City's already precarious finances would come when he submits his first budget next year. The official, who requested anonymity, said that if the Republican Governor moves forward with the first phase of his tax cut plan, it could mean across-the-board reductions in assistance to localities in everything from mass-transit aid to funds for education.
Mr. Giuliani, meanwhile, moved to shore up other alliances. He spoke to H. Carl McCall, the Demcratic State Comptroller he had opposed during the campaign as overly political, and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat who has often been hostile to Mr. Giuliani's initiatives. He praised both Democrats as officials who "understand the interests of the city." Mr. Giuliani also congratulated Dennis C. Vacco, the Republican elected as state attorney general.
Jay Severin , a New York-based Republican political consultant, said that in 1997 Mr. Giuliani could face both a nuisance Republican primary and a Conservative Party challenger who could wound him in a three-way race by drawing large numbers of Italian-American and Jewish voters from Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.
On the other side of the aisle, Herman Badillo, a Democratic ally of Mr. Giuliani, said the Mayor had helped Mr. Cuomo draw a huge margin of support in the city and remained highly popular in the 5-to-1 Democratic city. And former Mayor Edward I. Koch called for Democrats to give Mr. Giuliani their own ballot line when he seeks re-election.
Mr. Giuliani said simply that the political ramifications of the election would play out over two or three years. "American politics changes so quickly now," he said, "I think all of us would be foolish to try to assume what's going to happen."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: CONNECTICUT
GOVERNOR;
Now Comes the Hardest Part: Repealing That Hateful Tax

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 9

 BODY:
On the morning after the Republican John G. Rowland was elected governor with 36 percent of the vote, he began the difficult job of broadening support for his plan to eliminate the income tax, reaching out to Democrats and independents and describing his victory as a message about the public's feelings concerning government.
"It's a mood," he said. "I think people of this country, let alone this state, want someone who will reverse the trends of the Great Society that has been around for the last 30 years." 
 But in a response being heard today in New York, Washington and beyond, the Democratic opposition here, while conciliatory, indicated it did not intend to go away quietly.
Though Republicans now control the Governor's mansion and have a majority in the Senate, the Democrats still control the House of Representatives, and Thomas D. Ritter, the House Speaker, had a few barbs for the Governor-elect. When reporters asked Mr. Ritter about repealing the income tax, he needled Mr. Rowland, saying, "Is he still for it?" And added, "Without drawing lines in the sand, I think our priority is property tax relief."
In a four-way race that splintered the electorate, Mr. Rowland made sweeping promises to cut spending and repeal the three-year-old income tax, which raises roughly one-fourth of the state's revenues.
And he takes office with a potentially fractious legislature. While the Republicans gained at least one seat in the State Senate and now command a majority, Democrats picked up at least four seats in the House of Representatives, increasing an already substantial majority.
This sets the stage for a volatile showdown in the Legislature, and by bringing the income tax back to center stage, Mr. Rowland may reopen a Pandora's Box that in 1991 provoked one of the most heated political battles in recent state history.
Still, both Mr. Rowland and Mr. Ritter said they preferred to focus on the potential for cooperation between the two parties.
Mr. Rowland said that as a member of the Legislature and Congress in the 1980's, he had a reputation of being able to work with people "on both sides of the aisle," a point that many Democrats confirm. And Mr. Ritter said that he had worked well with Mr. Rowland years ago, and said, "I'm going to be a lot nicer to John Rowland than Newt Gingrich will be to President Clinton."
Mr. Ritter pointed to the gains Democrats made in the Connecticut House.
"In the little world we live in here, we're very pleased that we picked up four or five seats," he said, adding, "We're elated about the message that voters sent to House Democrats. I'll bet you that this was one of the biggest pickups of seats of any in the country."
The political obstacles are only part of the problem Mr. Rowland faces.
The income tax this year provided $2.6 billion of the state's $9.5 billion budget. Mr. Rowland has promised to cut the 4.5 percent tax by 1 percent in 1995 and another half-percent in 1996, and then phase it out entirely over the next three years without raising any other taxes.
One of the first problems he will face is how to cut the state budget in 1995 to achieve his first goal. According to figures from the Office of Fiscal Analyis, a nonpartisan state legislative agency, the state will have a budget deficit of $430 million in 1995 that will require cuts before any reductions above and beyond that can be applied to the income tax.
And Mr. Rowland's plan has not detailed where he would find the savings for about two-thirds of the needed cuts to implement his income tax plan. In the campaign, he said that over five years, half of the $2.6 billion in lost annual revenue from the income tax would be offset by reductions in the state budget, with the other half coming from increased economic activity that would spur revenues from other taxes.
While Mr. Rowland outlined $400 million in savings, achieved in part through reorganization of state agencies and reductions in borrowing and state employee overtime, he has yet to specify how he will make another $900 million in cuts.
Harry Harris, vice president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, a business organization in Fairfield County that supported the income tax in 1991, said today, "There's a great deal of doubt whether it's possible." And he added that the group's board would be meeting Wednesday to discuss whether such a plan is even desirable.
Still, Mr. Rowland was confident today that he would have the political support to get the job done. Supporters say that the 36 percent of the vote he received Tuesday was substantial, given the four-way race. They noted that Tom Scott, an independent candidate who was a leader of the anti-income tax movement, received 11 percent of the vote, and said that much of Mr. Scott's support came at Mr. Rowland's expense.
Jonathan Pelto, the former political director of the Democratic Party, said, "Had Tom Scott not been in the race, it would have been a landslide victory for Rowland."
Mr. Rowland was upbeat about his future with the legislature. He noted that he announced his candidacy from the floor of the House earlier this year, and that his campaign pointedly avoided attacking its members.
Mr. Rowland's bipartisan efforts will be aided by his Lieutenant Governor, Jodi Rell, a 10-year veteran of the legislature, who is well respected by Democrats, and there has been a history of Republicans forming coalitions with moderate Democrats in the House.
"I think they're going to look forward to working with us," Mr. Rowland said.
Mr. Ritter seemed open to the idea, saying that both sides needed to be prepared to compromise.
Asked whether he could consider repealing the income tax, he said: "It will be a mutual discussion and if we end up somewhere in the middle, that's fine. I guess we're all going to start an interesting few years."

HEADLINE: Regulators Get Leeway In Bank Takeover Rule

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
Worried that a new accounting rule might make crises in the financial market worse, Federal bank regulators announced a narrow exception yesterday aimed at preventing unintended Federal takeovers of commercial banks.
The new rule, Financial Accounting Standard 115, will soon force banks to show the current market value of securities on their books, rather than the price at which they acquired the securities. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which is part of the Treasury Department, announced yesterday that banks would be required to follow the rule except in determining whether they retained enough capital to cover possible losses on loans and other investments. 
 The exception is important because banks and regulators had worried that a sudden plunge in financial markets could send a bank's capital below regulatory minimums. Five-year-old legislation requires the Federal Government to move quickly to take over banks and savings institutions that fall below these minimums.
Congress passed the law in response to the collapse of the savings and loan industry, in which many undercapitalized institutions stayed open for years while toting up billions of dollars in losses that taxpayers eventually covered. In recent months, bankers and Federal regulators began to worry that a dip in the market could provoke costly Federal takeovers before markets recovered or before the stricken institutions could raise new capital, such as through a sale of stock.
Most Federal banking laws require that regulators follow generally accepted accounting practices, which now include Financial Accounting Standard 115. But the five-year-old law on Federal takeovers does not explicitly require that generally accepted practices be followed, giving Federal regulators the leeway to make an exception, the Comptroller's office said.
"Under current law, incorporating F.A.S. 115 into risk-based capital could have forced bank regulators to intervene unnecessarily when temporary changes in market interest rates reduced risk-based capital below regulatory minimums," Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, said in the statement.
A regulator who insisted on anonymity said that other bank and savings regulatory agencies were likely to make the same exception in the coming months.
The banking industry welcomed the Comptroller's decision. Without the exception, regulators would have lost their flexibility in deciding when to take over an institution, said Edward Yingling, the chief lobbyist of the American Bankers Association.
"This would have, in effect, put you on an automatic pilot for regulatory purposes," he said.

HEADLINE: AT&T Gets Mexico Partner For Long-Distance Service

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Making its bid for one of the biggest prizes in the Mexican economy, the AT&T Corporation announced a $1 billion alliance today with a Mexican partner, Grupo Industrial Alfa S.A., that would provide long-distance telephone service when the present Government-approved monopoly ends in 1997.
Analysts had expected AT&T to decide to enter the expanding Mexican market, but were surprised by its selection of Alfa, an industrial group that manufactures diverse products ranging from cold-cut meats to flat steel, but has no telephone experience. 
 AT&T had been expected to choose Telefonos de Mexico, the privately run national telephone company known as Telmex.
Victor A. Pelson, executive vice president of AT&T and chairman of its global operations team, explained that negotiations with Telmex were broken off because of concern about possible regulatory problems in the United States.
The Southwestern Bell Corporation bought 10 percent of Telmex when the company was privatized in 1990. But the Federal Communications Commission bars regional phone companies in the United States from entering the long-distance market. Mr. Pelson said that because of Southwestern Bell's involvement, the F.C.C. could prohibit Telmex from providing long-distance service into the United States.
"Traffic between Mexico and the United States, that was the issue," he said.
The MCI Communications Corporation and the Sprint Corporation have also joined Mexican partners to vie for one of the treasured long-distance concessions to be granted by the Government. The GTE Corporation and Motorola Inc. have also expressed interest. But none of these would bring to the table the combination of AT&T's technological advantages and the financial resources of Alfa, which had sales in 1993 of $2.5 billion and has strategic alliances with 15 other multinational companies, including Ford Motor, Du Pont and Oscar Meyer, a unit of Philip Morris.
"Let's face it," said Jack Grubman, a telecommunications analyst at Salomon Brothers in New York. "When you take a company like AT&T, which is clearly the world's most powerful telecommunications entity with the world's most sophisticated technology, and combine it with a company like Alfa, with all its considerable financial assets, and you make it the new kid on block -- it's scary."
The exclusion of Telmex did not seem to have hurt its stock much today. Telmex shares dropped about 1 percent in Mexico and its American depository receipts closed at $56 on the New York Stock Exchange, down $1.
At a news conference here today, officials of both AT&T and Alfa said that over the next four to six years, they were prepared to invest $1 billion to create a network that would compete with Telmex in long-distance service. Alfa would own 51 percent of the new venture, and AT&T the remaining 49 percent.
Long-distance service in Mexico is seen as a lucrative market with great potential for growth as the Mexican economy expands under the North American Free Trade Agreement. Personal phone services are also expected to grow as more Mexicans can afford telephones. Mexico now has 8 lines for each 100 inhabitants, AT&T said, compared with 55 lines in the United States. AT&T said the number of lines in Mexico could triple by 2000.
Mexican regulators have not yet set out all the criteria for selecting long-distance competitors. But analysts say the Government could effectively control the number of companies by demanding a high level of technological expertise or what would become a multibillion-dollar entrance fee.
Such prospects have not deterred AT&T officials. "I can't imagine that any entrance requirements would be too restrictive for us to enter the market," Mr. Pelson of AT&T said.
The chief executive officer of Alfa, Dionisio Garza Medina, said he expected the Government to select the winning long-distance bidders by the end of the first quarter of 1995. He said Alfa had planned to bid for the Telmex concession when the company was privatized in 1990, but decided instead to revamp its own basic businesses.
Three years and more than $1.5 billion later, Mr. Garza Medina said, his company is looking for investments in long-term, high-growth sectors like telecommunications.
Berge Ayvazian, a telecommunications industry analyst at the Yankee Group, a market research firm in Boston, said the Alfa-AT&T alliance showed new boldness on the part of the American company, which is trying to become a force in the telecommunications markets in several other developing countries.
"This is just the first shoe that you'll see dropped regarding the rest of Latin America," Mr. Ayvazian said.


GRAPHIC: Though Alfa is far from a household name in the United States, it is one of Mexico's largest industrial corporations, with 22,500 employees and $2.49 billion in sales in 1993. Its ambitions and clout in its home market can be discerned in the alliances its four business groups have forged with leading foreigh companies.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Gain Despite Rate Threat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were higher yesterday for the second consecutive session on a stronger dollar and optimism that Republican gains would help the fixed-income market.
Prices of United States securities started rising overnight as European investors interpreted the election results to mean that Republicans would provide a more favorable environment for the financial markets. 
 But the election results are not likely to prevent the Federal Reserve from raising short-term interest rates next Tuesday, when the Fed's policy-making group, the Federal Open market Committee, meets, traders said.
In New York, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond settled up 5/32 , to 932/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 8.11 percent from 8.12 percent on Tuesday.
"The bond market itself was firm all day," said Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "And I believe we've reached a point in interest rates where the the shorter maturities are attractive enough to draw portfolio managers out to buy longer maturities."
An auction of 10-year notes was well received yesterday but it failed to push the market higher. The sale lacked the strong demand seen in Tuesday's auction of three-year notes. The $12 billion auction of 10-year notes drew an average yield of 7.96 percent, just above the 7.955 percent traders expected. The yield suggested that investors wanted to be compensated more for buying these securities in a bear market, so dealers repriced them a little cheaper.
The only major economic report yesterday had little impact on the bond market. The Labor Department reported that third-quarter nonfarm productivity rose at an annual rate of 2.7 percent in the third quarter. The figure showed a larger-than-expected rebound after a revised 2.1 percent decline in the second quarter. Labor costs rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in the latest quarter, which was mildly positive news for the bond market.
Ahead of the auction there was a little nervousness at the prospect of selling a 10-year note with a return below 8 percent. The when-issued yield rallied to 7.93 percent in London and had only backed off 7.95 percent in early trading here, still well below the 8.05 percent yield earlier this week.
New York City priced $703 million of tax-exempt general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch. And in an unusual move, underwriters were given approval by the city to extended the pre-marketing retail order period.
It allowed the underwriters to first tap the retail sector and than approach institutional investors having sold over $300 million of the financing. With a good portion sold, institutionals felt comfortable in bidding more aggressively.
Bonds due in 1996 through 2005 -- representing the short end -- drew very good retail demand, while the middle maturities saw good institutional demand and the longer maturities saw good demand from both.
Underwriters priced the issue to yield from 7.10 percent for a bond due in 2006 to 7.45 percent for one with a maturity date of 2011. The longer-term bonds were offered with a maximum yield of 7.55 percent for a bond due in 2020, while another due in 2016 was priced to yield 7.52 percent and another due in 2013 was priced to yield 7.48 percent.
The issue is rated Baa1 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by Standard & Poor's and Fitch Investors Service.

HEADLINE: Productivity In Business Shows Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Business productivity rose in the third quarter as American workers put in long hours and labor costs held steady, Labor Department figures showed today.
Nonfarm productivity increased 2.7 percent at an annual rate in the third quarter after falling by 2.1 percent during the second quarter, the first decline since the first quarter of 1993. 
 "Good productivity growth is going to help keep down labor costs, and any acceleration in inflation will be modest," said Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Money Watch in New York.
The Labor Department's report measures the time, effort and cost of producing goods and services. Higher productivity suggests businesses are being efficient and keeping costs under control.
Labor costs, which make up more than half of production costs, increased just one-tenth of 1 percent in the third quarter while the implicit price deflator, a measure of inflation, rose a modest 1.9 percent.
Still, workers who have managed to hang onto their jobs as companies curtailed operations have been pushed to work longer hours without major pay increases. Hourly compensation, adjusted for inflation, fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter after dropping 2 percent in the second quarter. It was the fifth decrease in seven quarters.
The strains from longer workweeks are already starting to show. Earlier this week, for example, General Motors workers at a Janesville, Wis., truck plant voted to strike unless more workers were hired. Similar complaints earlier this year led to a brief strike at a G.M. plant in Flint, Mich.
Today's report also showed that manufacturing productivity climbed 5.3 percent during the third quarter after rising 5.7 percent in the second quarter.
By category, unit labor costs for nonfarm businesses edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in the third quarter after increasing 2.9 percent during the second quarter.
The number of hours worked increased by 1.2 percent in the third quarter -- the 10th consecutive increase -- after rising by 5.5 percent in the second quarter. "We're seeing record levels of overtime in manufacturing," said Norm Williams, an economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Silver Prices Fall Sharply On Fear of Interest Rate Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Silver prices fell sharply yesterday as investors eyed a strengthening dollar and the possibility of an interest rate increase next week.
Declines in energy and wheat prices helped drag the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities down 0.76 point, to 233.21. 
 On the Commodity Exchange of New York, silver for December delivery fell 10.7 cents, to $5.118 an ounce, a level not seen since the metal traded at $5.10 on Aug. 16. The December gold contract slipped 30 cents, to $384.50 an ounce.
Precious metals have been hampered in recent days by uncertainty over just how far the Federal Reserve Board may go next week in trying to curb inflation. Some analysts predict interest rates will be increased half a percentage point.
Investors have historically bought precious metals to hedge against inflation because those metals tend to hold their value better than other investments. An interest rate increase at a time of relatively low inflation could send investors elsewhere.
"A rate hike is the No. 1 public enemy for a lot of the markets, particularly precious metals," said Peter Cardillo, director of research for Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York. "It put a lot of markets in technical trouble despite high physical demand."
Gasoline led a slide in energy prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The American Petroleum Institute reported late Tuesday that gasoline stocks rose 4.327 million barrels last week, while Energy Department figures showed stocks rose 3.1 million barrels.
Investors had believed stockpiles in the United States were low following the rupture and shutdown of the Colonial Pipeline system in Texas.
December unleaded gasoline fell 1.65 cents, to 56.45 cents a gallon. December crude oil fell 42 cents, to $18.16 a barrel.
Wheat futures fell to a two-month low on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid a Government estimate that China, as well as Russia and other former Soviet republics, may not buy as much.
The Agriculture Department said yesterday that it expected China to import only 9 million tons of wheat this year, down from the the agency's previous estimate of 10 million tons. Russia, another major wheat buying country, is expected to import 4 million tons, down from 4.5 million.
