HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Putting a price tag on life, and regulation that protects it.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
HOW much is a life worth? Merely posing the question offends most people.
But answer it they must and answer it they do, says Kip Viscusi, an economist at Duke University. Every time the Government decrees a cleanup strategy for a toxic-waste dump or spends Medicaid dollars on kidney dialysis it is making implicit decisions about the dollars-and-cents value of life. The hard part, Mr. Viscusi suggests, is facing up to it. 
 That hard part may be about to get a little easier, however, thanks to the seemingly obvious but long-ignored idea that life-protecting expenditures can put other lives at risk. "It could prove to be the political breakthrough," says Robert Hahn, of the American Enterprise Institute.
Civil courts have traditionally valued life by earnings lost. When juries did not like the implied figure -- surgeons are more valuable than saints -- they threw in extra cash for "pain and suffering."
To economists, that misses the point: life is worth what people are willing to pay to stay alive, not what others are willing to pay them to toil from 9 to 5. The only test anchored in reality is one in which people implicitly value their own lives by taking avoidable, life-threatening risks in return for more income.
Dozens of such calculations have been published, most of them derived from measuring the extra pay demanded by workers in dangerous jobs. Some have looked at consumer choices, measuring how much people were willing to pay for smoke detectors, safer cars and the like.
The results, alas, are all over the lot. In part, presumably, that's because individuals sort themselves according to their tolerance for risk: Those who join the Green Berets are different from those who fight their wars in offices. In part, it may simply follow from individuals' mis-estimate of the actual risks.
But virtually none of the studies put the value of life above $10 million, a figure Mr. Viscusi believes ought to be an upper bound on what Government spends -- or demands that consumers or workers spend to save lives.
Many regulations pass the test easily. Rules on unvented space heaters save lives for just $130,000 each; regulations on emergency floor lighting on commercial aircraft checks in at $900,000 per life saved. Many, however, do not. Asbestos-removal standards, regulations on the storage of benzene and limits on arsenic in glass-making all top $100 million per life saved.
The bean counters in the Carter and Reagan Administrations asked regulators to justify new standards in cost-benefit terms. But the Bush Administration and now the Clinton Administration did not press the point.
As a result Mr. Viscusi thinks a few agencies -- notably the Department of Transportation and the Federal Aviation Administration -- are implicitly undervaluing life. Others, notably the Environmental Protection Agency and the Occupational Health and Safety Administration, hardly bother with the costs.
But Mr. Viscusi thinks there is a back door to common sense even for those unwilling to balance costs against benefits. Virtually every economic activity is dangerous, he notes. More lives may be lost, for example, by trucking soil away from toxic-waste dumps than could be gained by reducing already low exposure to carcinogens. Simply demanding that agencies net out losses from benefits would put a lid on excesses.
More important, perhaps, it has been noted that
on average richer people live longer. In 1984, the Joint Economic Committee of Congress estimated that the 3 percent drop in income during the 1973 recession increased mortality rates by 2.3 percent. And just last year Randall Lutter and John Morall, economists working for the White House budget office, used cross-country data from the World Bank to estimate that a $9 million decrease in income leads to one premature death.
The implication -- that very expensive health and safety regulations can kill more people than they save because income available for other purposes is reduced -- is probably a bridge too far for gung-ho environmentalists in the Clinton Administration. But John Graham, the director of Harvard's Center for Risk Analysis, believes "Congress is definitely receptive" to the idea that Federal agencies should examine "the risks they create as well as the risks they conquer."
What's more, Jonathan Weiner of the Duke University School of Law thinks the Federal courts may use this concept of "income mediated" net benefits as a brake on regulatory excess. There is a "fairly short connection," he argues, between the idea of looking at overall health and safety impacts and the regulators' legal obligations under the Administration Procedures Act.
Washington, apparently, is not about to jump headlong into the controversy of valuing life. But it may yet creep where it is loath to leap.

PUB-DATE: November 10, 1994

SECTION: Section B; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1924 words

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
Midwest

BYLINE: This report was written by Keith Bradsher, Raymond Hernandez, Robert D. Hershey Jr., Lynette Holloway, Randy Kennedy, Stephen Labaton, Tamar Lewin, Neil A. Lewis, Norimitsu Onishi and Eric Schmitt. 

 BODY:

ILLINOIS
Once one of the most powerful lawmakers in Congress, Representative Dan Rostenkowski was soundly defeated by a relative unknown, Michael P. Flanagan. Mr. Rostenkowski, an 18-term Chicago Democrat, was forced to relinquish the chairmanship of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee earlier this year after his indictment on corruption charges. Nonetheless, his defeat on Tuesday was considered a huge upset in the ward politics of Chicago, which in earlier times did not find indictments particularly troublesome.
As expected, Gov. Jim Edgar won a second term, trouncing his Democratic challenger, Dawn Clark Netsch.
In other Congressional races, one other Republican managed to win a seat that had been in Democratic hands. The district in Joliet that has been held by Representative George E. Sangmeister, a Democrat who is retiring, was won by State Representative Gerald C. Weller, a Republican. 
 Representative Mel Reynolds, a Democrat who was indicted this year on charges of statutory rape, child pornography and obstruction of justice, was unopposed and retained his seat.
 
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Edgar, 1,973,239, 64%
 Netsch, 1,051,068, 34%
 HOUSE, 100% reporting
 Flanagan, 73,340, 55%
 Rostenkowski, 61,152, 45%
 
INDIANA
Senator Richard G. Lugar swept to a fourth term with more than twice as many votes as his Democratic opponent, former Representative Jim Jontz. Mr. Jontz, who served in the House from 1986 to 1992 and was a leading force there for the protection of the timber owl and the Pacific Northwest forests, tried to build anti-incumbent sentiment, but could not dent the Senator's popularity.
David M. McIntosh, a Republican who was once on Dan Quayle's staff, won Muncie's Second District, opened by the retirement of Representative Phil Sharp, a Democrat. In the Fifth District, Representative Steve Buyer, a freshman Republican, held off a challenge from John D. Beatty.
 
SENATE, 100% reporting
Jontz, 467,715, 31%
Lugar, 1,029,421, 67%
 
IOWA
Although Gov. Terry E. Branstad, a Republican, had trouble in the primary, he went on to become only the second governor in history to win four four-year terms in his state. Nelson Rockefeller in New York was the first. Mr. Branstad, who barely edged out Representative Fred Grandy, a more moderate Republican, in the primary, easily swept past his Democratic opponent, Attorney General Bonnie Campbell, by 15 percentage points.
The election also gave Iowa an all-Republican House delegation. The only Democratic House incumbent, Neal Smith, lost his seat to Greg Ganske. Representatives Jim Ross Lightfoot, Jim Leach and Jim Nussle all fended off Democratic challengers. And Mr. Grandy's district went to the Republican candidate, Tom Latham.
 
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Branstad, 562,918, 57%
 Campbell, 411,495, 42%
 
KANSAS
By seizing the governorship and the House seats of two veteran Democrats, Kansas Republicans will hold every post from the Topeka Statehouse to a six-member Congressional delegation led by Bob Dole, restored as Senate majority leader.
In the race for governor, Bill Graves, the Kansas Secretary of State, handily beat Jim Slattery, a six-term House veteran who not only lost his bid but also saw his seat fall to the Republicans as Sam Brownback trampled former Gov. John Carlin.
But the major surprise was that Wichita-area voters completed the Republican sweep, choosing Todd Tiahrt over the redoubtable Dan Glickman, a nine-term Congressman who had risen to be chairman of the Intelligence Committee. But Kansas will still have Representatives Pat Roberts and Jan Meyers heading committees on agriculture and small business.
 
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Graves, 524,624, 64%
 Slattery, 294,516, 36%
 
MICHIGAN
With the retirement of Senator Donald W. Riegle, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, the race for his replacement was considered an important barometer of which party would control the Midwest and the Senate.
So it was no surprise in light of the other Election Day results that the new Senator from Michigan will be Spencer Abraham, a former Republican state chairman and aide to Dan Quayle.
Mr. Abraham, who defeated Representative Bob Carr, received considerable support by being on the same line as John Engler, the popular Republican Governor who prevailed over former Representative Howard Wolpe. Early on, Mr. Engler seized the campaign after fulfilling promises to reduce taxes and change the way that public education was financed. He was also aided by a state economy on the rebound.
Republicans picked up one House district, the Eighth in Lansing, which had been held by Mr. Carr. It was won by Dick Chrysler, who defeated Bob Mitchell.
 
 SENATE, 99% reporting
 Abraham, 1,577,675, 52%
 Carr, 1,298,659, 43%
 GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
 Engler, 1,892,215, 61%
 Wolpe, 1,186,436, 39%
 
MINNESOTA
Democrats saw a rare opportunity to take a Republican-held seat when Senator Dave Durenberger decided to retire. But Ann Wynia, a Democrat, lost a race in which she and her Republican opponent, Rod Grams, portrayed each other as extremists.
Ms. Wynia, the former majority leader in the State House, had the support of women's groups and stressed the need for a greater government role on social issues. But Mr. Grams, a House freshman with a voting record as conservative as any in the House,called for a smaller Government that is tougher on crime.
Gov. Arne Carlson, a Republican moderate, won re-election in a landslide over State Senator John Marty, who changed campaign managers three times.
 
 SENATE, 100% reporting
 Grams, 595,869,568, 49%
 Wynia, 781,496, 44%
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Carlson, 1,101,345, 63%
 Marty, 591,350, 34%
 
MISSOURI
A nine-term Democrat attacked as a liberal spender and supporter of big government, Representative Harold L. Volkmer, showed just how vulnerable incumbents could be this year. He was in a tight race from the start.
But he also displayed the power of incumbency in his defeat of Kenny Hulshof, a Republican state prosecutor. In his campaign, Mr. Volkmer stressed his effectiveness in Washington, citing among other things his sponsorship of a 1993 House bill to help the state's flood victims.
Mr. Hulshof had tried to capitalize on disgust with Congress, signing the "Contract With America," a Republican agenda pledging tax cuts and a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget.
The Republicans did retain the Senate seat that was opened by the retirement of John C. Danforth. John Ashcroft, a Republican and former Governor, defeated his Democratic opponent, Representative Alan Wheat, the first black to be nominated for statewide office in Missouri.
Mr. Ashcroft supports giving line-item veto power to the President and passage of a balanced budget amendment.
The Republicans also kept a House seat in southwestern Missouri, where Representative Mel Hancock defeated the Democrat, James R. Fossard, a lawyer.
 
SENATE, 100% reporting
Ashcroft, 1,058,320, 60%
Wheat, 633,941, 36%
 
NEBRASKA
In the bleak Republican desert of Tuesday's elections for Democrats, Nebraska was an oasis. Senator Bob Kerrey breezed to re-election over his Republican challenger, Jan Stoney, a former top executive at US West, by reminding votes that he and President Clinton have clashed repeatedly.
The governor's mansion also stayed in Democratic hands as Gov. Ben Nelson easily beat Gene Spence, the Republican candidate and director of Omaha Public Power.
Not all Democrats were so lucky. In the Second Congressional District, Jon Christensen, an insurance executive, toppled a three-term incumbent, Peter Hoagland.
 
 SENATE, 100% reporting
 Kerrey, 314,442, 55%
 Stoney, 258,417, 45%
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Nelson, 420,048, 74%
 Spence, 146,971, 26%
 
NORTH DAKOTA
Senator Kent Conrad, the freshman Democrat who once vowed that he would not seek re-election if he could not cut the deficit, defeated Ben J. Clayburgh, an orthopedic surgeon. Coming from a state that handed its three electoral votes to President Bush in 1992, Mr. Conrad kept his distance from Mr. Clinton. In his advertisements, he allied himself with Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, noting that he had voted with Mr. Dole more than half the time.
In the contest for the state's sole House seat, the Democratic incumbent, Earl Pomeroy, soundly defeated State Representative Gary Porter.
 
 SENATE, 99% reporting
 Clayburgh, 98,069, 42%
 Conrad, 135,668, 58%
 
OHIO
For decades an important battlefield in Presidential campaigns, Ohio now looks like a hard sell for President Clinton in his 1996 re-election campaign. Republicans took one Ohio Senate seat from the Democrats on Tuesday, kept the governor's mansion and converted a 10 to 9 deficit in the state's House delegation into a 13 to 6 advantage.
Lieut. Gov. Mike DeWine easily beat Joel Hyatt, the founder of a chain of legal clinics, in the race to replace Senator Howard Metzenbaum, who is retiring and is Mr. Hyatt's father-in-law. The candidacy of Joseph Slovenec, an anti-abortion campaigner who attracted many votes from conservatives, prevented Mr. DeWine's margin of victory from being even larger. A survey of voters leaving polling places found that distaste for President Clinton and Mr. Hyatt's background as a lawyer mattered most to Mr. DeWine's supporters.
Gov. George V. Voinovich easily won re-election over Robert Burch, a Democratic State Senator.
 
 SENATE, 100% reporting
 DeWine, 1,818,126, 53%
 Hyatt, 1,330,287, 39%
 Slovenec, 268,386, 8%
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Burch, 829,859, 25%
 Voinovich, 2,382,591, 72%
 
SOUTH DAKOTA
To little surprise, the Republicans maintained control of the governership even though the Republican incumbent, Gov. Walter D. Miller, had lost in the primary.
William Janklow, the Republican candidate, easily defeated his Democratic opponent, Jim Beddow, the former president of Dakota Wesleyan University.
A major factor was that Mr. Janklow was much better known, having been Governor for two terms. He was barred from seeking a third consecutive term by state law.
Mr. Janklow had been criticized as a dictatorial Governor. But he was also praised for getting things done, including luring credit-card companies like Citibank to the state.
Representative Tim Johnson, a Democrat, was elected to a fifth term.
 
 GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
 Janklow, 172,500, 55%
 Beddow, 126,258, 41%
 
WISCONSIN
While anti-incumbent Republicans swept many states, Senator Herb Kohl, a centrist Democrat, held his own, fending off a challenge from Robert T. Welch, a conservative Republican. Senator Kohl, the owner of the Milwaukee Bucks basketball team and many commercial properties, spent millions of dollars of his own money to win the seat in 1988, and millions more to keep it.
And Gov. Tommy G. Thompson won a third term, pulling more than twice as many votes as his Democratic opponent, State Senator Charles J. Chvala. Governor Thompson has remained a voter favorite in part because of his tough stance on welfare -- the state's welfare rolls have shrunk by 23 percent during his tenure -- and Mr. Chvala aroused little voter interest with his charge that Mr. Thompson was unconcerned that poverty among children rose as welfare payments fell.
 
SENATE, 100% reporting
Kohl, 912,826, 58%
Welch, 637,103, 41%
GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
Chvala, 480,343, 31%
Thompson, 1,052,776, 67%

SECTION: Section B; Page 11; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2820 words

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
West

BYLINE: This report was written by Keith Bradsher, Raymond Hernandez, Robert D. Hershey Jr., Lynette Holloway, Randy Kennedy, Stephen Labaton, Tamar Lewin, Neil A. Lewis, Norimitsu Onishi and Eric Schmitt. 

 BODY:

ALASKA
A Democratic incumbent is leading, but the party may have to wait until next week before it celebrates. That is, if it gets to celebrate at all.
With 100 percent of the precincts reporting, Gov. Tony Knowles has a lead of 339 votes over James Campbell. But 7,500 absentee ballots remain to be counted and a winner will not be declared until Monday. Lieut. Gov. Jack Coghill, running as the Alaska Party Choice, held 13 percent of the vote. 
 One campaign issue centered on whether Indian villages, instead of sportsmen or corporations, should have priority over fish, game and land.
Mr. Knowles went into the election with a big lead in the polls despite acerbic advertisements run by Mr. Campbell, a retired Anchorage businessman.
For the fifth time in two decades, a measure to move the state capital from Juneau, a waterfront city of 26,000 people, to Wasilla, a frontier-like town of 4,000 people, failed, partly because of voter concerns about the cost of the move. This time, 54.7 percent of the voters said no while 45.3 percent were for the change.
 
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Campbell, 77,969, 41%
 Knowles, 78,308, 41%
 Coghill, 24,766, 13%
 
ARIZONA
It was a bad year all around for Democrats in Arizona. In one of six Senate races across the nation in which Democratic incumbents were not seeking re-election, Arizona went as the others did: to the Republican Party.
For the seat vacated by Dennis DeConcini, who is retiring, Representative Sam Coppersmith, a freshman Democrat, lost to Representative Jon Kyl, a four-term Congressman who has been a leader of the Conservative Opportunity Society, a Republican caucus founded by Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia.
Democratic designs on Arizona's governorship failed as well, despite a strong campaign by Eddie Basha, a supermarket magnate, who ran against the Republican incumbent, Fife Symington.
Governor Symington used Mr. Basha's support for homosexual marriages to undercut the challenger's popularity among conservative Democrats.
Republicans also picked up three House seats, including the one Mr. Coppersmith vacated and one in the Sixth District, where Representative Karan English, a Democrat, fell to J. D. Hayworth, a first-time candidate and a former sportscaster.
 
 SENATE, 99% reporting
 Coopersmith, 427,285, 40%
 Grainger, 73,156, 7%
 Kyl, 577,934, 54%
 GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
 Basha, 484,307, 44%
 Symington, 570,501, 52%
 
CALIFORNIA
Angry over crime and illegal immigration, Californians overwhelming approved a tough new initiative against undocumented workers and re-elected Gov. Pete Wilson, positioning the 61-year-old Republican for a possible Presidential bid in 1996.
Once 23 points behind his Democratic rival, Kathleen Brown, the State Treasurer, Mr. Wilson pounded away on the two themes Golden State residents said they worried about most: porous borders and crime.
The Republican surge even swept the singer Sonny Bono into a Southern California Congressional seat. And Republicans picked up seven seats in the State Assembly, leaving the lower house tied at 40 to 40 and making the selection of a new speaker and other leaders more difficult. Democrats have controlled the Assembly since 1971.
But Republican coattails came up short in one of the nastiest and costliest races of the 1994 campaign. Senator Dianne Feinstein, the Democrat, edged Representative Michael Huffington, the Republican challenger, after the two candidates spent weeks and a total of nearly $38 million calling each other liars and hypocrites, and swapping charges of hiring illegal nannies. Mr. Huffington has refused to concede until 500,000 absentee ballots are counted.
Ms. Feinstein, a native Californian with 20 years in government, was supported by voters who cited her experience, while Mr. Huffington tapped into voters angry over illegal immigration. But Mr. Huffington's Texas roots and willingness to spend as much of his own money as needed to win may ultimately have doomed his candidacy.
The emotionally charged Proposition 187, which would bar illegal aliens from welfare, education and nonemergency health services, seemed to buoy the fortunes of virtually all Republicans. The party was one of the measure's biggest financial backers.
Californians approved the measure by 59 to 41 percent, but yesterday a state judge in San Francisco issued an order blocking the expulsion of illegal immigrants from public schools and colleges.
Health-conscious Californians rejected one initiative backed by the tobacco industry to loosen anti-smoking laws and another to create a single-payer health-care system.
 
 SENATE, 100% reporting
 Feinstein, 3,608,497, 47%
 Huffington, 3,484,887, 45%
 Barron, 231,110, 3%
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Brown, 3,191,428, 40%
 Wilson, 4,357,713, 55%
 
COLORADO
Compared to the rest of the country, voters in Colorado were gentle to their Democratic incumbents, re-electing their Governor and two longtime members of Congress.
Portraying himself as a centrist and problem solver, Gov. Roy Romer, who was endorsed by Ross Perot, was able to deflect much of the anger aimed at other Democrats. His campaign for a third term was greatly helped last month by a series of miscalculations and embarrassing personal disclosures by his challenger, Bruce Benson, an oilman and a former state Republican chairman. Until then, Mr. Benson had been gaining in the polls.
Representatives Patricia Schroeder and David Skaggs avoided the anti-Democrat wind that toppled incumbents elsewhere. Republicans handily won the state's four other House seats.
Among the initiatives on the ballot, voters soundly rejected one that would have increased tobacco taxes by 2.5 cents per cigarette to raise money for educational programs and medical research related to smoking. They also turned down an initiative to give towns and cities more power to regulate sexually explicit books, magazines and videos.
 
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Benson, 430,252, 39%
 Romer, 616,521, 55%
 
HAWAII
In a wild, three-way race featuring no incumbent governor, Lieut. Gov. Ben Cayetano, a Democrat, won by eking out a few thousand more votes than his opponents in a state so dominated by the Democrats that a Republican was last elected chief executive in 1959.
A decline in tourism, as well as rising living costs and welfare rolls, threatened the Democrats' grip on the office. And Patricia F. Saiki, a former Republican Representative, who focused her campaign on reducing crime and improving Hawaii's economy, led in polls for much of the year. In the end, though, voters were apparently more comfortable with Mr. Cayetano, a liberal Democrat less concerned with crime than with education.
But with only 37 percent of the vote, Mr. Cayetano's mandate is not what Democrats are used to in Hawaii. The challenge of a popular independent, Frank Fasi, a former Mayor of Honolulu, siphoned votes from both parties. In fact, Mr. Fasi got more votes than Ms. Saiki.
Senator Daniel K. Akaka, the incumbent Democrat, won an overwhelming victory.
 
 SENATE, 100% reporting
 Akaka, 256,189, 72%
 Hustace, 86,320, 24%
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Cayetano, 134,978, 37%
 Fasi, 113,158, 31%
 Saiki, 107,908, 29%
 
IDAHO
For the first time in 29 years, the Governor of Idaho will be a Republican.
Retiring Gov. Cecil D. Andrus will be succeeded by Phil Batt, a former Lieutenant Governor and part-time onion farmer, who defeated Larry Echohawk, the Democratic Attorney General who had hoped to become the nation's first Indian governor.
Larry LaRocco, a two-term Democratic Representative from Boise, was defeated by by a Republican energy consultant, Helen Chenoweth. Mr. LaRocco's campaign never recovered from revelations that his former brokerage firm had paid his female assistant $40,000 to settle a sexual discrimination lawsuit. In 1992, before the suit was filed, Mr. LaRocco said rumors of the relationship were a lie, but he was forced to backpedal and acknowledge it this time around.
Idaho voters also approved a proposition to limit state and Federal terms and appeared to have narrowly defeated an anti-gay-rights amendment.
 
 GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
 Batt, 214,809, 52%
 Echohawk, 181,471, 44%
 
MONTANA
Retaining a seat once thought ripe for a Democratic take-away was not easy for Senator Conrad Burns, who campaigned hard and spent heavily to overcome poor ratings from voters and criticism for traveling at lobbyists' expense. But Mr. Burns soundly defeated his Democratic challenger, Jack Mudd, a Missoula lawyer and novice candidate, becoming the first Republican this century to be returned to the Senate from solidly Democratic Montana.
In a race in which the incumbent seemed to have so many weak spots, Democrats were confounded by Mr. Burns's popularity. A recent poll showed that despite a highly publicized remark in which he used a racial epithet to refer to blacks, his support grew from 44 percent at the start of the campaign to 51 percent at the end. Advertisements criticizing him for taking 63 trips that were underwritten by lobbyists failed to turn voters against him. Support for Mr. Mudd, who had trouble raising money, remained about 37 percent throughout the campaign.
In the nation's most populous Congressional district (Montana lost a second seat to reapportionment after the 1990 Census), Pat Williams, an eight-term Democratic Representative, survived a strong challenge by Cy Jamison, former director of the Bureau of Land Management.
 
 SENATE, 95% reporting
 Burns, 212,618, 62%
 Mudd, 128,950, 38%
 
NEVADA
Nevada, at least, was a welcome place for the Democrats this year. Gov. Bob Miller was the person principally responsible for delivering Nevada to the Democratic column for Bill Clinton in 1992, and his Republican opponent this year, Assemblyman Jim Gibbons, worked tirelessly to remind voters of it, but to no avail.
Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Democrat, was also re-elected, defeating Hal Furman, a Republican.
Nevada voters also faced a slew of ballot propositions, approving two that added the state to the list of those trying to impose term limits on local and Federal officeholders. Voters also overwhelmingly approved a referendum question requiring a two-thirds vote of the Legislature to raise taxes.
 
 SENATE, 99% reporting
 Bryan, 193,444, 51%
 Furman, 155,547, 41%
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Miller, 199,891, 53%
 Gibbons, 156,637, 41%
 
NEW MEXICO
Republicans fought long and hard for a Senate seat in New Mexico, where Colin R. McMillan, a Republican rancher and oilman, jumped on his opponent, Senator Jeff Bingaman, for supporting many of President Clinton's policies, most notably higher grazing fees.
But the attempt to swing rural voters his way while cashing in on anti-Administration sentiment was not enough, and Senator Bingaman prevailed in a close contest.
Senator Bingaman, a Clinton-style policy enthusiast, was faulted for running a lackluster campaign that was slow to counterattack and studiously focused on issues like technology conversion and education technology.
But as Mr. McMillan pulled to within three percentage points of Mr. Bingaman in polls near the end of the campaign, the Senator began running negative television advertisements that questioned Mr. McMillan's support of Social Security and Medicare.
Mr. McMillan, a former Assistant Defense Secretary, was also criticized for pumping more than $1 million of his own money into his campaign and not fully disclosing the expenditures.
Democrats did not fare as well elsewhere. A strong state economy was not enough to prevent Gov. Bruce King, the Democratic incumbent, from losing to Gary E. Johnson, a construction company owner. An independent candidate, Roberto Mondragon, collected enough votes to establish his Green Party as a major party under the state's election law.
 
 SENATE, 99% reporting
 Bingaman, 243,759, 54%
 McMillan, 205,334, 46%
 GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
 Johnson, 224,411, 49%
 King, 182,154, 40%
 Mondragon, 47,080, 10%
 
OREGON
Although efforts to overhaul health care stalled in Congress, the issue propelled Dr. John Kitzhaber, a Democrat, into the governorship. Dr. Kitzhaber, who designed Oregon's health care rationing plan, beat Denny Smith, a former Republican Congressman.
Republicans also failed in their effort to take the seat held by Representative Elizabeth Furse after she waged an expensive campaign in which she portrayed herself as tough on both crime and Pentagon waste.
It also helped that her Republican opponent, Bill Witt, a businessman, had been criticized for his past ties to the Oregon Citizens Alliance, a conservative group promoting issues like a measure to limit government protections for homosexuals.
That initiative, which would have prohibited state and local governments from enacting laws to shield homosexuals from discrimination, was defeated by voters, as was a similar measure two years ago.
Also on the ballot was a measure to allow the terminally ill to obtain lethal prescriptions for suicide. That measure appeared headed for victory, but opponents refused to concede yesterday.
 
 GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
 Kitzhaber, 501,539, 53%
 Smith, 386,484, 41%
 
UTAH
 Although Utah has been in the vanguard of the rapidly spreading movement to limit political tenure -- earlier this year state legislators scored a first by voting to limit their own terms, not somebody else's -- voters turned down a chance to be even tougher.
In doing so, Utah avoided creating a bizarre situation in which the state would have had conflicting laws on term limits since the latest petition, which was circulating before the Legislature passed its own version, would have held terms to 8 years while the Legislature allowed 12. But voters did approve a measure giving crime victims the right to a role in prosecuting their attackers.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Republican, breezed to victory for a fourth term and is poised to become chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. And Enid Greene Waldholtz, a free-spending Republican, turned out Karen Shepherd, a freshman Democratic reformer, in a rematch of their 1992 race.
 
 SENATE, 100% reporting
 Shea, 146,731, 28%
 Hatch, 356,345, 69%
 
WASHINGTON
 Throughout this year's campaign, no man or woman so symbolized four decades of Democratic rule in the House as Speaker Thomas S. Foley, a silver-haired, silver-tongued patrician. Yet his sheer power and visibility proved his undoing on Tuesday, as he lost to a little-known Republican who called for change and portrayed as a vice even Mr. Foley's talent for bringing home Federal money to Washington's Fifth District.
George Nethercutt, the 50-year-old chairman of the Spokane Republican Party, received considerable help from national talk show hosts and the former Presidential candidate Ross Perot, who heaped abuse on Mr. Foley. The Democratic leader tried to defend himself by campaigning heavily, warning prophetically that Mr. Nethercutt's election might mean moving the speakership to Marietta, Ga., home of Republican Representative Newt Gingrich.
Voters across Washington abandoned their longtime Democratic leanings. The political complexion of the state's House delegation, eight Democrats and one Republican now, changed radically, with seven Republicans and only two Democrats elected to next year's session of Congress. Senator Slade Gorton, another Republican, won re-election against Ron Sims, a member of the County Council in King County, which includes Seattle.
 
 SENATE, 99% reporting
 Gorton, 796,233, 55%
 Sims, 654,357, 45%
 HOUSE, 99% reporting
 Foley, 97,448, 49%
 Nethercutt, 99,622, 51%
 
WYOMING
The nation's first transcontinental railroad runs across southern Wyoming, and descendants of its builders have long voted Democratic. But Republicans in the state's ranching and mining communities prevailed this year. Unpopular Clinton Administration policies, especially moves to raise fees for grazing cattle on Federal land, helped Republicans retain House and Senate seats and win the governorship.
In the race to replace Senator Malcolm Wallop, a Republican who is retiring, Representative Craig Thomas, Wyoming's only House member, beat Gov. Mike Sullivan. Another Republican, Barbara Cubin, won Mr. Thomas's House seat, and Jim Geringer, a State Senator, easily beat Kathy Karpan, Wyoming's Secretary of State, to take Mr. Sullivan's place as Governor.
Voters defeated ballot propositions to legalize slot machine gambling and to subject people performing abortions to felony prosecution, except in cases of rape or incest or when the woman's life is in danger.
 
 SENATE, 100% reporting
 Sullivan, 79,553, 40%
 Thomas, 118,061, 59%
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Geringer, 117,491, 59%
 Karpan, 80,383, 40%

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
Northeast

BYLINE: This report was written by Keith Bradsher, Raymond Hernandez, Robert D. Hershey Jr., Lynette Holloway, Randy Kennedy, Stephen Labaton, Tamar Lewin, Neil A. Lewis, Norimitsu Onishi and Eric Schmitt. 

 BODY:

CONNECTICUT
If there is a survival model for shaken Democrats, it would seem to be Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who in one term has soared to seeming invincibility with his moderate views and superior connections that include many prosperous supporters in New York and Hollywood. Despite being a friend of President Clinton, he defeated Gerald Labriola, a retired pediatrician and former State Senator whose campaign never took shape, by more than 2 to 1 and consolidated his hold on one of his party's most secure Senate seats.
But the crowded governor's race, dominated by debate over taxes, seemed to offer few lessons. John G. Rowland, a Republican and former Representative, outlasted three opponents, the closest being William E. Curry Jr., the Democratic state controller, after a disclosure late in the campaign that Mr. Rowland had tried to suppress a police report about a quarrel with his former wife. 
 Representative Gary Franks, who in 1990 became Connecticut's first black member of Congress and the first black House Republican with voting status in 55 years, beat a challenge by James H. Maloney.
 
 SENATE, 100% reporting
 Labriola, 333,346, 31%
 Lieberman, 720,079, 67%,
GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Curry, 372,479, 33%
 Groark, 215,952, 19%
 Rowland, 412,255, 36%
 Scott, 129,920, 11%
 
DELAWARE
William V. Roth Jr.'s re-election seems to indicate that the general sentiment in this election was more anti-Democrat than anti-incumbent. How else to explain how this quintessential incumbent, 73 years old and seeking a fifth Senate term, managed to rack up a 14-point victory over Charles M. Oberly 3d, the state's 47-year-old Democratic Attorney General, who had superior crime-fighting credentials and was a proven commodity in statewide campaigns?
Mr. Roth, in fact, had looked so vulnerable that Representative Michael N. Castle, a former Governor, considered challenging him in the primary. But an expensive television blitz by Mr. Oberly failed to enliven voters, and he lost ground in the final weeks.
Mr. Castle retained the state's only House seat by routing Carol Ann DeSantis, a hospital executive.
 
 SENATOR, 100% reporting
 Oberly, 84,465, 42%
 Roth, 110,886, 56%
 
DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
Former Mayor Marion Barry's victory in the District's mayoral race was never seriously in doubt. The surprise lay in the strong showing by Carol Schwartz, a white Republican running in a heavily black and Democratic city. She benefited from an unusually high turnout in the city's predominantly white neighborhoods and support among blacks that was stronger than expected.
Mr. Barry won a three-way Democratic primary in September with only 47 percent of the vote. Many backers of his primary opponents apparently crossed party lines on Tuesday to avoid voting for a man whose last term as Mayor ended with a drug conviction in 1990 and a six-month jail term.
 
 MAYOR, 100% reporting
 Barry, 101,200, 56%
 Schwartz, 75,011, 42%
 
MAINE
In this state, where Ross Perot won 30 percent of the vote in the 1992 Presidential election, the fiercely independent streak of voters appears to have been a major factor again.
Angus King, a businessman who ran for governor as an independent, was elected in a narrow victory. Maine has now had two independent governors within the last 20 years, and it is now the only state in the nation with an independent governor. Mr. King defeated Joseph E. Brennan, a Democrat who was Governor from 1979 to 1987.
And Olympia J. Snowe, a Republican, soundly defeated her Democratic opponent, Thomas H. Andrews, in the Senate race after a campaign in which Ms. Snowe's moderate Republican views drew support from many who had voted for Mr. Perot.
"Maine voters have always had a love affair with 'none of the above,' " said Al Diamon, who writes a political column for The Bangor Daily News.
This was to have been a relatively calm political year in this state, with much of the attention focused on the governor's race. But Senator George J. Mitchell's plan to retire set off a ripple effect throughout the state, as both Mr. Andrews and Ms. Snowe gave up their House seats to run for senator.
 
SENATE, 99% reporting
Andrews, 185,210, 37%
Snowe, 304,516, 60%
 GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
Brennan, 171,787, 34%
King, 178,606, 36%
 
MARYLAND
In a state where Democrats hold a 2-to-1 edge in voter registration, the chances that a Republican would seize the governor's chair seemed slim. But in one of the closest races in Maryland history, Parris N. Glendening, a Democrat and three-term Prince George's County executive, and Ellen R. Sauerbrey, the Republican leader of the Maryland House, hooked up in a cliffhanger.
Mr. Glendening and his running mate, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, led by about 6,000 votes with all precincts reporting, but both sides claimed victory would be theirs once 50,000 absentee ballots were tallied later this week.
Ms. Sauerbrey had recently pulled even with Mr. Glendening by patterning her campaign after that of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, pledging tax cuts.
With a record ripe for an anti-Clinton vote, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Democrat, also seemed vulnerable. But the three-term Senator brushed aside a challenge from William E. Brock 3d, a former Republican Senator from Tennessee, who never effectively countered Mr. Sarbanes's accusations that he was a carpetbagger.
 
 SENATE, 100% reporting
 Sarbanes, 788,032, 59%
 Brock, 538,351, 41%
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 Glendening, 683,995, 50%
 Sauerbrey, 677,808, 50%
 
MASSACHUSETTS
It was a close race, at least early on, between two candidates with familiar political names and huge personal fortunes.
In the end, Senator Edward M. Kennedy managed to buck the Republican tide and anti-incumbent sentiment and defeat his challenger, Mitt Romney. He did it by stressing his 32 years of experience, his grasp of the issues and his influence on Capitol Hill.
But his victory, one of the few bright spots for Democrats, came only after a hard-fought final month of campaigning.
Mr. Romney, a venture capitalist and a onetime Mormon missionary, had been even with Mr. Kennedy in polls in September. In harsh television advertisements, Mr. Romney, the son of former Gov. George Romney of Michigan, strove to portray Mr. Kennedy as a has-been, worn-out and obsolete. One commercial showed the Senator having difficulty sitting.
But the Republican fell behind as Senator Kennedy rose to the challenge in the campaign's final weeks and Mr. Romney's performances in two debates failed to shift the race. To a large extent, Mr. Romney was successful only in casting himself as someone who was "not Ted Kennedy," as one pollster said.
Mr. Kennedy, a liberal icon who has won six times with at least 55 percent of the vote, was an uncomfortable campaigner. But he counterattacked in the last month, characterizing Mr. Romney as a businessman who "puts profits over people."
In the race for the governorship, Gov. William F. Weld, a Republican who has been mentioned as a possible Presidential contender in 1996, rolled over State Representative Mark R. Roosevelt.
 
 SENATE, 99% reporting
 Kennedy, 1,257,945, 58%
 Romney, 888,435, 41%
 GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
 Roosevelt, 606,648, 28%
 Weld, 1,521,561, 71%
 
NEW HAMPSHIRE
With no Senate race, the spotlight in New Hampshire fell on a grudge match of sorts in which Republicans succeeded after four years in reclaiming a seat that had been theirs since Woodrow Wilson was President.
Charles F. Bass, a former State Senator, defeated the Democratic incumbent, Representative Dick Swett, by a small margin, making much of his golden pedigree as the grandson of a former Governor and the son of a former Congressman from the state. Despite being outspent by his opponent, Mr. Bass ran a strong campaign, criticizing his opponent's ties to President Clinton. (One advertisement showed Mr. Swett and the President embracing.)
This year's curse of incumbency did not touch Gov. Steve Merrill, a Republican, who defeated Wayne D. King, a State Senator, by a wide margin. And a two-term Republican Representative, Bill Zeliff, also easily beat his challenger, Bill Verge.
 
 GOVERNOR, 100% reporting
 King, 79,493, 26%
 Merrill, 216,755, 70%
 
NEW JERSEY
Discouraged by heavy losses in the State Legislature two years ago and Christine Todd Whitman's stunning victory as Governor last year, New Jersey's Democratic Party rallied hard for Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, and the strong support was apparently enough to give the incumbent a slight edge over Chuck Haytaian, the Republican State Assembly Speaker.
Last spring, Republicans eyeing control of the United States Senate had cited Mr. Lautenberg, a two-term incumbent, as vulnerable. Although Mr. Haytaian raised $3 million less than the incumbent, the challenger, a strict conservative, campaigned ferociously. He appeared often with the popular Governor Whitman, and made a flat Federal income tax the cornerstone of his campaign. But in the end, traditional Democratic backers, including union members, women and voters in Essex and Hudson counties, turned out in big numbers.
In the House races, the Democrats were not so lucky. Frank A. Lobiondo, a Republican State Assemblyman, easily succeeded Representative William J. Hughes, a Democrat retiring after 10 terms. The Republicans gained a second seat as William Martini, a former Assistant United States Attorney, defeated Herb Klein, a freshman Representative, in a closely watched race.
 
 SENATE, 99% reporting
 Haytaian, 954,439, 47%
 Lautenberg, 1,027,167, 51%
 
NEW YORK
New York voters ended 20 years of Democratic possession of the Governor's mansion by turning out Mario M. Cuomo, one of the nation's most persistent and eloquent liberals. The shock administered by the Republican candidate, George E. Pataki, made it clear that Mr. Cuomo was unable to overcome a combination of anti-incumbent, anti-Democratic sentiment along with what could best be described as voter fatigue with Mr. Cuomo himself.
The Pataki victory poses a risky situation for Rudolph W. Giuliani, New York City's Republican Mayor, who crossed party lines shortly before the election to endorse Mr. Cuomo and denounce his party's candidate. Mr. Giuliani was quick to declare his eagerness to work with Mr. Pataki in Albany.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan was another Democrat up for re-election this year, but he coasted to victory. Mr. Moynihan was never seriously challenged by his Republican opponent, Bernadette Castro, whose family developed a lucrative business in convertible sleeper sofas.
In another statewide race, H. Carl McCall was elected state comptroller, New York's chief financial officer, becoming the first black candidate ever elected statewide.
 
 SENATE, 99% reporting
 Castro, 1,940,345, 42%
 Moynihan, 2,549,012, 55%
 GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
 Cuomo, 2,286,117, 45%
 Golisano, 210,553, 4%
 Pataki, 2,477,882, 49%
 
PENNSYLVANIA
In a great show of political muscle in this state of blue-collar Democrats and middle-class suburbanites, the Republicans pulled off a coup in the Senate race, a seat the Democrats believed they could maintain.
Rick Santorum, a 36-year-old Congressman from the Pittsburgh area, upset Senator Harris Wofford, 68, in a close race.
A self-proclaimed rabble-rouser who has pledged to reduce taxes, Mr. Santorum called his victory "a referendum against big government."
Senator Wofford won his seat in a special election three years ago largely on a platform of overhauling the health-care system.
In another victory for the Republicans, Representative Tom Ridge took over the governorship by defeating Lieut. Gov. Mark S. Singel. The two men and Peg Luksik, an abortion opponent who ran as an independent, fought a heated race to replace the popular Governor, Robert P. Casey, who was barred from a third term.
Mr. Singel stumbled when it became known that as head of the State Board of Pardons he had recommended parole for a prisoner who was later charged with rape and murder in New York City.
 
SENATE, 99% reporting
Santorum, 1,1,729,614, 49%
Wofford, 1,1,642,199, 47%
GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
Luksik, 458,206, 13%
Ridge, 1,622,835, 45%
Singel, 1,422,072, 40%
 
RHODE ISLAND
This Democratic-leaning state split its votes in four races but chose Republicans for its two top positions.
In one of the dozen governorships the Republicans gained across the nation, Lincoln C. Almond, a former United States Attorney, narrowly defeated State Representative Myrth York, a Democrat. Mr. Almond, a no-nonsense, take-charge campaigner, impressed voters anxious about crime and the economy.
It was a race that may be remembered more for its primaries. Mr. Almond stunned many by easily taking the Republican nomination from Representative Ronald K. Machtley, who was hurt by widespread anti-Washington sentiment. The Democrats denied renomination to Gov. Bruce Sundlun, whose administration had been plagued by ethical and fiscal problems.
Senator John H. Chafee, a moderate Republican seeking his fourth term, crushed State Representative Linda J. Kushner, the Democratic candidate.
But Democrats won the state's two House races. Patrick J. Kennedy, the 27-year-old son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, won the seat vacated by Mr. Machtley. Soon to be the youngest member of Congress, Mr. Kennedy campaigned as the candidate best suited to bring Federal programs and money to the state.
Voters also rejected an initiative that would have legalized casino gambling.
 
SENATE, 99% reporting
Chafee, 213,896, 64%
Kushner, 118,411, 36%
GOVERNOR, 99% reporting
Almond, 164,130, 47%
York, 151,861, 44%
 
VERMONT
Vermont, which is noted for upsets in off-year elections, didn't come close this year.
Senator James M. Jeffords, a Republican who is as apt to vote against the party leadership as with it, beat a Democratic State Senator, Jan Backus, by a comfortable margin despite her late endorsement by the state's biggest newspaper, The Burlington Free-Press. Ms. Backus campaigned for a political role for ordinary people, but her accusations that the Senator had abused the perquisites of office did not help.
For their part, the Democrats enjoyed a landslide as Howard Dean, a doctor who is one of the country's most popular governors, held his Republican challenger, David F. Kelley, to less than 20 percent of the vote.
In the lone House race, Bernard Sanders, a socialist who runs as an independent and caucuses with the Democrats, kept his seat despite being targeted by foes of gun control because of his vote for the crime bill, which included restrictions on assault weapons.
 
SENATE 99% reporting,
Backus, 84,833, 41%
 Jeffords, 102,978, 50%
 GOVERNOR 99% reporting
 Dean, 142,998, 70%
 Kelley, 39,703, 19%
 
WEST VIRGINIA
Never let it be said that West Virginians are ungrateful.
The state depends heavily on Federal aid to help its poor and build its highways, and it has relied on Democratic incumbents to keep the money flowing. While the rest of the country turned to the right this week, West Virginia re-elected its three-member House delegation, all Democrats, and Senator Robert C. Byrd, a Democrat who has held his seat since 1959. Mr. Byrd beat Stan Klos, a Republican real estate developer.
West Virginia's other Senator, Jay Rockefeller, is also a Democrat, giving the state one of the few all-Democratic delegations left in Congress.
 
SENATE, 100% reporting
Byrd, 288,353, 69%
Klos, 129,458, 31%

SECTION: Section A; Page 34; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 731 words

HEADLINE: Dr. Fell's Election

 BODY:
Tuesday's vote produced a political upheaval of historic proportions. It decimated the top ranks of the Democratic Congressional leadership, awarded the Republicans control of both houses of Congress and most of the big-state governorships, and confronted President Clinton, who was elected as a minority President, with a stark problem of political survival. Whether he can get any legislation passed and whether he is re-electable now depend largely on the strategic calculations of the likely Republican leaders, Representative Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, and such obstreperous ideologues as Senator Phil Gramm.
In the aftermath of a calamity that even the Cassandras among them had not predicted, disconsolate Democrats began to ask whether their party was flying apart like a disintegrating galaxy and losing any identity with which American voters could connect. Republicans, in the aftermath of a triumph that fulfilled their rosiest fantasies, are left to wonder whether they can -- or want to -- shift from opposition to governance. 
 The gripes, hopes, wobbles, tics and other impulses filtering through millions of individual synapses contributed to the Democratic defeat. So did some other, more definable factors:
The Government Factor. The vote plainly reflected widespread disgust with big government and impatience with government activism, two things with which the Democrats are most closely identified. The question is how Mr. Clinton, a different Democrat, came to be seen as an old-fashioned tax-and-spender. The best answer is probably the health-care reform program whose Brobdingnagian design -- following as it did his successful (and justifiable) move to raise taxes in order to shrink the deficit -- tagged him in the public eye as an advocate of big government.
The Governance Factor. Americans might have felt more kindly toward government -- and indeed the whole idea of legislation -- had the Democrats actually delivered on Mr. Clinton's campaign promises. On this score, the downfall of Thomas Foley, the House Speaker, was a historic marker of voter discontent with Congressional indulgence of the status quo. Mr. Foley had the devotion of his colleagues, but his defeat was deserved. He did far more to preserve the perks and PAC money of his fellow members than to provide the legislative leadership to support a Democratic President and his program.
The Fell Factor. This has also been known as the Carter factor, and may come to be known as the Clinton factor. It was first described three centuries ago by the poet Thomas Brown. "I do not love thee, Dr. Fell./ The reason why I cannot tell./ But this alone I know full well,/ I do not love thee, Dr. Fell." Exit polls showed that one-third of all voters acted as they did because they disapproved of the President. The polls were not specific, but something about Mr. Clinton -- Whitewater, the early foulups over important appointments, a White House staff that uniquely combined hubris and incompetence, perhaps even his wife -- has clearly nettled many voters to the point of distraction.
The Economic Factor. A puzzler. Unemployment and inflation are low, the deficit is declining and the recession receding. Still, many people -- again to use Mr. Clinton's own words -- feel "insecure." They are easy targets for anyone who promises to put more money in their pockets through tax cuts, which is precisely what the Republicans did.
Give the President this: He is militantly inclusive, even in disaster. Whatever the reasons for his shattering defeat, Mr. Clinton embraces them all. "I agree with much of what the electorate said yesterday," he declared, urging the Congressional majority to "join me in the center of the public debate."
President Clinton has been moved by this election from a controlling to a reactive position. Senator Dole was coolly ambiguous in defining areas of cooperation. Mr. Gingrich seemed to be trying to brainwash himself into believing his own promises of more Speaker-like behavior.
Mr. Clinton must hope that decades of partisanship, a frenzy of Presidential ambition and their bloodthirsty fringe constituencies will lead these Republicans into an extremist binge of socially restrictive legislation. If the Republicans decide to camp out in the responsible center, the President could find himself just another face in the crowd.

HEADLINE: As Washington's Old Order Gives Way, No Clear Signs From the New

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
For American business, the immediate post-election impact from the Republican Party victories is the new faces coming to the fore in Washington as committee chairmanships change hands. Even so, the shift in control may not result in radical departures from current Congressional policies.
Here is a look at several leading industries most likely to be at the top of the agenda next year: 

 
Health Care
 Health care executives yesterday welcomed the Republican electoral success amid signs that limited changes in the system would still be on the front burner in Congress and state legislatures.
They still expect some Federal action because "the Republicans want to be the do-something party," Margo Vignola, a health care securities analyst at Salomon Brothers, said. But broader changes in the health system are already under way in the states and private sector.
"Health care will remain under economic pressure, regardless of the politicians," Kenneth Abramowitz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, said.
 Charles N. Kahn 3d, a spokesman for the health insurance industry in Washington, expects "some kind of incremental package" that would make insurance "portable" for people moving to a new job and prohibit insurers from withholding coverage from people with health problems. Such measures, he said, need not include new taxes or benefits that employers would have to offer.
"The Republicans now have an opportunity to best the President and the former Congress on health reform," Mr. Kahn, executive vice president of the Health Insurance Association of America, said.
Dick Keelty, a vice president of the Warner-Lambert Company, said that pharmaceuticals for the elderly would continue to be an issue. He said subsidies should be limited to the uninsured who cannot afford expensive drugs.
The role of the states in shaping health care is also growing. "This election was about the beginning of a transfer of power back to the states, and one of the key issues will be the financing and reform of health care," said Carl Schramm, executive vice president of Fortis Inc., an international group of insurers.
 Industry analysts noted that Democratic critics of health care companies in Congress lost their powerful committee chairmanships. "Dingell, Waxman and Stark will be in the minority now," Ms. Vignola noted. John D. Dingell of Michigan and the California Democrats Henry A. Waxman and Fortney H. Stark headed important House committees dealing with health issues.
Mr. Kahn agreed, saying that "Their day is gone." MILT FREUDENHEIM

HEADLINE: The New Era of Instability

BYLINE: By John B. Judis; John B. Judis is author, most recently, of "Grand Illusion: Critics and Champions of the American Century."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Since 1968, there has been much talk of a "Republican realignment." Quieted by Bill Clinton's victory in 1992, it resounds again after Tuesday's Republican victories.
This election may in fact hail the emergence of a 20-year Republican lock not only on the Presidency but also on Congress and the statehouses. But it is more likely to usher in an era of greater political turbulence characterized by empty sloganeering, mean-spirited campaigning and the growth of local and national third parties -- an era in which neither Democrats nor Republicans can count on stable majorities. 
 What the 1994 election most clearly signaled was the last fevered gasp of the Democratic majority that has prevailed since 1932. That majority, which controlled Congress and the statehouses even when it ceded the Presidency, was based on a coalition among urban ethnic machines, minorities, labor unions and the white South and Southwest.
In 1948, Strom Thurmond and the Dixiecrats temporarily bolted. In 1968, the Democrats suffered a more permanent reverse, as Gov. George Wallace of Alabama led many Southern whites and some working-class Northerners out of the party to protest Democratic support for racial desegregation. In the late 70's, as international competition forced down real wages and eliminated budget surpluses, the Democrats suffered another wave of defections from voters angered by higher taxes, which they believed were being squandered on new social programs. They became the so-called Reagan Democrats.
These last two splits were fundamental: they removed the basis for a liberal populist alliance between the middle and lower classes and opened the way for a conservative populism directed against immigrants, welfare cheaters and the urban underclass. The Democrats made their share of foreign policy mistakes, but what undermined the party was the voters' perception that it had made irrevocable choices -- on spending, taxes, crime, education -- between its white middle class supporters and its low-income black and Hispanic constituents.
With this dark cloud hanging over them, Democrats lost five of six Presidential elections from 1968 to 1988. Yet except for a six-year hiatus in the Senate, the party maintained power in Congress and the majority of statehouses. In the South, Democrats continued to win by staying sufficiently to the right of the national party to preserve a share of the older Democratic vote, while gaining the new minority vote against even more conservative Republican opponents.
In House and state legislative races, Democrats were aided by the the Republicans' weak local organizations. And they gained the allegiance of well-to-do young voters drawn by the environmental and social movements of the 60's. Once the party of James Eastland, Richard Daley and Hubert Humphrey, the Democrats became the party of Sam Nunn, Jesse Jackson and Michael Dukakis.
After the 1992 election, the Democrats had a fleeting opportunity to revive the party by uniting the old Democratic constituencies with the voters who flocked to Ross Perot, wooed by his economic nationalism, fiscal conservatism and calls for political reform in Washington.
But the Clinton Administration quickly alienated Perotistas and Reagan Democrats by supporting homosexuals in the military, appointing lobbyists and Wall Street heavies to high positions, abandoning the middle-class tax cut and championing a stimulus package directed at cities.
Of course, no other Democrat could have done much better. While Mr. Clinton made obvious tactical errors, he had to address the needs of cities and suburbs, poor and middle class, under the straitened circumstances of a competitive international economy. It's the same dilemma that has plagued Democrats since 1968.
Mr. Clinton's victory in 1992, like Jimmy Carter's in 1976, was a product of unique circumstances -- in this case, a powerful third-party challenge and a tone-deaf Republican incumbent. Tuesday's elections represent the culmination of the process that began with Mr. Wallace's defection in 1968 but was interrupted by Watergate and George Bush's ineptitude.
This week, Republicans finally established a solid Congressional beachhead in the South: North Carolina's delegation, which had eight Democrats and four Republicans, now has eight Republicans and four Democrats; Georgia's, which had seven Democrats and four Republicans, now has seven Republicans and four Democrats.
Democrats also continued to lose ground among suburban whites in the East and Midwest who had been drawn to Mr. Wallace, Ronald Reagan and Mr. Perot. In a white suburban Cleveland district that went 23 percent for Mr. Perot in 1992, the freshman Democrat Eric Fingerhut was easily unseated. In the suburban Lansing, Mich., district formerly held by Representative Bob Carr, where Mr. Perot also won 23 percent in 1992, a Republican, Dick Chrysler, won easily. Nationwide, Perot voters voted for Republican House candidates by almost two to one.
The Democrats increasingly resemble a rump version of the old New Deal and Great Society coalition, supplemented by some upper-middle-class suburbanites offended by Republican ties to the religious right. Democrats can win elections against oddball candidates like Oliver North and Michael Huffington, but in economically devastated California they couldn't defeat an unpopular Republican Governor running on a platform of bashing immigrants.
Doesn't this mean that a Republican realignment has occurred? Not necessarily. Although united against Mr. Clinton, the Republicans are deeply divided among themselves. These differences surfaced in California's Senate election, where Mr. Huffington was widely scorned by the G.O.P. establishment, in New York's gubernatorial race, and in Virginia's Senate race, where the Republican Senator John Warner endorsed a third-party challenger, Marshall Coleman, against Mr. North. To some extent, the national Republican Party is the fractious Virginia branch writ large. And these internal differences will grow as the party is forced to govern rather than merely oppose.
While some Republican mayors and governors have proved effective leaders, the national party lacks the kind of constructive leadership that would allow it to create national prosperity without exacting the kind of sacrifices it condemns the Clinton Administration for. Representative Newt Gingrich's "Contract With America" was largely a throwback to the campaign platform of 1978, which also promised tax cuts and a balanced budget but led to huge deficits and financial scandals.
Republicans have nothing more to offer Perot voters than the Clinton Administration did. The party leadership is thoroughly committed to free trade and has blocked every effort at lobbying and campaign reform. Now that Republicans have won back the House, they will probably back away from their commitment to term limits. Their conservative populism is thematic rather than substantial.
In all likelihood, this election does not augur a new Republican realignment, but rather more instability. Both parties are likely to remain in the minority while more and more Americans cast about among third parties or abandon politics altogether. Congress will become more contentious, as it was in the late 19th century, and the results will be much the same: the near-impossibility of adopting major social legislation or undertaking comprehensive political reform. It's a situation that cries for change but makes change itself impossible.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE BUDGET;
Pataki Voices Shock at Learning Size of Gap in Budget He Inherits

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Governor-elect George E. Pataki expressed shock today upon learning that he would inherit a projected $4 billion budget shortfall next year from the Cuomo administration, but said he remained committed to his campaign pledge to cut income taxes by 25 percent over four years.
Mr. Pataki also asserted that the Cuomo administration should have taken steps to close next year's budget gap this year. "There's no question if there is that much of a deficit looming that it should have been revealed and steps should have been taken during the course of the year to correct our spending problems so we wouldn't be facing them come next April," he said. The state's fiscal year begins on April 1. 
 Mr. Pataki said during the campaign that his tax cut would be paid for through growth in the state's revenues and by curbing state spending, an explanation that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and other critics of the plan derided as unreasonable. Although there was no precise estimate of the size of the budget gap for next year, few in Albany expected it to be as high as $4 billion, a figure that Cuomo administration officials cited on Wednesday. But Mr. Pataki still will have to find far more savings than he has proposed just to balance next year's budget, even before he looks for additional cuts to achieve his tax plan.
The Governor-elect, a Republican, first heard about the projected budget gap when questioned about it by reporters in Buffalo this morning during a victory tour of four upstate cities. "Four-billion-dollar deficit?" he asked incredulously.
After pausing to collect his thoughts, he said: "The Governor leaving us with a $4 billion deficit -- it raises grave concerns. I haven't seen it. I haven't heard that before. We are just going to have to take a look at the numbers and look and see what we can do.
"Obviously, it's very upsetting if there is a deficit at all," he said. "Certainly a deficit of that proportion would be shocking."
Mr. Pataki spoke to reporters while flying from Buffalo to Rochester on a day in which he thanked upstate voters for his victory. He ended his tour in Albany, where he received a baseball bat as a gift from a local Assemblyman and joked, "Let me say there are a few people in the government we might use it on." [Page B4.]
Earlier in the day, top aides to Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki sat down in the Capitol for a first peacemaking session between the victor and the vanquished. Three advisers to Mr. Pataki met for nearly an hour with Mr. Cuomo's chief of staff, Andrew J. Zambelli, this afternoon to begin planning a transition from one government to the next.
Michael C. Finnegan, Mr. Pataki's campaign chairman and closest political friend, led the delegation, which he described as an ad hoc committee appointed by Mr. Pataki. The other members are James G. Natoli, the chief of staff to Clarence D. Rappleyea, the Assembly Republican minority leader, and John F. O'Mara, a former judge and Republican state committeeman from Elmira who is close to both Mr. Pataki and his patron, United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Mr. Finnegan said Mr. Zambelli acknowledged during the meeting that Mr. Pataki would inherit a large budget shortfall when he takes office on Jan. 1. But he said Mr. Zambelli did not say precisely how large the gap would be.
Mr. Finnegan said details would be provided when Mr. Pataki meets next week with Mr. Cuomo's budget director, Rudy Runko, who was out of town today. Mr. Zambelli declined to discuss the budget today, and Mr. Cuomo did not return telephone calls to his office and to the Executive Mansion seeking comment.
Cuomo administration officials, speaking on Wednesday on the condition of anonymity, said the state may face a shortfall of $4 billion, and possibly more, in next year's budget. This year's general-fund budget is $34 billion.
The shortfall does not mean there is a deficit in this year's budget. In fact, the Cuomo administration projects a small surplus in that budget. But when Mr. Cuomo proposed his budget early this year, he projected that it would leave a gap in next year's budget of $1.4 billion if spending and revenue levels stayed constant, except for inflationary increases.
And after negotiations with Mr. Cuomo, the Legislature enacted a budget in June that included deeper tax cuts and higher spending than Mr. Cuomo had proposed, and the Governor signed it into law. It was clear then that the adjustments made to Mr. Cuomo's proposed budget would leave a larger gap than originally projected. But it was not thought until recently that the gap would approach $4 billion, at least partly because tax revenues are not increasing so quickly as anticipated.
Anne W. Crowley, a spokeswoman for Mr. Cuomo, refused to confirm or deny the possibility of a $4 billion budget shortfall, a figure that was reported today in The New York Times. And she said Mr. Pataki was wrong to describe the shortfall as a deficit.
"There has been a projected deficit -- and projected is a very important word here -- every year," she said. "There have been years when we have had projected deficits of up to $7 billion. There were projected deficits in the last two years and we finished with a surplus. It's something you have to deal with when you propose your budget.
"This year, it would be inaccurate to state that there was no knowledge of a projected deficit for next year. There was certainly knowledge that there would be a projected deficit of over $2 billion."
Cynthia Green, a senior analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private organization, told The Associated Press that New York's fiscal status was the worst it has been in years. And other fiscal analysts said today that a shortfall of $4 billion would make the already difficult task of cutting taxes even more difficult.
Mr. Pataki's plan calls for the state to cut income taxes by $5.6 billion over four years, starting with a reduction of just over $1 billion next year. He must submit a budget proposal by Feb. 1.
"If there is this $4 billion deficit, obviously it's going to be very difficult," Mr. Pataki said of the budgeting process. "But I don't find the task daunting."
Mr. Finnegan, the Pataki aide, said his meeting with Mr. Zambelli also touched on the appointments process, labor negotiations and office space. He said Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki probably would speak directly about the transition at some point in the next day or two.
"Drew indicated that the Governor wanted to cooperate with George one on one and offered to be of any assistance in insuring a smooth transition," Mr. Finnegan said of Mr. Zambelli. "He indicated up front that the Governor had asked him not to take any action contrary to the philosophy of the Governor-elect." He described Mr. Zambelli as "gracious."
Mr. Zambelli said: "We're obviously going to have to run a government for the next seven weeks. But we're also conscious of the fact that someone else is going to be taking over after Jan. 1 and we're going to try to make that transition as seamless as possible."
Mr. Zambelli and Mr. Finnegan also discussed the number of political appointments in state government, a matter of dispute that became an issue in the campaign. Mr. Pataki contended during the campaign that Mr. Cuomo controlled between 5,000 and 15,000 patronage appointments and he pledged to cut that number by 20 percent. Mr. Cuomo scoffed at that number, and Mr. Zambelli reiterated today that there are not more than 2,500 political appointments.
Both Mr. Finnegan and Mr. Zambelli said the Pataki aides asked whether the Cuomo administration would provide state office space for the Pataki transition team in Manhattan and Albany, a request that Mr. Zambelli said was "reasonable."
The Pataki aides also asked whether it would be possible to place some members of the transition staff on the state payroll. "I told them I would look into that," Mr. Zambelli said.
Mr. Pataki is expected to make his first announcements about his transition operation early next week after returning from a three-day vacation. Mr. Finnegan said he was sending the Governor-elect off on Friday with a thick briefing book about state policy and personnel issues.
