SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1186 words

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE VOTERS;
Defections Among Men to G.O.P. Helped Insure Rout of Democrats

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Large numbers of men abandoned Democratic candidates in Tuesday's elections, a trend that gave Republicans an edge in races around the nation and one that Democratic leaders fear might be hard to reverse.
The overwhelming advantage that men gave Republicans touched races all over the country. For example, in Senate races in Michigan and Tennessee, where Republicans picked up open seats that had been held by Democrats, 61 percent of the men voted for the Republicans. 
 The defections among men to Republicans was compounded by signs that women were less enthusiastic about voting for Democrats this year. The most notable example is in Texas, where Gov. Ann W. Richards, a tough-talking Democrat, drew a far smaller proportion of women in losing to George W. Bush than she had four years ago. In part, that may be because Mrs. Richards's opponent in 1990, Clayton Williams, made statements that were offensive to many women.
And while Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Republican, had expressed fears that Democratic women would flock to his opponent, Kathleen Brown, that did not happen. He captured 50 percent percent of women's votes; 60 percent of men supported him.
Political analysts say the shift by men to Republicans was fueled by a particular disaffection for President Clinton among men, who are troubled more than women by his stands on issues like homosexuals in the military and health care and because men have become more sympathetic to hard-line Republican positions on issues like crime and taxes, which were central in political campaigns this year.
Nationwide, 54 percent of men and 46 percent of women voted for Republican House candidates, according to a survey of voters leaving the polls, the largest gap since at least 1980.
Black voters, both men and women, continued to vote overwhelmingly for Democratic candidates. But among whites, 62 percent of men voted for Republicans, as did 55 percent of women.
"We got clobbered among white men," said Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of moderate Democrats that Mr. Clinton once led. "When I go around I hear them talking about gays in the military, raising taxes and health care. Clinton has the problem of being more defined by his failures than his successes." Mr. From said there were no easy remedies for winning back men except that Mr. Clinton needed to display tougher leadership on a range of issues.
Some Democratic women said the problem was not simply Mr. Clinton but the lack of interest this year among women in the wake of record gains among female candidates in the 1992 campaign, when the fracas between Clarence Thomas and Prof. Anita F. Hill energized women voters. This apathy, they said, made it difficult for Democrats to counter the movement of men to the Republican Party.
"I see a lot of women stunned," said Senator Patty Murray of Washington, a Democrat who was elected two years ago. She said 1992 was "a new mood for women."
"They were excited and they won and they went home and they didn't realize that it could all be undone in two years," Senator Murray said.
There are still more factors driving men to vote Republican. Many independent voters, including those who backed Ross Perot for President in 1992, voted for Republicans. The supporters of Mr. Perot were disproportionately male. In addition, analysts say many younger men who turned on President George Bush two years ago because they were not doing well financially are now turning on the Democratic Administration because they are still no better off.
"I don't think men feel like they're being helped out," said Charles Rund, a Republican poll taker in San Francisco. "Clinton gave up his economic discussion way too early in the Administration."
Democratic women who ran for office, already fighting a Republican tide, said their campaigns had been complicated further by their sex.
Representative Lynn Schenk, a Democrat from San Diego who was elected in 1992 and lost her race for re-election, said she was in partly a victim of impossibly high expectations for women.
"Two years ago was the so called 'Year of the Woman,' and there were enormous, I think unrealistic, expectations that the women in Congress could somehow in 18 months turn around a mess that was created in 18 years," she said. "It was sort of the 'Mom can fix it' attitude. And mom just needed a little more time. I think there was a backlash."
Some Democratic women said they were at a disadvantage this year not only because greater proportions of men voted for Republicans but also because the sex of the candidates played to the stereotype that women were not as strong on issues like crime.
In Ms. Schenk's case, she said she was hurt by her opponent's effort to make her look weak on another issue, immigration. "I debated my opponent seven times," she said, "where the audience was overwhelmingly white male and overwhelming angry about illegal immigration.
Phil Roeder, who ran the losing campaign of Bonnie Campbell, a Democrat who ran for governor of Iowa, said his candidate's sex was also a disadvantage. "The gender issue was always just under the surface," he said "It raised the hurdle that a campaign needed to clear a little bit higher. The Republicans certainly wanted to portray Bonnie as often as they could as being weak on crime. They'd say, "This is a women, so how could she be tough on crime?' "
One notable exception where women rallied to help a Democratic candidate was in Virgina, where analysts said women and blacks gave an edge to Senator Charles S. Robb, a Democrat. These voters may have been spurred to participate out of concern that Mr. Robb's opponent, Oliver L. North, was not supportive of issues that concerned them.
The biggest disappointment for women on Tuesday was that in addition to Governor Richards, every women who ran for governor was defeated. They were Democratic challengers in California, Illinois, Iowa and Rhode Island, and Republicans in Hawaii and Maine.
They fared better in the Senate, where Dianne Feinstein of California, a Democrat, who claimed victory in a race awaiting a count of absentee ballots, Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas, a Republican, who was re-elected, and Olympia J. Snowe, a Republican, captured an open Senate seat in Maine.
In the House, the losses of women who are Democrats were roughly representative of those among Democrats over all. Though a handful of House races with women have yet to be decided, nine Democratic women House incumbents were defeated. Seven of them were elected in 1992 and were from districts that were not heavily Democratic. And those losses were balanced by the victories of 10 women. But the ideologies many of the new women are much different: six of them are Republicans, and their ranks include several who are opposed to abortion.
One of the newly elected Republican House members, Sue Myrick of North Carolina, said she did not believe she was helped or hurt by her sex. "We ran on the agenda that the American people wanted to hear and they said they wanted done. That's the bottom line."

HEADLINE: IRAQIS TO ACCEPT KUWAIT'S BORDERS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Iraq said today that it would recognize the independence and current borders of Kuwait, a major step apparently intended to allow at least some United Nations sanctions against Baghdad to be lifted.
A declaration of the Revolutionary Command Council, signed by President Saddam Hussein, said Iraq accepted the "sovereignty of the State of Kuwait, its territorial integrity and political independence." The recognition, more than four years after Iraq invaded Kuwait and provoked the Persian Gulf war, was also approved by the Iraqi Parliament and is to be published in the Government's gazette, as required by United Nations resolutions. 
 If Iraq follows through on the pledge and ceases to portray Kuwait in any way as an Iraqi province, this would be its first formal recognition of an independent Kuwait since the small emirate ceased to be a British protectorate 33 years ago.
The move brought only a guarded response from the United States and other members of the Security Council, including the French, who have tried to encourage Iraqi compliance by holding out the prospect of rewards. American and British diplomats said recognition of Kuwait was only one step toward compliance with resolutions that would allow the Council to consider lifting sanctions imposed before and after the gulf war in 1991.
"There is a very long list of things Iraq has to do to get sanctions lifted, which related to its policies and practices, some of which in the last few weeks have not been of the sort to encourage people to lift sanctions," said Sir David Hannay, the chief British delegate.
In Baghdad, Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia, who has been urging Mr. Hussein to recognize Kuwait, told reporters that Iraq was still surrounded by "a wall of ice." But according to the Iraqi news agency, he said he hoped there was now a little sun in the sky to begin to melt it.
The Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, has asked for a meeting on Monday with Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate, in her capacity as this month's Security Council President. American officials said this was not to be interpreted as a high-level meeting between Iraq and the United States. Ms. Albright is a member of the President Clinton's Cabinet.
Mr. Aziz is expected to present to the Council the Iraqi declaration recognizing Kuwait and give assurances of cooperation in other matters, including the international monitoring of Iraqi weapons programs. Baghdad's leaders got a less than positive message on that front today.
Rolf Ekeus, the head of a United Nations commission charged with monitoring Iraqi weapons programs, reported to the Security Council that there were come concerns that Mr. Hussein's Government was not giving his team "straight and factual answers" about past suppliers of material for chemical weapons. He also said there was more investigating to be done on an Iraqi research project possibly related to the production of biological weapons.
The Clinton Administration takes the position that the United Nations sanctions program is not a mechanical process in which steps announced by Iraq bring automatic rewards. The United States, sometimes to the annoyance of other Council members, sees the decision on whether to ease sanctions as a political judgment about Mr. Hussein's intentions as well as his actions.
In Washington, a State Department spokeswoman said the United States was studying the Iraqi announcement. "If today's announcements are followed by the necessary implementing measures, it will mark an important achievement for the United Nations Security Council, which has steadfastly insisted that Iraq comply and comply fully with all its requirements," said the spokeswoman, Christine Shelly.
But she added: "The international community will not be satisfied with partial steps. Even if Iraq has by Monday taken the necessary steps to carry out today's announcements, it will have complied with only one of a number of requirements established by the Security Council."
Mohammed A. Abulhasan, Kuwait's delegate to the United Nations, said in an interview today that Iraq's announced decision to recognize his country was "an important step in the right direction." But he added that he hoped this would be followed by the freeing of over 600 Kuwaiti prisoners of war and the return of Kuwaiti property and military equipment seized in 1991.
The economic embargo against Iraq was imposed by the Security Council on Aug. 6, 1990, and allows the importation of only medicines and food. With its economy now in ruins, Iraq is eager to sell oil to raise money abroad, and would be free to sell commodities if it met all its obligations to destroy its major weapons or to allow full control and monitoring of them.

HEADLINE: Clinton Asks G.O.P. to Back Free Trade

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton appealed today to the newly victorious Republicans to maintain their party's traditional support for free trade and approve a worldwide trade agreement in Congress, arguing that failure to do so would "jeopardize our leadership and our prosperity."
In a speech at Georgetown University Mr. Clinton, clearly tired as he prepared to leave for Asia on Friday for an economic summit meeting, sounded frustrated that many Americans still suspected that his trade proposals will cost them jobs and cut their wages. 
 His speech was the kickoff of what the Administration hoped a few days ago would be an economic triple-play: a meeting with Asian and Pacific leaders aimed at securing a political commitment to free trade in the region, the quick passage of the trade pact and then the first "hemispheric summit" with trading partners in Latin America.
But as the enormity of the electoral setback on Tuesday settled in on the White House, that ambitious agenda seemed threatened. Mr. Clinton's stature among Asian and Pacific leaders is already somewhat diminished by the election results, his aides acknowledged today, and it would be further undermined if the trade pact failed to pass Congress. The agreement is the base upon which Mr. Clinton hoped to build his still vaguely defined vision of a "Pacific community," binding trading partners from China to Chile.
Mr. Clinton seemed to acknowledge today that passage of the 123-nation agreement known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is still far from assured. He urged Republicans in Congress to make a first showing of post-election bipartisanship and "do what's right for all Americans," arguing that the United States is well placed to gain from the agreement. But he seemed to sense that a growing number of Americans were unconvinced.
"For too many of our people, trade still appears to be a gale force wind, just another threat ready to blow away the prospects of a stable job at a good wage," Mr. Clinton said, with some frustration in his voice.
In private, Mr. Clinton's aides were increasingly concerned that the approval of GATT, as the agreement is called, could run aground in the Senate, or be delayed until the new and far more conservative Congress comes to town. That failure, Mr. Clinton's aides acknowledged, would kill any chance that America's biggest trading partners would agree to more open markets or make vast reductions in their tariffs.
"The combination of efforts to open markets in Asia, the GATT vote and the hemispheric summit will quite literally shape the economic future of America in the next century," Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, said today. "If you delay the GATT to next year you are costing the American economy tens of billions of dollars in growth. I don't think anyone, Democrats or Republicans, wants to do that."
Mr. Clinton's hope is to go beyond GATT and build even greater commitments to open markets in the two biggest regions for American business: Asia and Latin America. In Asia, the plan is to obtain general agreement for free trade by the year 2020 -- a goal distant enough, the Administration hopes, to relieve the fears of China and smaller nations of being overrun by more competitive American and Japanese products.
Officials are hoping for more concrete agendas at the Latin American meeting, saying that the area's common cultures and languages will make it easier to integrate a free-trade region, probably by taking new members into the North American Free Trade Agreement.
While the meeting with the Asian leaders will be more symbolic, there are several challenges and potential risks for Mr. Clinton.
His aides are groping their way toward a redefinition of foreign policy in an age when free-trade zones are debated with a passion once reserved for disarmament talks.
Mr. Clinton's first challenge is to convince Americans of an argument he has been advancing for the past two years: that broader, freer trade with Asia will benefit the American economy and American workers.
It is not an obvious truth. While Asia has been a great new market for American exports, the United States is currently running its biggest trade deficits in the Pacific. The deficit with Japan this year is likely to hit $60 billion, flirting with a record. The deficit with China, the market every American company is rushing toward, was $17.6 billion for the first eight months of 1994.
And there are smaller but significant deficits with South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore.
Mr. Clinton is also caught in a moment of transition, a moment in which the United States -- for the first time since World War II -- needs Asia as much as the Asian nations need the United States.
In recent years, trade with the United States has diminished greatly as a percentage of all trade in Asia, meaning that the countries in the region are far more dependent on each other than on trade across the Pacific. In contrast, nearly a third of all American exports are now headed across the Pacific, and that figure is rising.
Moreover, the United States is now one of the least important sources of capital for Asia. About 11 percent of all investment in Asia now comes from the United States.
In fact, the major American influence in the region today stems from the military's continued presence. Most Asian nations want that presence to continue, partly to contain North Korea and partly as a counter to the two biggest military powers in the region, China and Japan.

HEADLINE: Asian Nations Wary on Free Trade

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 10

 BODY:
The nations of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which represent more than half the world's economic output, all say they agree in principle with President Clinton that the path to further prosperity is to lower ever more barriers to trade and investment.
But as leaders from the United States and the other 17 member countries gather here for a summit meeting, the notion of achieving even a vague commitment for a giant Pacific free-trade zone from Chile to China, even far in the future, has led to apprehension as well as expectation. 
 The Pacific zone was pressed vigorously by President Clinton a year ago, when he spoke in Seattle of an Asian Pacific "community." The leaders are gathering here to decide whether to begin turning that concept into reality by setting a target date for free trade.
Foreign ministers and trade officials will meet on Friday and Saturday here in the capital. On Tuesday heads of state, including President Clinton, will assemble in Bogor, a scenic area just outside Jakarta. In between, the leaders will pair off for bilateral meetings.
To be sure, any declaration that emerges from Bogor will be vague and nonbinding. Exactly how to achieve free trade will be left to future meetings. And the deadlines being contemplated, 2020 for developing nations and perhaps 10 years earlier for some other countries, are far enough away so that it will not have much immediate impact.
But in an organization that spans four continents and levels of wealth ranging from Japan's per-capita output of more than $30,000 a year to China's $400, there are certain to be conflicting agendas.
Initially there were fears that the West wanted to create a model of the European Union, an idea that raised fears of an integrated association that could threaten the sovereignty of member nations.
And many of the Asian nations with closed markets have suspicions that despite Washington's talk of community, it is merely interested in using the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation group, known as APEC, to break down trade barriers that prevent American companies from selling more products to the fast-growing markets of the East.
"Asia is an area where there is potential economic opportunity for the United States, and that is as far as it goes," said Derek da Cunha, senior fellow at the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies in Singapore, describing his view of Washington's priorities.
It is too soon to tell whether Mr. Clinton's ability to influence events here will be weakened by the triumph of Republicans in mid-term elections this week. But the Republican sweep has raised some doubts about whether the Democratic-controlled, lame-duck 103d Congress will approve the GATT agreement at a special session after Thanksgiving. Most nations at the conference are counting on GATT to spur their economies.
The first skirmish of the meeting in Jakarta has already broken out. In preparatory talks this week, the United States objected to a proposed voluntary code aimed at liberalizing foreign investment in member countries, saying it did not go far enough.
China has expressed reservations about a timetable for free trade. "In view of the diversity of the Asia Pacific countries, this timetable should be very flexible," President Jiang Zemin said before leaving Beijing earlier this week.
Even more firm in his opposition is Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who fears APEC will diminish the importance of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, six countries that are already moving to form a trading bloc. Mr. Mahathir has also championed an East Asian Economic Caucus, which would include Japan but exclude the United States, Australia and other Western members of the larger group.
Rafidah Aziz, Malaysia's Minister of International Trade and Industry, said this week that an effort to establish a trade timetable was a meaningless exercise because the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum has no means of enforcement.
Still, many analysts say the prospects for movement forward are probably better now than they were a year ago.
"There is discussion and debate about whether there should be a target or not, but nobody disagrees on trade liberalization," said Ippei Yamazawa, a professor of economics at Hitotsubashi University in Tokyo and a member of the so-called Eminent Persons Group, a committee of private citizens that drafted proposals for APEC trade liberalization.
Last year, Asian nations were also fearful that linking up in a big community would subject them to more pressure from Washington on human rights, although those fears were eased somewhat by the decision to detach human rights concerns from China's trade status.
Moreover, this year the free trade agenda is being pushed most strongly by Indonesia, the host country. It is harder for developing nations to resist the appeals of one of their own.
Indonesia last year resisted the United States trade proposals. Some experts say Indonesia's about-face this year reflects the desire of President Suharto to leave an international legacy by making the Bogor declaration something to remember.
Even without the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation group, the Asian region is moving toward economic integration. The member nations' economies are becoming too big to grow simply by exporting to the United States and Europe. Now, they must sell to to one another.
Japan's exports to Asia now exceed its exports to the United States, in part because Japanese companies have built a network of factories in Southeast Asia that must be supplied with components and machinery. Some of the biggest investors in China are ethnic Chinese entrepreneurs from Hong Kong, Taiwan and Southeast Asia.
The six Asean nations -- Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand -- recently accelerated plans to lower tariffs among themselves.
Even some of those who favor free trade, however, wonder whether APEC should be the organization to bring it about. The group was started in 1989 as a forum for discussion. The fact that its name, Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, does not end with "organization," "association" or a similar noun attests to the reluctance of its founders to make it an institution. It operates by consensus, without any mechanism for voting, and many members would prefer to see it stay that way.
"At this stage, making it rigid might not be the right emphasis," said Rizalino Navarro, secretary of trade and industry of the Philippines. "The emphasis should be on the direction, not the timetable or the institution."
But APEC is rapidly growing more institutional. Two years ago members decided to create a permanent secretariat based in Singapore, and this year there is talk of expanding it. More committees have been formed. The number of members has grown. And Chile's enrollment at this year's meeting extends the forum into South America.
A big step toward increasing the group's importance came at last year's meeting in Seattle, when the heads of state were invited for the first time.
Another question is whether an APEC free-trade plan is needed and whether it would conflict with or complement the global trading system under GATT or the smaller, more tightly integrated trade zones like the North American Free Trade Agreement and the new Asean Free Trade Area.
"With progress made in the GATT and with progress made in unilateral liberalization, the need for regional arrangements weakens a great deal," said Djisman Simandjuntak, a member of the board of the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Jakarta.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTIONS: THE REPUBLICANS;
New Majority's Agenda: Substantial Changes May Be Ahead

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
When Republicans take control of the Senate and House in January, they will propose a legislative agenda drastically different from President Clinton's, which could lead to substantial changes in a broad array of Federal programs and laws, as well as the workings of Congress. Following are brief looks at the main issues.
 
FOREIGN POLICY
 
 
With Jesse Helms of North Carolina in line to become chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, the Republican majority in Congress is expected to push to cut foreign aid as well as money for the U.N. Republican lawmakers also say they will require a Congressional vote before the United States contributes troops or money to any U.N. peacekeeping mission. 
 Judging from past statements, the Republicans will also take a skeptical view of economic aid to Russia and of the Administration's new agreement with North Korea that freezes the North's nuclear program.
Mr. Helms, a conservative, vows not to rubber-stamp new treaties, and some Congressional aides predict he will oppose ratification of treaties restricting the use of chemical weapons and establishing rules on shipping and mining in the world's seas. He also wants to rethink the level of the nation's contributions to the World Bank and to reduce the size of the Agency for International Development. Mr. Helms, an expert parliamentary street fighter, is also expected to exercise veto power over some nominations for ambassadorships.
With Mr. Dole, who is a critic of the Administration's Bosnia policy, likely to become Senate majority leader, the President will face even more pressure to push other nations to lift the arms embargo on Bosnia. Efforts to set a deadline on withdrawing all troops from Haiti may also gather steam, and it may be harder for Mr. Clinton to win ratification of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a world trade agreement.
Arlen Specter, a moderate Republican from Pennsylvania, will take over the Senate Intelligence Committee, while Larry Combest, a conservative Republican from the Texas Panhandle, is in line to oversee intelligence matters in the House. Mr. Specter says the intelligence community needs an overhaul, but Mr. Combest has generally supported the Central Intelligence Agency and has suggested that its budget be increased. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell Last Month

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Producer prices dropped by five-tenths of 1 percent in October for the second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported yesterday, providing more evidence that inflation remained mild despite strong economic growth for more than a year.
More than anything else, car prices pulled down the Producer Price Index in October. The index measures the prices charged for finished goods as they leave factories, mills and refineries ready for use and are sold to wholesalers, retailers, auto dealers and others. 
 "During the past year, we have seen annual rates of inflation that are among the lowest in a generation," Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, said in a statement.
She noted that producer prices during the last 12 months had risen by just 1 percent. Moreover, unit labor costs -- the wages paid to make a product -- were up by just nine-tenths of 1 percent.
The Consumer Price Index has risen a mild 2.8 percent for the year through September. The October number will be released next week.
The bond market initially greeted the producer price report by pushing down interest rates yesterday morning. [Page D5.] By late afternoon, however, rates had regained all the lost ground and then some, in part for other reasons. Despite the mild inflation reports, many traders remain convinced, as they have for weeks, that the nation's inflation will soon rise.
To prevent that from happening, the Federal Reserve's top policy makers almost certainly will raise interest rates again when they meet next Tuesday, according to many bond traders. The higher loan rates
would slow inflation by slowing the growth of an economy that lives on credit. In the process, unemployment would rise.
No one knows, however, what the Federal Reserve will actually do on Tuesday. Some Fed policy makers said last week that while economic growth was stronger than they had expected, inflation was weaker. That might suggest, they said, that the economy has more room for growth without inflation than anticipated.
"The bond market rejects that view," Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said. "The market wants a Federal Reserve determined to preserve the gains against inflation that have occurred so far."
Adding to the fear that inflation will accelerate eventually was the Labor Department's report yesterday that prices for intermediate goods -- steel, plastics, chemicals, metals and the like that go into finished goods -- rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in October, matching the increase in September.
What is more, if food and energy are taken out of the calculation, because they move up and down with great volatility, then intermediate prices have risen by a little more each month since July, reaching an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in October.
"If the pressure from intermediate prices keeps coming, eventually this will push up finished goods prices," said Donald C. Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting center at Georgia State University. But he and other analysts noted that while wages accounted for 70 percent or so of a product's cost, materials prices contributed less than 30 percent.
Two other statistics yesterday added a little weight to the view that inflation would remain mild.
The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, a measure of the public's willingness to spend, fell in November, according to private subscribers to the index. The university will not release the final index figure until further polls are taken this month.
And the Labor Department reported that first-time applicants for unemployment insurance rose to 330,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, from 322,000 in the previous week.
The producer price report was straightforward. Pricing for new-car and light-truck models accounted for more than 90 percent of the fall, said Angelo Maggi, an economist at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. New-model prices did not actually fall. But they rose by less than the Labor Department had calculated that they would in October, a traditional month for model introductions. That registered in the October Producer Price Index as a drop in vehicle prices.
"The index is overstating the moderation in automobile and truck prices," Mr. Ratajczak said.
There were no other significant price changes, except for sharp drops in heating oil and gasoline, perhaps reflecting concerns that oil inventories were high, and sharp changes, up and down, in various food products, particularly roasted coffee, which rose in price by 50 percent.
Excluding these volatile changes in food and energy, the "core" Producer Price Index for consumer goods still fell by five-tenths of 1 percent, after a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in September. With vehicles also left out, the index for finished goods rose just one-tenth of 1 percent.
The index for crude goods -- items like raw tobacco, coal, cattle hides and unprocessed milk -- fell by six-tenths of 1 percent in October and 1.6 percent in September.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Decline After Early Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday, falling back from substantial early gains and ending a two-day rally as the dollar stumbled and investor fears again turned to the threat of inflation.
Some of those fears were attributed to comments made by a Texas Republican, Bill Archer, the incoming chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. He said in an interview on the cable channel CNBC that he favored cutting taxes. 
 Traders said he raised the specter among some market participants of a higher budget deficit, which would mean the Government would have to borrow more, perhaps leading to higher interest rates.
Mr. Archer is scheduled to take over as head of the crucial tax-writing panel when the Republicans take control of the House in January. Among his goals, he said, are a cut in the tax rate on capital gains from investments and the restoration of tax-sheltered individual retirement accounts for upper-income people.
Mr. Archer's comments brought an earlier market rally to a halt. Initially, bonds gained ground following a decline in the October producer prices data. Many had expected the numbers would show an increase instead. It was the second straight decline in the Producer Price Index, suggesting that inflation remains mild. A survey by Bloomberg Business News showed analysts had been expecting a one-tenth of 1 percent gain over all.
The long bond fell 13/32 of a point, to 92 26/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 8.14 percent, after falling as low as 8.04 percent on the release of the producer prices data.
Other news favorable to bonds yesterday included the University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index for November. It slipped to 90.1 from 92.7 in October, slightly lower than expected, indicating that consumers are less optimistic about the economy. That suggests the economy might slow enough for price pressures to ease.
The market caught a second wind as bonds appeared to benefit from speculation that the dollar's weakness would be addressed at a meeting of finance ministers of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations yesterday in Toronto.
James Hale, fixed-income analyst for MMS International, pointed to Mr. Archer's comments as one of the reasons for the afternoon fall. He said the technically driven traders who follow charts and trends also contributed. "They were faked into the market early thinking prices would continue up," he said, "but when prices sagged as the dollar fizzled they reversed themselves and sold to cut losses."
Mr. Hale added, "The fact that we couldn't pull off another solid day after a favorable report underscores that we're still in a bear market."
Some analysts suggested that the absence of significant price pressures in recent reports meant that the Fed was more likely to proceed cautiously in raising rates. Producer prices at the final goods level remained stable in October. But the price increases at the intermediate goods level, excluding food and energy, continue to generate some concern to investors.
"The P.P.I., down for the second straight month, could suggest that the Fed is not as far behind in its inflation watch as the market has feared," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh. "The rest is just a guessing game."
But the Fed will be looking at an array of information that indicates that economic growth remains strong enough to add to inflationary pressures. "This good number," Mr. Hoffman said, "will not deter them from moving rates up."
The Government bond market is expected to be closed today because of Veterans Day, a Federal holiday. Some dealers, however, will keep skeleton trading crews on hand.
Yesterday, the Treasury sold $17 billion of one-year bills at an average rate of 6.09 percent, and $12 billion of 37-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.11 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's one-year bill and 37-day cash-management bill auctions:

HEADLINE: Restoring the Rails on Staten Island;
Plans for Economic Revival Stretch Along 15 Miles of Track

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
To the people who live on the north shore of Staten Island, the abandoned railroad that cuts through their neighborhoods is an unsightly ruin where prostitutes and drug addicts hide. It barely resembles the gleaming steel line that 40 years ago linked local factories to their markets and carried passengers to the amusements of South Beach.
But to New York City officials, the defunct Staten Island Railway -- a 15-mile stretch of overgrown, rusty tracks and ramshackle stations -- is essential to revitalizing the area's stagnant economy and could provide an alternate freight route that would reduce pollution from trucks. 
 So two weeks ago, the city took the unusual step of buying the railroad, with an eye toward restoring freight service over the next two years and, perhaps, creating a new and possibly less expensive way for freight to reach Brooklyn and Long Island.
Using Federal transportation money, the city's Economic Development Corporation bought the railroad for $10.3 million from CSX Transportation. It said it plans to spend $1 million in state funds to rehabilitate the part of the railroad on western Staten Island over the next year. As part of the deal, the New Jersey Department of Transportation bought the section between the Arthur Kill and Cranford Junction, N.J.
City officials say their main priority is to restore freight service from Staten Island to points west. The hope is to revitalize the idle Howland Hook Marine Terminal on Staten Island near the Goethals Bridge and to make the economically depressed north shore more attractive to manufacturers.
In addition, they said, the line would allow train cars to be floated on barges to the newly rebuilt 65th Street Railyard in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, where they could be hauled east on the Long Island Rail Road or north to New England. This would reduce the number of trucks that traverse the city, clogging the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and highways in Brooklyn.
Staten Island political leaders are also dreaming out loud about resurrecting passenger trains that used to link neighborhoods along the north shore to the Staten Island Ferry terminal in St. George. Although no money is available to rebuild a passenger line -- officials estimate that it would cost $65 million -- the city's purchase has insured that no one else will acquire the old right of way and develop it.
"If you lose a railroad corridor, you never get it back again," said Chris Ward, vice president for transportation for the city's Economic Development Corporation. "That is the biggest issue."
Guy V. Molinari, the Borough President of Staten Island, said he had dreamed for years about restoring rail service to the impoverished neighborhoods along the north shore. He said he believes a passenger train there would revitalize the area economically and reduce the congestion on highways.
For older residents, the proposal to restore passenger service recalls simpler times when railroads were king. Leon Suwalski, 87, can remember his youth when the railroad, built in 1886, was the gateway to the city and, for some, the entire country. Restless young men would hop freight trains going west, he said, while the less adventurous would ride passenger cars to the Staten Island Ferry or the amusement parks on the southern shore of the island.
But in 1953, passenger trains stopped running, and the freight trains that used to supply factories along the route gradually disappeared.
The immediate goal, city officials say, is to break Conrail's stranglehold over freight lines into New York City and Long Island. Trains now carrying goods into New York City must go north over Conrail lines to Selkirk, just south of Albany, then back down the east side of the Hudson, through the Bronx and finally onto Long Island. Or they can travel to a Conrail rail yard between Jersey City and Bayonne, the Greenville Yard, and be tugged on barges to Bush Terminal in Brooklyn.
Conrail, created by the Federal Government in the 1970's from several bankrupt railroads, also controls the flow of goods in the opposite direction. Ships coming through New York Harbor to marine terminals in New Jersey must unload onto Conrail trains before they can reach other railroad lines that go west.
Because Conrail has no competition from other railroad companies, city officials say, it has little incentive to try to undercut the prices of trucking companies for freight business east of the Hudson River in Manhattan and on Long Island.
The result is that most of the goods arriving by freight train into the region stop in New Jersey, where they are loaded onto trucks. The trucks then take them through already congested bridges and tunnels, contributing to air pollution.
City officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the Giuliani administration is considering setting up a paper railroad corporation and seeking permission from the Federal Government to operate between Howland Hook and Cranford Junction. The corporation would then contract with a major railroad other than Conrail to provide service on the line.
New York City is more dependent on trucks than any other city in the nation, with about 60,000 coming in every day. Rail carries only about 2.8 percent of the freight the city uses, while trucks account for 90 percent. On average in the rest of the nation, about 26 percent of freight is moved by train and less than 50 percent is hauled in trucks.
One open question is whether there will be enough ships coming into Howland Hook to make it attractive to a train operators. The city bought the terminal in the early 1970's, but the former tenant, United States Lines, went bankrupt by 1986 as more and more ships opted to go to Port Newark and Elizabeth, in New Jersey.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which leases the terminal from the city, is spending $24 million to renovate it. The authority has found a new tenant for the terminal, Carmine F. Ragucci, and is predicting at least 50,000 containers a year being shipped through the terminal by next year.
For residents on the north shore of Staten Island, the refurbished marine terminal and rail line represent a promise of 1,700 jobs and the possibility of a return to the days before World War II, when people could take trains to the St. George Ferry Terminal rather than join the crush of cars at rush hours on Richmond Terrace, the main road along the north coast.
"Now the railroad is just a haven for hookers and junkies. And Richmond Terrace is jammed with traffic," said George Lauro, 38, who owns a garage next to the tracks in Port Richmond.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Allstate's size helps profits, but also makes for added risk.

BYLINE: By Michael Quint 

 BODY:
AS one of the nation's largest insurers of homes and autos, the Allstate Corporation reaps the rewards of name recognition and economies of scale that in normal times help make it very profitable.
But with that size comes additional risk that the company would just as soon avoid, or at least reduce. A $2.7 billion loss in 1992 from Hurricane Andrew in Florida and a $1.3 billion loss from the Los Angeles earthquake early this year have wreaked havoc on Allstate's profits. After a loss of $500 million in 1992, the company saw profits jump to a record $1.3 billion in disaster-free 1993, but earnings have slumped to $320.7 million in the first nine months of this year. 
 Despite the company's success in recent years in building up both its property insurance and its life insurance businesses, cutting overhead expenses and maintaining a good record for limiting its ordinary loss claims, the vulnerability to disasters has cast a shadow over its stock price.
Since June 1993, when Sears, Roebuck & Company, sold nearly 20 percent of Allstate for $2.36 billion -- the largest initial public stock offering of any company -- its stock rose from $27 to a peak of $34.25 in October last year only to slide to yesterday's close of $24.125, down 75 cents.
Because of Sears's plan to distribute the remaining 360 million Allstate shares to Sears shareholders, some traders expect the stock to come under additional pressure.
A. Michael Franquilli of Salomon Brothers said before the Sears announcement that Allstate's growth and success in controlling costs and day-to-day claims losses justified a buy recommendation. Others, such as Weston M. Hicks of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, have neutral opinions, partly because of its vulnerability to disasters.
Mr. Hicks said that the company was not likely to improve on the stellar performance of its automobile insurance business. He reduced his estimate for 1995 earnings yesterday to $3.05 a share from $3.15 because ending the ties with Sears will eliminate some tax benefits.
Jerry D. Choate, Allstate's chief executive, says reducing the exposure to catastrophe losses was his top priority. But in an interview yesterday, he did not offer much hope for a quick solution.
By not accepting new customers in California and large parts of Florida -- and declining to renew any customers in three Florida counties, soon to be five -- he said the company was making good progress toward reducing its estimated maximum loss from any single event to $1 billion by 1997. But he added that Allstate had still not purchased reinsurance to reduce its losses from disasters "because it is too expensive" and unavailable in the amounts Allstate would need.
In the meantime, Mr. Choate said he watched the weather channel on TV "a lot more than I would like."
John Snyder, senior vice president at the A. M. Best Company, a rating firm, said that operating without the reinsurance that most other companies buy "is a viable strategy for Allstate because they are big enough to survive." But the absence does mean "that from time to time they will suffer some very big losses and have to pick themselves up."
How lucky Allstate will be can only be a guess. But other insurers expect even more costly disasters. Munich Re, a German company and the world's largest reinsurance company, said earlier this week that it planned to reduce its exposure in many parts of the world because climatic changes, including global warming, would lead to more severe storms in areas where population growth and real estate development have sharply increased insurers' risks. "If I was a betting man, I could offer you a bet that the records of recent years will be beaten by new damage records," Wolf Otto Bauer, a director, said in a recent article in The Financial Times of London.
But even if Allstate continues growing and improving its efficiency and is lucky enough to avoid new disasters, some analysts assume that many Sears shareholders will want to sell the stock, thereby depressing its price. Managers of index funds, for example, are big investors in Sears because of its place in the Standard & Poor's 500 Stock Index, but would have no reason to hold Allstate, which is not part of that index.
Institutions that own both Sears and Allstate may find themselves with more of the insurer than they want. Fidelity Management of Boston, for example, is the largest outside holder of Sears, with 19 million shares at midyear, and also one of the largest holders of Allstate, with 10.7 million shares. Fidelity declined comment.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains, Then Steadies After U.S. Bond Activity

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday, following United States bonds higher before retreating.
Traders often watch the Treasury market to gauge investor demand for American assets and the dollars needed to buy them. A late slump in bonds prompted traders to pare the dollar's gains yesterday. 
 Bonds and the dollar rose after the Labor Department reported that producer prices fell five-tenths of 1 percent in October. It was the first back-to-back drop in more than three years and a signal that inflation is under control. Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds, and fears that inflation will accelerate have weighed down the bond market and the value of the dollar this year.
"There is more and more a sense from market participants that the dollar has hit bottom," said Richard Koss, manager of currency sales at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in New York. But for the dollar's rise to be sustained, he said, "we need a signal from the bond market that it has bottomed as well."
The dollar rose as high as 1.5365 German marks yesterday before settling in New York at 1.5285 marks, down from 1.5315 marks. The dollar also slipped against the Japanese yen, to 97.73 yen, from 97.80 yen on Wednesday.
Foreign-exchange trading is expected to be limited today, with many banks and businesses in the United States and Europe closed because of holidays.
Many traders expect the dollar to tumble next week if the Federal Reserve does not raise short-term interest rates by at least a half a percentage point after its policy-making committee meets on Tuesday. The Fed has not raised rates more than that since the early 1980's.
A larger rate increase could bolster the dollar by easing concern about inflation and making American deposits more attractive.
In other currency trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.2831 Swiss francs, up from 1.2825 francs on Wednesday; at 5.2565 French francs, up from 5.2502 francs, and at 1,567.0 Italian lire, down from 1,569.50 lire. The British pound fell to $1.6000 from $1.6055.

HEADLINE: Why Do Male Athletes Assault Women? Research Begins

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
Somewhere between the West Point football gropers and the heavyweight rapist, Mike Tyson, may be a vast, troubling, uncharted area of sexual assault on women by male athletes, a kind of Bermuda Triangle of sports in which discussion mysteriously disappears.
Anecdotal evidence pops up several times a week, a paragraph or two here and there about another pro player beating his wife or a college team raping a drunken classmate, but rarely has an attempt been made to pull this information together to find out if there is a pattern of behavior. Even the coverage of the murder trial of O. J. Simpson, which seems to have diagrammed every racial, sexual, class and economic X and O, seems so far to have avoided dealing with the possibility that football players, as surely as combat soldiers, have been programmed and rewarded for a kind of violence that can't always be turned off. 
 And if there is a pattern of violence, why? Does the nature of combat sport itself build a "character" that is out of control off the field? Are the best of these athletes genetically disposed to be more aggressive? Is it hormonal? Are drugs a factor? Are they conditioned by coaches to regard nonmembers of the team -- including all women -- as the enemy? Is it just a heightened alpha male entitlement, is it a further example of the lack of communication between men and women? Is there a homoerotic strain here, as the writer and counselor Ed Gallagher of Alive to Thrive, a self-help organization for the handicapped, suggests, making athletes angry about their suppressed desires?
Or is all this just more celebrity churn?
Performance athletes are under such intense scrutiny, why wouldn't their police ink blots become mini-series while most rapes, assaults and incidents of abuse are not even reported?

 Whatever the answers, the questions seem to make most sports officials, business people and fans uncomfortable enough to touch their wallets, cross their legs and send in a substitute conversation.
Nevertheless, the exploration of that Bermuda Triangle began in earnest, albeit cautiously, yesterday in Savannah, Ga., with the presentation of a short academic paper to the North American Society for Sports Sociology.
Titled "Male Student-Athletes Reported for Sexual Assault: A Survey of Campus Police Departments and Judicial Affairs Offices," the paper concludes that at 20 schools with highly rated Division I football and basketball teams, surveyed between 1991 and 1993, "athletes appear to be disproportionately involved in incidents of sexual assault on college campuses."
The conclusion is hardly a "Yesss!" to anyone who has been paying attention, but the mere existence of the paper, by three academic men, is worthy of notice. What little work that has been done in the field has tended to be either anecdotal anthologies or serious rape and assault studies by female scholars with little access to sports information. Beyond the conclusion of the paper is a call for more research; specifically needed, according to the authors, are studies involving contact versus noncontact sports, the relation of the coaching staff to the team, and the specific conditions under which women report sexual assault by athletes.
The authors of the paper are from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, Todd W. Crosset, a professor of sports management, and Mark A. McDonald, a professor of statistics, and a 28-year-old graduate student of political science at Northeastern University, Jeffrey R. Benedict.

 Benedict, a former high school wrestler and a youth basketball coach, is the engine of the study. Raised in an abusive household, he plans to attend law school next year so he can become a prosecutor of sex criminals. He has already begun work on a more ambitious project, for his master's thesis; a study of three rape cases in which the "consensual sex" defense was used, and why that strategy is considerably more persuasive when the accused is a famous athlete.
"This is a very touchy area," said Benedict in an interview last week in Boston. "Race and socioeconomic status is a huge factor, and lot of people, particularly scholars, are concerned that racial conclusions could be drawn, although no mention is made of race."
The thesis, which is being advised by the well-known sports anthropologist, Alan M. Klein of Northeastern, concentrates on the cases of alleged acquaintance rape involving Mike Tyson, the former Boston Celtic Marcus Webb and a group of Cincinnati Bengals.
"I don't mean to dismiss the seriousness of the West Point case," said Benedict, "but that's childish behavior compared to what I'm studying. On the other hand, whenever women can be looked upon as objects and treated as fun, there's trouble.
"We have to make a careful distinction between rape culture and the behavior of celebrity athletes who, because of their access to women, have a distorted perception of what is appropriate behavior."
The course of Benedict's explorations, an engaging combination of scholarship and self-righteousness, will churn their own questions: will scholars shoot him down, will big-time sports buy him off, will tabloid journalism eat him up? With his wrestler's short hair and pug face, Benedict looks eager for the challenge.
"There's a real make-it-while-you-can, sex-and-money attitude in sports, and it's not so different in music, acting, maybe some aspects of politics," he said. "But there's a special factor here; some of our best athletes are trained in violence and deception, and they just can't turn it on and off when we want them to. And given the money involved, coaches and owners might not want to risk them losing their edge for the game."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mike Tyson, the former boxing champion whose rape case is the subject of a sociological thesis. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Getting Serious on Bosnian Arms

 BODY:
Prodded by Congress, the Clinton Administration is now asking the United Nations Security Council to lift its unjust arms embargo against Bosnia and has announced that American military forces will stop enforcing that embargo tomorrow. Lifting the embargo is the right policy and the fairest, surest path to an honorable and stable peace.
For years, Washington has been saying that it favors lifting the embargo. But it has never deployed the full diplomatic weight of the United States to get it lifted. Doing so would mean standing up to European countries like Britain, France and Russia that prefer to keep the Bosnians disarmed and impose an internationally brokered partition plan. Instead of trying to win over the Europeans, the Administration has repeatedly backed off the issue. But perhaps there will be a more whole-hearted effort this time. 
 One good reason is that the Administration now must reckon with an increasingly assertive Congress. Even before the elections, Congress voted to cut off funds for U.S. enforcement of the embargo this month. Senator Bob Dole, a strong advocate of lifting the arms embargo, becomes majority leader in January. The Administration is now torn between its desire to avoid a Congressional cutoff and its reluctance to confront the Europeans.
Serbian forces hold 70 percent of Bosnia's territory; the partition map would award them barely half. That is one reason they reject the map, which the Bosnian Government accepts. Recently, however, Government forces, armed with smuggled weapons, have reoccupied some of their lost territory. Further Bosnian gains, which lifting the embargo would encourage, could make the peace plan more attractive to the Serbs.
A stronger Government army would also make Serbia and Croatia more likely to respect Bosnia's territorial integrity in the future, reducing the need for international monitoring of any peace agreement.
Even though Bosnia is now smuggling in enough weapons to turn the tide, formally lifting the embargo is important because it would allow in the tanks and other heavy weapons the Government side still lacks. It would also give Bosnia's political authorities more control over which units get the new arms -- and thereby let it impose more discipline on rogue commanders like those who allegedly attacked residential areas of Sarajevo. A procurement system based on smuggling directs arms to those commanders who have the best underworld connections. Lifting the embargo would also free Bosnia from reliance on radical weapons suppliers like Iran and Libya that have few inhibitions about circumventing U.N. rules.
Still, the embargo will not be lifted unless the U.S. lobbies for votes. Merely declaring that Washington is strongly interested would rally most of the fence-sitting smaller powers. That leaves Britain, which has said it would not veto a resolution; France, which hints it might agree in principle to lifting the embargo but worries about endangering its U.N. peacekeepers, and Russia, which might be able to accept a formula that also eases economic sanctions on Belgrade.
Winning these votes will require compromise language. But any wording that assures Bosnia that it will be able to exercise its right to self-defense -- either unilaterally or through the U.N. -- unless the Bosnian Serbs agree to peace by next spring would be a useful advance.
Until the Administration insists on language that gives Bosnia that minimum right and works hard to round up the necessary votes, senators returning for a special post-election session will need to keep up the heat.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Anger And Reality

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Newt Gingrich was brilliant at playing to the resentment of Americans. Brilliant and nasty. But those of us who disliked his tactics must not let that shut our eyes to the fact that the resentment is there. It is resentment of what many Americans see as an arrogant ruling class, out of touch with their concerns.
What are the reasons for the extraordinary anger, directed at incumbent Democrats right across the country? I believe it is first of all a matter of economics. 
 There is a puzzle here. Unemployment is down, the deficit falling, the national economic figures robust. Yet in exit polls, 6 out of 10 voters agreed that the economy was "in bad shape." Why the discontent?
Figures are deceptive, for one thing. Average real per capita income has been essentially stagnant for years. And "average" is itself a distorting concept. The richest 20 percent of Americans have been growing rapidly richer; their incomes bring up the average figure, but those in the middle and below are losing ground.
Most American families today depend on two incomes. They are working harder, but they feel they are hardly holding their own. They don't know how they are going to send their children to college, or how those children will find jobs that will put them in the middle class -- or keep them there.
Expectations for one's children may be the key factor in political discontent. America is the land of expectations. From the beginning, immigrants and native-born alike, most Americans have expected their children to do better than themselves.
The assumption that the family's lot would improve was heightened during the extraordinary U.S. economic growth of the decades after World War II. In those years America became a country of middle-class homeowners.
And then -- suddenly, it seemed -- the boom came to an end. There was an illusory revival during the Reagan years, based on deficit financing. Today, for many people, expectations are embittered.
To see public resentment in these terms is to understand its seriousness. For the truth is that the economic discontent will not be easily dispelled. The kind of improvement people want is hard to achieve in the real world of the 1990's.
Take the "contract" that Mr. Gingrich produced for Republican House candidates to sign. It calls for higher defense spending and tax cuts totaling $200 billion over the next five years. It also talks of a balanced-budget constitutional amendment. But its hope of a balanced budget in fact rests on the Reaganomics notion that lower taxes will produce higher revenue, which proved to be a fantasy.
So the Gingrich contract would in all likelihood pile more debt on the shoulders of our children and grandchildren. So will the refusal thus far, by both Republicans and Democrats, to do anything about the growing burden of entitlements.
A related part of the public resentment expressed in these elections was dislike of "big government." There is a certain irony in that. Government policy, after all, made possible the housing boom and the growth of international trade that fueled the postwar economic miracle. At the same time that people condemn big government, they want government to do things on their behalf.
But it is true that the Federal Government has grown too large, and far too intrusive in its regulations. Democrats, and in particular President Clinton, should long ago have followed the example of Justice Brandeis, a progressive who believed in decentralization and small institutions. Maybe Republicans can do something on that score.
But the central economic dilemma demands political courage of a kind that we have not seen lately. It requires leaders to tell voters that they cannot have benefits without paying the cost and still expect a better life for their children.
Economic growth requires investment. This country saves and invests much less than its competitors in the world market. If we want our children to have more, we must practice self-denial -- spending less and investing more, both privately and publicly.
It is urgently necessary to address the causes of our economic discontent. If we do not, resentment can easily fall prey to demagoguery -- and to scapegoating that would tear our social fabric.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTION;
In Their Own Words: The Republican Promises

 BODY:
During the election campaign, Republican candidates for Congress gathered in Washington to endorse a set of proposals for legislative action that they called their "Contract With America." They said that in the first 100 days of the 104th Congress, they would introduce bills they described as follows:
 
1. The Fiscal Responsibility Act: A balanced budget/tax limitation amendment and a legislative line-item veto to restore fiscal responsibility to an out-of-control Congress, requiring them to live under the same budget constraints as families and businesses.
 
2. The Taking Back Our Streets Act: An anti-crime package including stronger truth-in-sentencing, "good faith" exclusionary rule exemptions, effective death penalty provisions, and cuts in social spending from this summer's "crime" bill to fund prison construction and additional law enforcement to keep people secure in their neighborhoods and kids safe in their schools.
 
3. The Personal Responsibility Act: Discourage illegitimacy and teen pregnancy by prohibiting welfare to minor mothers and denying increased AFDC for additinal children while on welfare, cut spending for welfare programs, and enact a tough two-years-and-out provision with work requirements to promote individual responsibility.
 
4. The Family Reinforcement Act: Child support enforcement, tax incentive for adoption, strengthening rights of parents in their children's education, stronger child pornography laws, and an elderly dependent care tax credit to reinforce the central role of families in American society.
 
5. The American Dream Restoration Act: A $500 per child tax credit, begin repeal of the marriage tax penalty, and creation of American Dream Savings Accounts to provide middle class tax relief.
 
6. The National Security Restoration Act: No U.S. troops under U.N. command and restoration of the essential parts of our national security funding to strengthen our national defense and maintain our credibility around the world.
 
7. The Senior Citizens Fairness Act: Raise the Social Security earnings limit which currently forces seniors out of the work force, repeal the 1993 tax hikes on Social Security benefits and provide tax incentive for private long-term care insurance to let older Americans keep more of what they have earned over the years.
 
8. The Hob Creation and Wage Enhancement Act: Small business incentives, capital gains cut and indexation, neutral cost recovery, risk assessment/cost-benefit analysis, strengthening the Regulatory Flexibility Act and unfunded mandate reform to create jobs and raise worker wages.
 
9. The Common Sense Legal Reform Act: "Loser pays" laws, reasonable limits on punitive damages and reform of product liablility laws to stem the endless tide of litigation.
 
10. The Citizen Legislative Act: A first ever vote on term limits to replace career politicians with citizen legislators.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Connecticut Revisits its Income Tax

 BODY:
Let no one quibble about John Rowland's 36 percent victory in Connecticut. His share of the vote for governor in a four-way race was not significantly less than Lowell Weicker's winning share in a three-way race in 1990. Governor Weicker used his victory to force adoption of a personal income tax. Mr. Rowland, a Republican with the advantage of a newly elected Republican majority in the State Senate, is pledged to repeal it.
Repeal poses two threats: The tax will yield $2.7 billion this year, more than one-quarter of the $9.4 billion budget. Mr. Rowland maintains that he can offset half the revenue loss with spending cuts that will not cut services -- a dubious proposition -- and that healthier economic activity will offset the other half. Just as bad, the state would again be dependent on regressive sales taxes, and taxes on dividends and corporations that drive people and businesses away. 
 Perhaps when the Governor-elect faces the budget realities he will modify his pledge, as Gov. Christine Todd Whitman did in New Jersey. Mr. Rowland wants a phased repeal over five years. Governor Whitman promised to reduce New Jersey's tax by 30 percent over three years, but she has now stretched it to four. Yet New Jersey's economy is in better shape than Connecticut's, which has suffered from severe cutbacks in its heavy concentration of defense industries.
It is clear that voters everywhere are demanding lower taxes -- and equally clear that newly elected governors must proceed with care.

HEADLINE: Reagan Revolution Redux

BYLINE: By Richard Brookhiser; Richard Brookhiser is a senior editor of National Review.

 BODY:
Tuesday's carnage was not, as many liberal pundits have claimed, a revolt of random wrath against incumbents. The voters directed their fire at liberal Democrats, and set in motion the second stage of the Reagan Revolution, which will make the one-term Presidencies of George Bush and Bill Clinton seem like political hiccups.
The voters want Republicans to address specific problems, some of them spelled out in the "Contract With America," some of them brought to national attention by Ronald Reagan in 1980, some of them brand new. Now the Republicans must make good on those promises or face another voter backlash in 1996. 
 The first thing the G.O.P. can do is make the next two years even more frustrating for President Clinton than the first two were. There is nothing wrong with gridlock if the initiatives that are locked up are wrongheaded. The Clinton health care plan died because it was bad. If majority status helps Senator Bob Dole and Representative Newt Gingrich block such plans more effectively, more gridlock to them.
But what can Republicans accomplish in Washington and in the statehouses they now control?
Tax relief. The Reagan reforms reduced the income tax burdens of people of all classes and took four million low-income Americans off the rolls by raising the standard deduction. The economy boomed and tax revenues went up by a third. But spending rose at a faster rate, while the tax increases mandated by the budget deals of 1990 and 1993, and the upward creep of Social Security taxes, wiped out the cuts. This deepened the Bush recession and weakened the Clinton recovery. Voters expect Republicans to refill the pockets that were picked by Presidents Bush and Clinton, through a combination of spending restraint and 80's-style tax relief.
Electoral reform. This means, primarily, term limits, which are a dumb idea. We already have a term limit system -- elections -- which tossed out a lot of incumbents. But now that the Republicans have promised, they must perform. Should there be campaign spending limits? Oliver North might have liked them in retrospect: they would have saved him from blowing $20 million in a lost cause. The rest of us should take comfort from the fact that elections are not buyable.
Social Security reform. The Democrats resurrected their hoariest scare tactic in the homestretch, charging that the Republicans would cut Social Security. But Social Security is going to hit the wall soon enough anyway, when the baby boomers start leaving the work force for Sun City. The Social Security Administration is predicting that its cash balance will be in deficit by 2013. The conventional-wisdom solution is to tax the benefits of the well-to-do. Better that the Republicans develop a plan that allows people to opt out of Social Security and provide for themselves in the private sector.
Immigration retrenchment. Although an important victory, California's Proposition 187 dealt only with illegal immigrants; legal immigration needs to be cut back, too. Historically, immigration has proceeded in waves of ingestion and digestion, controlled more by upheavals abroad than by laws here. But the world has shrunk to the point where we can no longer count on foreign developments to regulate the flow. We have taken in a huge influx since 1965. Time to chew our cud.
Crime. Republicans at the state level need to do the rethinking on punishment that some Republican governors have done on welfare. Mandatory sentencing ("three strikes and you're out") is a rigid solution; building more prisons is a form of throwing money at the problem. Some measures (such as drug laws) don't belong on the books. But the key is reforming the judiciary -- by appointing judges who will push for expeditious trials and sentencing -- and passing laws to cut down on the appeals process, so as to diminish the gap between arrest and jail.
Some of these points are old G.O.P. standbys; others may strike the new crop of Republicans as marginal. That's all right. The last two years have shown that the Democrats cannot address our problems in new or creative ways. All of Mr. Clinton's talk of New Democrats got swept out with the 1992 campaign buttons. Republicans have a solid foundation, laid in the Reagan years and in this election. Now is their chance to build.
