HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTION: VOTERS;
When Considering Cuomo, Upstate Voters Saw Revenge

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GREECE, N.Y., Nov. 10

 BODY:
The human toll of upstate New York's lingering recession, and the motives for the revenge visited upon Gov. Mario M. Cuomo by its voters this week, can be sensed most mornings in the sun-washed dining room of Buckman's Bakery.
Here in Monroe County, middle-aged men, lured into early retirement as companies like Kodak cut back, while away their mornings over endless cups of coffee, rehashing their theories about life, taxes, politicians and the cure for New York's ills. 
 Taxes have to come down, they say. Government waste has to stop. Crime must be controlled. And the state must stop squandering the hard-earned money of upstate residents on downstate people's problems.
This is, after all, a part of the state where people joke bitterly that it's always New York City people who win the lottery.
"I'm fed up with everything going to the Big Apple," said Tony Grammatico of Greece, a Rochester suburb, who voted against Mr. Cuomo for the first time in 12 years. "They get the biggest piece of the pie for all the social programs."
That was one of the sentiments that echoed resoundingly this week across the upper reaches of New York State, where voters turned out at higher rates, and voted more decisively against Mr. Cuomo, than did voters elsewhere.
Mr. Cuomo focused much of his upstate campaign in traditionally Democratic Erie County, which includes Buffalo. But he lost the county to State Senator George E. Pataki by nearly 40,000 votes. Four years ago, the Governor had outpolled his nearest competitor there by more than 90,000 votes. Over all, his share of the upstate vote -- 62 percent in 1986 and 46 percent in 1990 -- plunged this year to 32 percent.
Taxes, crime and government waste are among the issues cited by upstate voters who rejected Mr. Cuomo. In addition, strategists from both camps have suggested that upstate-downstate sensitivities are such that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's endorsement of Mr. Cuomo may have hurt the Governor more than it helped.
For one thing, Republicans here, to whom the Giuliani endorsement might have been expected to appeal, consider New York City Republicans a different, sometimes suspect breed. And few people in and around cities like Rochester and Syracuse seem to have any doubt that Mr. Cuomo had paid a price for Mr. Giuliani's blessing -- probably, they said, by promising millions of dollars in aid to New York City.
"I think that influenced a lot of people," said Bob Kempen, 49, a Pataki voter and manager of a meat-processing plant in Rochester. "That was something they could understand. Simple. I mean, really, money being funneled to New York City does not appeal to many upstate voters."
Jim Branch, 34, a driver for the United Parcel Service and former Cuomo voter from Rochester who voted for the independent candidate, B. Thomas Golisano, said: "In the back of my mind, I'm thinking, 'O.K., here goes my money. Taxes are going up again. It's coming out of my pocket again.' "
Deal or no deal, interviews with voters in five of the counties that turned against Mr. Cuomo with especial ferocity this week suggested that the main reason for their defection was their feeling that Mr. Cuomo had failed to fix their broken economy.
From Erie County in the far west, through Monroe, Onondaga, Chemung and Broome counties, nearly everyone seemed to know someone who lost their job when their company cut back, their plant closed, their employer moved South.
Judy Gettino, 43, of Liverpool, near Syracuse in Onondaga County, saw her brother move to Florida after the brewery where he worked closed. Mrs. Gettino, who publishes a weekly Pennysaver newspaper with her husband, said she had voted against Mr. Cuomo for the first time since 1982.
Another Pataki voter in the county, Mark Warren, 45, of Pompey, said he had friends who moved to Tennessee when their plant moved South. Ray Shorts, 53, of Greece, identified himself succinctly: "Early retiree from Yellow," he said, referring to Kodak, also known in these parts as the Yellow Father.
Mr. Kempen, the meat-processing manager, said high state workmen's compensation insurance had forced him to shut one plant and lay off 35 people. He said he blamed the state's business climate for his troubles.
"Cuomo has not been effective in dealing with it for 12 years," said Roger W. Boily, a Republican and the town supervisor in Greece. "It isn't just his stand on abortion or the death penalty or Thomas Grasso. It's that this state isn't doing well economically. Something has to be done about it. It's No. 1 in people's minds."
Even his administration's efforts at economic development in the area didn't seem to win Mr. Cuomo many points. Some voters said they appreciated the state support, but others said the projects were misguided or merely pork.
Terry Mehlenbacher, 47, a house builder from Pittsford in Monroe County, suggested Mr. Cuomo's attempt to bail out a troubled salt mine in his town amounted to little more than a taxpayer-supported boondoggle "to assure him more votes."
In Chemung County, Bill McElveney, 63, a former Cuomo voter and owner of Mail Boxes Etc. in Elmira, said the Governor "only came here when a new business opened up. And then he'd shake some hands and take all the credit."
Charles Cleveland, 70, a retired frozen-foods company executive from Manlius in Onondaga County, said the administration had "put up about $10 million to build a frozen-food warehouse here in competition with the company I retired from."
And in Erie County, at a hotel bar in Blasdell, Mike Yoerk, 42, a service station owner, said he was grateful for Mr. Cuomo's support of the minor-league baseball stadium in nearby Buffalo but tired of being nickel-and-dimed on thruway tolls and everything else.
"People are fed up in this area," complained Mr. Yoerk, who voted straight Republican after voting for Mr. Cuomo in the last three elections. "They tax gas, beer, everything. I think 12 years is enough."
While voter turnout in upstate counties, always high, was even higher than usual -- estimated at about 70 percent of registered voters -- some Democrats were sufficiently disgusted that they simply chose not to vote.
Ann Denk, 29, a former Cuomo voter in Greece who works as a sales representative for a toy company, said: "I exercised my right to not vote. I guess I'd sort of soured on him. It's just a gut feeling that he outlasted his usefulness."
Robert W. Lown, 67, a retired maintenance man from Castle Creek, near Binghamton in Broome County, described himself as a Democrat who supported Pataki -- but said he ended up not getting around to voting, for the first time in his life.
Even some of those who got what they wanted this week -- change -- were jaded enough to be taking nothing for granted. Some seemed to doubt, in the end, that their taxes could really be cut and that their lives would significantly change.
Richard Whipple, 52, the president of a medical-imaging company in Orchard Park near Buffalo, and a former Cuomo supporter who voted this time for Mr. Pataki, paused over a bowl of soup and mustered a little cautious optimism.
"We'll give him four years and if he doesn't do it, we'll get rid of the bum," said Mr. Whipple. "I want somebody who will produce. They get into office and they all become politicians."

LENGTH: 738 words

HEADLINE: So Friendly: Chinese and Christopher

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 11

 BODY:
What a difference eight months make.
On his last trip to Asia, in March, Secretary of State Warren Christopher verbally battled the Chinese over their human rights record every day of his visit. 
 But that was before the Clinton Administration ended its policy of linking trade benefits to human rights and before a parade of Cabinet secretaries marched into Beijing armed with business contracts and pledges of better relations.
Today Mr. Christopher and the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, looked downright comfortable together as they met on the fringes of a meeting of foreign ministers of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, shaking hands vigorously for the cameras and accentuating the positive.
Their meeting was a prelude to President Clinton's meeting with the Chinese President next week.
In a brief exchange with reporters, Mr. Christopher praised China for what he called its constructive role in the negotiations that led to the nuclear deal between the United States and North Korea, and announced that China would have an important role in carrying it out. He noted that the Chinese had signed a pledge not to export missiles or technology controlled under an international nonproliferation accord.
He also said China had taken some positive steps on human rights, but did not mention the widespread belief within the Administration that the situation has deteriorated in recent months.
"This broad engagement is producing progress on various fronts," Mr. Christopher said.
Perhaps to reassure Mr. Qian of American constancy, Mr. Christopher brushed aside a question that the Administration might find it more difficult to execute its policy of engagement with a Republican-dominated Congress.
When asked about the election, Mr. Qian, whose Government has accused the American Congress of meddling in China's affairs in the past, politely deferred to Mr. Christopher. "I believe the election of the U.S. Congress is the entitlement of the United States," he said. "Therefore, I consider that question directed to Mr. Christopher."
But in their private meeting, Mr. Qian stepped out of character. He told Mr. Christopher that he appreciated his words about continuity in foreign policy during his formal speech to the forum. "We're interested and concerned to know how the election affects us," a senior State Department official quoted Mr. Qian as saying.
In a way the remark was not surprising. The two foreign policy committees in Congress will be headed by men who are sworn enemies of Beijing: Senator Jesse Helms, who favors independence for Taiwan and demonizes the Chinese military, and Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, who considers himself a close friend of the Dalai Lama of Tibet.
The cozy atmosphere between Mr. Christopher and Mr. Qian did not mean that there were no issues dividing them. Mr. Christopher raised the matter of China's refusal to accept revisions and updates of an international accord controlling missile exports or to disclose what missile technology it shipped abroad before it agreed to abide by the accord. He also told Mr. Qian that the United States would like China to make more progress in improving its human rights record.
Human rights in Indonesia was one of the themes discussed today by Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative. He announced an agreement with Indonesia on the rights of workers, a source of tension between Washington and Jakarta. Among the accord's provisions are vague pledges by Indonesia to amend its labor laws and regulations and to make the Government-run All Independent Worker Union more independent.
Early last year, Mr. Kantor suspended a formal review of whether Indonesia deserved certain trade benefits despite its poor record on workers' rights.
In analyzing Indonesia's human rights record at the time, Mr. Kantor noted the overwhelming role of the military and the absence of free association in the workplace.
But neither of these issues was addressed in today's accord. Mike Jendrzejczyk, the Washington director of the human rights organizationAsia Watch, said: "For any labor accord to be meaningful, it would have to allow truly independent labor organizations to emerge and curb the pervasive role of the military."
Mr. Kantor acknowledged that the agreement had its limitations, telling reporters even as he touted it that it was only "a step in the proper direction."

HEADLINE: U.S. Supports Asia-Pacific Free Trade, but Questions Timing

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Saturday, Nov. 12

 BODY:
A meeting of representatives from 18 countries on both sides of the Pacific Ocean opened on Friday with signs that the United States had reservations about how rapidly different countries should move toward achieving free trade across the region.
The central question at the annual meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which continued through this morning, was whether the 18 member countries would agree to lower trade barriers by the proposed date of 2020. The United States is a big backer of the free trade proposals and of the 2020 deadline. 
 But Washington has expressed some reluctance about part of the proposal that would require industrial countries to eliminate trade barriers 10 years earlier than the developing countries, according to two Asian officials.
Viewed from Asia, Washington's concerns are political. Asian officials say that the United States is worried that certain American industries will be unhappy if American markets are opened to imports from the fast-growing East Asian nations a decade before those nations fully open their markets to American products.
Arousing opponents of free trade in the United States could, in turn, also make it harder for the Administration to win Congressional approval of the world trade knows as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT.
The United States appears to be the only country unwilling to accept the target date of 2010 for the advanced nations, Asian officials said.
Still, it is not clear whether the United States will press its case because doing so could make developing nations less supportive of the overall trade goal. The proposed 10-year difference is intended to make the trade agreement more palatable to developing nations by giving them extra time to improve their industries before subjecting them to foreign competition.
At a news briefing on Friday, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said there might have to be some difference in the dates for the developing and developed nations. But he avoided expressing support for the 2010 target.
"There's general agreement that, of course, the developed countries and the newly industrialized countries have a greater ability to meet certain standards earlier than maybe developing countries," he said. "However, particular dates have not been discussed.
"The fact is, I think that there is general consensus that the year 2020 should be a goal and vision for achieving free trade in the region."
The meetings began on Friday with a speech by President Suharto of Indonesia at the state palace, urging the delegates to "maintain the momentum" toward free trade. In Indonesian tradition, he then banged a gong to declare the meeting in session.
Among the actions taken at the first session was approval of a nonbinding code governing foreign investment. Agreement was reached late Thursday in a compromise between the United States, which wanted stronger language guaranteeing fair treatment to foreign investors, and the other 17 nations.
Officials said that meeting of the ministers, which was behind closed doors, was cordial. "We are quite pleased with the progress we have been able to achieve," Ali Alatas, the Foreign Minister of Indonesia, said at a news conference. "The atmosphere was good throughout."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, in a speech proposing new initiatives for Asia and the Pacific, departed from his prepared text to assure the delegates that there would be continuity in American foreign policy despite the crushing losses suffered by the Democratic Party in the elections on Tuesday.
"That's a subject that's clearly been on the minds of many of the people we met here today," a State Department spokesman said.
One of the big questions here is whether the election setback will undermine President Clinton's effectiveness at the APEC summit meeting, which will take place on Tuesday in Bogor, outside Jakarta. At last year's meeting in Seattle, the President was the commanding figure and played a major role in expanding the scope and ambitions of the organization.
Some people who attended the meetings today and Friday said there was consensus building toward the target date of 2020 for achieving free trade in the region, although Malaysia still appears to be against the idea.
China seemed to support a timetable as long as it was flexible. "As the levels of economic development of APEC members are widely different, we support President Suharto's proposal that the timetable be drawn up in the light of the diverse conditions," Qian Qichen, China's Vice Premier and Foreign Minister, said.
But in a separate meeting with Mr. Christopher, Mr. Qian said China should not be asked to approve the Asia-Pacific free trade plan unless it was allowed to join GATT, according to Winston Lord, United States Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs. "That's sort of apples and oranges as far as we're concerned," Mr. Lord said.

CLINTON LEAVES FOR ASIA
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- President Clinton set out on Friday for Asia suggesting that the trade talks could help bring prosperity to dissatisfied Americans.
"We simply must turn insecurity about our future into confidence," Mr. Clinton told reporters before he left. "The ultimate goal is to produce a strong America."
After a stop in Alaska to speak to members of the military, Mr. Clinton plans a two-day visit to the Philippines before attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Indonesia.
In Manila he is to meet with President Fidel Ramos, visit World War II battle sites and discuss trade issuew with American business executives.

HEADLINE: With Thai Rebuff, U.S. Defers Plan for Navy Depot in Asia

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The United States has put on hold a proposal to build a floating war depot in Southeast Asia that would strengthen American military readiness in both Asia and the Middle East, senior United States military officials said today.
The plan was frozen, at least for the moment, after Thailand rejected a proposal last month to base a flotilla of up to six supply ships permanently in the Gulf of Thailand. 
 Since then senior officials in Malaysia and Indonesia have indicated publicly that they would also reject any proposal to position United States ships off their coasts.
"The plan of where the ships are going to go is on hold," said a senior American military official involved in formulating it. But the official emphasized that "the plan is not dead in the water -- it's being looked at again."
The rebuff by Thailand follows a decision by Saudi Arabia last month to refuse a United States request to base enough tanks and planes on Saudi soil to support a brigade of troops.
The United States wants to position the flotilla permanently in Asia to augment its eight-ship flotillas in Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean and in Guam in the Western Pacific. Such pre-positioning, as it is called, gives the military much-needed flexibility, so that if troops are flown quickly to a crisis in the Middle East or Asia, the tanks, heavy artillery, ammunition, fuel, food and medical supplies to support them will already be in place.
After the Persian Gulf war of 1991, which began more than four months after Iraq invaded Kuwait, a Pentagon study on mobility concluded that the shipment of weapons and other equipment took too long and recommended that the United States seek offshore bases in Southeast Asia.
So far the United States Pacific Command, which is based in Hawaii and has responsibility for Asia, has failed to come up with an alternative location because military planners disagree on what country to approach, senior officials said.
President Clinton first proposed anchoring a flotilla in the Gulf of Thailand at a meeting in September at the White House with the Thai Prime Minister, Chuan Likphai.
Thailand, a close United States ally, initially indicated a willingness to allow the ships to use its refueling and repair installations, and the United States hoped to send the first ships by the end of the year.
The flotilla would be able to sustain up to one heavy brigade or one armored cavalry regiment for at least 15 days.
But after the plan was attacked both within and outside the coalition Government as an infringement of Thai sovereignty, Thailand rejected the proposal, saying the arrangement might strain relations with China, Vietnam, Cambodia and Burma.
There was another factor: Thai military officials were upset by passage of the 1995 Foreign Operations Act, which included a provision to cut off military training aid and education to Thailand because of its apparent support for the Communist Khmer Rouge in Cambodia.
The rebuff will complicate Secretary of State Warren Christopher's visit to Thailand next week after the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting here.
The United States has not approached any other government with the proposal, and no other government has rejected the plan in advance, a senior Administration official said.
But in an interview today, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, said his country would not be interested because of its policy of nonalignment. "America knows full well it would be against our nonaligned policy, so I don't think they'll come to us," Mr. Alatas said. "I don't know what the purpose of these ships is, but it's very interesting that even Thailand said no."
Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, has said such an arrangement could contribute to regional hostility.
It is questionable whether Singapore would agree to play host to the ships if its neighbors said no to the United States. The Philippines, which closed the last American military base on its territory two years ago, might also be reluctant to allow what inevitably would be perceived as a floating base.

A LAST RESORT IS NOW PART OF THE SYSTEM
On many nights hundreds of people continue to take refuge in the city's after-hours homeless office in the Bronx, where straight-back plastic chairs or a plot of dirty floor are luxuries for the weary. The spectacle has become such a fixture that the city has budgeted $5 million to cover fines it owes to families dating back to 1991 and penalties it expects to pay through the end of year. And beginning next week, families left overnight in the office will be eligible for a $50 penalty payment the first night and $100 payment for each successive night. Page 1.

Interviews with voters in five of the counties that turned against Mr. Cuomo with especial ferocity this week suggested that the main reason for their defection was their feeling that Mr. Cuomo had failed to fix their broken economy. Page 1.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTION: WHITE HOUSE MEMO;
In Defeat, Clinton Aides Find Their Silver Lining

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
In the Pennsylvania Avenue home of the Comeback Kid, the talk to reporters since Tuesday has been about rising again from the canvas and rolling the stone back up the hill.
"Remember, this is a resilient President," one staff member said. 
 So the central question among White House aides now is how Bill Clinton recovers from the 40-story fall that his political fortunes took on Tuesday evening. Not whether. How.
"The consensus, it's fair to say, is that he's going to be re-elected," one confident and quite senior Administration official said today.
"There's no reason to panic," said Tony Coelho, the former House member and Democratic Party strategist. "Be patient. Wait for the opportunities, because they surely will come."
In a White House famed for its relentless powers of positive thinking, a sunny face is the standard reaction to any disaster. But the optimism voiced by Clinton aides, however surprising, appears to be more than spin deep.
To some, including some Democrats, such statements are acts of denial. In their view, Tuesday's vote was a resounding rejection of the Democratic philosophy of governing, writ large, and of a President who promised to change that culture and is seen as having failed.
Within the White House and adjacent party councils, there are those who very nearly see the Democratic whipping as a positive force. Like many impartial analysts, they were convinced that the Republicans would capture the House of Representatives within one or two elections anyway. Moreover, the current Democratic margin was so thin as to make it difficult for the President to push the rest of his domestic agenda into law.
In their view, losing Congress shifts some of the hard choices of governing to their opponents, and gives the White House a definable enemy to campaign against.
Just as important, it concentrates their minds on two problems that many of them see as Mr. Clinton's greatest political liabilities: his failure to give citizens a clear, consistent explanation of his goals, and the widespread belief that he is weak, that he can be rolled.
The two are related, because each time Mr. Clinton has switched sides on an issue, he has muddled voters' impressions of his Administration and of his own strength. White House officials now have two years to fix matters up, with the certainty that he and they will be on the street if they do not.
Senior officials and party strategists who have talked with them said in interviews this week that despite pledges of cooperation, the President is far from choosing a strategy to deal with a Republican Congress. And the House Speaker-designate, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, has already said he will give Mr. Clinton no quarter on the issues he holds dear.
"After every one of these elections, there's lip service given to bipartisanship from both sides," one White House political adviser said. "I think there'll have to be assessments later on."
For the moment, people inside and outside the Administration say, Mr. Clinton's advisers have loosely organized themselves into two schools of thought. One, which one strategist called the conciliators, believes the President should cast himself more directly in the center of the political spectrum by cooperating with moderates of both parties.
Its advocates would press for compromises on issues where both parties have room to agree, like welfare reform and shrinking the Federal Government and its budget, and to answer the voters' clear demand that the Government stop bickering and get something done.
They also argue that Mr. Clinton should speak out more often about values issues, like crime and teen-age pregnancy, on which he has proven himself a compelling orator and on which his views have broad appeal.
Those views are close to the new Democrat thinking that the President campaigned on and that moderates in his party have long supported. Among its proponents are Erskine Bowles, a former head of the Small Business Administration who is a new deputy to White House chief of staff Leon E. Panetta, and Rahm Emanuel, a Clinton aide who was a fund-raiser for the Democratic Party and Mr. Clinton.
The other school of political strategy is not far removed, but is more aggressive. Its advocates would press Mr. Clinton to "fight and assert and re-establish why he's here," in one Administration official's words. That school would push for more programs, including but not limited to education and worker training, to address what its proponents see as Americans' real political ulcer: uncertainty about the economy and their own future.
The advocates are said to include Mr. Panetta's other deputy, Harold M. Ickes, and aides like George Stephanopoulos and Labor Secretary Robert Reich. Mr. Clinton campaigned to shift Government spending to address exactly those concerns, and he is said to prize such programs more than most of his initiatives.
But Republicans would almost certainly oppose them, and the strategy would mean a more contentious relationship with Congress, and more of the gridlock that voters seem to detest. Some advisers say it is worth the fight for Mr. Clinton to be seen as standing firm for the little guy, and good politics to boot.
"On the question of who hates Government more, and who wants to cut it more, Republicans will always win," one official said.
Either strategy, that of confirmed moderate or feisty populist, would give Mr. Clinton a consistent image he so far seems to have lacked. And either would presumably make him look stronger, either by enacting legislation or by exercising a veto power that he so far has not had to use.

Stocks declined as traders awaited the next move by the Federal Reserve. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 2 points, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.26 points. [40.]
Sugar prices surged after the Agriculture Department lowered its forecast for world production. Orange juice prices rose. [48.]
 
The dollar ended little changed in quiet trading. The Swedish krona rose against the mark and the dollar ahead of a referendum on whether Sweden should join the European Union. [48.]
 
The Treasury cash market was closed in observance of Veterans Day. Futures trading was limited. [49.]
 
 
Your Money
 
What does the Republicans' election sweep mean for taxpayers? The proposals in the Contract With America, the Republican action plan, provide some clues, tax and investment professionals say. The proposals include cutting the capital gains tax in half, phasing out the 1993 tax increase on Social Security benefits and creating a new type of individual retirement account. [35.]
 
Health care stocks have surged since the end of a drive to overhaul the nation's health care system, to the benefit of mutual funds that invest in such stocks. [35.]
 
Americans are paying real estate agents too much, the Consumer Federation of America argues. Home sellers should negotiate with agents over commissions, the federation says. [35.]
 
Many investment clubs collapse in the early going. Some of the hallmarks of surviving clubs, surveys show, are close links among members and an egalitarian approach. [36.]

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTION: THE MAYOR;
Giuliani Tries to End Feud, But His Phone Isn't Ringing

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called his fellow Republicans petty, ungracious and dangerously overconfident yesterday for the retaliation they are inflicting on him for supporting Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and he warned them that if in trying to punish him, they hurt New York City, they would only hurt themselves, too.
 Still feeling the stings of retribution for his stunning -- and, in hindsight, inopportune -- decision to endorse the Democratic Governor, Mr. Giuliani appeared to be shoring up his weakened political position and trying to send a message that the city's interests could not be ignored. 
 "Boy, they shouldn't make any mistake of the fact that I can be very, very outspoken and still have the opportunity to fight back very, very hard for New York City," he said. "If they try to hurt New York, they're not only going to be having to hear from me, but also all of the people that care about New York City."
 Speaking in turn about Governor-elect George E. Pataki, the Republican National Committee and, by implication, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mr. Giuliani urged -- or perhaps pleaded -- that they put the divisive campaign behind them and work with him for the good of the city and state.
 Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that the Republican National Committee had displayed "the pettiest kind of partisan politics" by deciding not to consider holding its 1996 convention in the city -- a decision the committee chairman, Haley Barbour, made a point of disclosing on Thursday, though many in the party doubted New York was a likely choice even before Mr. Giuliani broke ranks.
 After seeming uncharacteristically chastened in the wake of Tuesday's election, Mr. Giuliani also lashed out at Mr. Pataki, saying that he would hurt the economy of the whole state if he favored other regions at the expense of the city. And he suggested that the Governor-elect had acted ungraciously for still refusing, three days after Election Day, to return his phone calls.
 "Once an election is over with, my goodness -- it's enough having to go through it during election time," Mr. Giuliani said in a radio interview on WCBS-AM (880), trying to move past the bitter tone of the campaign, when he traded barbs with Mr. Pataki and his patron, Mr. D'Amato. "The very next moment you should get over it and then not worry about that stuff for four years. If they carry on this partisan stuff, they're going to hurt themselves."
 Still, the retributions have come.
 Mr. Pataki departed yesterday for a weekend vacation with his family, and a spokeswoman, Caroline Quartararo, said he would put aside discussions of budget policies or other transition issues until he returned on Tuesday. That would appear to mean the Mayor should not wait by the phone.
 And Senator D'Amato, the Mayor's now and again bitterest rival, offered a double-edged pledge on Thursday not to hold Mr. Giuliani's attacks against him. "I'm not going to squish him," he told Don Imus on his morning radio show on WFAN-AM (660). "He's going to squish himself. You leave the bug alone unless the bug is biting."
 The sniping between Mr. Giuliani and the state's other most prominent Republicans, Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato, showed that the nastiness of the campaign would linger for at least a while. And the Mayor's pointed counterattacks raised questions about whether they could work together or whether their feud would spill into policy decisions affecting the city, which has more than 40 percent of the state's 18 million residents, once Mr. Pataki takes over as the first Republican governor in 24 years.
 Since election night, Mr. Pataki has reiterated his campaign pledge to enact a 25 percent cut in income taxes over the next four years -- a plan Mr. Giuliani derided as "phony" during the campaign. But he has offered scant details on how he would cut spending to cover a $5.6 billion cut in tax revenues or how he would close a $4 billion shortfall Mr. Cuomo's office has now projected in next year's state budget.
 The feuding, however, may have already had an economic impact on the city. Mr. Giuliani has estimated that playing host to the Republican convention in 1996 could have added $100 million to the city's coffers. That evaporated with Mr. Barbour's announcement that the convention would now be held in either New Orleans, San Diego or San Antonio -- in spite of the Mayor's attempts to woo the site selection committee, going so far as to promise to ride an elephant into Madison Square Garden if need be.
 Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani said the decision was "a lost opportunity" for the G.O.P. to showcase a new urban agenda on issues like crime and fiscal conservatism that he has made the priorities of his mayoralty. "This is something that would be good for the Republican Party," he said, "and here they're turning it down to make some petty point."
 Mr. Giuliani also had a message for the new Congress, saying it would be foolhardy for Republicans to not address the concerns of cities. And in apparent reference to Mr. D'Amato, who is in line to become the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, he issued a caution to those who were "feeling extra powerful."
 Speaking to reporters after marching in the Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan, he said, "People make the most mistakes sometimes when they feel too powerful and too strong and that they are kind of, like, on top of the world."
 If the feud continues, Mr. Giuliani might find the Democrats his strongest allies in Albany, particularly the Speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, who represents the Lower East Side of Manhattan.
 Mr. Silver said yesterday that he expected that the new governor would recognize the importance of New York to the state's economy and reach out to it even though its voters went overwhelmingly for Mr. Cuomo.
 "I think George Pataki is smart enough to realize that, whatever internal squabbling exists, New York City is an important factor in the state," he said.
 The Mayor's budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, also downplayed the likelihood that Mr. Pataki's plans would single out the city's budget -- even though Mr. Giuliani hopes to receive millions of dollars in new aid to help close a $1.1 billion gap that has opened in the city's $31.6 billion budget.
 "There are no 'just New York City' spending programs in the state budget," said Mr. Lackman, who worked for the Republicans who control the State Senate before joining the Giuliani administration.
 He compared the state's budget to a marble cake, where the flavors and colors are mixed, saying, "When you take a slice from it, you're not taking a slice from one specific part."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Europe's Insulation Market Is Target of Owens-Corning

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: VISE, Belgium

 BODY:
The Pink Panther is coming.
 The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, the largest manufacturer of insulation in the world, is using its cartoon mascot to spearhead an assault on Europe's $75 billion home improvement market. 
 To win the consumer hardware wars here, the company will have to make inroads into a European culture that can be indifferent to aggressive marketing, initially unresponsive to America's do-it-yourself revolution and unacquainted with the most hyper of American institutions, the hardware hyperstore.
 Winning hearts and minds of European consumers is not going to be easy. Owens-Corning is the dominant player in insulation in North America, with a 60 percent market share of insulation sales. But so far, the company, which has a plant in this town two miles from the Dutch border, accounts for only 15 percent of the market in Europe, where the major player is the French company Saint-Gobain.
 Owens-Corning, based in Toledo, Ohio, was the first company to trademark a color -- pink, back in 1987, for its insulation material. The Pink Panther, the rascally cartoon character, was licensed last August to help promote the company's insulation products worldwide.
 It cost $150 million for Owens-Corning to introduce Pink Panther insulation to the United States, and analysts estimate it could ultimately cost as much in Europe. But Owens-Corning, which had total sales of $3.2 billion last year, has picked Europe as a place to make major inroads into the $250 billion worldwide home improvement market.
 The Pink Panther is but one element of the most sweeping brand-name transformation in the company's international operations, one that will make Owens-Corning itself a worldwide brand. Until now, the company marketed its building-materials products under a variety of names in Europe, including Thermolan, Crown, Dritherm and Rocksill.
 Many a brand introduction has turned on the unpredictability of foreign markets. Pepsico even had to take the cheese out of Cheetos to introduce the snack food to China. In this case the symbol for Owens-Corning is associated with Hollywood's bumbling French detective, Inspector Jacques Clouseau, and a sendup of things European.
 "Our preliminary research shows no negatives with the Pink Panther," said Nina Fiorenza, the company's European marketing and communications director.
 But Karen Strauss, the Owens-Corning director of corporate branding programs, added: "We are going to do some formidable research to make sure. We don't want to slam-dunk American ideas and practices on a different culture and a different way of doing business."
 Warren Knowlton, president of the Owens-Corning building-products division in Europe, said the insulation market "cannot fail to grow" there. "Governments everywhere are demanding more energy conservation and pollution control," he said in an interview in Vise.
 In the United States, insulation has been a staple of hardware supermarkets. In Europe, though, insulation is largely sold by so-called builders' merchants, who had traditionally catered to contractors but now sell retail to the public.
 In its unaccustomed European role as the little guy, Owens-Corning makes do with a small sales and support staff. But the company "needs to make a major investment in marketing and manpower if they're going to make it here," said Willi Philippeth, a builders' merchant who owns Isolem, a wholesale and retail operation in Limburg, Belgium.
 Jos Peeters, a sales representative for Isolem, said suppliers "won't care a bit about the color pink, or the Pink Panther." "But," he added, "it could be a selling point for home consumers."
 The manufacturing center of the new Owens-Corning marketing push will be the insulation plant in Vise. With the factory's output sold out for the last four years, Owens-Corning plans to construct another production line at a cost of $40 million. The expansion will increase capacity by 60 percent and will have the capability to spray the insulation trademark-pink. Although there is a risk of a consumer backlash against an aggressive campaign by an American multinational, Mr. Philippeth said many Belgians thought of the Owens-Corning operation as economically beneficial, since the company has 1,300 employees in Europe.
 In most of Europe, insulation products are relegated to a corner of the large hardware chains. That's the configuration in the G. B. Brico store in Tongeren, a picture-postcard town 20 minutes from Vise.
 "We sell only 300 to 400 rolls of insulation each fall," said Guido Van Hacht, the store's assistant manager. "But we would carry Owens-Corning if we were supplied with it."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTION: THE TRANSITION;
Looming Budget Gap Was No Surprise, Cuomo Tells Pataki

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Responding to criticism from Governor-elect George E. Pataki about a projected $4 billion budget gap, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo told Mr. Pataki on the phone this morning that the shortfall should have come as no surprise.
 Cuomo administration officials, meanwhile, went a step further, issuing a statement to outline the shortfall and suggesting that if Mr. Pataki had done his homework before promising a 25 percent cut in personal income taxes over four years, he would have realized that there was a problem. 
 "All these developments were public knowledge," Rudy Runko, Mr. Cuomo's budget director, said in the statement. "That is why so many private economists said Governor-elect Pataki's proposed tax cut was unaffordable."
 But a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki said that Mr. Cuomo had either hidden the numbers or had not made them widely available during the campaign. "How could he have known about these numbers when they were not released until after the election?" said the spokeswoman, Caroline Quartararo. "Why didn't the Cuomo administration take steps to correct the problem?"
 Three days after the election, campaign bickering continued even though the two principals were out of the public eye. Mr. Cuomo again spent the day in the Executive Mansion taking calls; Mr. Pataki left his home in Garrison for a weekend vacation, his destination a secret. He is expected back to work on Tuesday, Ms. Quartararo said.
 Much of the political speculation in the capital today centered on the person who is now the second most powerful Republican in state government, the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay.
 Mr. Marino's hold on power seemed vulnerable after Mr. Pataki won, because he tried to block the Governor-elect's candidacy this spring. United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's most potent patron, promised several times during the campaign to unseat Mr. Marino from leadership.
 But today, one of the people most often mentioned as a challenger to Mr. Marino, State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Saratoga Springs, said he had no immediate plans to try to topple Mr. Marino.
 "I support the majority leader at this time," said Mr. Bruno, who is close to Mr. Pataki, Mr. D'Amato and the Republican State Committee leaders. "If and when a vacancy occurs in the Senate leadership, I will make my judgment then as to what will be in my best interest and that of the majority conference."
 Though a challenge remains distinctly possible, several key senators said privately this week that Mr. Marino seemed secure for the moment. Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Westchester Republican who some observers also mentioned as a possible challenger, said Mr. Pataki had told him recently he did not wish to push Mr. Marino from power at this time.
 "My own opinion is that George Pataki will have his hands full governing the state, especially in light of the fact that we are looking at a $4 billion deficit," said Mr. Spano, who denied any immediate ambitions to the seat. "I don't think this is an additional burden he would take on."
 It was unclear who initiated the phone call between Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki, but a Cuomo aide said the Governor had told Mr. Pataki that the gap was only a prediction, and that such projected gaps open every year and are corrected through spending cuts. He also told Mr. Pataki that the size of the gap had been the main problem with passing the budget this year, and had been public knowledge long before Election Day, the aide said.
 "The Governor said to him, 'I'm just surprised that you would express surprise about something that was discussed so much,' " said the aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
 According to Mr. Runko's statement, the budget Mr. Cuomo presented for this fiscal year was balanced but left a projected gap for next year of $1.43 billion. In June, the Legislature enacted a budget with more spending and deeper tax cuts than the Governor proposed, though he signed this budget into law. The tax cuts and extra spending added $1.63 billion to the projected gap, Mr. Runko said.
 A slackening of revenue will mean an additional loss of $500 million next year, and Mr. Runko also cited greater projected costs for prisons and higher interest rates on state debt.
 Mr. Cuomo also urged Mr. Pataki not to dismiss out of hand his proposal for a state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, saying it was not simply an empty campaign promise.

HEADLINE: Dr. Robert Henry Strotz, 72, Chief of Northwestern University

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dr. Robert Henry Strotz, an expert in economic theory and econometrics who served as president of Northwestern University from 1970 to 1985, died on Wednesday in a nursing home in Deerfield, Ill. A resident of Wilmette, Ill., he was 72.
 He had suffered a long illness, the university reported. 
 During Dr. Strotz's tenure, Northwestern experienced continued faculty and student growth and made capital improvements of more than $142 million, the university said.
 After his retirement as president, Dr. Strotz became university chancellor and remained in that post until 1990. As chancellor he acted primarily as a fund-raiser and liaison to alumni.
 Born in Aurora, Ill., he graduated from the University of Chicago, where he earned his doctorate in 1951 with a thesis on welfare economics. He studied econometrics at research centers in England, the Netherlands and Sweden.
 In World War II he put his studies on hold while he served with the Army in Europe.
 He joined the faculty of Northwestern in Evanston, Ill., in 1947 and became a professor in the department of economics by 1958. From 1966 until 1970 he served as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences.
 Before becoming president, he was the author or co-author of books and many articles on business investment and many other subjects. He was a former editor of Econometrica, the quarterly of the Econometric Society, associate editor of the International Economic Review and editor of Contributions to Economic Analysis.
 He is survived by his wife, Margaret Hanley Strotz; four daughters, Vicki Rhodes of Madison, Wis., Frances Strotz of Waukegan, Ill., Ellen Macieiski of Danville, Ill., and Ann Pence of Kasilaf, Alaska; a son, Michael of Winnetka, Ill.; a brother, Loren of Aurora; three stepdaughters, Katie Hanley and Elizabeth Hughes of Evanston and Marcia Hoover of Seattle, and 13 grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert H. Strotz (Associated Press, 1974)

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTION: THE VOTERS;
Religious-Right Candidates Gain as G.O.P. Turnout Rises

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Candidates aligned with conservative religious groups scored major gains on Tuesday in an election in which turnout increased among Republicans in every region of the country, two surveys showed today.
A study by People for the American Way, a group that calls itself "a voice against intolerance," found that 60 percent of the 600 candidates for national, state and local offices who were supported by religious conservatives won their elections. 
 Arthur J. Kropp, president of the group, said the gains would significantly increase the influence of religious conservatives in American politics. "More politicians than ever owe their jobs to the organizing and financial support supplied by religious-right groups," he said, adding that "their expectation is that the right-wing agenda will receive top priority in the next two years."
Still, some high-profile candidates affiliated with religious conservatives, like Oliver L. North, who ran for Senate from Virginia, were defeated. In Oregon and Idaho, statewide initiatives to limit protections for gay people, which had been supported by many religious conservatives, also lost.
But Ralph Reed, executive director of the Christian Coalition, said the involvement of greater numbers of religious conservatives and the success of candidates they supported represented "a sea change in American politics."
About 75 million Americans cast ballots for the Tuesday election but many more than that who were eligible did not vote, according to a second study, announced today by the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a nonpartisan group here.
Turnout was estimated by the study at 38.7 percent of eligible voters, an increase of 2.2 percentage points from four years ago. The turnout was the highest for any midterm election since the recession year of 1982, but it was well below the levels in the 20 years ending in 1970.
The study, based on final, unofficial returns reported by the News Election Service, which tabulates election results for television networks and wire services, found that Republican turnout nationally exceeded Democratic turnout for the first time in a midterm election since 1970.
Turnout was up in all regions of the country except New England and the farming portion of the Midwest, and Republican turnout increased in every region. Democratic turnout, however, declined in every region except the Middle Atlantic states. There were huge increases in turnout in Tennessee and Virginia and substantial increases in New York, Maryland, Michigan, Pennsylvania, Texas and Florida, perhaps because the elections in those states were so hotly contested.

HEADLINE: Issues of Race and Pollution Trouble L.I. Town

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW CASSEL, L.I.

 BODY:
For years, residents of this predominantly black and Hispanic working-class community have held their noses, shut their windows and tried hard not to dwell on the smells and the unsightliness of the 170-acre industrial site just across the railroad tracks.
 The putrid odors from the chemical plants and garbage-transfer stations and fish processing factories make some people sick. But they are so taken for granted in New Cassel, directly downwind of the plants, that few residents lodge complaints. In fact, Nassau County health officials say, a vast majority of complaints have come from wealthier, primarily white communities upwind of the plants like Salisbury and South Westbury, where the smells are not nearly so intense. 
 But now, the people of New Cassel are suddenly transfixed by the sources of the odors. A recent report by a public-interest research group detailed several environmental hazards, from air pollution to toxic waste to groundwater contamination, in the industrial area, and revealed what many residents say they had not known: Since 1988 their suburb's industrial zone has been on the state's Superfund list, awaiting cleanup.
 John Addison, president of a New Cassell citizens group, the Progressive Civic Association, said the information in the report, gleaned from the state's own documents, stunned him. "I was awestruck by the literature," he said. "We never as a community acknowledged with any understanding how serious the issue could be. We've been in the dark for years."
 The report, prepared by the New York Public Interest Research Group, criticized state environmental officials for failing to inform residents of the potential hazards at their doorsteps and for not taking quick action against the polluters. This has angered the community's civic leaders, who think that the slowness of the cleanup reflects New Cassel's second-class status in a predominantly white, suburban county. But the report has also inspired introspection among the community's leaders, who have begun to wonder if the apathy of New Cassel's residents also contributed to the state's slow response.
 "I have to say, I feel that it's because we're African-Americans here," Mildred Little said, explaining why she thinks there has been no cleanup. But Ms. Little, who has lived in New Cassel since 1957 and serves on the Town of North Hempstead's zoning board, also said it is difficult to get residents to protest, because many feel so disenfranchised. "A lot of people do not speak up," she said.
 A growing number of minority groups across the country have been arguing that when it comes to living in areas contaminated with industrial pollution, black, Hispanic and American Indian communities bear a disproportionate share of the burden. Last year, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency reported that higher percentages of blacks and Hispanics than whites lived in areas polluted by dust, soot, carbon monoxide, ozone and emissions from hazardous waste dumps.
 Environmental groups say some studies have shown hazardous waste sites in white and wealthier communities are attended to more quickly by the Government than those in minority and poorer communities. Patricia Williams, counsel on solid and hazardous wastes for the National Wildlife Federation, said low-income and minority communities lack the political and economic influence to get swift action.
 "You have poor communities that are not necessarily focused upon," Ms. Williams said. "They aren't the fund raisers, they aren't the people with the PAC's. They're not on the front lines of attention."
 State environmental officials deny that they have dragged their feet on the New Cassel site. Although the state first designated it as a Class 2 hazardous waste site -- meaning that it presented a "significant threat to the public health and environment" -- in 1988, officials say the complexity of finding the source of the contamination has prolonged the investigation of the New Cassel industrial area, one of 570 Class 2 sites in the state.
 Chemicals found underground at the site have been identified as trichloroethane and tetrachloroethane, degreasers used by many of the dozens of companies in the industrial zone. The problem, officials say, is trying to determine which of the 129 properties in the zone is the source.
 "This is not a typical site where you have one industry and one owner," said Michael O'Toole, director of the Division of Hazardous Waste Remediation for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. "Under the state's Superfund law, we can't use Superfund money unless we make efforts to identify the responsible parties."
 Last year, the department hired an environmental consultant to determine the origins of the underground concentrations of pollution. A draft report identifying several of the concentrations is to be submitted by the consultant this month and released to the public in December, Mr. O'Toole said.
 So far, the state has spent $250,000 on the New Cassel investigation, he added.
 But what troubles residents like Mr. Addison, a mortgage banker who was raised in New Cassel and moved back here with his family a decade ago, is that until the report by the New York Public Interest Research Group, he knew nothing about the extent of the problem. He is not sure who is at fault: the state for not doing a better job of spreading the news, or the community, for not doing a better job of looking after itself.
 Still, Mr. Addison said, New Cassel is at a severe disadvantage in trying to protect its interests. According to the 1990 Census, the per-capita income in the hamlet, where 66 percent of the 10,200 residents are black and 20 percent are Hispanic, is $12,918. That is about half the Nassau County average and about one-third less than the state average.
 The economic and social pressures of daily life in New Cassel leave its residents little time to consider the long-terms health effects of what might be produced in the industrial area, Mr. Addison said: "We've always been the community that is last to know. It's almost like being punched in the arm too much. You come to accept the pain."
 Ludovic Blain, who prepared the 54-page report for the New York research group, said New Cassel's experience fits a pattern for several minority communities around the state that are near industrial and hazardous waste sites, including Wyandanch on the Island and a black neighborhood in Albany. Whether the phenomenon -- and the Government's response to it -- is evidence of racism or lack of influence is a matter of conjecture, he said.
 "It's difficult to prove," Mr. Blain said. "But just like when a car hits you, the intent is secondary as far as you are concerned. The issue here is whether these communities can control the character of their neighborhood, and get the resources to make that happen."
 In recent weeks, meetings organized by Ms. Little and the public interest group in New Cassel's community center have drawn dozens of residents as well as the area's representatives in Albany. What residents would like, Ms. Little said, is for the state to hire a local ombudsman, someone from the community who could insure that residents are apprised of what is happening in the industrial area, and keep the pressure on environmental officials to pursue the cleanup.
 Mr. Addison said he was skeptical that the state's indifference to New Cassel would change. The only time he ever sees politicians, he said, is before Election Day. "The political atmosphere is, 'Here in September, gone in November,' " he said with a sigh.

HEADLINE: Only Futures Are Traded In Treasury Bond Market

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Futures trading in an abbreviated session was the only activity yesterday in the Government securities market, with the cash market closed in observance of Veterans Day.
 Traders said the price of the December contract for a 30-year Treasury bond finished down 17/32 , at 962/32 . David Ging, manager of MMS Treasury Technical in Chicago, said that the equivalent price in the cash market was 9210/32 or slightly more, for a yield of 8.19 percent. 
 Mr. Ging said, "If the overseas markets do nothing ahead of Monday's opening of the U.S. market, this is the yield investors will be looking at in the morning."
 Yesterday's futures trading underlined the bearish tone of the bond market, Mr. Ging added. "One thing interesting to note was that the low for the current futures market was 961/32 on Monday, and yesterday that low was tested again and barely held," he said.
 "Last Monday," he continued, "the low in the cash market was 9214/32 for a yield of 8.18 percent. Given the current conditions, the long bond is likely to open even lower, setting a new low in the cash market for this current cycle in the bear market. We're looking for the yield on the long bond to move to 8.25 percent in the New York cash market some time next week."
 In the municipal and corporate bond markets, there was virtually no trading because of the holiday, dealers said. Although the cash market was unchanged, futures in municipal bonds were down substantially. The December municipal contract was down nearly a point, and investors focused on next week's slate of new issues, mindful that the Fed will be meeting on Tuesday.
 Treasury issues were virtually unchanged in Europe. There was a limited futures session, but the December contract was not trading when European markets were open so there was little incentive overseas to take fresh positions. European markets edged slightly lower in listless trading. Treasuries also saw little activity in Tokyo.
 The bond market now turns its attention to Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making panel of the Federal Reserve. The market consensus is that the Fed will raise short-term interest rates for the sixth time this year after the meeting. Increases of 50 basis points in both the discount rate (the rate the Fed charges member banks) and the Federal funds rate (the rate banks charge each other for loans, usually overnight loans) are expected.
 No economic reports are scheduled for release until Tuesday, when the Fed will also report on industrial output and capacity utilization for October and the Commerce Departmant will report on October retail sales.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Little Changed In Quiet Holiday Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed in quiet trading yesterday as most American banks operated with limited foreign exchange staff because of the Veterans Day holiday.
 The dollar was unchanged at 97.73 yen in New York trading; it edged up to 1.5305 German marks, from 1.5285 marks on Thursday. 
 Traders are waiting to see if the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates after its policy-making committee meets on Tuesday. The Fed is expected to raise short-term interest rates by 50 basis points, or half a percentage point, to keep inflation in check. But some traders say it will take a larger increase in rates to keep the dollar from weakening again.
 "Fifty basis points won't be enough to support the dollar, because that's so widely expected," said David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, a New York consulting firm.
 Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds, and fears that inflation will accelerate have weighed down the bond market and the value of the dollar this year. Many traders say the dollar is unlikely to strengthen until the United States bond market stages a significant recovery. And that is unlikely to happen until the Fed convinces the bond market that it is doing enough to quell inflationary pressures.
 "The Fed has to say it's achieving a tight monetary policy rather than aiming for a neutral one," said Marc Chandler, director of research at Ezra Zask Associates, a Norfolk, Conn., hedge fund with $160 million under management.
 Mr. Chandler, however, thinks the dollar's descent may be over. "The bulk of bad news has been discounted for the dollar," he said.
 The dollar has fallen about 13 percent against the yen and the mark so far this year.
 In other currency trading yesterday, the Swedish krona rose against the mark and the dollar ahead of a referendum on whether Sweden should join the European Union. A "yes" vote would help the krona by forcing Sweden to cut deficit spending to meet union economic requirements. Opinion polls show almost an even division between voters who favor joining the European Union and those who are opposed.
 In New York, the Swedish krona was last quoted at 7.2437 kronor to the dollar, stronger than 7.2589 kronor on Thursday.
 The British pound slipped to $1.5960, from $1.6000 on Thursday. The dollar was little changed against the Swiss franc, at 1.2830 francs, down from 1.2831 francs on Thursday.

HEADLINE: The Outlook For Tax Cuts, G.O.P. Style

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
The Republican action plan, known as the Contract With America, calls for tax relief for millions.
 Although it might be tempting to disregard the proposal as just another Washington wish list, the contract is far more substantive than campaign rhetoric. In fact, it is 41 pages of black-and-white details. 
 And for individuals to ignore the contract's financial elements would almost certainly be a mistake, investment professionals said after digesting this week's election results.
 "I think we're going to see action -- and soon," said Stephen Corrick, a tax partner at Arthur Andersen & Company. "We've already sent out some alerts to clients."
 This is what some of the proposals would do:
 * Cut the capital gains tax in half.
 * Phase out the 1993 tax increase on Social Security benefits.
 * Give a tax credit to married couples who pay more than they would by filing as two singles.
 * Create a new type of individual retirement account.
 * Give families earning up to $200,000 a $500 tax credit for each child under 18.
 * Allow small businesses to deduct the first $25,000 of annual investment.
 "I think the odds are very high that the Congress will deliver" with some significant changes, said Fred T. Goldberg Jr., a former Treasury official and a former Commissioner of Internal Revenue in the Bush Administration. He declared a lower capital gains tax so compelling for politicians as to be a near-certainty. Only strenuous opposition by George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, halted such a measure during the Bush years, and the Maine Democrat is retiring this year.
 Not only is it among the most likely and significant changes, but a capital-gains tax reduction is one of the few proposals that might prompt some immediate changes in financial plans. The proposal, which calls for excluding 50 percent of any capital gains from taxes, would favor middle-income people whose income tax bracket may now be little different from the 28 percent they pay on capital gains.
 The basic strategy for investors is to hold off selling stock or other appreciated assets until 1995, keeping in mind that the tax tail should not wag the investment dog.
 "Movements in the market can overwhelm tax considerations," warned Robert B. Coplan, a tax partner at Ernst & Young.
 Although there is no guarantee that current holdings would qualify for any lower rate on capital gains tax, policy makers are normally sensitive to market reaction, said C. Clinton Stretch of Deloitte & Touche, who is, however, less confident about a capital gains cut than others. "The one thing I know Congress will do is to seek very hard to avoid making people sit on the sidelines" by pegging a tax cut to some future date, Mr. Stretch said.
 The Republicans, euphoric over their impending control of Congress, also propose indexing assets so investors will no longer have to pay taxes on gains that merely reflect inflation. However commendable, the idea would be so difficult to administer that tax specialists give it almost no chance of adoption.
 Most of the rest of the program falls into a gray area. Passage of these elements is plausible, but paying for them would be expensive. In any event, financial planning now is of limited use even if these other elements become law.
 Few people are likely to use the Republican proposals to help them decide, for example, whether to have children or to get married. Still, two high earners who plan to marry will benefit by putting the wedding off until the new year, no matter what. That's because they will avoid the marriage penalty on 1994 income and the penalty could be eliminated in future years.
 There's little chance to plan for a proposed new I.R.A. -- a "back-ended" investment that would provide a tax advantage for withdrawals, not for contributions.
 Repeal of last year's tax increase on Social Security benefits would theoretically encourage retirees to put more emphasis on income than on growth in their investments. But the tax benefit would be so small that it would probably not be worth changing one's behavior, tax specialists said.
 Another proposal would raise the amount people aged 65 to 69 could earn without losing Social Security benefits to $30,000 by the year 2000 from $11,160 now.
 An item that has caught the attention of financial planners is the proposal to increase the tax exemption for estates. Anyone can now leave $600,000, over a lifetime or at death, to heirs free of taxes. There had been speculation in recent years that the limit would be lowered, but the Republicans want to raise the amount to $750,000. Some people who have reached the limit could then resume annual gifts to children.
 A major consideration, of course, is how Congress will pay for any tax breaks given its self-imposed requirement not to worsen the budget deficit. Some specialists are already nervous about a possible threat to the tax-free status of annuities, of the money building up in pension funds or even of I.R.A.'s.
 "It's hard to see how we get a middle-class tax cut that won't affect the middle class" adversely somewhere, said Stuart Kessler, a tax lawyer at Goldstein Golub Kessler & Company in New York. And he cautioned those deferring income this year not to overdo it lest they be caught by the alternative minimum tax.
 "Capital gains will be cut," said Charles D. Youree, a financial consultant to Smith, Barney. "But I don't look for a lot of other things."

HEADLINE: Latin America's Privatization Path

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Arching over oceangoing freighters and stretching for 10 miles, the bridge across Rio de Janeiro's bay symbolized Latin America's state-led economic development when it was inaugurated here 20 years ago.
 Early next year, the operation of the deteriorating steel-and-concrete bridge is to pass into private hands, once a construction consortium starts renovating it and collecting tolls under a 20-year concession. 
 As governments across Latin America turn to private-sector concessions to satisfy their people's hunger for infrastructure projects, investment opportunities loom large for companies from the United States. Billions of dollars are starting to flow into projects for telephone service, highways, ports, airports, electricity, water and sanitation systems.
 With the World Bank increasingly restricting long-term, below-market financing to poorer nations in Africa and Asia, some better-off though still developing nations in Asia, Eastern Europe and Latin America are turning to private business to help build up their facilities and services.
 Latin America has moved furthest along this road, says William G. Reinhardt, who surveys private projects for Public Works Financing, his monthly newsletter in Westfield, N.J.
 "Latin America is trying harder than anywhere else; Latin America is the largest region for successful projects," Mr. Reinhardt said in a telephone interview after touring parts of Mexico's new 3,000-mile network of privately run toll highways.
 Next month, Brazilian authorities will open bids from companies to double the width of the nation's busiest road, a 265-mile highway from Rio de Janeiro to Sao Paulo. In return, the contractors will have the right to levy tolls.
 "With the Rio-Sao Paulo highway, we are talking about a $1 billion investment," said Jack W. Lillywhite, manager of Latin America project development for Bechtel Civil Inc. of San Francisco. He added, "There haven't been too many billion-dollar toll roads around the world."
 In Colombia, the Enron Corporation of Houston is the lead partner in a consortium to build and operate a $200 million gas-fired electric power plant.
 In Chile, where road traffic has quadrupled in 20 years, the Public Works Ministry is seeking bids on a project to convert a 1,000-mile stretch of the Pan American Highway into a four-lane, divided highway, with toll plazas every 100 miles. The concessions would last 15 years.
 Argentina ranks with Mexico as a regional pioneer in highway privatization. Since 1991, the Argentine Government has granted private construction companies 15-year concessions to renovate 6,000 miles of the country's most heavily traveled roads. Spanish and Brazilian construction concerns are widening the access roads to Buenos Aires.
 Privatization "has been a success in spite of initial resistance by the public, who could not understand why they had to pay tolls on existing infrastructure," said H. Jorge Lafage, general manager of Argentina's Chamber of Road Concessions, a private group. After companies repaved highways, added lanes, rebuilt bridges, put up new signs and inaugurated tow-truck service, opinion polls taken at toll booths started to show consumer satisfaction with privately run roads.
 Colombia, which has aggressively pursued improvements, is privatizing its seaports and six busiest airfields. It is negotiating concession contracts with private companies for the construction and operation of $3 billion worth of power plants and $1.5 billion of highways. Some of the Colombian toll roads will be built by Mexican, Brazilian, Spanish and Italian companies.
 Chile's Public Works Minister, Ricardo Lagos, has drawn up a list of 28 toll road and tunnel projects, so that within a decade, truckers could drive in less than three days from factories near the Atlantic coast in Sao Paulo or Buenos Aires to Chile's Pacific ports, distances ranging from 800 to 1,500 air miles.
 United States companies, which have lagged behind, are expected to enter highway projects in Latin America either as minority partners in joint ventures with local construction companies or as technical consultants.
 "The Mexican highway projects have been largely done by Mexican companies, and I would imagine that would be the same in Brazil," said Edwin Berk, senior vice president for Latin America of ICF Kaiser International, the engineering company based in Fairfax, Va. With new privatization projects on the horizon, the company is returning to Brazil after a 10-year absence.
 "What an American company usually brings to a project is either specialized technical expertise or credibility in international financial markets," Mr. Berk said.
 To ease financing, the Inter-American Development Bank decided in April to start lending directly to private companies for Latin American public works and services.
 "Our participation should leverage more private-sector money, particularly long-term financing," Nancy Birdsall, executive vice president of the lending agency, said in a telephone interview from Washington. "Our participation should provide some comfort that governments would honor their promises on prices for energy or tolls for roads."
 In many countries, private companies have been reluctant to operate toll roads or power plants for fear that politicians would yield to public pressure and lower tolls and utility rates below profitable levels.
 "The need for infrastructure is great, but the ability to pay is not," said Mr. Reinhardt, who surveyed 900 private project proposals around the world for a report in his newsletter. "So you have a political disconnect when it comes time for paying."
 Brazilian governments, trying to fight triple-digit inflation for most of the last decade, repeatedly kept electricity, telephone and gasoline prices below profitable levels for private investors.
 "We won't go into countries that have not provided the regulatory framework for profitable operation," said Scott Swensen, senior portfolio manager for the Scudder Latin American Trust for Independent Power. "In Brazil, power rates are so low that doing a power project does not make any sense." The Scudder fund, which started last year, now has a capitalization of $100 million.
 Brazil seems about to allow the largest-scale foreign investment in electricity generation, telephone service and highway construction in Latin America.
 "Brazil needs to restore and expand its transportation, energy and telecommunications infrastructure," Fernando Henrique Cardoso, the President-elect, wrote last month in the newspaper O Estado de Sao Paulo. "The entry of private capital is no longer a question of ideological preference. It means the difference between carrying out or not carrying out necessary investments."
 Mr. Cardoso, who is to take office on Jan. 1, has promised a four-year, $100 billion infrastructure program, half of which is to be financed by private money. He hopes that by early next year, Brazil's Congress will approve a concessions bill, which is intended to speed foreign investment in electricity generation and to make the projects profitable for the investors.
 With 16 unfinished hydroelectric projects expected to be privatized next year for roughly $12 billion, four international consortiums have already been formed by potential investors. They include the Chase Manhattan Bank, Southern Electric International, which is based in Atlanta, and Houston Lighting and Power in Texas.

Map: Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Colombia and Mexico lead the rest of Latin America in allowing the private sector to handle development projects. (The New York Times)(pg.49)
