HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Health Care Plan Out; Health Care Stocks In

BYLINE: By Deborah M. Rankin 

 BODY:
HEALTH care stocks enjoyed an election bounce this week as the Republican victory dashed any hopes of reviving President Clinton's ambitious health care plan.
 But the stocks have been gaining momentum for months. In fact, some of the mutual funds that invest in them are having outstanding years, in large part because of a sparkling third quarter. The leaders, both from Fidelity, are its Medical Delivery fund, up 20.9 percent, and its Health Care fund, up 17.5 percent. 
Charles Magnum, portfolio manager of the Health Care fund, is "cautiously optimistic" about the industry's prospects. "We're probably still in the early- to mid-innings of the game," he said.
 For the year through Nov. 4, the 15 health care funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. gained an average of 3.28 percent, compared with zero gains for the average equity fund. After a dismal first half, the funds broke out in the third quarter, soaring 14.03 percent. Along with the demise of health care overhaul, which was expected to squeeze industry profits, a flurry of mergers bolstered health care stocks.
 "Funds that had a lot of exposure to H.M.O.'s did best," in the latest run-up, said Amy C. Arnott, a Morningstar analyst who follows health care funds. Such funds included Fidelity Select Medical Delivery, Putnam Health Sciences, and Franklin Global Health Care.
 "Laggards this year have been funds that concentrated on biotech stocks," Ms. Arnott said. A striking example is Fidelity Select Biotechnology, down 17.7 percent through Nov. 4. Not only have biotech stocks been hurt by rising interest rates, which makes financing more expensive, but they were tarnished by the recent collapse of David Blech's brokerage firm, which made a market in many of these stocks.
 A consistent performer has been Vanguard Specialized Health Care, the only fund in the category to earn Morningstar's five-star designation -- for top returns with minimal risk.
 "It was basically able to sidestep a lot of problems in the health care area by staying diversified and going for the best values," said Daniel P. Wiener, editor of the Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors, a Watertown, Mass., newsletter.
 Edward P. Owens, the manager since the fund's inception in 1984, says he holds about 70 stocks, spread among health services companies, medical products, major pharmaceuticals, specialty pharmaceuticals and international companies. Turnover is low and major changes infrequent, Mr. Owens said.
 His three biggest holdings are Zeneca Group, a spinoff of a British drug company, Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson. "Most sectors of the health care industry look pretty attractive right now," he said, and are selling at multiples below historic norms. H.M.O.'s, he said, are the exception.
 An area he calls ripe for growth is therapeutic treatment of disorders like depression, schizophrenia and Alzheimer's disease. "It's the fastest-growing area in the drug industry," Mr. Owens said. Just as antibiotics were the drugs of the 50's and tranquilizers the drugs of the 60's, "antidepressants will be the drugs of the 90's," he said. The well-known drug Prozac is manufactured by Eli Lilly and Pfizer has a similar drug, Zoloft, "growing just as fast," he said.
 Mr. Magnum of Fidelity Select Health Care is also light on H.M.O.'s. "My focus has primarily been the drug and product side," he said. "There's been a profound change in the way that major drug makers run their companies." He said Bristol Myers-Squibb and American Home Products, two major fund components, "are very, very cheap, and will benefit from cost cutting."
 Invesco Strategic Health Sciences, which is down 2.1 percent for the year through Nov. 4, has been faltering since 1992, when John Kaweske was portfolio manager. Mr. Kaweske left the fund in a flap over unauthorized trades early this year, and his former co-manager, Barry Kurokawa, has made some changes.
 The fund continues to focus on small- and medium-size companies, but is trying to reduce volatility by avoiding big positions in one-product companies. The most striking change has been slashing biotech holdings to 8 percent from 19 percent. "Clearly, our exposure to the biotech sector was much, much too large," Mr. Kurakowa said.
 Investors don't have to own a sector fund to get exposure to health care stocks. Among the diversified funds with large health care positions are Robertson Stephens Emerging Growth (53 percent of its portfolio), Robertson Stephens Value Plus Growth (48 percent) and Smith Barney Shearson Aggressive Growth (36 percent).
 Trying to time the volatile health care sector is notoriously difficult. "A lot of people poured into health care funds in 1991 because of their phenomenal returns," Ms. Arnott of Morningstar said. "They were really shocked at their losses in 1992, and then got out at the bottom."
 Mr. Owens takes the long view. "There is still money to be made," he said, "if you take a 10- or 15-year horizon."

LENGTH: 436 words

HEADLINE: Shock Treatment for the Budget

 BODY:
Governor-elect George Pataki finds it "shocking" that New York State faces a huge budget gap next year. But people who keep an eye on the state's finances have known for months that the situation was bad and getting worse. The gap will make it that much harder for Mr. Pataki to deliver his promised tax cuts.
According to sources in the Cuomo administration, as well as outside budget-watchers, revenues in the fiscal year beginning next April 1 are likely to fall short of projected spending by about $4 billion. Mr. Pataki must find ways to close that gap before he presents his first budget. Having promised lower taxes, he will presumably try to balance the books with spending cuts and restraints, and by revenue growth from a healthier economy. 
 Gov. Mario Cuomo submitted a balanced budget for the current fiscal year last January, but it projected a $1.4 billion gap for the next fiscal year. The Legislature, driven by thoughts of Election Day, compounded the problem by voting more tax reduction and more spending this year than Mr. Cuomo wanted. As finally adopted, the current budget was still in balance -- at $34 billion -- but the additional spending and tax cuts enlarged next year's prospective gap. Then came big losses on Wall Street, a dip in anticipated tax collections and a slackening in jobs. The result: the projected gap of about $4 billion.
If New York State budgets included a financial plan for future years -- like the planning that the state requires of New York City -- the implications of all those negative developments would have been laid out for everyone to see. The public exposure might even have forced Governor Cuomo and the Legislature to make precautionary adjustments, although election campaigns have a funny way of ignoring budget truths. Neither the incumbents nor the challengers want to deal with the bad news.
Mr. Pataki promised $5.6 billion of tax reduction over the next four years, and has now re-promised it, but he has not detailed what spending reductions would offset the loss of revenue. Obviously, he must crack down hard to balance the budget he inherits, and harder to compensate for any tax reduction he wants in his first year.
Absent systematic accounting by Albany, it is hard to compare the looming $4 billion gap -- bad as it is -- to other years. For too long, the state has budgeted short-term, a year at a time, while failing to establish a long-term balance between the taxes it collects and the money it spends. Faced with this knowledge now, Mr. Pataki could do the state a great service by projecting his budgets well ahead.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Science Fiction

BYLINE: By Gerald Jonas 

 BODY:
"Nan-" or "nano-": a prefix derived from the Latin word for dwarf. Used by scientists to denote the very, very small, as in "nanosecond," a billionth of a second. Used by science fiction writers in combination with the suffix "-tech" to refer to tiny machines that function on a molecular or even atomic scale.
QUEEN CITY JAZZ (Tor/Tom Doherty, $23.95), by Kathleen Ann Goonan, is a dizzying novel that takes full advantage of the creative potential of nanotech. Imagine a technology capable of transforming matter on the most intimate level, a technology that finds it no more difficult to rewire a human brain from the inside than to make a silk purse out of a sow's ear. Literally. 
 For Ms. Goonan, the freedom to remake the world in one's own image poses a terrible temptation. She sets her story in the second half of the next century, in a United States -- the state of Ohio, to be exact -- that has been changed almost beyond recognition by the wand of nanotech. Verity, a young girl who does not know her parents, has been raised in the enclave of Shaker Hill by people who have resisted the lure of nanotech, which they refer to as "nanoplague." Driven by violence to the nano transformed city of Cincinnati, Verity, in the course of learning who she is, uncovers the all-too-human tragedy at the heart of what was meant to be the ultimate triumph of human ingenuity.
Perhaps inevitably, Ms. Goonan, a first novelist of enormous talent and energy, overreaches in the same way as the nanotechnologists whose hubris she chronicles. When everything is possible, nothing is more important than selectivity. Like cyberspace, which offers a dangerous freedom to science fiction writers who dive into its boundless universe, nanotech can set the imagination free of all constraints, including those of plausibility and economy. Ms. Goonan's inclination to inflate her already padded narrative with references to every work of literature and music that she admires is counterproductive -- as is her attempt to make more plausible the fall of Cincinnati by attributing it to "an unfortunate and unforeseeable combination of cataclysms."
In the end, what saves her novel from self-destructing through sheer exuberance is the way she grounds her apocalyptic vision in a few short, finely detailed scenes that reveal how personal failings can become writ large in the great events of history.
NAUTILUS (Spectra/Bantam, paper, $5.99) is the fourth book in Vonda N. McIntyre's Starfarers series, which has no rival as science fiction's most leisurely treatment of the dramatic moment known as first contact between humans and aliens.
In a star system far from Earth, a diverse crew of humans has encountered an even more diverse assortment of aliens, whose galaxy-spanning federation of worlds is known simply as Civilization. To gain admission to Civilization, the emissaries from Earth must convince the aliens that human beings have outlived their violent past.
Like its predecessors, "Nautilus" spends as much time tracking the ever-shifting emotional relationships among the crew members as it does describing the nature of the alien worlds and their inhabitants. Even an anatomically frank account of a multisexual menage a quatre comes out sounding a little like futuristic soap opera.
But there is a purpose to Ms. McIntyre's obsessive attention to the minutiae of human and alien psychology and physiology. When one of the characters finally takes action and the others are forced to react, the reader is in full possession of all the facts needed to appreciate what is happening and why. The payoff is a brilliant set piece of colliding cultures that fully justifies the painfully slow buildup.
Paul J. McAuley's RED DUST (Avonova/Morrow, $22) begins with the line: "Mars was dying." To anyone familiar with the modern scientific picture of Mars as a dead planet, a world too small and too distant from the sun to develop life of its own, these are provocative words.
As it turns out, "Red Dust" is set some 600 years in the future, at a time when human efforts to render the surface of the planet habitable -- by introducing genetically engineered varieties of animals and plants, and by modifying the atmosphere -- are faltering. The human inhabitants of Mars are descendants of a mixed bag of settlers from Earth, mostly Asian, with a scorned minority of Europeans and Americans known collectively as Yankees. Most people live in domed communes and cities, but it is possible to survive in the open, like the "cowboys" who tend the free-ranging herds of yaks.
Politically, the Martians are under the thumb of a Chinese elite who control life-extending technology and access to a possibly damaged super computer known as the Emperor. There are rebels in the outback, in the crowded capital of Xin Beijing and in the asteroid belt beyond the orbit of Mars. The rebels have an uncertain ally in "the King of the Cats," an entity who seems to reside on Jupiter and who communicates with the Martians by assuming the persona of Elvis Presley.
Mr. McAuley, it should be apparent, combines a disciplined scientific imagination with a view of history as a kind of evolutionary joke played on the survivors. The story of how the protagonist of "Red Dust," Contract Agronomist Technician Wei Lee, survives assaults on his safety and sanity to become the new Emperor of Mars is not so much a straight-line narrative as a meandering quest for enlightenment, both personal and global. It is a quest well worth sharing.
Maureen F. McHugh's first novel was the justly acclaimed "China Mountain Zhang," which was published in 1992. In that book she created a memorable 22d-century New York City controlled by a resurgent but relatively benign Chinese empire. In her new novel, HALF THE DAY IS NIGHT (Tor/ Tom Doherty, $21.95), Ms. McHugh once again demonstrates her ability to create a persuasive sense of place.
The underwater nation of Caribe is cold and claustrophobic. In hiding themselves away from the sun within domed cities on the ocean floor, the inhabitants appear to have lost all sense of joy. Their pleasures revolve around making money and making revolution; the two sides in what appears to be endless political conflict are presented as equally distasteful. The opiate of the common people is virtual reality: violent war games that fill empty days with a new kind of emptiness.
So oppressive is the chill atmosphere of Caribe that even Ms. McHugh seems to have fallen under its influence. The two main characters, a young woman of Chinese and American parentage named Mayla Ling and a Vietnamese veteran of military operations in Africa named David, are passive to a fault. David, a burnt-out case in the Graham Greene mold, arrives in Caribe to work as Mayla's bodyguard. She is supposed to live up to her grandfather's reputation as a deal-making banker.
Faced with adversity, David decides to flee. Mayla struggles a bit longer before succumbing to the same impulse. Despite Ms. McHugh's consistently fine writing, I found it hard to sustain interest in such a dispirited pair.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2007 words

HEADLINE: The Cruelest Game

BYLINE: By Brent Staples; Brent Staples writes on politics and culture for The Times's editorial page and is the author of the memoir "Parallel Time: Growing Up in Black and White."

 BODY:

THE LAST SHOT
City Streets, Basketball Dreams.
By Darcy Frey.
230 pp. Boston:
A Richard Todd Book/Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95. 
INNER-CITY poverty entails distressing states of mind as well as material misfortune, the former being firmly secured by a pernicious system of myths. The most disastrous of the myths that confront young African-American men today is the notion that academic achievement and middle-class normalcy are the exclusive province of white folks, and that only swagger and blessed ghetto ignorance are "authentically" black. Add to this the popular racist canard that blacks are "naturally" (read genetically) more suited to athletics than to pursuits of the mind (Eldridge Cleaver called this "the myth of the super-masculine menial"). Stir in the greed of the universities, which share billions of dollars in revenues from college athletics. What you get in the end is mass conversion to, and ruthless promotion of, The Big Lie. To wit: that prowess in basketball magically guarantees a "ticket out of the ghetto," a college degree and perhaps even a career as a professional player. Learn to dribble and shoot, my boy, and the world will beat a path to your door.
That's not how it works. Fewer than 1 percent of the half-million young men who play high school ball will win scholarships. A depressing number of those who do will never graduate. Fewer than one in a hundred of those who play in college will go on to careers in professional basketball. Of this final, golden few, most, through injury, insufficient skill or defects in personality, will last no longer than four years -- has-beens at the age of 26.
Enter here Darcy Frey's "Last Shot: City Streets, Basketball Dreams," a revelatory description of how the basketball myth plays out in the public housing
projects of New York's Coney Island, an isolated and impoverished spit of land at the seaward end of Brooklyn. This book -- compellingly written, with elegance, economy and just the right amount of outrage -- should be read by every parent who has a child involved in school sports, by every college president who pretends not to know what his coaches and recruiters are up to, by every member of Congress who has any interest at all in higher education. "The Last Shot" should be read especially by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and every other top official of New York City, whose corrupt public school athletic system this book lays plainly and painfully bare.
THE myth of deliverance through basketball has always been nonsense. The sport has traditionally involved semiliterate athletes who performed mightily in gyms, failed in classrooms and were discarded when their scholarships ran out. But the competition for these athletes grew heated in the 1980's, after the National Collegiate Athletic Association signed a billion-dollar contract for television rights to college basketball -- and when winning coaches began to earn additional millions for themselves by fronting for the sneaker companies. When Congress and the press put up too much of a stink about poorly educated athletes who never graduated, the N.C.A.A. responded with Proposition 48, raising eligibility standards for those seeking to play big-time college ball in their freshman year. To be eligible for freshman play, an athlete needs a 2.0 average in a high school core curriculum -- and a combined score of at least 700 on the Scholastic Assessment Tests (S.A.T.), about 200 points below the national average for college-bound seniors.
Those who fall short of 700 are grimly referred to as "Prop 48 casualties." Scholarship offers are withdrawn. College coaches look upon these athletes as damaged goods. Illicit characters called street agents broker them to outlaw junior colleges, where they play without even the pretense of being students. The players kick around the outlaw circuit, dropping out of one school and into another, until they end up back at home -- in the case of Coney Island, peddling cold sodas on the scorching summer sidewalks. Proposition 48 came into being in 1986. Since then, Mr. Frey tells us, 91 percent of its casualties have been black.
It is against this backdrop that the journalist Darcy Frey, young, white and curious, arrives at Coney Island's Abraham Lincoln High School to spend eight months with Lincoln's powerhouse basketball team. Lincoln counts among its alumni the novelist Joseph Heller, the playwright Arthur Miller and three Nobel laureates in physics. White flight, budget cuts and a population grown steadily poorer have all done their work. Math and science no longer hold sway here. Lincoln has become a virtual annex of Coney Island's basketball courts.
Coney Island was once the leisure-time Mecca of the white working class, ablaze with the lights of world-famous amusement parks. Today it is home to a 30-square-block area devoted exclusively to high-rise apartment buildings occupied largely by the black poor. Gutted by what was euphemistically called urban renewal, devoid of even the barest social amenities, Coney is hemmed in on three sides by water and on a fourth by the Russian ethnic enclave of Brighton Beach.
Coney Island is in New York, but not of it, a dismal shell of its former self, as distant from the city proper as is the island of Guam. In black Coney Island, as in the Chicago portrayed in the film "Hoop Dreams," basketball is the true and only religion. Deep in the projects, with their ill-kept grounds and urine-soaked hallways, the players have constructed an impeccably maintained basketball court, known as the Garden, a homage to Madison Square Garden in Manhattan, home of the New York Knicks. Mr. Frey writes, "Even the dealers and hoodlums refrain from vandalizing the Garden, because in Coney Island the possibility of transcendence through basketball -- in this case, an athletic scholarship to a four-year Division I college -- is an article of faith." Faith, unfortunately, is impervious to facts. And the facts shout out something to the contrary: Those players and families who worship at Coney Island's Garden have become akin to a cargo cult, praying for blessings -- college scholarships and professional basketball contracts -- that will never come.
A depressing scenario, without question. Yet "The Last Shot" is not, repeat not, just another story of Reporter Goes to Ghetto, Finds No Hope. Mr. Frey shows us levity and light in Coney Island's grimmest corners. His portraits of its young men and boys are warmly, even lovingly written. He cares for them and lets it show. He also reminds us that the basketball players are vulnerable, breakable -- and still children, despite the fact that they appear to us as giants.
AMONG Coney Island's best is Russell Thomas, a studious, hardworking player who studies every night for the S.A.T.'s and carries his vocabulary flash cards everywhere he goes. Despite his estimable powers as a player, Russell has the nervous constitution of an opera singer. When he thinks his scholarship is in jeopardy, he climbs to the top of Coney Island's highest building and threatens to jump. But Russell's poor education undoes him. He never wins the scholarship and is cast off to the junior college circuit.
Russell's teammate Corey Johnson is clearly whip- smart, and he showed as much in junior high school. In high school, though, he has deteriorated into the clown, as if ashamed of the brains he was born with.
The linchpin of Mr. Frey's narrative is Lincoln's tall, muscular center, Tchaka Shipp. In addition to having a body by Michelangelo, Tchaka is the first player in years to meet the college eligibility requirements in his junior year. With Tchaka we take some illuminating trips, among them the jaunt to the annual basketball camp sponsored by Nike, the giant sports- shoe company. Here the players (all of them black) are prodded, poked, weighed and in various ways scrutinized by the coaches (who are nearly all white). The similarity to a cattle auction is clearly apparent.
It is with Tchaka that we see the coaches at their most mendacious, as they romance him and make promises they'll never be able to keep. The reader wants to cheer when Tchaka, having none of it, looks right through them. Tchaka, by the way, is an abbreviation of an African name meaning "the king-child has come home."
THE most startling presence in this book, however, is the freshman Stephon Marbury, already a stellar player at 14. Stephon knows very little, except that he would like to go to Syracuse University "because at Syracuse, you play in front of 32,820 people every home game -- it's crazy-loud in there." How does a 14-year-old boy just out of eighth grade know numbers like that? Stephon is one of an alarming new caste: those for whom the chimerical quest for the Final Four and a pro basketball contract begins in junior high school.
Eighth and ninth graders now shop for high schools based on their knowledge of which ones will pass them along in their grades, give them the most playing time and the best chance to win a title, so that they can be recruited for college. Stephon confides to Mr. Frey that coaches from the Public School Athletic League have been recruiting him since fifth grade. Thus we see that the corruption and emphasis on sports above all else have bled from college down into elementary school. Mr. Frey writes that public school basketball teams are "now riddled with players crisscrossing the city to play on their favorite teams, others whose grades (and second-grade reading levels) should have rendered them ineligible, as well as 19- and 20-year-old kids who shouldn't even be in school."
If there were fewer obstructions, Stephon might be able to read the cautionary tale that is spelled out all around him. His oldest brother, Eric, played at the University of Georgia, failed to graduate and returned to Brooklyn to work on a construction crew. His next two brothers, Donnie and Norman, became Prop 48 casualties, were banished to the junior college circuit and have yet to graduate when Mr. Frey ends the book. The hazards, then, are abundantly clear. But how can Stephon see anything when his own father is trying to broker him to the scouts, and when college coaches aplenty hang all over him -- despite N.C.A.A. regulations to the contrary.
Like millions of others across the country, the Coney Island kids are often fatherless and broke, easy marks for college recruiters like the one from Fordham University who allegedly wrote to a recruit in dollar signs: "See how Fordham can change your life? . . . Health, Happine$$ and Hundred$." It is not the job of the colleges and the sporting goods companies to do what Abraham Lincoln High School is failing to do. But the door out of Coney Island might indeed open a crack if the colleges and Nike paid as much attention to math and science summer camps as they do to profiteering from the basketball myth.
THE cruelest irony of Coney Island's casualties? As Mr. Frey writes: "They stay in school -- though their school hardly keeps its end of the bargain. They say no to drugs -- though it's the only fully employed industry around. . . . But they operate in an environment that forgives none of the inevitable transgressions of adolescence and bestows few second chances.
"Which makes this process of playing for a scholarship not the black version of the American dream, as I had thought eight months earlier, but a cruel parody of it. In the classic parable you begin with nothing and slowly accrue your riches through hard work in a system designed to help those who help themselves. Here, at 17 years of age, you begin with nothing but one narrow, treacherous path and then run a gantlet of obstacles that merely reminds you of how little you have: recruiters pass themselves off as father figures, standardized tests humiliate you and reveal the wretchedness of your education, the promise of lucrative N.B.A. contracts reminds you of what it feels like to have nothing in this world."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tchaka Shipp, a graduate of Abraham Lincoln High School in Coney Island, playing for Seton Hall in 1993. (THE NEW YORK TIMES)(pg. 67)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
California Regulates Those Who Sell Travel

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
IN an effort to protect the California consumer, Gov. Pete Wilson has signed legislation designed to offer a safeguard against potential travel-related scams and bankruptcies. The law, which revises existing legislation, is widely expected to be used as a national model.
Travel scams cost consumers $12 billion a year, according to Federal Government estimates. 
 The revised California Travel Promoter Law, sponsored in the California Assembly by Jackie Speier of San Mateo, will take effect next January for a three-year trial period.
The law includes provisions for a $100 annual registration fee for anyone selling travel services in the state and a $225 one-time fee for California concerns to create a new consumer restitution fund.
The law will also apply to companies based outside California who are selling services in the state and have a business address there.
The fees will be used to create a $1.6 million fund managed by a nonprofit corporation.
In the event of bankruptcy, business failure or fraud, consumers who buy travel services from registered sellers in California will be able to apply to recover the amount they paid, up to a maximum of $15,000 a person.
In the future, travel agencies' advertising or promotional material will be required to print a registration number identifying them as contributors to the fund.
"We were looking for a way to protect the consumer and at the same time do something of benefit to the travel industry," said Patty Campbell, owner of All About Travel in Northridge, Calif., and a director of the California Coalition of Travel Organizations, which actively supported the legislation.
Recent economic hard times in California have also contributed to the risk to consumers who buy travel services there, Ms. Campbell said. "We had four continuous years of economic disaster, which was very hard -- even for established businesses," she said.
The demise in 1989 of Hemphill-Harris Travel in Encino is estimated to have cost California customers a total of $900,000 or more.
"This is a good first step," said Thipphavone Phabmixay Ark, alawyer at the West Coast office of Consumers Union in San Francisco, a consumer protection group. "It is likely to set a precedent for the nation, because travel agents have a huge presence in California."
Although most of the California travel industry supported the law, it is opposed by the Association of Retail Travel Agents, a national organization that supports smaller travel concerns. The association warns that the bill will create a bureaucracy that will be a burden on travel agents and scare off customers.
Because California has a vast economic impact on the rest of the nation, it is likely that the law will serve as a model for other states, according to travel-industry executives and state officials.
Only 10 states -- California, Florida, Hawaii, Iowa, Illinois, New York, Ohio, Oregon, Virginia and Washington -- impose even minimal legal requirements on the sale of travel.
Rhode Island is alone in requiring someone setting up as a travel agent to take an examination to obtain a state license.
Christopher Ames, a deputy attorney in the consumer law section of the California Justice Department, said he expected many states to adopt the registration provisions of the law, but that most would take a wait-and-see attitude toward the restitution provisions.
Travel fraud is widespread in the state, he said, although individual losses are usually not high. For example, his office is now prosecuting American Travel Incentives, a California company that for several years offered a travel certificate that promised a free trip to Hawaii. After a $19 phone call, consumers found out that they had not received a free trip, but only information on how much a trip would cost, according to Mr. Ames.
The California Travel Promoter Law revises a law, passed in 1971, that requiredthat travel promoters post bonds or maintain trust accounts to protect travelers until money for tickets was passed on to airlines or cruise lines.
But that law was considered vague in defining who was covered. In 1988 the California legislature tried to close the loopholes by passing a new law requiring travel promoters to register with the state attorney general's office, pay a $50 filing fee and disclose their trust or bond accounts.
The law was largely ineffecual, Ms. Campbell said, because the state chose not to enforce it uniformly until it became an issue with state travel agents last year.
Travel industry executives said they expected as many as 8,000 companies doing business in California to register initially. If the fund drops below $1.2 million travel agents can be assessed up to $200 a year to replenish it.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1846 words

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Battered but Unbowed, a Maestro Rebounds

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
HOW QUICKLY HAS Franz Welser-Most, a 34-year-old Austrian with a complicated personal history, risen to the top tier of international maestros?
A scant 10 years ago, he was the principal conductor of the Austrian Youth Orchestra, scarcely known outside his homeland. He has already announced his resignation in 1996 from his first position as music director of a major orchestra, the London Philharmonic. He takes up a similar post next season at the Zurich Opera, having conducted only 12 operas (at prestigious houses, to be sure). Perhaps most remarkable, Mr. Welser-Most, now in demand at leading American orchestras as well as the Berlin Philharmonic, the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, the Bavarian Radio Symphony and the Salzburg Festival, has yet to conduct several of the concert staples stockpiled by every budding maestro, like Dvorak's "New World" Symphony. 
 Not that he lacks initiative. He cut his conductorial teeth on blockbusters, leading his young charges in works of Bruckner and Mahler. With professional orchestras, he has championed wayside discoveries of his own, like Franz Schmidt's Fourth Symphony, which he brought to the New York Philharmonic a year ago, and the odd contemporary work. He returns to the Philharmonic on Thursday evening with Arvo Part's Third Symphony and works by Beethoven and Ravel.
As usual on his American visits, Mr. Welser-Most has cut a wide swath, with one-week stints at the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the St. Louis Symphony and the Philadelphia Orchestra. These and other American orchestras seem unable to get enough of him, and it is probably only a matter of time -- not much time, despite his relative inexperience and the cautionary precedent at the London Philharmonic -- before he is offered the music directorship of a major American orchestra. That suits him fine, though not just yet.
"America is my future," Mr. Welser-Most said recently in a V.I.P. lounge at Kennedy International Airport on his way from London to Los Angeles. "I really love coming here and working here. I feel so free, and I enjoy that enormously."
As one exercise of that freedom, he looked forward to Rollerblading in California despite a flare-up of a chronic back problem. His traveling companion, Angelika von Bennigsen, the ex-wife of his former manager and adoptive father, Baron Andreas von Bennigsen, wrapped a scarf around his neck to shield him against the draft.
He spoke with little apparent effort in idiomatic, colorful, British-accented English, replete with umlauts, and his forward, assured manner belied a previous onstage impression of an aw-schucks Woody Harrelson retreating in the face of a clamorous ovation at Avery Fisher Hall.
The St. Louis sojourn must have been especially interesting this time around. Mr. Welser-Most has been widely rumored to be a candidate to succeed Leonard Slatkin as music director of the St. Louis Symphony, which was the first American orchestra to present the young Austrian, in 1989.
"I think it's common knowledge that the orchestra was more than interested in me," Mr. Welser-Most said, treating the issue as dead. "I love St. Louis, and if Zurich hadn't come up, I would have considered it seriously. But for me, personally, opera was more important now."
Just how interested was (is?) the orchestra? Bruce Coppock, the executive director of the St. Louis Symphony, said: "The job hasn't been offered to anybody. It is common knowledge that we have a very special relationship with Franz. He has been here four or five times, and every time has been terrific. We look forward to many happy returns."
For lack of discretion, which is hardly a Welser-Most hallmark, hesitancy may be the better part of valor when it comes to taking on another orchestra soon. His four years with the London Philharmonic have grown nightmarish.
The orchestra has undergone a management transition in recent years, and the London orchestral world has quite simply been in turmoil. Mr. Welser-Most appears to have been something of a pawn at times in the London Philharmonic's successful bids, amid cutthroat competition, to establish a residency in the South Bank Center and to retain financing from the Arts Council of Great Britain. And he has taken a thrashing from the press.
"IT HAS BEEN HELL," HE SAID. "NO other conductor, I think, ever got such a rough ride in London." Although Giuseppe Sinopoli, as music director of the Philharmonia Orchestra (to stick to the present), might debate the latter, the point is well taken.
"London is absolutely a mine field today," said Nicholas Kenyon, whose responsibilities as controller of BBC Radio 3 include oversight of the BBC orchestras. "He was thrown into the middle of all these bloodthirsty Machiavellian politics completely untried and unknown. His difficulties bear no reflection on his artistic credibility."
Few would dispute Mr. Welser-Most's claim that "the basic problem is the system," though others might approach the problem on a different level.
"The system of the self-governing orchestra is in principle maybe a good one, but under these circumstances, it just doesn't work," he explained. "England has been in a heavy recession longer than any other Western country, and the market has really dried out. Especially in bad times, the system needs innovation and new ideas, and people are resistant to that.
"I wanted to give the orchestra more artistic challenges, playing a new piece once in a while, playing sinfonietta-type programs with 40 people involved, playing chamber music, playing an experimental series, all under an umbrella London Philharmonic, organizing and promoting it. And I didn't get anywhere with that. Our people just didn't want to do it. So I said: 'Sorry. You don't have to call me music director if I just conduct some concerts.' "
Hugh Canning, a critic of The Sunday Times of London and one of Mr. Welser-Most's fiercest antagonists, agrees with him about the system, though not in a manner calculated to warm his heart.
"Of course the system is at fault," Mr. Canning said. "He would never have been offered the job if it were not. This is what you get when the funding is totally inadequate, and no major conductor is willing to become a music director in London. Rehearsal conditions are not right. The players are tired. It's compromise all the way."
In fact, Mr. Canning said, all that most London music directors seem to do nowadays is conduct some concerts, and not many of them. "I wonder when London orchestras will come clean and have no music directors at all," he added.
Christopher Lawrence, the manager of the London Philharmonic, rises spiritedly to Mr. Welser-Most's defense. "He came at a difficult time and met tremendous pressures extremely well," Mr. Lawrence said. "The problem is not the self-governing orchestra. It's true that with the shareholders on the premises every day, there is constant scrutiny, and shareholders are innately conservative. But the system of self-government gives a flexibility, resiliency and instinctive commitment that has allowed the orchestras to survive. The fundamental flaw is the structure of the orchestras, which have no permanent financial base. We are always living on the edge."
No wonder Mr. Welser-Most's glasses turn rosy as he contemplates life beyond London. "The Zurich Opera is like Paradise," he said. "The director of that house," he added, with reference to Jurg Keller, "is a maniac, but a wonderful maniac. He's 150 percent committed."
His new base of operations will be closer to his home in Liechtenstein and to land he recently purchased near Salzburg. "I'm still very strongly rooted in Austria," he said. "That's where my heart is."
He was born in Linz, in 1960, the "youngest" of five surviving children, he said instinctively. "Not quite," he corrected. "I've got a twin sister 10 minutes younger."
He also had a sister four years younger, who died in infancy, badly handicapped. In her memory, he has taken up sponsorship of a home for the handicapped in Linz that is saddled not only with financial difficulties but also with an infamous past; during the last two years of the Third Reich, it became an extermination camp for handicapped people from 100 miles around. Even now, Mr. Welser-Most said, with "the mood going more to the right wing," sentiment is widespread in the region that such people do not deserve to live, and he received a death threat last year at the Salzburg Festival because of his advocacy.
He comes by his political and social convictions rightly, since his mother, having studied agriculture and raised the family, sat in the Austrian Parliament. His father was a doctor, and he describes his upbringing as conservative Catholic and not particularly musical.
Like his siblings, he took up an instrument in school: in his case, violin. He was bitten by the conducting bug at 16, when he led the school orchestra, and his future course was sealed by an automobile accident two years later that left him with broken vertebrae and permanently "sleepy" fingers on his left hand.
THE REST IS A VERY brief history that includes positions in Winterthur, Switzerland, and Norrkoping, Sweden, and performances at the Vienna State Opera, the Deutsche Oper in Berlin and Covent Garden. Baron von Bennigsen heard him conduct, took him under his managerial wing and eventually adopted him legally, though his parents were (and are) still alive. The conductor has since parted ways with the baron professionally and personally, though he continues to travel under the name Franz von Bennigsen.
He declines to discuss his relationship with Angelika von Bennigsen. "There has to be some private life," he said, reasonably enough.
Even Mr. Welser-Most's harshest critics concede that he is a gifted musician and that if his performances are uneven, the dispiriting circumstances of recent years may be a factor. Through it all, he has retained great favor with EMI Classics and, according to Mr. Lawrence of the London Philharmonic, with English listeners. "He has an instinctive and wonderful ability to communicate to audiences," Mr. Lawrence added.
St. Louis players report, Mr. Coppock said, that "he puts them in touch with the spirituality of the music."
At his best, as in a superbly supple performance of Brahms's Second Symphony with the London Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall two years ago, Mr. Welser-Most achieves an almost Furtwanglerian flexibility and spontaneity, a sense of creating the music on the spot. Not surprisingly, he prefers the word "re-creation" (though he more often terms it "reproduction") to "interpretation."
"You can't interpret marriage," he said. "You have to live it. And if you just say, 'I loved you yesterday, and that's exactly the way I feel today,' oh, boy! Music is very much connected to life. It has to happen at the moment you do it. If you just try to do it again, it's like warming up food -- although some food actually gets better when you warm it up."
Most music, he did not have to add, does not.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 48; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1432 words

HEADLINE: DESIGN VIEW;
More Than One Way to See Art

BYLINE: By Joseph Giovannini; Joseph Giovannini is a New York architectural designer and critic.

 BODY:
FOR MUCH OF THIS CENTURY, there has been one way of looking at contemporary art, and that is the way the Museum of Modern Art does it -- on right-angled white walls in evenly lighted, shadowless spaces within a highly controlled sequence of rooms. Painters have long supported the neutrality that the Modern represents: in the 1950's a score of prominent artists complained to the Guggenheim Museum that the sloping walls and curved ramps of Frank Lloyd Wright's spinning rotunda would fail to provide "the rectilinear frame of reference necessary for the adequate visual contemplation of works of art." Wright's design, which is indeed inhospitable to some kinds of art but glorious for others, continues to fuel the deep suspicion many artists harbor toward architects.
But a growing number of architects are resisting what they regard as restrictive spaces that limit viewers to a single position in front of an object. One architect weary of what he calls the missionary position is Wolfgang Prix, who has designed -- among many other art projects -- studios for Anselm Kiefer, a painter who climbs ladders, lies prone and stands on his head to "test" his compositions. Two weeks ago, when Queen Beatrix opened the Groninger Museum of Art in Groningen, the Netherlands, Mr. Prix, its designer, led her on catwalks through a turbulent landscape of tilted and angled walls that afford more than one way to see a painting. 
 The stroll with the Queen was a departure for an architect who used to stroll down the streets of his native Vienna in the late 60's inside room-size balloons during urban happenings -- and for one whose work descends from that of Kurt Schwitters and from the insolent gallery installations of Marcel Duchamp.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Prix, a member of the firm Coop Himmelblau, with offices in Los Angeles and Vienna, is an admirer of the Guggenheim -- for its constantly changing vistas and different vantage points, "not only at eye level but from below and above and in between."
"The Modern is an obedient nonstatement," he said, "and the Guggenheim is a disobedient work of art."
The Modern's plain white, evenly illuminated spaces, designed by Philip Goodwin and Edward Durrell Stone in the tradition of the gallery as a white cube, represent a Newtonian universe of objects floating in empty space. Indeed the cool, clean, somewhat clinical galleries are distantly related to laboratories designed for the study of specimens and artifacts. The neutrality is intentional; the art enjoys a detached, antiseptic relationship to the architecture.
If the Modern's design takes the side of the object, the Guggenheim sides with the subjective perception of the viewer. Wright's rotunda, with its hypnotic vortex and curved walls, anticipated Robert Irwin's realization in the 1970's that light and space are media in which even small shifts change the perception of a painting. In the Guggenheim, the universe around a painting is warm, not cold.
Mr. Prix designed the Groninger Museum at the same time that he was working on an installation for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Last winter, in a brilliant match of designer to subject matter, he produced a "dancing landscape" of curved, broken, tilted, floating and shifted columns and planes for the show "Expressionist Utopias."
Works of art hung not on walls but on panels made of steel, ribbed acrylic and concrete board, which leaned against the walls or stood free, creating an agitated Expressionist landscape. Shifting angles of vision caused unexpected juxtapositions. "If the art is good and the architecture is good, it's a most beautiful discussion -- an energy field," said Mr. Prix, "as in the Renaissance when artists and architects worked together without sacrificing their ideas."
Mr. Prix is not alone in deneutralizing museum spaces. At the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, the New York architect James Ingo Freed devised a shadowy, harsh and sometimes confining environment of brick and steel that evokes the banality of Nazi evil and conditions viewers for the exhibits.
To house three 13th-century religious frescoes in Houston, another New York architect, Francois de Menil, designed an entire structure in frosted glass that will be the ghost of the original masonry chapel in Cyprus for which the art was conceived. When lighted, the glass will glow, establishing a context of spirituality conspicuously absent even in museums that display religious art.
Last winter, in the classicized galleries of the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal, the New York architect Peter Eisenman designed an installation for an exhibition of his own work, with a wall-to-wall, floor-to-ceiling landscape of heaving and subsiding walls. The installation surrounded viewers, forming an active rather than a passive space. Architectural ideas were presented in drawings and models shown in pockets and shelves of the dislocated walls. By embodying the ideas in the models, the installation reversed the usual relationship of the container and the contained, the viewer and the viewed.
Mr. Eisenman's installation was controversial in Canada, and his design has been even more so at the Wexner Center for the Arts at Ohio State University, his exhibition hall for art of the 21st century. He based his scheme on two conflicting surveyor's grids, creating an unsettling space of crossed floor and ceiling patterns and inclined facades that whisper strange nothings to the inner ear: the design incorporated principles of uncertainty that underlie Mr. Eisenman's philosophy.
Curators who have worked in the space report that conventional paintings do not hang there easily or well. But the center has been especially successful as a petri dish for new art. Its ideas and forms have raised the cultural temperature in Columbus, helping provoke such shows as the current "House Rules" (on view through Dec. 11), about rethinking the suburban house for a multicultural society.
"Once you realize that space is not neutral, it's liberating," said Thomas Krens, director of the Guggenheim. While acknowledging that Wright's rotunda does not suit all art, Mr. Krens has turned its character to advantage by asking artists, including Dan Flavin, Lothar Baumgarten, Mario Merz and Rebecca Horn, to create site-specific works.
When Mr. Krens was director of the museum at Williams College, he was predisposed to the idea of the white box. He was convinced by the architect Charles Moore, however, while working on an extension, that varying the volume and height of space enriched the experience of viewing art. Unpredictable changes from space to space proved more engaging than a chain of white rooms.
MR. KRENS ALSO concluded that the object was not as objective as the white box led the eye and mind to believe. By the time he became director of the Guggenheim, he was an advocate of what he called variable space. "You can have a variety of experience and interpretations with the same object," he said, "because the experience of the architecture is qualitatively different."
In the Guggenheim's ambitious building programs in Austria and Spain, spatial variety has been an underlying principle of designs done by Han Hollein, an Austrian architect, and the American Frank Gehry. The same Kandinsky traveling between Guggenheims, and even within a single Guggenheim, will be experienced in several different environments.
If the Modern's galleries have helped spread the notion of the white cube through the art world, reactions to it have recently rebounded on the Modern. Last spring, its department of architecture and design staged a small show of the work of the New York architect Bernard Tschumi in a remarkably forlorn gallery. Mr. Tschumi, the dean of architecture at Columbia University, designed the installation, suspending several building models on wires in midair at chaotic angles so that their flutter activated the gallery's space, as if it were a medium rather than a vacuum.
In an otherwise darkened area, he purposely illuminated the models and drawings unevenly, to create light, dark and penumbra: the exhibits occupied the space of the viewers, surrounding them in a setting that dissolved the museum's own spaces. The means for transforming and defamiliarizing the gallery were much more economical than Mr. Eisenman's at the Canadian Center for Architecture -- simply a matter of dimmers, spotlights and hardware. But the installation proved an unexpected, even a subversive and subjective, object lesson suggesting other ways to see.

HEADLINE: THE $500 WEEKEND;
At Play in Old Miami Beach

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER; MELINDA HENNEBERGER is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times.

 BODY:
(The budgets for the $500 weekends covered accommodations, sightseeing, food and drink, but not the cost of transportation to and from the cities.)
THERE is nothing subtle about the charms of Old Miami Beach, and nothing particularly authentic. Imported palm trees and trucked-in sand line the shore just opposite the blocks and blocks of pastel Art Deco hotels and outdoor cafes that are packed, in the middle of the afternoon, with people drinking liquor and smoking up a storm, listening to piped-in Edith Piaf and Nat (King) Cole. 
 Minutes after our 3 P.M. Friday arrival, my friend Laura and I are being handed menus, at the News Cafe on Ocean Drive in South Beach, with pictures and little bios of film stars from the 30's and 40's. We get Bette Davis and Gloria Swanson. Because of this $500 budget business, which later becomes a nuisance, landing us in a Denny's for the $1.99 Grand Slam breakfast, we order only what we really want: some brie and saga blue, tomatoes and wine ($35.20). There is a sea breeze, and Ella is singing, "Every time we say goodbye." What a sucker I am. This must be heaven.
Just over a decade ago most of this area was run down and ruined, abandoned by the high rollers who hung out here from the 20's until World War II, when South Beach began to fade. Along the boardwalk, farther up the beach, some of the larger hotels, which peaked later, in the 60's, are still unimproved. And their huge empty pools throw the rest of this wonderful, gaudy display into relief, adding a nice note of melancholy.
After lunch, we walk back to our hotel, the Park Central, 640 Ocean Drive, (305) 538-1611, a six-story Art Deco treasure designed by Henry Hohauser in 1937, with porthole windows over the entrance and wide terrazzo floors in the lobby. Our clean, white oceanfront room has high ceilings, the requisite pink and black tile in the bathroom, and funny old photos of girls in modest bathing costumes mugging in front of a sign that outlaws nude swimming. There is fresh fruit on a table by the window, and a room service menu that promises breakfast served until 2:30 P.M. Even if we never actually order at that hour, it's sort of thrilling to know we can.
The accommodations, at $125 a night plus tax, account for more than half of our budget. But numbed by New York rents, I figure this seems about right.
Even though the local people say that fall is in the air, with the temperature dipping into the 80's and palm fronds turning yellow, it's still warm enough for a swim before the light goes, and we head for the ocean across the street at about the same time that the crowd we saw earlier begins to clear.
The wide, white beach is just as Mac, my favorite baby sitter, described it to me 30 years ago. She had a son living here then, and used to tell great stories about this exotic, glamorous place where the flowers were always in bloom and anything could happen. One New Year's Eve, she dressed up in something sparkly -- gold lame, I think -- and brought my brother, sister and me party hats and horns and a carton of Cokes so we wouldn't be sorry we were missing the adult parties. We made a resolution that year to take the bus here together someday and see the Orange Bowl parade.
But the only other time I was here, on assignment, I never saw the ocean, ate in my room and fell asleep watching pay TV, running up charges for multiple viewings of "Dangerous Liaisons." So this is my first real visit. The water is very warm, and we swim back and forth along the coast, watching the cruise ships head out to sea, until the late-day showers begin. By that time it's getting dark, and in this decadent place a nap seems just the thing. Economical, too. When we finally venture out, a lounge singer in the lobby is doing "I'm Beginning to See the Light," acting out the lyrics with goofy hand motions, and we just can't leave. All around the bar there are more pictures of movie stars -- Kate Hepburn in gingham, Burt Reynolds, Elizabeth Taylor in her turban phase, Burt Reynolds.
THE bartender explains that Burt is a part-owner. Or, more precisely, part owner of the bar and restaurant in the lobby. "He's made a lot of bad investments and doesn't really have much money," our barman confides. I don't know how much this guy knows about his boss's bank account, but Laura is moved and orders a budget-busting Tanqueray martini for $7.50, so that poor little Quinton, son of Burt, can go to college. There goes the price of dinner, so we load up on pretzels and feel like Connie Francis and Paula Prentiss ordering tea without the tea bag to stretch their vacation dollars in "Where the Boys Are." We wind up dropping $36.80.
Then we walk up Ocean Drive, where every club seems to offer live music and fusion jazz is fusing with the sound of a samba. The sidewalks are jammed, and surely the world's largest convention of classic convertible owners is cruising past the fountains, backlighted glass brick and neon.
Two blocks over, on Washington Avenue, there are several nightclubs, including the Warsaw, where the sign says, "This is a gay nightclub," and the Glam Slam, No. 1235, (305) 672-2770, a new place owned by the artist formerly known as Prince. Admission is $10 but they let me in for a quick look around. Once Al Capone's nightclub, the building was designed in 1936 and the original chandelier and magnificent sweeping staircase are still in place. Almost as impressive is the bathroom, where a dressing table overflows with makeup, mouthwash, Mylanta, perfume, deodorant and even contact lens solution. When the main floor opens at 12:30 A.M., there is a brief dance show, and real fake fog. Just before leaving, I get a fashion tip from one of the regulars, which perhaps I should pass on. "You need to change your attire," he said. "This is Miami. Get into silk."
Out on the street, several men with pythons wrapped around their necks are making a living charging tourists $5 to be photographed wearing their reptiles, one of which looks like a giant squash. "It can eat a baby," one of the owners says.
A homeless man standing by a pay phone approaches us, not for money, but to ask if we would be so kind as to ask the directory assistance operator for the number of his favorite radio station, and then remember it for him. He's thrilled when we comply, and yells, "I'm on the air, baby!" We spring for a Diet Coke and head back to the hotel, where we find grapes on the nightstand.
I start a mystery by Edna Buchanan, the Pulitzer Prize-winning former Miami Herald police reporter, in which a beautiful, brilliant and blond Cuban reporter named Britt is investigating a murder, lecturing her editor, and carrying on with her source, a hunky cop. Uh-huh. The next thing I know, my roommate, in her early morning Susan Powter mode, is rousing me for a run on the beach. This turns out to be unnecessary, since we spend the rest of the day walking, having economized by forgoing a rental car.
First we join the 90-minute Art Deco District walking tour led by members of the Miami Design Preservation League, which begins every Saturday morning at 10:30 at 1001 Ocean Drive. Our guide, Barry Zaid, tells us how a tiny band of preservationists saved the area from developers, and continues to fight those hoteliers whose buildings are painted in bold shades, like turquoise and tangerine, that would never have been used by the original designers.
"But in Miami Beach, nothing is very pure, none of this is authentic," he says. "So who's to say?"
According to Mr. Zaid, these some 800 Art Deco buildings, with their angular, geometric lines, which went up during the 20's, 30's and 40's, survived chiefly because they were so unfashionable for so long that they weren't worth tearing down.
He does not mention that the preservationists got a lot of help from the 80's TV show "Miami Vice," which brought the beautiful people flocking to an upscale South Beach that had to be rushed into existence.
We begin and end the tour near Gianni Versace's place on Ocean Drive, then stop for lunch at Larios on the Beach, 820 South Ocean Boulevard, (305) 532-9577, which the singer Gloria Estefan owns. I go with black bean soup and plantain chips, and Laura has what she hails as "one subtle tamale" ($32.77).
We spend the rest of the afternoon continuing the walking tour on our own, and then, come evening, head to the Lincoln Road Mall, a pedestrian enclave carved out of mangrove swamps, for one of the periodic Lincoln Road Home Furnishings Walks. All along this surprisingly vibrant walking street, art galleries and stores that specialize in Deco furniture, vintage posters and collectibles have stayed open late, offering coffee, cookies, and in one case, vodka shots, to the artsy, mostly hometown crowd drifting from one store to another. We admire a $4,500 Deco dining table at P.M. Studio (741 Lincoln Road) and a $3,300 upholstered sleigh bed dubbed "The Harlow Bed," at Nu-D-Zine (1006 Lincoln Road).
But before long we are more than ready for the major meal of this excursion. Several people have told us we should not miss Joe's Stone Crab, at 227 Biscayne Street, (305) 673-0365, and we take a cab there. Hang the ($6) price!
Outside the restaurant and all down the block hungry people are waiting. The doorway is blocked, and someone on a loudspeaker is ordering exiting diners to step lively. The parking attendant says the wait is somewhere between two and three hours. We laugh and walk a few blocks to the Century, another Deco hotel by Hohauser, at 140 Ocean Drive, (305) 674-8855, where the lobby is filled with decorative sheet metal furniture by Ron Arad.
In the adjoining garden restaurant, illuminated by candles, there is no wait, and a meal that would have been worth one: corn chowder, warm greens with hazelnuts and goat cheese and two fettucines, along with a bottle of Washington State fume blanc and coffee. Believe-it-or-not total: $60.
Still, we are heading into Sunday with just about $30. Thus the Denny's breakfast and a city bus ride to the waterside development called Bayside. We just can't leave without taking the hokey cruise of "Millionaire's Row" ($10 apiece), and are soon passing properties owned by Ms. Estefan, Julio Iglesias, Vanilla Ice and, of course, Thomas Kramer. Thomas Kramer?
"Ladies, he's single, 33, a billionaire and we have his number!" shouts our captain. Most of the women onboard are middle-aged tourists here with their husbands from the Caribbean or South America, and they are not exactly jumping overboard. We see the house that Madonna looked at before buying elsewhere in Miami, and the building where Melanie Griffith and Don Johnson used to stay.
Then a last, lingering look at the house where "The Specialist" was filmed, and it's time to go. We are $8.41 over budget; I knew we should have skipped Denny's.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

HOLLAR'S ETCHINGS
 The first great etchings produced in England were made by a Bohemian from Prague named Wenceslaus Hollar (1607-1677), who had been brought to London by the Earl of Arundel in 1636. A comprehensive exhibition of his work, the first such display in America, opens at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven on Wednesday, remaining through Jan. 22.
A free symposium is scheduled on Saturday with English and American scholars and experts appearing at the museum, 1080 Chapel Street, from 10:30 to 4:30. 
 Forty watercolors and 219 prints have been assembled from the British Museum and the Yale Center for British Art by Richard Godfrey, an authority on the subject at Sotheby's in London. They include views of Germany, Antwerp and London, and some large watercolors depicting the British colony at Tangier. Also featured are some works by Hollar's contemporaries: Rembrandt and Van Dyck.
Mr. Godfrey will lead off the program on Saturday with a talk on "An Artist in Search of a Market: Hollar's Early Years in England." Christopher White, a professor of art history at Oxford and director of its Ashmolean Museum, will address "The Iconography of the Earl of Arundel" and a talk on "The Culture of the Early Modern Metropolis" will be given by Lawrence Manley, a professor of English at Yale.
Following a lunch break, there will be "Hollar and the English Revolution" by David Underdown, professor of history at Yale; "Hollar's Graphic Art and the Culture of Curiosity" by Celeste Brusati, associate professor of the history of art at the University of Michigan, and "The Antiquarian Endeavor in the 17th Century" by Graham Parry, reader in English at the University of York. 
Visiting hours for the exhibition are Tuesday through Saturday from 10 to 5 and Sunday from noon to 5. Admission is free. The number for more information is 432-2850.
 
ARTISANS IN WESTPORT
 When the first Creative Arts Festival of the Westport Young Women's League was held in 1976, about 65 artisans set up their displays in the junior high school cafeteria and admission was 50 cents.
This year's two-day edition, on Saturday and Sunday from 10 to 5, will feature the work of 145 craftspeople from around the country, be held at Staples High School and cost $6 for adults, $3 for people 65 and older and nothing for children under 12. A breakfast preview on Saturday from 8:30 to 10 A.M. is also available at $12 for adults and $9 for older people.
In recent years the festival has drawn more than 10,000 people annually. Pottery, quilts, jewelry, toys, leather goods, dolls, food, clothing, textiles, furniture and holiday decorations are for sale.
Proceeds are distributed to the more than 50 organizations that the league helps support, in the arts, education, human services, and programs for children and the elderly. To reach the high school take Exit 18 off I-95 or Exit 42 off the Merritt Parkway and follow the signs. For more information, the number is 222-1388.
 
SLAVERY IN GREENWICH
 "Chains Unbound: Slave Emancipations in Greenwich, Conn." is the title of a book to be published early in December by Gateway Press of Baltimore. Its author, Jeffrey B. Mead, will be discussing the work on Monday at 7:30 P.M. in the Greenwich Arts Center, 299 Greenwich Avenue. Mr. Mead is a 12th-generation descendant of one of the founders of the Town of Greenwich. He is a local historian and a member of the Connecticut Society of Genealogists and the New England Historic Genealogic Society.
While slavery was not widespread in what is now Fairfield County, its existence in Greenwich was prevalent enough to arouse Mr. Mead's curiosity. To investigate the period of abolition, from 1776 through 1838, He relied on Town Hall probate records, deeds and texts of the time. Admission to the lecture will be $10, or $8 for students.
 
ON THE MIDDLE EAST
 Each year the Program in Judaic Studies and Middle Eastern Affairs at the University of Connecticut's Stamford branch holds a public conference and this year's program comes at an especially significant point in that region's stormy history.
The conference topic is "The New Middle East: Opportunities and Risks in an Era of Peace," scheduled today from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. on the Scofieldtown Road campus. Admission is $45 and includes lunch.
The first speaker will be Dr. Mary-Jane Deeb, the Egyptian-born director of the Omani Program at American University. She is also an author and television commentator. Her subject is "The Arab World and the Peace Process: Dissent and Support."
Dr. Howard Rosen, a former economist for the Bank of Israel and the United States Department of Labor will talk about "The Economics of Peace: Interaction between the Israeli and Arab Economies;" and Dr. Bernard Reich, professor of political science and international affairs at George Washington University, will address "Peace from the Israeli Perspective: Benefits and Risks."
The final hour, from 2 to 3 P.M., will be devoted to a discussion among the three speakers, moderated by Dr. Abraham Aschkenasy, a former senior lecturer at Tel-Aviv and Hebrew Universities in Jerusalem. Subjects will include international terrorism, economic reconstruction, Islamic fundamentalism and politics, the status of women and family planning. For more information, the numbers are 322-6336 or 322-3466.
 
TABLE SUGGESTIONS
 With the holidays coming, people who entertain at home will welcome the tips they can pick up at the Ridgefield Community Center's Women's Committee exhibition, "Creative Table Settings: A Table for All Seaons." The show contains more than 40 inspired table settings, seminars on all kinds of entertaining, and boutiques offering decorations and knick-knacks.
It will take place Thursday through Saturday from 10 to 4 at Lounsbury House, the 19th century Georgian Revival headquarters of the Community Center at 316 Main Street. Tickets, at $7, or $5 for older adults, will be good on all three days.
Among the exhibitors are Ruth Henderson, co-proprietor, with her husband, Skitch Henderson, of The Silo in New Milford; Ira Joe Fisher, the NBC weatherman and poetry buff; Tonya Walker, known as Alex Olanov on the TV soap, "One Life to Live;" Lisa Nichols, whose sweater designs are sold under the Marisa Christina label, and a number of shops and antique dealers including Yellow Monkey Village, Keeler Tavern, the Pottery Barn, and Paper Connection. The number for more information is 438-4657.
 
TALL (AND SMALL) TALES
 The time for telling tales tall, small and in between has arrived again, as storytellers around the country prepare to gather on Saturday for the annual "Tellebration: Night of Storytelling."
One location for the Connecticut Storytelling Center's observance will be the Unitarian Church at 10 Lyons Plain Road in Westport, starting at 8 P.M. Tom Callinan, Ann Shapiro and Connie Rockman will be among the local taletellers, joined by Diane Crehan, who specializes in Irish yarns; Josephine Fulcher-Anderson with African-American stories, and Lot Therrio with ballads of the American South. Admission will be $8 at the door, or call 227-5986 or 972-3731 for reservations or more information.
 
BRUCE BAZAAR
 The Bruce Museum in Greenwich, recently renovated, will reopen its seasonal International Bazaar, but for only four days, from Thursday through Sunday. Merchandise has been separated by point of origin -- England, Russia, South America, Morocco, India, Mexico, Guatemala and the Orient -- and displayed in a "Street of Shops."
Items available include glass ornaments, Russian nesting dolls, silver, porcelain, amber jewelry from the Baltic, silver cuffs from Israel, toys, cookbooks, handmade quilts and baby clothes, hooked rugs and needlepoint. Prices start at $5 and go up to the hundreds. Hours are 10 to 5 on Thursday through Saturday, 2 to 5 on Sunday, and museum admission is $3.50 for adults, $2.50 for older people and children 5 to 12. There is no charge for visitors to the bazaar in the museum's store. For more information call 869-0376. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Seeking A Solution To the Key
 
Q Years ago, for security reasons, our co-op installed on the front door an expensive lock whose keys supposedly cannot be duplicated without a "key card" that is held by the board president. In an effort to control access to the building, we voted on a policy of one key per adult per unit, and one extra key per unit for emergencies. 
 Recently, one of our tenants wanted four permanent extra keys. When the board refused, he found a locksmith to make the keys illegally. What is our legal recourse in a situation like this? Can we get those keys from this tenant, and is there any way to prevent this from happening again? . . . Lisa Ramaci, Manhattan.
 
A There is no standard provision in the usual co-op documents prohibiting reproduction of keys, said Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives. "So unless the policy you adopted was expressed as an amendment to the proprietary lease or the house rules, or was contained in a written agreement that each shareholder signed, there is probably nothing you can do," Mr. Weinstein said.
If however, the policy was properly adopted, "the violation described would be a breach of the proprietary lease, which you can enforce by sending the shareholder a default notice," he said. "Unless he cures the default notice by returning the keys, you may then terminate the proprietary lease. The shareholder's equity in his apartment would be in jeopardy."
If the policy was not properly adopted, Mr. Weinstein said, the co-op board "should consider locking the barn door by amending the house rules to include the key policy, so that if you change keys in the future you will have an enforceable remedy against this abuse."
 
Right to Take In Other Tenants
 
Q In a rent-stabilized apartment, does the tenant have the right to take in other tenants or children, including welfare recipients, without the landlord's approval?
Would this fall in the category of a business being conducted in the apartment without permission? If so, would it be in violation of the lease? . . . M. Napolitano, Brooklyn.
 
A The answer in this specific case is uncertain, because it all depends on the individual lease, said Lou Ganim, a spokesman for the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which oversees rent administration in the city.
"But the bottom line is that the tenant may have the right to take someone into their apartment and even charge them rent," Mr. Ganim said.
"If it's a sublet of the apartment, of course they would have to go to the landlord first," he said. But if the tenant who holds the lease remains in the apartment, the terms of the lease govern the situation. "And subject to any lawful clause in the lease that might exist regarding occupancy or that might limit the right to take in unrelated guests, the tenant may have the right to do so."

LENGTH: 570 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Strength Denies Cuomo A Close Finish;
Suburbs Give Pataki Bounce

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
VOTERS in the New York City suburbs played a pivotal role in George E. Pataki's victory last week, sending him to the Executive Mansion with a margin of victory that far exceeded his statewide performance.
Interviews with 379 voters leaving polling places on Long Island and in the seven counties immediately north of New York City indicated that 60 percent voted for Mr. Pataki, compared to 38 percent for Mario M. Cuomo, whose 12 years in Albany came to an abrupt end. 
 Statewide, the race was much closer. With 99 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Pataki, a State Senator from Putnam County, had 48 percent of the vote. Mr. Cuomo, a longtime Queens resident, had 45 percent.
In New York City, exit surveys showed that Mr. Cuomo drew 70 percent of the vote, compared to 28 percent for Mr. Pataki. The suburban survey was part of a larger exit poll of the whole state conducted by the Voter News Service, a consortium of ABC News, CBS News, NBC News and CNN and The Associated Press. In addition to Nassau and Suffolk Counties, it represented voters in Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Dutchess, Orange, Sullivan and Ulster Counties.
Mr. Pataki owed his strong showing in those counties to a confluence of factors, not the least of which is the solid Republican base outside New York City. But some Pataki voters in the suburbs also said they supported his advocacy of tax cuts and the death penalty, felt that the economy was slumping and disapproved of President Clinton's performance.
When asked about the economy, 9 out of 10 of Mr. Pataki's suburban voters described it as not good or poor. One of 4 of Cuomo voters said they thought that the economy was good. Nearly 1 out of 2 Pataki voters said they felt that the family financial situation was in worse shape than it was two years ago.
Asked what form of punishment they favored for people convicted of first-degree murder, 4 out of 5 Pataki voters said they supported the death penalty. Fewer than 2 in 10 said they advocated life in prison without parole. Mr. Cuomo has vetoed every death-penalty bill that the Legislature sent to him, but Mr. Pataki promised in the campaign to sign such a measure.
Asked to identify the one or two issues that mattered most to them, the Cuomo and Pataki voters in the suburbs diverged sharply. More often than not Mr. Pataki's supporters cited the death penalty, government spending and taxes. Mr. Cuomo's backers mentioned his personal qualifications and experience. One out of 5 Pataki voters said it was simply "time for a change."
It was clear that the troubles of Mr. Clinton, who campaigned hard for Mr. Cuomo, loomed large in the minds of suburban voters. Three out of 4 Pataki voters said they disapproved of the way that Mr. Clinton was "handling his job as President."
Fewer than 1 out of 3 Cuomo supporters said they were unhappy with Mr. the President. Three out of 4 Cuomo voters said they voted for Mr. Clinton in 1992, and half the Pataki supporters said they had voted to re-elect President Bush. Nearly 1 out of 5 Pataki voters said they had supported Ross Perot's candidacy.
Each candidate received about half his support in the suburbs from voters whose total family income ranged from $30,000 to $75,000 a year. While Mr. Pataki attracted more voters whose incomes fell below $30,000 a year, Mr. Cuomo attracted more votes among those whose incomes exceeded $100,000.
