HEADLINE: In America;
A Simple Case of Fraud

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The beauty of Ronald Reagan, Newt Gingrich and so many other Republicans is that they make it all sound so simple.
If the Republicans can reduce taxes, increase defense spending, balance the budget, get people off welfare, reconstitute the American family and accelerate the current reduction in crime -- if they can do all that -- they deserve to be in power. God bless them. They should be running the world. 
 But if you walk the streets of urban America, where the punishing effects of the Reagan-Bush years are most stark, you will be overwhelmed by the evidence that the Republicans cannot do what they are promising. America's cities are the encampments for the most seriously sick and wounded of the last Republican revolution -- the Reagan revolution.
On Thursday, an unemployed plumber's assistant who lives in a doorway in the East New York section of Brooklyn said bitterly: "I don't care who won the election. They can't do no worse to us."
He was wrong. The Democrats were no prize, but the Republican Party is approximately as friendly to the cities as the Visigoths were to Rome. When the next Congress is sworn in the Republicans will resume their war on urban America with a vengeance, targeting especially the elderly, the poor and the very young.
"You will see that this will be a dark time for the cities," said a high-ranking national Democrat, who asked not to be identified. "The Reagan Administration launched a vicious attack on urban programs. Most programs were eliminated, or downsized to the point where they became totally ineffective. Politically, the Republicans have no motivation to solve urban America's problems. They have no constituency there. For the Republicans, the urban scene is the embodiment of all that is wrong with America."
But it is not just the cities that face serious trouble. The G.O.P. message, so simple and attractive, is a fraud. Mr. Gingrich is grinning like the Cheshire cat because he's put one over on the country. Complex problems like underemployment, the budget deficit, inadequate health care and crime will not yield to simple-minded solutions. Many of the voters who joined in Tuesday's orgiastic backlash against Bill Clinton are going to find that they cast their ballots against their own interests.
What the Republicans are good at is siphoning money from the lower and middle classes and funneling it to the wealthy. In the introduction to his book, "The Politics of Rich and Poor," Kevin Phillips wrote, "Despite the armies of homeless sleeping on grates, political leaders -- even those who professed to care about the homeless -- had little to say about the Republican Party's historical role, which has been not simply to revitalize U.S. capitalism but to tilt power, policy, wealth and income toward the richest portions of the population."
That was in 1990. Here we go again. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, who will likely become chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, wants to abolish the Federal income tax, replacing it with something more regressive, like a national sales tax. This would be an incredible boon to the rich, and would hurt virtually everybody else by making all consumer goods much more expensive.
Mr. Archer has also expressed his disdain for the whole idea of universal health coverage, which he derides as "socialized medicine."
Meanwhile, Mr. Gingrich is gleefully readying his plans for tax cuts for the rich and service cuts for the poor.
You can't blame the Republicans. Why should they change the bait when the fish keep biting? But what about the Democrats? What do they do now?
The first thing they should do is stop pretending to be Republicans. The Democrats were so busy running away from their President, their party and their traditional supporters that they never were able to benefit from the successes of the last two years.
The Republicans had a simple-minded message, but the Democrats had no message at all. Throughout the country Democratic candidates pointed to Bill Clinton and said, "We're not with him," and they pointed to traditional Democratic voters and said, "We're not with them."
It's hard for politicians to win when they are ashamed of their base. It may be that the voters who spoke loudest on Tuesday were the voters who stayed home.

HEADLINE: Income and Marriage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "When a Woman Earns Like a Man" (The Week in Review, Nov. 6): According to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, women's earnings have risen to 77 percent of men's, significantly more than your 70 percent. In addition, nearly one-third of working married women earn more than their spouses, another rising proportion. 
 The closing gap between women's and men's earnings, even as women's labor force participation rates have leveled off and men's have dropped, means women will have personal options, such as whom to marry or when to unmarry, that men have long had. What if men were expected to marry for financial support and women for companionship and a household? Is this closer than you think?
 
JANE SJOGREN
Associate Professor of Economics
Simmons College
Boston, Nov. 9, 1994

HEADLINE: THE 1994 ELECTION: ISSUES;
MOMENTUM BUILDS FOR CUTTING BACK WELFARE SYSTEM

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
After a campaign in which voters rewarded a barrage of anti-welfare attacks, both parties are now calling the issue a top priority, and both are repeating stern promises to make recipients work.
As the smoke clears from the new political landscape, Democrats and Republicans each appear ready to cut benefits, increase work obligations and provide fewer protections for the 14.3 million people who rely on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program. More than nine million of the recipients are children. 
 In his first public remarks after the Democrats' electoral debacle, President Clinton emphasized the toughness of the welfare bill he proposed this spring, calling it "quite similar to one that several Republicans themselves have proposed."
But the talk of common ground masks profound differences between Mr. Clinton and his Republican opponents, particularly Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who is poised to become the next Speaker of the House.
Mr. Clinton's bill would require people who stayed on the A.F.D.C. rolls for more than two years to join a work program. But those who worked could continue to receive aid.
And Mr. Clinton would preserve the broad array of food, housing and disability programs that, in the eyes of their defenders, act as a crucial safety net between needy people and destitution.
Mr. Gingrich, by contrast, describes such programs not as the strands of a safety net but as the teeth of a trap that lures the poor into self-destructive behavior.
He would allow states to end assistance to large numbers of A.F.D.C. recipients, whether or not they were willing to join a work program. He would use some of the money to build orphanages or group homes for the children of those families rendered destitute.
But Mr. Gingrich's proposal goes beyond the main Federal welfare program. Indeed, some Republicans estimate that over the next five years his proposal could translate into cuts of roughly $40 billion or more in food, housing and income programs, including those that serve the disabled and the indigent elderly.
On Friday, Mr. Gingrich said that the programs promote a "counterculture value system" and "ruin the poor."
Given the Republican sweep on Tuesday, the momentum for far-reaching changes appears strong. Welfare rolls are at near-record levels, and Mr. Gingrich collected the support of more than 300 Republican candidates when he outlined his plan in the "Contract With America," the campaign document listing measures Republicans promised to vote on in the first 100 days of the next Congress.
But there are also counterbalancing pressures. Behind the scenes, Republicans clashed angrily among themselves when drafting the contract, with some members of the party arguing it went too far in a punitive direction. The proposals would probably face an uphill fight in the Senate, where institutional rules give Democrats more leverage.
And public support is fickle: the same voters who clamor in opinion polls for a crackdown on "welfare spending" show much less support when the issue is defined as "reducing aid to the poor," especially poor children.
Nonetheless, the balance of power unmistakably shifted this week toward provisions that would withdraw assistance (but risk harming children) and away from those that offer more protections (but preserve elements of the unloved status quo).
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr. of Florida is among those Republicans who said Mr. Gingrich's plan to substitute orphanages for welfare checks could prove "unduly harsh." But Mr. Shaw did not seek to minimize the number of families who could lose aid under his own proposal for a strict work program, saying "some people are going to fall through the cracks."
Mr. Shaw, who is likely to head the Ways and Means subcommittee responsible for welfare legislation, described such failures as the price to be paid in fixing a broken system. "It may be like hitting a mule with a two-by-four, but you've got to get their attention," he said.
The debate over public assistance -- which sometimes seems to have the accelerating force of a snowball running downhill -- began during the 1992 Presidential campaign, when Mr. Clinton promised to "end welfare as we know it." He pledged to expand the training that recipients could get in their first two years, then require those still unemployed to join a work program.
But after assuming office, Mr. Clinton waited 17 months before producing a bill, in part because he hoped first to push through a program of universal health insurance. He has argued that welfare recipients will not be able to survive on entry-level jobs without the promise of health care.
Republicans disagree and have pushed forward their own end-welfare plans with no promises about health care. A bill sponsored by 164 House Republicans would create a much larger work program than Mr. Clinton envisioned, spending $20 billion over five years on child care, training and supervision. It would raise the money by denying all aid to legal immigrants.
But that proposal was in turn attacked as a big government solution by a smaller faction of Congressional Republicans, led by Representative James M. Talent of Missouri. They have argued that work programs are wasteful and that the Government should instead simply abolish benefits to discourage unmarried women from having children in the first place.
Mr. Talent would permanently deny payments to children born to mothers younger than 26. States could use the money instead to care for children in orphanages or other group settings. While as recently as a year ago, such talk was considered far too radical for mainstream politics, it is edging into the prime-time debate.
Mr. Talent has said the move would sharply cut the number of out-of-wedlock births. But critics conjure up visions of Dickensian England or the modern de-institutionalization of the mentally ill, warning the move would dump hordes of needy families into the streets.
In the Contract With America, the Republican factions temporarily compromised. The plan outlined in the document would enroll 1.5 million recipients in a work program by 2000, but it would also allow states to abolish benefits to mothers younger than 21.
It remains unclear which Republican faction will gain the upper hand.
Mr. Shaw, who is skeptical about abolishing benefits to adults, said the idea was also opposed by most Republican governors, who fear they could inherit responsibility for the dispossessed families. "The states don't want us to just dump our problems on them," Mr. Shaw said.
But Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is likely to lead the Ways and Means Committee, reacted favorably when asked about the provision this week. "We're going to have to face that, we're going to have to face the fact of illegitimacy," he said.
Bruce Reed, a White House welfare adviser, said the Administration remained opposed to proposals like Mr. Talent's that would abolish benefits. "We've said all along that the provision would cause more problems than it solves," he said.
Two other crucial issues are likely to separate Democrats and Republicans in coming months. One is the structure of a work program. The Administration's bill allows recipients to remain in the program indefinitely, as long as they are making good-faith efforts to find private jobs.
The theory is that in an economy with 7.6 million unemployed workers, some welfare recipients will remain unable to find jobs, particularly in areas of high unemployment. Welfare recipients typically have little education or few skills, and many employers shun them.
Mr. Gingrich's plan, by contrast, allows states to drop recipients from the rolls completely within two years, leaving them with neither welfare nor the work program. How many of the nation's five million welfare recipients will then find jobs on their own? "Some will, some won't," said Mr. Shaw, who supports the two-year cutoff. "But more people will be helped than hurt."
The second issue involves the fundamental size and structure of anti-poverty programs. The Clinton plan allows states to reduce some welfare payments by denying extra payments to families that have additional children, for instance.
But the Clinton plan does not seek wholesale cuts, and it does not affect programs like Supplemental Security Income, which provides $23 billion a year in payments to the disabled and the indigent elderly.
By contrast, Mr. Gingrich would limit the growth of both programs and convert them from entitlements into discretionary programs. Under his plan, the programs would provide finite assistance on a first-come, first-serve basis, instead of providing benefits to all who qualify, as they now do.
This could lead to long waiting lists for needy families, like those for housing programs, where waits can last years. Mr. Gingrich would also limit the growth of housing and nutrition programs.
Bloodied by the ballot-box defeat this week, Democrats avoided public criticism of the Republican plans, eager to avoid any hint that they opposed welfare changes. They seem to hope the Republicans will moderate themselves and give Mr. Clinton a bill he can sign. "We should wait for the Congressional debate to unfold," said Mr. Reed, the White House aide.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "VIEWPOINTS: Clinton and Gingrich on Welfare"
 
Clinton Proposal
--Requires 400,000 recipients to join a work program by the year 2000.
--Allows recipients to stay in a work program and collect benefits, as long as they are seeking private jobs.
--Does not alter the food stamp, housing or disability programs.
--Reduces but does not eliminate aid for legal immigrants.
 
Gingrich Proposal
--Requires 1.5 million recipients to join work program by the year 2000.
--Allows states to drop recipients from both welfare and a work program within two years, even if they cannot find private jobs.
--Allows states to abolish aid to children of mothers younger than 21. The states could use the money to build orphanages instead.
--Eliminates aid for legal immigrants.
--Seeks cuts of $40 billion or more in food, housing and income programs, including those for the elderly and disabled. (pg. 30)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: A Celebrity At Last

BYLINE: By Peter S. Prescott; Peter S. Prescott was the senior book critic at Newsweek for two decades. He has been collecting interviews for his forthcoming biography of Alfred and Blanche Knopf.

 BODY:

REMEMBERING ELIZABETH BISHOP
An Oral Biography.
By Gary Fountain and Peter Brazeau.
Illustrated. 408 pp. Amherst:
University of Massachusetts Press.
$35. 
EXCEPT among her fellow poets and her friends within the narrow literary precincts, Elizabeth Bishop (1911-79) was never famous in her lifetime. She resented the neglect. She had won virtually every major award in sight, but she felt, rightly, that she had been denied the celebrity given her male peers; she was never as well known as her close friend Robert Lowell. Now, for some reason only an astrologer could explain, the attention has arrived in bulk, and I suspect that Bishop -- the great poet was an intensely private person -- would have been appalled by all of it. Three big books have descended in the past 18 months: Brett C. Millier's excellent critical biography, "Elizabeth Bishop: Life and the Memory of It"; Robert Giroux's monumental edition of Bishop's letters, "One Art," and now Gary Fountain and Peter Brazeau's "Remembering Elizabeth Bishop: An Oral Biography," in which Bishop's friends tell all they knew of her or guessed at, sparing us no ghastly detail.
A collection of interviews, strapped together by an intelligent though minimal narrative, presents problems. Such a book looks unfinished. Of course a biographer will interview everyone above ground -- 118 people are listed as contributors to this book -- but shouldn't the biographer then assess their testimony, correct errors, eliminate the contradictions and repetitions? Shouldn't he challenge anything he hears? After all, in an interview everyone sets out to make himself look good. If anyone failed to extend the helping hand Bishop so often needed, if she had any detractors, their recollections do not seem to have been solicited.
Another problem: If the biographer weaves the interviews into a continuous text, he will lose some detail -- and detail may be the only reason for taking the oral history route -- but if he doesn't, he'll have to sacrifice a lot of context. We learn, for instance, a great deal about the affection Bishop and Lowell had for each other in the 1940's (he even proposed to her, prompting us to speculate on the marriage of a violent, schizophrenic poet to a reserved, lesbian poet), but we don't learn that in 1947 Lowell's "Lord Weary's Castle" edged Bishop's "North & South" for the Pulitzer Prize -- a detail that must have been important to them both.
Peter Brazeau, the author of "Parts of a World: Wallace Stevens Remembered," began collecting interviews for this oral biography in 1984, five years after Bishop's death; he died two years later. Gary Fountain, chairman of the English department at Miss Porter's School, has done the bulk of the work, transcribing Brazeau's tapes, conducting more interviews and writing the connecting narrative. In an oral history -- one of Studs Terkel's volumes, for example -- the testimony comes in different flavors from people of widely differing backgrounds and conditions, but oral biography is different: the friends of Elizabeth Bishop are a homogeneous lot; their voices in these edited transcripts are mostly interchangeable.
Generic difficulties aside, "Remembering Elizabeth Bishop" amply succeeds in what it proposes to do: It offers an intimate view of Bishop's desperate and lonely life, as that life was observed by those who were there at the time -- and those observers are a particularly perceptive and articulate lot. Bishop was born in Worcester, Mass., in 1911, but after the death of her father and the incarceration of her mother in an asylum, she was brought up by relatives in Nova Scotia and Massachusetts. A sickly child -- her asthma afflicted her throughout her life -- she developed into a dreamy, preoccupied adolescent with an early interest in poetry. Lonely from the start, and without geographical roots, she had to grow up on her own. Most of her close friends were women, as were her companions in later years. One friend explains that she and Bishop "belonged to a generation of women who were terrified by the idea of being known as lesbians, and for Elizabeth as poet, the lesbian label would have been particularly dangerous." The poet Frank Bidart remembers her saying that she "believed in closets, closets and more closets."
CLEMENT GREENBERG, the art critic, recalls Bishop as "self-possessed. . . . so agreeable, so amiable, so right -- good company. . . . No professional jealousy, unlike some good poets." Her friend Helen Muchnic speaks of Bishop's taste as a "combination of the simple, authentic and unusual." This quality of taste provoked occasions that I'd have paid dearly to attend. Bishop liked jazz, befriended Billie Holiday, and arranged a jam session between Holiday and the harpsichord master Ralph Kirkpatrick, though neither had heard of the other before. The publisher James Laughlin remembers Bishop in Key West, inviting him and Tennessee Williams to tea in a brothel that she knew of.
Yet before she was 30 Bishop had begun drinking heavily, and acquaintances remember times when she was "totally drunk," "hitting the banisters" so she "ricocheted off the walls." In such a state she was likely to ask, to the horror of those who heard her, "Should I kill myself?" More and more Bishop depended on the strong women she lived with to save her from herself, and there seemed always to be one willing to restrain her, clean up after her, take her to the hospital. Always worried that she hadn't written enough, she died of a ruptured cerebral aneurysm in 1979.
"Her life was often out of control, but her poetry is precise," a former student says. It was "as if her poetry had to create an order missing from her life." When Bishop spoke of Vermeer's paintings -- "the objects in them are very precisely observed and rendered" -- she might have been describing her own work, which combines rigorous observation with a highly economical and disciplined line to provide verse that points to a mystery at the heart of things and conditions. In a generation of slack and confessional poets, she forgave herself and her poems nothing.

HEADLINE: The County's Lure: More for the Money

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHAT induces companies to move from New York City to Westchester? Is it because of the city's problems? Tax reasons? Or is it simply because a company's chief executive lives in Westchester? Perhaps it is a quality-of-life decision.
Those may be contributing factors, said William V. Cuddy Jr., senior vice president and principal of Rostenberg-Doern Company, a commercial brokerage in Purchase. But the bottom line, Mr. Cuddy said, is that space in Westchester is a better buy. 
 "The rent spread in similar buildings in Manhattan and Westchester is somewhere in the neighborhood of $10 to $15 a square foot with Westchester in the low end," Mr. Cuddy said. "Currently, rents for Class A and B space in Westchester range from $19 to $24 a square foot plus electricity, and right now in New York City, rents are rising. Rates for similar space in Midtown are between $34 and $44 a square foot. We are working with a number of people in diverse industries from the city who are considering relocating their businesses to Westchester."
Which is good news for the county, Mr. Cuddy added.
Bolstered by third-quarter results showing positive absorption of office space and lower vacancy rates, the Westchester office market is positioned for a significant recovery this year, he said.
"According to our third-quarter real estate report, the vacancy rate for Westchester was 24.6, down from 26.9 at the end of 1993," Mr. Cuddy said. "With the completion of several major leases, including the Mastercard relocation from Manhattan to the former International Business Machines building in Purchase and the expected move of Ciba Corporation, the international chemical company, to 575,000 square feet in Tarrytown, from a building Ciba owns in Ardsley, the absorption, which is the net increase or decrease for occupied space could exceed a million square feet by the end of the year. It would be a dramatic rebound from last year when the county had a negative absorption of 1.25 million square feet."
Despite continuing downsizing by major corporations, lower vacancy rates were achieved in part by strong leasing activity in the county's so-called trophy buildings.
Warren L. Schwerin, president of Related Properties of Purchase and Manhattan, is the investor-builder of the five trophy buildings that make up the Center at Purchase. Four of the buildings have tenants, and the fifth is owned by Nestle.
"The Center is now 10 years old, so leases are coming up for renewal," Mr. Schwerin said. "We have renewed long-term leases with many of our tenants, including Sprint and Apple Computer, but when Mutual of New York, one of our original tenants, sold their pension division to Agon, a Dutch company, the new company that emerged, Diversified Investors, was considering moving to new headquarters and looked at a number of potential buildings."
In an effort to keep Diversified Investors from moving out of 200,000 square feet, Mr. Schwerin said, "we approached them exactly as if they were a brand-new tenant." He added: "We even supplied an architectural presentation and showed a plan for the rehabilitation of the building. Other landlords in Westchester and in Fairfield were wooing them hard. We emphasized the value of continuity, keeping them in the building that they had always been in and the advantages of being in a building that was owned and operated by the original investor-builder, who has an office on the premises."
Mr. Schwerin further observed: "I believe what also worked strongly in our favor was that in addition to the major renovations we were willing to make to the building was our ability to out-source. Out-sourcing means that we were willing to take over all the responsibility and costs of the security and the food-service facility, which had previously been the tenants' responsibility. And we also installed a health club for the use of all our major tenants."
Eventually, he said, Diversified Investors signed a 10-year lease for the 200,000 square feet of space with a 5-year option and rights for an additional 40,000 square feet.
"And as 1970 lease cycles are ending, he said, "we are receiving inquiries from a number of entrepreneurs in Manhattan who want to relocate."
For tenants looking for space outside Manhattan, the amenity packages that most campus office parks in Westchester offer are a big draw, Mr. Cuddy said.
"Suddenly, office parks have improved dramatically in response to the times," he said. "The sterile atmosphere is gone. They have become more like self-contained villages with many services available, everything from barber shops and dry-cleaning stores to health clubs. On-site food services have also improved tremendously. Upscale catering services on the premises are available for dinners and meetings in addition to supplying breakfasts and luncheons for the occupants of the park."
Also new are lunchtime seminars, lectures and newsletters, which announce park events. A supplemental bus service, run by the county, runs from the White Plains train station along Westchester Avenue, making stops at all the office parks.
In downtown White Plains, the county's central business district, the third- quarter vacancy rate was 32.4 compared with 35 at the end of last year.
About 60 percent of all the vacant space in downtown White Plains is concentrated in three large buildings -- Gateway, Westchester One and 360 Hamilton Avenue, buildings that have been adversely affected by the downsizing of I.B.M. and American Telephone & Telegraph. The largest transaction downtown was the Westchester County Appellate Court lease for 20,000 square feet of space.
Mr. Cuddy added: "The general feeling is that the office market in Westchester will continue to recover, and since there hasn't been any new construction in the county for three years, older buildings are being renovated and adapted for alternative use. And some special properties are coming on the market. The Ciba Building, for example. Ciba plans to sell its property in Ardsley next year. It has over 400,000 square feet of space with not only lab space but also unusual state-of-the-art equipment. This would be a unique opportunity for a biotech company to come into the county."
In the western half of the county, primarily the area along Route 119 in Tarrytown, absorption was more than 320,000 square feet at the end of the third quarter. The conversion of the landmark Axe Castle from offices to hotel-restaurant space removed 26,000 square feet from the inventory. Other major deals in the western half of the county include a Liberty Mutual Insurance Company lease of 19,203 square feet and Marshall Cavendish Corporation's acquisition of 31,500 square feet.
In the northern half of the county, which includes Mount Pleasant and Mount Kisco, the third-quarter figure was nearly 173,000 square feet absorbed. A major transaction was the leasing of 29,000 square feet by the Travelers and 9,000 square feet by Merrill Lynch. In the negative column was 50,000 square feet that came on the market when I.B.M. moved out of two buildings in Ossining.

HEADLINE: New Greenburgh Law On Carbon Monoxide

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
AS part of a restructuring of an already rigorous building code, the town of Greenburgh recently adopted a provision to require that new buildings, both commercial and residential, install carbon-monoxide detectors. This measure was prompted in part by the recent death of the tennis star Vitas Gerulaitis and, closer to home, the death last year of a Hartsdale resident .
"We are re-adopting a sprinkler law that has been around since 1982 because the state told us that the law was defective on technicalities," said Paul J. Feiner, Greenburgh Town Supervisor. "As we were revising a tough sprinkler law, we thought we might as well add this." 
 Detectors would be required in new construction and also recommended for any living quarters. In December, Greenburgh will begin alerting residents to the dangers of carbon monoxide poisoning and the benefits of installing detectors, primarily through meetings of neighborhood groups and townwide mailings. Carbon-monoxide detectors are available at hardware stores and places like Caldor and Pergament. Prices start at about $40.
"These would prevent deaths," said Walter J. Schoonmaker, the Hartsdale Fire Chief. "Smoke detectors work; sprinklers work, and these carbon-monoxide detectors are just one more way to help people not be overcome by fumes. We have such energy-efficient homes now that everybody is sealed up."
Since the requirement in Greenburgh is more stringent than the State Building Code, the state Building Code Council in Albany, a division of the State Housing and Community Renewal Agency, must rule on the change. Few problems are expected, however, said Frederick W. Turner, the Greenburgh Town Attorney.
"Other municipalities have adopted this provision," Mr. Turner added. "If Kingston, for example, can justify it, it can be justified in Greenburgh." MERRI ROSENBERG

HEADLINE: The View From The Former Top

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley, a professor of history at Columbia University, is the author of "The End of Reform: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War," which will be published early next year.

 BODY:

SPECIAL TRUST
By Robert C. McFarlane with Zofia Smardz.
Illustrated. 399 pp. New York:
Cadell & Davies. $25. 
 AS self-exculpatory memoirs go, Robert C. McFarlane's "Special Trust" is more interesting, and more convincing, than most. Mr. McFarlane was President Ronald Reagan's national security adviser from late 1983 to late 1985. He served during the first, critical years of the Mikhail S. Gorbachev regime, and he considers his work in redefining Soviet-American relations during that period his principal public achievement. But he also launched the policy initiatives that led to the Iran-contra scandal, and he is astute enough to realize that his own reputation depends above all on what he reveals of that ill-fated venture.
In July 1985, Mr. McFarlane reports, David Kimche of the Israeli Foreign Ministry called on him and proposed a scheme to assassinate the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran. Mr. McFarlane rejected that idea out of hand. But he was interested in Mr. Kimche's broader proposal that the United States begin making overtures to dissident, "moderate" groups within the Iranian regime, who might, with Western help, have a chance to seize power. Those groups would, Mr. Kimche said, arrange for the release of American hostages in Lebanon as evidence of their legitimacy and good faith. But within a few days, the "moderate" Iranians added demands for sophisticated American weapons. Mr. Reagan nevertheless approved the initiative, and Mr. McFarlane (with some misgivings and somewhat inattentively) oversaw its execution.
It was, he now concedes, a mistake. It became clear almost from the start that the effort was turning into nothing more than a swap of arms for hostages, and an unsuccessful one at that. Mr. McFarlane soon urged the President to terminate the venture, but Mr. Reagan, emotionally committed to the fate of the hostages, kept it going against his advice. The other foreign policy principals in the Administration -- Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Vice President George Bush -- were fully aware of the initiative from the start. None of them, Mr. McFarlane claims, communicated any strenuous objections to the President, although Mr. Shultz and Mr. Weinberger complained loudly about the effort outside Mr. Reagan's presence.
The diversion of funds from the Iranian arms sales to the Nicaraguan contras -- and the entire illegal effort to fund the contras in defiance of Congressional restrictions, the effort that became the real heart of the subsequent scandal -- was, Mr. McFarlane insists, the work of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, and of Mr. McFarlane's own "right-hand man," Oliver North; it remained unknown to virtually everyone else. The diversions themselves did not occur until after Mr. McFarlane had left government, and he knew nothing of them until Mr. North mentioned them offhandedly to him in 1986. The larger fund-raising effort began earlier, right under Mr. McFarlane's nose, but Mr. North consistently falsified both his statements and his documents to leave Mr. McFarlane in the dark. Mr. McFarlane had suspicions, he admits, but he did not pursue them.
Mr. McFarlane offers a vivid portrait of good intentions gone awry, of zealotry run amok and of the torrent of lies and deceptions that followed exposure of the initiatives. At the time, he was hardest of all on himself, convinced that his failure to stop the plan when he had the chance was the cause of all that subsequently went wrong. Early in 1987, he attempted suicide. Later, he testified before Congress without immunity, pleaded guilty to four misdemeanors and eventually received a pardon (unasked for, he says) from President George Bush.
In hindsight, Mr. McFarlane believes he behaved unwisely but honorably. He cannot say the same about others. Mr. Shultz and Mr. Weinberger exaggerated their efforts to stop the initiative and, along with Mr. Bush, lied about how much they knew. Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, spread false rumors about Mr. McFarlane in an effort to make him a scapegoat for the scandal. Oliver North, "the man I had thought was patriotic, self-sacrificing and loyal" turned out to be "devious, self-serving" and "deceitful, mendacious and traitorous." And Ronald Reagan, for whom Mr. McFarlane obviously has real respect and affection and "who approved every single action I ever took in this matter," in the end "lacked the moral conviction and intellectual courage to stand up in our defense and in defense of his policy."
THE real tragedy of the Iran-contra affair, Mr. McFarlane believes, is that it obscured and, for a time, obstructed the larger foreign policy aims of the Reagan Administration, which he continues enthusiastically to defend. Although a bitter and largely personal feud between Mr. Shultz and Mr. Weinberger (which he describes in withering detail) all but crippled the national security system at times, there were real achievements, he feels. The great Reagan-era arms buildup, Mr. McFarlane contends, was the result of an official judgment, made early in Mr. Reagan's first term, that the Soviet Union was so weak that forcing it into a costly arms race would help hasten its demise. Subsequent events, he believes, have vindicated that decision.
The Strategic Defense Initiative, he claims, was essentially a "bargaining chip," designed to intimidate the Soviet Union into an arms control agreement; almost all its original proponents (except the President, who had a hazy, romantic commitment to the idea) realized that it was too costly and too unreliable ever to be built. Ultimately, Mr. McFarlane believes, S.D.I. produced its intended result.
Mr. McFarlane offers, in short, an account of how the United States (and the Reagan Administration) supposedly won the cold war, a version of history he has a clear stake in promoting. But his brutal honesty in describing the illegality, duplicity, jealousy and stupidity that ran through the foreign policy processes of the Reagan years greatly weakens his triumphal assessment.
 
 
 
UNVINDICATING OLIVER NORTH
 Robert C. McFarlane feels the Iran-contra affair was in essence a disagreement over separation of powers. "Ronald Reagan should have come forward and had a public argument over what the Constitution intended about the conduct of foreign policy," Mr. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles, where he was promoting his book, "Special Trust." "Then we would have gotten some useful lessons out of this scandal."
The heart of the disagreement, he observed, was not the White House agenda toward Iran and Central America but its arrogant indifference to the prerogatives of Congress. "Unless Presidents and Congresses engage with mutual respect, they're going to get in trouble," he said.
Mr. McFarlane thinks that no White House subordinates should have been punished for their roles in the Iran-contra affair, not even Oliver North. This is the reason he testified sympathetically for the defense at Mr. North's criminal trial, he explained, something he now says may have helped fuel his former aide's rise to national political prominence. "People feel that North was somehow vindicated, and that is unfortunate," Mr. McFarlane said. "His record of lying is by his own testimony, there for all to see."
Although Mr. McFarlane is now a private adviser to governments in the developing world and companies seeking to do business with them, he keeps a keen eye on national security issues. He considers the threat of nuclear proliferation in totalitarian states the key worry, and he has mixed reviews for the bargain the Clinton Administration and its emissary, Jimmy Carter, forged with North Korea. "Korea will be stable, but the process of contracting out your foreign policy to individuals who don't feel constrained to operate within any policy framework is a very worrisome methodology," he said. TOBIN HARSHAW

HEADLINE: To Dance In Veracruz

BYLINE: By ROSELLEN BROWN; Rosellen Brown is the author of "Cora Fry's Pillow Book," a volume of poetry (Farrar, Straus & Giroux).

 BODY:
IN Veracruz, everyone dances.
When I close my eyes on the city, a deep, methodical drumbeat throbs without flagging and everyone is in motion, from little boys gently guided by older girls to ancients like the decrepit woman I saw in the zocalo who put aside her tray of Chiclets and plastic doodads to dance with an equally old man in a shiny-elbowed suit jacket. Her face transformed, she moved with great spirit, hips in subtle motion, loose and comfortably graceful, her shoulders perfectly still. When she stopped to pick up her burden again and released her partner to the shaky gait in which he apparently lives his nondancing life, it was clear that "danzon," the very sober and formal dance favored by Veracruzanos, had held them upright as long as the music lasted. 
 I had heard that Veracruz was a cross between European cafe culture and a New Orleans-Havana haven of music and dance. Both and neither turned out to be quite true.
Once upon a time, Veracruz was a haven for pirates. In 1519, Hernando Cortes -- a man some might call a pirate for his own cause -- made landfall on the Mexican coast here. He gets credit for naming the city La Villa Rica de la Vera Cruz, the Rich Town of the True Cross, rather exhaustively blending his joint hungers for spiritual and material plenty. Veracruz became a thriving Gulf port, until the 1760's the only New World port allowed to trade directly with Spain: so, when gold and jewels from the Orient entered Mexico from the west coast, they exited to Europe through Veracruz, which apparently posed an irresistible invitation to those like Sir Francis Drake who lived by plunder.
For doubters, in the Baluarte de Santiago, a fortress in the center of town that is the last remnant of Veracruz's defensive wall, there is a permanent exhibit of a huge haul dredged up by an octopus fisherman 20 years ago -- exquisitely detailed gold tortoises, eagles, symbols of war and a depressing number of cigar-shaped gold bars made of melted-down jewelry by some power less interested in esthetics than in economics.
Early Veracruz got a bad press from travelers not bent on conquest or plunder. In 1843, Fanny Calderon de la Barca, the Scottish wife of the Spanish ambassador to Mexico, described the coastal city in her "Life in Mexico." "Anything more melancholy . . . and forlorn . . . cannot well be imagined . . . mountains of moving sand, formed by the violence of the north wind . . . The houses seemed blackened by fire; there is not a carriage on the streets," wrote the lady, whose hopes for festivity and glamour had to await her arrival in Mexico City, 200 miles inland. Her departure for the fertile green mountains to the west brought forth a final spasm of hyperbole: ". . . as in Dante's 'Commedia,' after leaving Purgatory, typified by Veracruz, we seemed to draw nearer to Paradise."
Fanny approached Veracruz by sea. Nowadays you drive in from the airport. The typically unbeautiful route, El Grand Route del Automotive Repair, takes you around a rather dingy traffic circle matter-of-factly overseen by a mammoth Olmec head of the sort that dominated the area in wilder times. It is an unmistakable sign of arrival.
Needless to say, the city gives a far better accounting of itself 150 years after Fanny Calderon de la Barca snubbed it, admitting even as she did so, that "those who have resided here for any length of time, even foreigners, almost invariably become attached to it; and as for those born here, they are the truest of patriots, holding up Veracruz as superior to all other parts of the world." That extraordinary zeal still holds true. A journalist who has lived in a number of other Mexican cities confided that she'd settled here because, though it might lack intellectual refinement, there is no place in Mexico like Veracruz for spirit, for joie de vivre. "Other people think we are crazy here," she insisted rather proudly, "but this is the most open city in Mexico." Politically? Morally? Socially? The answer was unclear but her loyalty was palpable.
Certainly it is the noisiest. If my memory of morning in serene and lovely Florence is a dozen Vespas furiously cranking up under the windows of my pension, in Veracruz, it is marimbas, guitars, plastic bottles filled with beans and a variety of gourds revised into rhythm instruments that keep their strict beat until 2 and 3 in the morning front of the hotel cafes that face the zocalo. It is impossible to spend time here and not think about how our reveries at home tend to be shattered by the irregular sounds of motors, leaf blowers, car alarms and the cheeping of large trucks backing up. Here, music leaps out everywhere, all the time, and incites a response: it blares from speakers, live bands send it forth from the propped-open doors of small cafes. Here, quiet is not sociable; therefore it is not much honored.
At just about any hour of the day, for example, my husband, Marv, and I enter either of the two huge, unadorned coffee houses called Gran Cafe de la Parroquia and hear not only the musicians who ply between tables shaking their little gourds for spare change, but also an unending high-pitched chorus of spoons tapping. The delightful routine here is to be served coffee in glasses into which a strolling waiter pours alternate streams of strong brew and steaming milk from big kettles -- pours from a daunting height without spilling so much as a drop -- and when it's time for a refill he answers to the sound of a spoon struck against the empty glass. The constant high-pitched tinkle is more merry than insistent; just to practice its effectiveness I succumbed to a horrific number of refills. (La Parroquia serves two specialties for breakfast that I've encountered nowhere else: gordas, great puffed pasties as fat as their name, filled with surprises like anise, and picadas, small pizzalike tortillas, their toppings held in by a raised border. They are filling and addictive.)
For another clientele entirely, there is one very pleasant bookstore-coffeehouse where a more genteel silence accompanies the cappuccino. The Atarazanas, a long, bright yellow, wood-and-tile-ceilinged building with an inviting garden, was a naval museum until its conversion a few years ago into this lovely, breezy, book-filled space.
In general, Veracruz offers few of the images we like to take home in our cameras. There are, for instance, only a small number of Indians in evidence (though some representatives of the flying men from nearby Papantla, famous for leaping upside down from poles, dance gravely in the streets in their mirrored hats). But perhaps because there are no lace-and-ribbon costumes, no rainbow-colored weavings, only one modest local crafts shop and no gilded cathedrals -- the 18th-century parish church, La Parroquia, is nothing special and several other churches were converted to warehouses during the Revolution -- the tourists for whom the party never ceases tend to be internal, not international.
Until Acapulco was connected to Mexico City by good roads to the southwest, many weekend vacationers routinely flocked east to the beaches of Veracruz; a fair number still do. South of the city, there is a fancy beach, the Mocambo, and a stretch of familiarly elegant hotels, not to mention those interchangeable tokens of commercial life, McDonald's, Sanborns et al. There is even an impressively large mall, as glitzy from a distance as anything north of the border. The sophistication of this local Zona Rosa would presumably surprise Ross Perot, whose stereotyped vision of Mexico seems more Rivera than Riviera, more peasant in rebozo than upscale diner with credit card.
Still, "upscale" is not really what this town is about. It is mainly working class, unfrenzied, casually dressed, and the Mocambo is not really for local consumption. The beach popular with residents is the Villa del Mar, paralleled by a wide drive, the malecon, not far from downtown Veracruz. Edged by a working port and its attendant international crop of sailors, it's not a particularly prepossessing stretch of golden sand, probably not worth leaving the zocalo for.
Veracruz is a lived-in city, and it comes most vibrantly alive after dark.
Walking the back streets after we'd had dinner in one of the small, family-run restaurants that always surprise with their hospitality -- the owner brought us fat pieces of orange cake, gratis, because we'd been having a neighborly conversation about the old photos on the walls -- we came upon a little square, La Plazuela de la Campana, beside the Convent of Santo Domingo. The sound of guitars drew us around the corner and into a well-lighted space, raggedly attended, with a stage where a performance of Garcia Lorca's "House of Bernarda Alba" was in progress. The play calls for a stageful of earnest young women in black, but here in the shadow of the church they looked far more at home than in the high school auditoriums and off-Broadway black boxes where I've encountered them before, passionately embracing and renouncing and declaiming. The troupe was modest -- no identifying placards announced its name --but perhaps, in this intimate town, it was assumed that anyone who cared knew who they were.
Dance, obviously, is the city's defining pleasure. We glimpsed couples of every unpromising size and age in continuous movement in the cafes. If La Bamba did not start right here, then it started near here, and Mexico's Mardi Gras is said to be a mini-Rio (only safer). So, when we were advised to "Come see the dancing on Saturday night in the zocalo," we obediently turned up, expecting a spectator sport. There is a lot of local "folkloric" performance in Veracruz -- young men and women in superb and colorful costumes flawlessly executing their intricate Spanish-influenced steps, stamping down hard and flaunting the most captivating faces and figures imaginable, and that was what we assumed we'd see.
Oddly, though, the dancing space, one broad swathe of sidewalk, was ringed by the kind of white plastic garden chairs ubiquitous in American backyards. They filled up quickly, the spectators waiting patiently, chatting. We bought some pudding from a vendor and settled in while half of Veracruz showed up (later we learned that the other half was assembling across town in the Parque Zamora). Some people were dressed up for going out, some looked like they'd just come from work -- soon enough it became clear that they were there to provide their own entertainment.
"Danzon," which evolved in Veracruz with the help of its numerous Cuban immigrants, is called "dancing on a brick." There is only the most subtle abandon in it; those who subscribe to the idea that partial undress is more erotic than total nudity will find it far more mesmerizing than any free spontaneous dance could be. Imagine a box step of the kind teenagers used to learn. This, however, is far more beguiling, a sort of elaborated rumba executed with formal dignity, a controlled flirtatiousness and an attentiveness -- eyes fixed unflinchingly on eyes -- that amounts to a built-in seductiveness. The dancers, in straw hats and baseball caps, in high heels and walking shoes, conduct themselves with regal bearing, their postures controlled if not exactly rigid (no shoulder movement allowed), and at a given point, though there is no inflection in the music that taught us to hear it coming, everyone breaks out for a minute -- they swing wide away from each other, solitary, then fold back together with a feeling of resolution, of safe return. And this they repeat with a nearly awesome patience.
Soon there are hundreds of people moving almost identically. Down at one end of the zocalo cluster half a dozen teen-age girls in matching white dresses with striped pastel sashes, and boys in white shirts, all of them wearing white satin team jackets that celebrate "Three Generations of Danzon in Veracruz" -- a club devoted to this single dance! The young partners change with a dispassion that must be club discipline, some form of democratic passing around of capable but interchangeable bodies. The little boys of 7 or 8 who dance with the older girls, right arms extended at an exactly dictated height, are learning a kind of courtliness far too constrained and gentlemanly for American kids of the same generation to imagine, let alone enjoy.
The whole surprising scene is only a reminder that culture is made of many subtle parts. Like this formal civility, which is very Latin -- nothing like the stodgy "ballroom dancing" I've seen in, say, St. Petersburg or Warsaw, which seems moored in the 40's -- some ideals are maintained against tides that otherwise shift and slip. The television sets blaring in shop windows proffer the usual American fare, or its local equivalent, untouched by anything that could remotely be called civility, old- or new-fashioned. Yet here we stand happily under the trees in the lee of the heavy beat and watch tradition stake its claims. The dance starts early and ends late: the children rehearse unchanging parts while their grandparents whirl past smiling, faces avid, like young lovers, focused magnetically on each other's eyes.
The music plays on, even on Sunday night. Under the portico of our hotel, we sit at a cafe watching two sailors trying to talk to some local women a little too young for courting. The women, who were walking by with a seductive torpor, will not sit down but they giggle and shrug until finally, discouraged by language, one of the sailors begins to sing along with the marimba-guitar-and-gourd-that-sounds-like-it-has-nails-in-it. Ah, then, the women seem to say, looking at each other quickly. Ah, then, he speaks our language. They pull their chairs out, one of them mouthing the words of the song, and sit.
 
TOWN AND BEACH
 Veracruz has accommodations in all price ranges. The three hotels listed below provide a sampler of choice locations -- downtown, harbor or beachfront. All are air-conditioned. The telephone country code for Mexico is 52.
 HOTEL VERACRUZ, at the corner of Avenida Independencia and Miguel Lerdo (telephone: 29-31-22-33; fax: 29-31-51-34), is in the heart of downtown Veracruz, just off the Plaza de Armas, or zocalo. Completely remodeled in 1988, the six-story hotel has an Art Deco lobby with marble floors and a small fountain. Its 104 rooms all come with showers and are simply furnished with dark mahogany pieces; each room has a wooden balcony that overlooks downtown. The music from the zocalo -- where live bands perform for diners in the sidewalk cafes ringing the square -- is less audible on the higher floors. Double rooms are about $85; one-bedroom suites are about $120. The hotel has a small rooftop swimming pool. At the 1940 restaurant, a dinner for two, which might include grilled Huachinango snapper served with a salsa Veracruzana of garlic, hot peppers and onions, costs about $50, with wine.
 HOTEL EMPORIO, 210 Insurgentes Veracruzanos (29-32-34-10; fax: 29-31-22-61), is set on the Malecon, the promenade that runs along the harbor. The hotel, which first opened in 1955, has a lobby bar, gym, three swimming pools and glass elevators. Its 202 rooms, which have color television sets and wall-to-wall carpeting, are painted in pastel colors and furnished in wicker. All of the rooms have bathtubs; more than 50 of them are equipped with Jacuzzis. Double rooms are about $95; master suites (with two bedrooms) are about $170. The specialty at DEL FARO restaurant, which overlooks the sea, is mariscada, a mixed-seafood dish of octopus, breaded shrimp and fresh fish. A dinner for two, with wine, costs about $60.
 HOTEL MOCAMBO, 4000 Calzada Ruiz Cortines, in Mocambo (29-22-02-11; fax: 29-22-02-12), is on the coast about six miles south of Veracruz. Built in 1932, the Mocambo is a sprawling beachfront complex of gardens, Moorish-style arches and whitewashed buildings. The hotel has indoor and outdoor swimming pools, game room, tennis courts, gym, sauna and steam bath. All of the 125 rooms, which come with color television sets, carved wooden furniture and bathrooms done in colorful tile from the city of Puebla, have ocean views. Double rooms are about $105; suites are about $120. A dinner for two at LA FRAGATA restaurant, which might include corn-and-shrimp chowder and grilled sea bass stuffed with shrimp and octopus, costs about $55, with wine.
 
A QUARTET OF EXCURSIONS
 There are a number of intriguing spots near Veracruz that merit a side trip. LA ANTIGUA, 14 miles to the north, is a somnolent river village where the ruins of Cortes's (alleged) headquarters stand strangled by petrified vines. Twenty-four miles to the north is ZEMPOALA, which contains the remains of an archeologically unique Totonac city. And in the picturesque town of TLACOTALPAN, some 70 miles to the southeast, time seems to have stopped around 1900.
 About two hours (62 miles) inland is JALAPA, the capital of the state of Veracruz. (Its inhabitants are called -- it never occurred to me -- Jalapenos.) The University of Veracruz makes Jalapa a city with a different feeling from Veracruz. Its Cafe Parroquia (unrelated to Veracruz's, perhaps every parish has its own) has a rather intellectual-looking clientele and a bulletin board crammed with announcements of concerts, theatrical events and poetry readings. A block or so away is the Government Palace, an imposing building of startling elegance. There is also an exciting anthropology museum (Museo de Antropologia de Jalapa), built into a hillside by local workers, from a design by the firm of Edward Durrell Stone -- Jalapa is as hilly as Veracruz is flat. The museum has an extremely rich collection of Olmec, Huastec and other local artifacts and statuary shown in spaces large enough to honor their mammoth size. Its explanatory wall texts are untranslated, but the collection is so imposing that it hardly depends upon words to make its strength felt. ROSELLEN BROWN

HEADLINE: Last of the Proudfoots

BYLINE: By Robert Wilson; Robert Wilson is the literary editor of Civilization magazine.

 BODY:

WATCH WITH ME
And Six Other Stories of the Yet-Remembered Ptolemy Proudfoot and His Wife, Miss Minnie, Nee Quinch.
By Wendell Berry.
210 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $21. 
THE talky subtitle of "Watch With Me," Wendell Berry's new collection of stories, might suggest that it belongs to the babbling-rube school of rural fiction. But it does not. His characters, who live near Port William, Ky., the fictional community where all eight of Mr. Berry's novels and books of stories have been set, speak straightforwardly or not at all. Even Ptolemy (Tol) Proudfoot, who is considered by his neighbors to be unusually sociable, and who late in life is known as something of a storyteller, talks with the efficiency of a man who makes a good living off a small farm.
Mr. Berry, who is also a distinguished essayist and an accomplished poet, works a Kentucky farm, like Tol Proudfoot. He writes as Tol speaks, with a good husbandman's care and economy. Although his stories are filled with gentle humor, he never disrupts the natural syntax of his sentences for the cheap comic effects of so much contemporary rural fiction. He views his characters with sympathy and with an honest curiosity that makes it unnecessary to exaggerate their characteristics -- or to turn them into grotesques -- in order to arouse his own interest in them, or the reader's.
In this collection Mr. Berry's narrator recounts episodes from Tol's life, beginning with his courtship of Miss Minnie Quinch, the local schoolteacher, in 1908 ("A Consent"), and ending, two years before Tol's death, at a church picnic in 1941 ("Turn Back the Bed"). During the picnic Tol relates an antic story of a chamber pot overturned during a large family gathering in his youth. The Proudfoots, the narrator tells us in another story, had been "a big family of big people" who "liked to work together and to be together." But "the old had died and the young had gone," until Tol was the only one left. Tol is the last of the Proudfoots, for he and Miss Minnie have had no children.
Tol does not dwell on his solitude, perhaps because he and Miss Minnie are such a good match. She is as small and neat as he is big and slovenly (about his dress, but not his farm). They sit close, nudging each other affectionately, when they ride together in their buggy, and later in their car. The warmth of their marriage radiates out into the community, which delights in their unlikely love.
"The Solemn Boy" takes place in the Depression year of 1934. A man and his young son, "poorly dressed for the weather," appear on Tol's farm. Tol can see that they are hungry as well as cold, and he begins to coax the proud father to accept his and Miss Minnie's hospitality. "Be nice to get that boy up beside the stove where he can get warm," Tol says. "And a bean or two and a hot biscuit in his belly wouldn't hurt him either, I don't expect."
When the father accepts, Tol tells them to go around back and find Miss Minnie in the kitchen. "She'll be glad to see you," he promises the strangers. As the two wanderers eat unrelentingly in the warm kitchen, Tol and Miss Minnie's interest in the boy changes from their reliable good will toward others into a very particular sadness about their own childlessness. It is typical of Mr. Berry that this quiet, poignant story turns on a pratfall of Tol's, which succeeds in its intention of separating the boy, if only for a moment, from his solemnity.
The long title story reminds me of one of my favorite short stories, Eudora Welty's wonder-filled "Wide Net," in which a decidedly miscellaneous party of neighbors helps a young husband drag a river, looking for his wife, who has threatened to drown herself. "Watch With Me" also begins with a neighbor in trouble. Thacker Hample, known for having spells, walks past Tol's shed one day, picks up a loaded shotgun leaning against it and walks away, threatening to kill himself.
Tol and a growing group of men begin to trail him at a distance, hoping to prevent him from hurting himself or anyone else. They follow him across the countryside for a day and a night, without rancor in spite of their hunger and weariness.
Here is how the narrator describes Thacker's dementia: "His mind, which contained the lighted countryside of Katy's Branch and Cotman's Ridge, had a leak in it somewhere, some little hole through which now and again would pour the whole darkness of the darkest night -- so that instead of walking in the country he knew and among his kinfolks and neighbors, he would be afoot in a limitless and undivided universe, completely dark, inhabited only by himself." Of course Thacker isn't really alone, and that is what turns this lovely definition of insanity into a vision of what it means to be truly sane.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1263 words

HEADLINE: Play Nice. Play Tough.

BYLINE: By Michael Kinsley; Michael Kinsley is senior editor at The New Republic and co-host of "Crossfire" on CNN.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton is getting a lot of free advice about how to deal with Tuesday's election disaster. Most of it is telling him to abandon his left-wing agenda and rediscover the inner moderate who propelled him to victory in 1992. Bipartisan accommodation should be his goal, it is said. This isn't completely wrong, but there are three problems with it.
First, the notion that Mr. Clinton ran as a moderate "new Democrat" and then has governed as some kind of McGovernite left-winger is mostly the product of Republican agitprop and lazy journalists' shorthand. The most familiar items in the indictment -- his top-bracket tax increase, his proposal to overhaul the health care system, homosexuals in the military -- were all things he clearly promised in the campaign. 
 The tax increase affected a tiny fraction of the population; 10 times as many have enjoyed a tax cut, through expansion of the earned income tax credit. The health care autopsy will go on forever, but Mr. Clinton's original plan, whatever its flaws, was not the standard left-wing proposal for a Canadian-style Government takeover. And Mr. Clinton (not to his credit) tried mightily to fudge and postpone and compromise the gay-troops issue; it was the opposition that mischievously made it Issue One of the new administration.
Meanwhile, Federal spending takes a smaller share of gross domestic product under Bill Clinton than it did under either Ronald Reagan or George Bush. Even leaving aside the military, the number of Federal employees went up under Presidents Reagan and Bush, and has gone down under President Clinton. But you can argue all this until you're blue in the face (I know: I do it for a living), and it doesn't sink in.
A second problem with the moderate, accommodationist strategy is that it wouldn't really give voters much reason to vote for Mr. Clinton in 1996. It would leave Republicans in charge of the agenda and leave Mr. Clinton to be perceived as a whiny supplicant, not a strong leader. Republicans will quite reasonably ask the voters, "If you like the last two years better than Bill Clinton's first two, why not finish the cleanup job?" Even if the Democratic President and the Republican Congress work well together, Mr. Clinton will be reduced to building his re-election campaign around the boring theme that divided government is best. And besides being boring, it contradicts what he said last time.
A third problem with a govern-from-the-center strategy is that the "center" these days is mostly a land of alchemy, where it is easy to campaign but hard to govern.
It is a place where taxes can be cut and budgets balanced without any impositions on treasured government benefits of the middle class. It is a place where health care can be extended to the uninsured without raising anyone's bill, and prices can be brought under control without curtailing anyone's freedom of choice.
On foreign policy, it is a place where America can stand tall as the world's leader, and strut as the promoter of democracy and human rights, but American blood and treasure need never be spent in any particular situation.
The politics of the free lunch, which Mr. Reagan introduced into fiscal policy in 1980, now dominate in every sphere. Being a "centrist" means mostly taking the pleasant stuff from both sides of the traditional debate and leaving out the unpleasant stuff. Both parties play this game. Mr. Clinton played it well enough to get elected in 1992. But surely one lesson of the 1994 election results is that Republicans -- who invented it -- will always play it better. The only hope for the Democrats is to wean the voters from the free lunch and force them to make an honest choice about what they want their Government to do and how they propose to pay for it.
So yes, President Clinton should join in at least some of the Republicans' agenda. But less in the spirit of accommodation than in the spirit of challenge -- calling their bluff, holding their feet to the fire. This is, among other advantages, a way to appear both feistily "Trumanesque" and becomingly "moderate" at the same time. Republicans have indeed managed to occupy the center of American politics. But the goal should be to kick them out, not just to join them there.
The G.O.P.'s "Contract With America," with its impossible combination of tax cuts and spending increases and balanced-budget promises, offers the perfect vehicle for such a challenge. The promise of a balanced budget (by the year 2002) alone will require something like a trillion dollars of spending cuts, even before the document's other goodies are paid for. During the campaign, the Republicans swore they could achieve this without reducing Social Security or Medicare benefits.
It can't be done, of course. That's why Mr. Clinton should give them every opportunity to try. He shouldn't "cooperate." His line should be: After you, Alphonse. Ronald Reagan's mantra -- repeated thousands of times by Republican politicians -- was that Government spending is not the President's responsibility, because under the Constitution "Congress appropriates every dime."
Fine, Mr. Clinton should say. Appropriate away. But give me that line-item veto you're always carrying on about, in case I notice some wasteful spending around Marietta, Ga. (home of the new House Speaker).
To keep up the pressure, the President should endorse the balanced budget amendment. The year 2002 will be more than two decades after the Reagan mega-deficits began, and 12 years after the much-maligned Bush 1990 budget deal started us back toward fiscal sanity. Although there is no real reason the budget needs to be balanced in any particular year, it was never anyone's idea of Keynesianism that the Government should spend more than it takes in every year, indefinitely.
True, it is a pity to clutter up the Constitution. But an acknowledgment by the majority that it is unable to restrain itself through normal democratic procedures is arguably just the sort of thing that does belong there.
Mr. Clinton should also endorse term limits, or at least say he has no objection to them. Term limits, like the balanced budget amendment, are a procedural gimmick addressed to a substantive problem and intended to appeal to the free-lunch psychology: a magic cure-all. But they won't do any great harm. It's not worth an ounce of the Democrats' dwindling political capital to stand in the way of this gimmick -- especially now that it would mainly affect Republicans.
You can debate endlessly whether term limits will produce a better or worse quality of legislator. But even from the high-minded poli-sci point of view -- as well as the narrowly partisan Democratic one -- that debate is now less important than getting this false panacea off the table. And the only way to do that, apparently, is to try it out.
Not everything in the Republican Contract is beneficial or meaningless. But after outflanking the opposition on one or two fronts, and by choosing his battles carefully, Mr. Clinton could score some mighty victories. Do the Republicans, for example, really want to push a big new tax cut for the rich by expanding the capital gains tax break? I hope so. And if they try to tie it to a broader tax cut for the middle class, that would be a perfect occasion for Clinton to demand the line-item veto they promised in their Contract.
The strategy I'm advocating here might be called "confrontational accommodationism" or "in-your-face moderation." It might not work. But does anybody have a better idea?
