HEADLINE: Interest Rate Illogic

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Once more we're seeing the Federal Reserve Board preparing to raise interest rates in the name of fighting inflation, which is cooling down the economy. 
 As an architect designing custom houses, I never could see the logic of fighting inflation by raising the interest rates paid to purchase (and produce) these big-ticket items.
It's not only houses: everything we have is built, bought and shipped with borrowed money. Adding on yet more interest cost is piling on and effectively guaranteeing inflation, not combating it.
 
JERRY GROPP
Bellevue, Wash., Nov. 8, 1994

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Political Depression Hits Brunch Belt

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
What did you think of the election?
Like Dorothy on the Yellow Brick Road, New Yorkers on the Upper West Side of Manhattan responded to the question posed to them on the sidewalk by figuratively tapping their heels together and whispering, there's no place like home.
The Upper West Side is the heart of liberal New York, which makes it the heart of the heart of liberal America, a kind of urban college town, the East Coast version of Berkeley, Calif., or Madison, Wis. True to form, a week ago, Assembly Districts 67 and 69, which more or less define the area, not only returned their Democratic incumbents, Scott M. Stringer and Edward C. Sullivan, to the State Assembly with some 80 percent of the vote, but they voted for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo by more than 6 to 1. Of course, Mr. Cuomo lost, along with many others of his ideological ilk across the country. 
 So how does the liberal Upper West Side feel now?
"The liberal Upper West Side is very upset," said Fran Schoen, who was walking along West 79th Street yesterday.
Indeed, in interviews over the last two days with often loquacious if weary-sounding people, the same adjectives kept surfacing: upset, distressed, disgusted, depressed, frightened, appalled.
Why they feel this way -- aside from the fact that their side lost -- is a question people found harder to answer, but it seems to have its roots in a kind of pride. The Upper West Side, with its well-educated populace, its bookstores and bagel shops, its older, lefty intellectuals and younger, upwardly mobile families, has long felt itself in the vanguard of social justice.
Many expressed gratitude and appreciation to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for his endorsement of Governor Cuomo. And now, with the Mayor in disrepute among the ruling party, there's a sense among Upper West Siders that the Mayor is one of them, and that heathens have united to repudiate their entire lot.
"I feel uncertainty and fear," said Matt Fried, a psychologist who was wheeling his 3-year-old daughter, Gaby, along West 80th Street yesterday. But he added, "I feel community here."
Downtown a block, Charles Kleinbaum, 54, a lawyer, was out for a midday stroll with his Chihuahua. "Giuliani had a lot of guts doing what he did," he said. "And now that he's picked the wrong person, the city's going to suffer because the Republicans seem a little vindictive."
Referring to the newly elected Republicans as "these people" -- as in, "These people are not going to find a way to cut the budget without affecting the services of those who need them" -- Ms. Schoen, a retired teacher who has lived in the neighborhood for 40 years, reflected the downtrodden-ness of many of her middle-class peers who find themselves suddenly opposed to the Zeitgeist, and are cast by the outspoken soon-to-be House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, as the enemies of normal Americans.
"Am I depressed?" said Susan Stone, a research scientist, who was window-shopping on Broadway on Sunday afternoon. "Of course, I am. Everyone I know is."
So were some people she didn't.
"I'm more depressed than anyone," said Dr. Kent Sepkowitz, a 41-year-old physician who grew up in Oklahoma. He was one among many who voiced the idea that the essential and essentially appealing quality of Manhattan is that spiritually even more than physically, it is but an island off the coast of America. "This is why I left the Midwest, and now it's caught up with me," he said. "The only consolation I have is that I grew up during the McCarthy era, and there was life after that."
Pausing in front of Shakespeare's, the bookstore on Broadway and 81st Street, Alfred Shapiro nodded at his wife, Jaclyn, and said: "She's depressed. I take a longer view. As the West Side goes, so goes the West Side."
Mrs. Shapiro nodded.
"He predicted it," she said, shuddering, particularly at the promise of the Governor-elect, George E. Pataki, to reinstate capital punishment, which Governor Cuomo staunchly resisted. "I can't imagine living in a state with the death penalty. It makes you feel less than human."
Mrs. Shapiro, 63, added, "I'm so old I'm afraid I'll never see the pendulum swing back."
In addition to liberalism, the Upper West Side is also a bastion of psychotherapy. And several therapists in the neighborhood said politics frequently found its way into sessions, though it's too soon, they said, for any reaction from last Tuesday to have settled in on the couch.
"These things take a while to filter through people's offices," one doctor said, insisting, like many others, on anonymity to protect her patients. "When Giuliani was elected, I heard a lot about it."
The big topic regarding politics, she said, "is whether to stay in the city."
"Especially people with young children," she said. "One person I'm seeing now comes to mind; he's well put together, not a crazy guy, who has the feeling that the world is coming to an end. Everything he lived for in the 60's and 70's has disappeared."
Of course, every now and then a contrary voice piped up. "I'm not your typical Upper West Sider," said Joel Martel, a rather big-voiced iconoclast sitting in the jammed Barnes & Noble bookstore cafe. "I'm a neo-Con. So of course I'm delighted."
Mr. Martel, 48, a lawyer, added: "I think there are more and more people turning to conservatism because of the failure of the Democrats and the increasing dependency of people on the largesse of the state."
In spite of his best efforts, Mr. Martel was unable to engage the diners around him in a debate. Indeed, it seems as though few on the Upper West Side want to listen to Republicans, even if they do have the loudest voices right now.
Though that isn't to say some aren't secretly conceding. A number of people shrugged, admitted defeat and looked on the bright side, saying, in one way or another: Oh, well. At least we can look forward to the tax cut promised by Mr. Pataki.
"Economically we'll probably do better," said a 56-year-old doctor walking in Riverside Park. The man, who would give only his first name, Bob, said, "I don't mind doing better, but when I think of what's going to happen to this city, I don't have an optimistic outlook."

HEADLINE: Asia-Pacific Countries Near Agreement on Trade

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Eighteen nations of the Asia and Pacific region were on the verge of a sweeping agreement to stimulate economic growth by seeking the removal of barriers to trade by 2020, senior officials said on Monday night.
As part of the overall goal of "free and open trade" in one of the fastest growing economic regions in the world, the officials said, the United States, Japan and other developed nations are expected to accept an earlier goal for ending their trade barriers, probably by 2010. The United States had previously resisted the earlier date. 
 The trade agreement is expected to be endorsed later today at the summit session of the leaders of the nations of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, known as APEC. The session began this morning, with President Clinton in attendance.
Held at the presidential palace in Bogor, 40 miles south of Jakarta, the meeting opened on an informal note, with the leaders wearing batik shirts made for them by a top Indonesian designer.
The trade accord would be nonbinding, and is not expected to contain any commitments for immediate actions. Nevertheless, it represents a victory for the United States, which had pressed for a timetable to the lowering of trade barriers despite wariness by some countries, particularly Malaysia and China.
Many delegates at the forum have been saying that the whole success or failure of the meeting of the nations of the Asia-Pacific forum would be defined by whether or not a timetable could be agreed upon.
Those countries resisting the specific timetable are concerned that they would be forced to deregulate their economies and expose themselves to foreign competition too quickly.
Backers of the trade agreement hope that liberalizing trade and investment will allow for a maintenance and perhaps acceleration of the economic boom in a region that spans four continents and accounts for more than 38 percent of the world's population and more than 40 percent of total trade.
Officials cautioned that until the final summit meeting, there was still a chance that some parts of the accord could change. But they were satisfied that the summit meeting would end on a positive note.
"It has come together," the trade minister of one Western nation said. "It's all been finally agreed."
President Clinton said he did not want to "jump the gun" on the declaration today, but that an agreement would increase jobs for Americans.
"This week's discussions, I believe, will allow us to take a critical step forward toward free and open trade throughout the region," the President said at a news conference Monday afternoon. "Already one-third of our exports go the Asia-Pacific region. Already two million American jobs are tied to this region."
Earlier on Monday, Mr. Clinton met separately with President Jiang Zemin of China, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea, Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan and Prime Minister Paul Keating of Australia. He also met on Monday evening with Mr. Kim and Mr. Murayama together.
The leaders meeting with Mr. Clinton separately reinforced their commitment to carry out the recent agreement between the United States and North Korea aimed at curbing the communist nation's suspected nuclear weapons program.
A declaration setting a target for free trade would represent a coming of age for the Asia-Pacific group, an organization that started five years ago as a forum for talking and is little-known even in its own region. Now APEC is showing signs of changing from an acronym to an institution that will produce concrete changes, much the way that the early beginnings of economic cooperation and discussions in Europe evolved into a powerful trading bloc. Many emphasize that they are not contemplating anything as powerful or all-encompassing as the European Union, however.
President Suharto of Indonesia, relishing his role as host of the summit meeting despite some unwanted attention being paid to his Government's human rights record, said the expected agreement proved the ability of industrialized and developing nations to work together.
"In spite of the tremendous diversity of our cultures, political systems and stages of development of our economies, we have been able to envision a community of Asia-Pacific economies imbued with a growing spirit of partnership," he said in a welcoming speech at a dinner of grilled salmon, smoked duck and fruit at the Jakarta Convention Center.
A senior official of one Asian country said that Malaysia, China, Japan and South Korea were reluctant about setting a target date of 2020.
The United States, meanwhile, strongly advocated the 2020 date but balked at accepting the 2010 date for developed countries.
Washington was said to be concerned that American industries might protest if American markets were opened to products from Southeast Asia before the booming Southeast Asian markets would open to American products. Criticism from American businesses, they feared, might threaten congressional approval of the new world trade agreement under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT.
But developing countries insisted on an earlier date, saying their industries need more time to adjust to foreign competition than those of the advanced nations.
A possible problem was posed by Malaysia, which remains opposed to the timetable. It is not clear what Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia will say at the final meeting on Tuesday. Mr. Mahathir does not want the Asia-Pacific free trade plan to usurp a free trade area being formed by six members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. He also says East Asia nations should have their own economic forum, free of influence from western countries like the United States.
Officials of member nations expect that Mr. Mahathir will, in the end, go along with the declaration.
The Asia-Pacific members generally say they do not want their organization to become an exclusionary trade bloc, leaving barriers to countries outside the region. Even after GATT, many Asian nations will have high trade barriers on some products, like automobiles.
Jakarta has been swept clean for the visit of the foreign dignitaries, and the Government has declared a holiday to relieve traffic.
Despite Indonesia's efforts to show off its economic progress, the summit has also focused attention on the Government's press censorship, suppression of labor movements and continuing protests over its annexation of the former Portuguese colony of East Timor in 1975.
Nearly 90 protesters were reported arrested in clashes with security forces in East Timor on Monday, the second day of disturbances. Meanwhile, 29 East Timorese students protesting Indonesia's policies continued the sit-in they began on Saturday morning at the grounds of the American embassy in Jakarta.
On Monday, two American journalists who had been arrested trying to enter East Timor tried to distribute leaflets in the Asia-Pacific conference press center announcing that they were holding a news conference. Security guards swarmed and tried to take away the leaflets, in front of the international press.
The Asia-Pacific leaders' final declaration today is not expected to define concretely what is meant by free trade or how to achieve it. The meeting next year in Osaka, Japan, will start to work out some of those details.

HEADLINE: THE NEW CONGRESS: TRADE;
HELMS REQUESTS A DELAY IN VOTE ON TRADE ACCORD

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
With a threat to disrupt the Administration's foreign policy plans, Senator Jesse Helms urged President Clinton today to delay a Congressional vote on a worldwide trade pact until next year, a move that could unravel the 123-nation agreement.
In a letter to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Helms, who is expected to become chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee when the Republican-led Senate takes office in January, objected strenuously to the Administration plan to push through the bill in a special session that begins after the Thanksgiving holiday. 
 Mr. Helms, a staunch conservative from North Carolina who has made it clear that he plans to challenge a number of Administration foreign policies, said in the letter that it would be unwise to vote until hearings on the accord are held.
"If you will agree to this, Mr. President," Mr. Helms wrote, "I can assure that it will have an exceedingly positive effect on my making certain that the Administration's positions on all foreign policy matters during the 104th Congress will be considered fairly and fully."
Mr. Helms made his statement as the Administration's hopes of quick and relatively painless passage of the comprehensive free-trade agreement by the current Congress are crumbling. The letter also is the first substantial disagreement to surface among the Republicans since Election Day, as they begin to stake out more detailed positions and flex their political muscles in anticipation of taking power.
A number of Republicans, traditionally the party of free trade, are splitting with the new leadership and abandoning the trade accord. They are joining forces with conservative Democrats, labor unions and some consumer-rights advocates who have mounted a lonely campaign against the pact, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Still apparently on the fence is the most important player in the vote in the Senate, the future majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas. Mr. Dole has generally voiced support for the agreement, but in recent weeks has backpedaled, saying that he is concerned that sovereignty would be undercut by the new World Trade Organization.
That organization will act as something of a court of world trade, capable of sanctioning signatories to the agreement that it judges in violation of the pact. Opponents of GATT contend that the deck will be stacked against American interests and that the international trade organization, in which every member country will have an equal voice, will try to undermine American competitiveness.
Mr. Dole met all afternoon with Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, who emerged predicting that Mr. Dole would ultimately support the agreement. In Jakarta, Indonesia, today, Mr. Clinton also expressed willingness to find a compromise with Mr. Dole, saying that he understood that people "want to be assured that we're not giving up the ability to run our own affairs."
"So we're working on it, and I think we'll resolve it," Mr. Clinton said.
House and Senate staff members said today that Mr. Dole was asking for the creation of a panel of Americans to review every trade decision against the United States and recommend whether remaining part of the trade agreement is in the country's interest. In coming days Mr. Dole will be negotiating on the issue with the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor.
The prospective House Speaker, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, came out in favor of passing the pact this month.
A senior Administration official said today that although the vote could be close, "I think we'll have it at the end of the day."
"In the end," the official added, "these guys know this is too big and too important not to get done."
Mr. Helms's letter leaves the Administration with an uncomfortable choice. If it pushes ahead with GATT, which seems all but inevitable, it gives the likely new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee an excuse to slow approval of treaties or ambassadors and investigate foreign aid and appropriations for the United Nations, long targets of his wrath.
If the Administration delays, however, the next Congress could pick apart the trade accord.
Any changes to the agreement would require reopening the negotiations that took 12 years to complete, and most trade experts say that would kill the agreement.
For Mr. Clinton in particular, a delay would be an enormous international embarrassment. The United States has led the drive for the bill for 12 years, beginning with the Reagan Administration. And Mr. Clinton has made the pursuit of free-trade agreements -- in Asia this week and with Latin American countries at a summit in Miami next month -- the linchpin of his international economic strategy, arguing that it would vastly increase American exports.
The free-trade zones that he is discussing with Asia and Latin America are premised on adopting the trade agreement, which is scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1. All of America's main allies have delayed passage, however, until they see what Congress does.
The lame-duck session on GATT was originally forced by a Democrat, Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina. He, like Mr. Helms, represents powerful interests in the textile industry, which has led the objections to the lowering of tariffs that the accord requires.
Most other business organizations favor agreement, however, and they have scheduled events on Capitol Hill starting on Wednesday to press for quick passage.
In his letter Mr. Helms argued that it was extremely unwise to consider the trade agreement under the rules that Congress agreed to last year to limit the House and the Senate to a straight up-or-down vote on the entire agreement.
"Mr. President," the letter said, "I implore you to inform the Senate that you are willing for consideration of the GATT implementation bill to be delayed until very early in 1995, thereby permitting meaningful public hearings at which significant witnesses on both sides can be heard."
Mr. Hollings is using his last days as the chairman of the Commerce Committee to press his attack on the accord, arguing that it would cost billions of dollars in lost tariff revenue and untold numbers of jobs. Mr. Hollings has essentially dismissed the arguments of many economists that the United States would emerge as a big winner because other nations would be forced to reduce far more tariffs than the United States would.
Today, Mr. Hollings dismissed the Administration's contention that in the long run far more jobs will be created by opening big emerging markets like Indonesia and Chile and by speeding their transformation into consumers of American software, automobiles and electronics.

HEADLINE: Bumper Crops Pose Political Problem for Farmers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The nation's farmers have been reaping their most bountiful harvest ever in many important crops, benefiting shoppers for groceries from meat to cooking oil but costing taxpayers an estimated $3 billion to $4 billion in additional farm subsidies.
Production of corn, the nation's biggest crop, is expected to reach 10.01 billion bushels, nearly 5.6 percent higher than 1992's record crop and almost 60 percent more than last year when the Midwest flooded and the Southeast baked, according to Department of Agriculture estimates released last Wednesday. Production also soared to new records for rice and soybeans, which are widely used in animal feed, cooking oil and food ingredients. Wheat crops, while short of records, were larger than average. 
 Analysts say that food prices will rise between 2 percent and 3 percent next year because of higher transportation and packaging costs, but that the increase might have been a full percentage point higher without the bumper harvest. Consumers could save more than $6 billion. But the same bounty has driven prices paid to farmers so far below Government support price targets that deficiency payments will soar. It now appears that direct payments could reach $12 billion to $13 billion next year, a sharp increase from the $8 billion to $9 billion the Department of Agriculture expects to pay out this year.
The potent display of what today's technology-rich farmers can achieve in a year when the weather cooperates -- and its impact on the Federal budget -- could not have come at a more sensitive time politically, according to many farming experts. The laws that govern most Federal farm policies, which run for five years, are up for renewal next year. Critics of farm subsidies in the Republican-majority Congress, among them such powerful figures as the projected House majority leader, Dick Armey, a Texas Republican, will be in their best position in a long time to weaken farm-support programs, some of which date back to the New Deal.
"We know we are going to be on the chopping block," said Representative Pat Roberts, a Kansas Republican who is expected to become chairman of the House Agriculture Committee and who is fighting to minimize cuts in farm-support programs. "We will be debating not just what kind of farm bill we'll have, but what the rationale is for any bill."
Mr. Roberts, whose district includes wheat farmers who have been among the biggest benefactors of Government supports, said he hopes to switch the focus from subsidy programs to legislation that would give farmers more flexibility over what they plant on land in Government programs and fewer restrictions on the chemicals and methods they use.
All that would help to improve production efficiency and reduce the need for Government support payments while preserving the basic outlines of policies that have provided Americans with a steady, inexpensive supply of food, Mr. Roberts said. The expectation of some level of price support is built in to farmland prices and the financial structure of most farms, creating the potential for a disastrous rural economic crisis if farmers are left completely exposed to market forces, he added.
But this year's crop underscored how difficult it is for the Government to manage supplies, its chief method of controlling the costs of grain subsidies. A growing number of critics want any future payments severed from production and linked directly to environmental goals, such as taking ecologically fragile land out of production. Some want stricter limits on the size of operations that receive subsidies. Under current rules, one operation may have many owners, with each allowed to pocket up to $50,000 a year in direct price-support payments when corn, rice or wheat falls below a target price.
The Government has been steadily chipping away at subsidies since the mid-1980's. One tactic in the grain sector has been to steadily lower the target price it uses as the baseline for calculating support payments. Another has been to restrict the amount of land a farmer has in the support program. And on those acres left in the program, the farmer can only be credited with the amount of corn per acre he raised in 1980, not the far-higher yields that are routine today.
The Government also attempts to keep prices up to levels where subsidies are minimal and to reap environmental benefits by paying farmers to put ecologically sensitive land into its 34-million-acre Conservation Reserve Program.
But getting the balance right still involves luck. Worried that grain reserves were dangerously low after bad weather in 1993, the Department of Agriculture eliminated grain set-asides. Farmers responded by planting 10 percent more acres in corn and soybeans. When they were blessed with adequate rain, plenty of sun but not too much heat at the right times and a mild harvest season, the results overwhelmed storage capacity in many regions.
"We got 15 bushels of corn an acre from one of our farms last year and 175 this year," said Neil Harl, an Iowa State University agricultural economist, describing the impact of the rebound in the western Corn Belt.
For the last month, corn has been piling up on the ground outside grain elevators across the Midwest. Corn prices plunged at some elevators to nearly 40 cents below the Board of Trade futures contracts, which bottomed in October to about $2.13 a bushel, then drifted up to yesterday's close at almost $2.17 on signs of stronger than expected demand. Mothballed terminals as far away as Norfolk, Va., where Cargill Inc. once held crops destined for export to Europe, have been hurriedly reopened to store soybeans.
One source of demand has been exports. Large orders from China for soybean oil have caused a sharp rebound in that market, and a falloff in Chinese corn exports has created an opening in world markets for American corn. A brutal drought in Australia has led to a sharp increase in American wheat exports -- and prices.
Some of the grain demand has also come from hog, poultry and beef farmers. The low prices have almost no effect on products like cereal -- corn accounts for about 5 percent of the cost of corn flakes -- but have a sizable impact in meat markets. Feed accounts for 70 percent of the cost of raising a chicken. The price for calves destined to become beef has rebounded in recent months as the projected cost of raising them declined. And hog farmers, suffering through a glut that has sent prices down to 30 cents a hundredweight, too low for even the most efficient producers to make a profit, are able to hang on to their hogs longer and wait for prices to rise.
The biggest beneficiaries of low grain prices are a Who's Who of agriprocessors. Low costs for grain and higher demand for meat, corn syrup, cooking oils, ethanol and other grain products have profits soaring at companies like the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, Cargill, Conagra Inc., Tyson Foods Inc. and Hormel.
Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy took a major step toward halting the price decline for grain with his initial decision in September -- made final Tuesday -- requiring farmers receiving corn-price supports to set aside 7.5 percent of their eligible land next year.
The set-asides have already hit the stocks of seed companies like Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. and the DeKalb Genetics Corporation, and analysts say that agrichemical companies may have trouble matching this year's sales. Fertilizer suppliers will fare better than pesticide producers because a big crop like this year's drains more nutrients from the soil. Indeed, fertilizer demand is already higher this fall as farmers who finished the harvest early start preparing fields that will not be set aside for next year.
By contrast, farm-equipment sales have begun to slow in response to higher interest rates, the 1995 set-aside and low crop prices, with October sales down 10 percent from the corresponding month last year. Analysts say that actual farm income will be about the same next year, when many payments from this year's crop will be received.
"But if the only reason farm receipts are even is the Government is giving you $4 billion more, it doesn't make farmers confident," said Thomas Burns, who follows farm equipment companies for NatWest Securities.
Even as the impact of the bumper crop ripples through the economy, agricultural economists are looking ahead anxiously to spring planting. Reserves are still modest by historic standards. A bad start next year could send prices higher even as farmers who held on to much of this crop send it to market. But a spring like this year's could raise fears of a much steeper price plunge.
"The one thing for sure," said Richard Brock, a Milwaukee-based farm marketing consultant, "is that what happened this year ensures lower support prices from the next Congress and more volatility down the road."

HEADLINE: Opening Asia's Door

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 15

 BODY:
In setting their vast and vital region on the path toward free trade by the year 2020, the leaders of 18 nations around the Pacific Ocean have taken a step that appears to be a bold move toward the future.
But whether it will truly be so judged by history will depend not so much on what the leaders said today but on how their "declaration of common resolve" is translated into action. Carrying out the free trade agreement will be far more arduous and contentious than merely enunciating the vision. 
 The declaration, issued from a colonial-era palace in Bogor, 40 miles south of Jakarta, proclaimed a "commitment" to achieve "free and open trade and investment" in the Asia-Pacific region by the year 2020. The industrialized nations in the group, like the United States, Japan and Canada, are to achieve the goal no later than the year 2010.
The goal is ambitious -- the world's largest free trading area, one that spans four continents and encompasses countries that now account for more than half the world economy, and more than 40 percent of its trade.
"This is the biggest single trade initiative in history," said C. Fred Bergsten, the American economist who chaired an advisory committee that helped draft the plan. "This is half the world deciding to eliminate barriers to trade and investment."
By contrast, he said, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade covers potentially the entire world but does not seek complete elimination of barriers.
But it will probably take several years for the first tariff cuts or other measures to be seen. The advisory committee chaired by Mr. Bergsten called for complete schedules of what steps should be taken to be finished by the year 2000 and for the first tariff cuts and other liberalization steps to begin that year. But that date did not make it into the final draft of the Bogor declaration.
Dismantling trade barriers will also not come naturally for the countries of East Asia. They have achieved their rapid economic growth in part through a strategy of offering Government incentives and protection to domestic industries.
American companies might benefit from increased exports of foods and industrial products. Automobile production is one area in which American companies could benefit by lower tariffs. In many nations of East Asia, imports of cars are virtually prohibited by high tariffs and other barriers, in order to build up the domestic industries of each country.
One of the effects of trade liberalization could be in the area of investment patterns. Right now, with imports difficult, Mitsubishi Motors has factories in Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines and Malaysia in order to sell in those countries.
But if trade were liberalized, it might export from Japan instead, or build one big factory in one country to serve all the others. Toyota is now moving toward a model where it makes different parts in different nations and then supplies all the others.
To make its region more attractive as a place to do business, the six members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, is already liberalizing trade at a fast rate. A company can make high technology components in Singapore or Taiwan and lower tech components in Malaysia, then have them assembled in Thailand to take advantage of the strengths of each country.
To be sure, the Bogor declaration does not clearly define free trade. Does it include trade in services as well as goods? Does it mean complete elimination of tariffs, something less, or something more? The document is also not legally binding and contains some language that appears to allow countries to drag their feet.
But such lack of specifics can be excused at such an early stage. Even getting all 18 nations to agree on the common goal was a big accomplishment, since it was only one year ago that President Clinton first invited the sometimes suspicious government leaders to meet on Blake Island near Seattle to talk about a "new Pacific community."
"Our main aim was to agree on the broad target and not to get bogged down at this stage in definitions and how to do it," said Hamish MacLeod, Hong Kong's financial secretary and its representative at today's summit meeting.
Eventually, however, the APEC members will have to get around to such questions, and that is where the difficulties will intensify. Indeed, barely was the ink dry on the Bogor declaration today than differences in interpretation began emerging.
For instance, many of the nations think South Korea is industrialized enough to be among the early liberalizers. But South Korea wants to be in the late group. The declaration itself is deliberately vague on where South Korea belongs.
An initial blueprint for putting the declaration into effect is expected to be ready by next year's meeting in Osaka, Japan. American officials expect that trade will be freed gradually through a series of small agreements, rather than through one comprehensive agreement as in the case of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
As the host country, Japan will have the leading role in pulling together a blueprint, a fact that gives pause to some of the other nations since Japan does not have a reputation as a free trader.
At a news conference today, Japan's Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, was somewhat restrained in praising the agreement.
"We expressed our political will for a broad direction based on a long-term perspective," Mr. Murayama said. But when asked if Japan will have to open its markets for agricultural products as a result of the Bogor Declaration, he said the matter would have to be looked at.
No doubt the most contentious issue at today's meeting was establishing the target date of 2020. The date seems so far away that it is easy to dismiss as almost meaningless.
"It doesn't require anybody to really change very much," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a former United States trade negotiator and president of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington. "People can all say they are free traders without having to change current protectionist practices."
The long-range nature of the goal no doubt made it easier for some of the reluctant nations to sign on to the Bogor declaration. After all, as one Prime Minister noted at Tuesday's summit meeting, the Sultan of Brunei was the only one among the leaders in the room with a chance of still being in office in 2020.
But looked at from another perspective, the target is impossibly ambitious. GATT was started 45 years ago and still hasn't brought about totally free trade. The Asia-Pacific plan will try to do it in 25.
It is possible that once the process starts, the pace will accelerate as businesses and politicians warm to the idea. This has happened with free trade agreements in the past.
The original European Economic Community agreement called for a phase-in period of 12 years but completed it in 7. Earlier this year the six members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations decided to accelerate by five years the timetable for freeing trade among themselves.
